('11', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 1
('11', 0, 1, 2, 41) 1. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 0, 2, 3, 57) Monday [April 11, 1910]
('11', 0, 3, 4, 81) SENT TO DELAGOA BAY
('11', 0, 4, 5, 101) Mr. Achary and 37 other satyagrahis were sent from Pretoria to Delagoa Bay on Saturday.
('11', 0, 4, 6, 189) Six of them were certainly not satyagrahis.
('11', 0, 4, 7, 233) I cannot say whether they have become so by now.
('11', 0, 4, 8, 282) All of them who bear Tamil names are satyagrahis.
('11', 0, 4, 9, 332) Thus, the Tamils have been keeping the flag of satyagraha flying.
('11', 0, 4, 10, 398) I have given the Tamil names in the English section 1 and therefore do not give them here.
('11', 0, 5, 11, 489) SHIPS REFUSE
('11', 0, 6, 12, 502) I reported in the English section 2 last week that some ships had refused to carry those persons who have been deported.
('11', 0, 6, 13, 623) I cannot say how far the report is true.
('11', 0, 6, 14, 664) But it appears that they have failed to get a ship so far.
('11', 0, 6, 15, 723) If India exerts sufficient pressure, no ship will dare carry the deportees.
('11', 0, 6, 16, 799) There is strong reason to believe that those who have been deported this time will rouse the whole of India to protest.
('11', 0, 7, 17, 919) CHETTIAR 3
('11', 0, 8, 18, 930) [He] was today ordered to be deported and was taken to gaol.
('11', 0, 8, 19, 991) Mr. Chettiar is about 55 years of age.
('11', 0, 8, 20, 1030) He suffers from a chronic ailment, and yet he is facing deportation with the utmost courage.
('11', 0, 8, 21, 1123) He is to be deported to Natal, from where he will return immediately.
('11', 0, 9, 22, 1193) OTHER ARRESTS
('11', 0, 10, 23, 1207) Mr. Chinan Diala 4 and Selmar Pillay were arrested and they, too, have been ordered to be deported.
('11', 0, 11, 24, 1307) 1 Vide “From ‘Transvaal Notes’ ”, 12 4 1910 2 Vide “From ‘Transvaal Notes’ ”, 4 4 1910 3 V. A. Chettiar, respected old Chairman of the Tamil Benefit Society, who had been arrested on April 5. Vide “Transvaal Notes”, Indian Opinion, 9 4 1910. 4 Vide, however, “Transvaal Notes”, Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910, where the name given is Anandi Alvar.
('11', 1, 0, 1, 1650) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 1, 1, 2, 1690) KARODIA
('11', 1, 2, 3, 1698) The case against the two Karodias 1 has been withdrawn.
('11', 1, 2, 4, 1754) One of them was charged with using a false permit and the other with making a false affidavit.
('11', 1, 2, 5, 1849) The police had spared no pains in preparing for this case.
('11', 1, 2, 6, 1908) They had called the Immigration Officer at Durban, Mr. Moosa Hajee Adam and others as witnesses; however, the case was withdrawn at the last moment.
('11', 1, 2, 7, 2057) The fact is that some Indians, out of spite, had made an affidavit and also induced someone else to make another against the two brothers.
('11', 1, 2, 8, 2196) Later they felt sorry for what they had done.
('11', 1, 2, 9, 2242) They found it very difficult to prove, their statements, for there was ample evidence to show that Mr. Karodia had lived in Johannesburg before the War.
('11', 1, 2, 10, 2395) I think the Government withdrew the cases in order to protect the persons who had given the affidavits.
('11', 1, 2, 11, 2499) Mr. Karodia does not intend to leave the matter here, but will approach the Attorney General for relief in order to make an example of the men concerned and prevent similar things from happening to other prominent persons.
('11', 1, 3, 12, 2722) WHETHER COLOURED PERSONS CAN STAY
('11', 1, 4, 13, 2756) In Johannesburg, many title deeds contain a provision to the effect that the landowners cannot permit Asiatics or Coloured persons other than servants to stay on their lands.
('11', 1, 4, 14, 2931) This is so in Norwood [also].
('11', 1, 4, 15, 2961) A certain white bought a stand there.
('11', 1, 4, 16, 2999) Later, he discovered that at several places there were Coloured persons staying.
('11', 1, 4, 17, 3080) He filed a suit against the company to have his tite deed nullified on this ground.
('11', 1, 4, 18, 3164) The magistrate decided against the company.
('11', 1, 4, 19, 3208) The case was taken higher up.
('11', 1, 4, 20, 3238) The Supreme Court has now ruled that, notwithstanding the provision in the title deeds, the company cannot be held responsible.
('11', 1, 4, 21, 3366) The owner of a stand can, if he chooses, file a suit against any person who permits Coloured persons to stay [on the stand].
('11', 1, 4, 22, 3491) Accordingly, the Coloureds will stay where they are, for the present at least.
('11', 1, 4, 23, 3570) We must now wait till there is another suit; its outcome is anybody’s guess.
('11', 1, 4, 24, 3647) The saying, “having survived a moment of danger, we may live to be a hundred years”, might come true in this case.
('11', 1, 5, 25, 3762) 1 Messrs Karodia Brothers, well known Indian merchants of Johannesburg; vide “Letter to Attorney General”, 14 4 1910
('11', 2, 0, 1, 3879) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 3
('11', 2, 1, 2, 3920) LORD SELBORNE
('11', 2, 2, 3, 3934) The miners gave a dinner to Lord Selborne.
('11', 2, 2, 4, 3977) Speaking on the occasion, he gave a warning to the whites that, if they were not careful and persisted in their unjust treatment of the Cape Coloureds, the consequences would be unhappy.
('11', 2, 2, 5, 4164) Men would arise from among them who would becomeleaders of the Kaffirs.
('11', 2, 2, 6, 4236) Lord Selborne thought that this was the biggest problem facing South Africa.
('11', 2, 2, 7, 4313) These views call for some comment.
('11', 2, 2, 8, 4348) It does not appear that in saying this Lord Selborne was actuated by concern for the welfare of the Coloured people; he said it only because he feared the emergence of a leader from among them.
('11', 2, 2, 9, 4542) Their sincere well wishers, however, should welcome the rise of such leaders—the more the better—and encourage them.
('11', 2, 3, 10, 4659) RAILWAY REGULATIONS The General Manager, the Assistant Manager, Mr. Bell, Mr. Cac halia and Mr. Gandhi met today.
('11', 2, 3, 11, 4773) After a discussion lasting nearly an hour and a half, the draft which the Association had forwarded was accepted with some modifications.
('11', 2, 3, 12, 4911) 1 The General Manager stated that he would recommend to the Railway Board the withdrawal of the Reg ulations which had been promulgated and that [new] regulations would be framed in terms of the draft as approved by him.
('11', 2, 3, 13, 5132) According to the draft agreement, there will be no discrimination in law on the gro und of colour.
('11', 2, 3, 14, 5231) The existing provision that Indians can travel only in the third class will be deleted and the former position will be restored.
('11', 2, 4, 15, 5360) CAUTION TO INDIANS This will be a welcome change, no doubt.
('11', 2, 4, 16, 5420) That it has come about shows that the Indian community is not to be trifled with.
('11', 2, 4, 17, 5502) But the Indian community’s responsibility will also increase.
('11', 2, 4, 18, 5564) There will, of course, be no difficulty if we bear ourselves with dignity; should we, however, forget ourselves, difficulties will certainly arise and discriminatory regulations will be introduced.
('11', 2, 5, 19, 5762) SHOP HOURS REGULATIONS These Regulations are again to be modified.
('11', 2, 5, 20, 5829) The most important change will be that European hotels will be allowed to remain open up
('11', 2, 6, 21, 5918) 1 Vide Appendix “Letter from General Manager, C.S.A.R., to Gandhiji”, 11 4 1910.
('11', 3, 0, 1, 5999) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 3, 1, 2, 6039) to 12 midnight, whereas Asiatic hotels will have to close at 6 p.m.
('11', 3, 1, 3, 6107) I do not see that we can do much to protest against this discrimination; all the same, the Association has written 1 to the Colonial Secretary about it.
('11', 3, 2, 4, 6260) ROW AMONG KANAMIAS Kanamia 2 friends had their fill of fighting.
('11', 3, 2, 5, 6325) They went at one another on a public road, a large number of whites watching the scene.
('11', 3, 2, 6, 6413) Three of them sustained serious injuries.
('11', 3, 2, 7, 6455) The brawlers got a bad name, and the Indian community as well, to some extent.
('11', 3, 2, 8, 6534) Fighting has brought no benefit to eitherparty.
('11', 3, 2, 9, 6582) Benefit there will be only for the Government and lawyers.
('11', 3, 2, 10, 6641) Both the sides have engaged lawyers and it seems, from the way they talk, that money will be spent like water.
('11', 3, 2, 11, 6752) The story that has been circulated by newspapers is that this was a dispute between satyagrahis and their opponents.
('11', 3, 2, 12, 6869) Mr. Cachalia has therefore addressed a letter 3 to newspapers, pointing out that the quarrel had nothing to do whatever with satyagraha.
('11', 3, 2, 13, 7006) I wish to say a few words to the Kanamias.
('11', 3, 2, 14, 7049) I know, and everyone knows, that they are strong of arms; they are making a big mistake, however, if they imagine that such brawls add to their reputation.
('11', 3, 2, 15, 7205) The reason for the quarrel is of no account.
('11', 3, 2, 16, 7250) I am not interested in finding out who is to blame.
('11', 3, 2, 17, 7302) I only know that the fighting has helped neither side.
('11', 3, 2, 18, 7357) However, those who are in love with physical strength and want occasions for its use would do well to employ it, not for purposes of revenge but in defence of others.
('11', 3, 2, 19, 7524) Moreover, those who would fight, must fight it out to the last, be the end death or victory.
('11', 3, 2, 20, 7617) To start a fight and then go to a court of law is cowardice twice over.
('11', 3, 2, 21, 7689) To use violence against anyone is cowardly enough, but going to a court is much worse.
('11', 3, 2, 22, 7776) If a man, after having fought, goes to a court, he will prove himself fit for nothing.
('11', 3, 2, 23, 7863) Duelling survives to this day in all parts of Europe, except England.
('11', 3, 2, 24, 7933) The idea behind it is that two persons actually fight with each other in order to prove himself in the right and the one who is defeated is considered to have lost his point.
('11', 3, 2, 25, 8108) It is not open to these persons to go to a court of law [subsequently].
('11', 3, 2, 26, 8180) I must admit that, from the point of view of those who approve of violence, this is an excellent
('11', 3, 3, 27, 8277) 1 Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 12 4 1910 2 Muslims from Kaman, in Central Gujarat 3 Vide “Letter to the Press”, 8 4 1910
('11', 4, 0, 1, 8406) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 5
('11', 4, 1, 2, 8447) practice.
('11', 4, 1, 3, 8457) But those who know that it is better to die than to kill, they know best; they have conquered all.
('11', 4, 1, 4, 8556) This is the Indian way.
('11', 4, 2, 5, 8580) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910

('11', 4, 5, 10, 9526) 3. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 2
('11', 4, 6, 11, 9561) [JOHANNESBURG,] April 12, 1910
('11', 4, 7, 12, 9592) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No.
('11', 4, 7, 13, 9661) 1459/10/247 of the 9th instant regarding the general treatment of Indian passive resisters in prison.
('11', 4, 7, 14, 9763) The submission of my Association is that the selection of Diepk loof Prison where alone the limitation of three months as regards visitors and letters prevails, is deemed by the Asiatic communities to show an intention to impose hardships additional to those warranted by the punishment awarded by the Magistrates to passive resisters.
('11', 4, 8, 15, 10099) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('11', 4, 8, 16, 10126) 2 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was signed by E. I. Aswat, Acting Chairman, British Indian Association.
('11', 5, 0, 1, 10245) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 5, 1, 2, 10285) With reference to the omission of ghee from the Indian dietary, my Association is aware that the Prison Governors have chosen the present scale.
('11', 5, 1, 3, 10430) The fact, however, stands that the revision of the scale has resulted in the deprivation of an article of diet which was given to Indian prisoners in most of the prisons of the Transvaal, and which is an article especially needed by British Indians.
('11', 5, 1, 4, 10680) In the humble opinion of my Association, the Prison Governors have taken no note of idiosyncrasies in deciding upon the revised scale.
('11', 5, 2, 5, 10815) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910
('11', 5, 3, 6, 10841) 4. LETTER TO GENERAL MANAGER, C.S.A.R.
('11', 5, 4, 7, 10880) JOHANNESBURG, April 12, 1910
('11', 5, 5, 8, 10909) SIR, On behalf of Mr. Cachalia and myself, I beg to thank you for your letter 1 of the 11th instant, containing a summary of [the] understanding arrived at yesterday between your Department and Mr. Cachalia and myself representing the British Indian Association.
('11', 5, 5, 9, 11172) The summary given by you correctly sets forth the position; and, on behalf of my colleague and myself, I beg to tender our thanks to you for the conciliatory manner in which you have met the representations of my Association in the matter of the gazetted regulations which have formed the subject matter of the correspondence between your Department and my Association.
('11', 5, 5, 10, 11542) Whilst I acknowledge that the smooth working of the arrange ment will depend upon the self restraint that may be exercised by the British Indians it is no less dependent upon the tact and the goodwill of the officials in charge of the regulation of passenger traffic.
('11', 5, 5, 11, 11810) In conclusion, I trust that the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony Governments and the Railway Board will accept your recommen dation, and that the regulations complained of will be repealed and replaced by those set forth in your letter under reply.
('11', 5, 5, 12, 12064) I have, etc., M. K. GANDHI HON.
('11', 5, 5, 13, 12096) SECRETARY, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION

('11', 6, 1, 2, 12332) 5. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY 1
('11', 6, 2, 3, 12366) [JOHANNESBURG,] April 12, 1910
('11', 6, 3, 4, 12397) SIR, With reference to the Shop Hours Bill published in the Government Gazette, my Association respectfully protests against the distinction drawn between the closing hours of European restaurants and those of Asiaticeating houses; 2 and, as it cannot be of serious importance to the Government if the same privileges are allowed to the keepers of Asiatic eatinghouses, my Association trusts that the differentiation will be removed.
('11', 6, 4, 5, 12831) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910

('11', 7, 1, 2, 13660) 7. LETTER TO ATTORNEY GENERAL
('11', 7, 2, 3, 13690) [JOHANNESBURG,] April 14, 1910
('11', 7, 4, 4, 13721) Messrs M. A. Karodia and A. A. Karodia were some time ago arrested, the one on a charge of having obtained a registration certificate under false pretences, and the other on a charge of having made a false affidavit.
('11', 7, 4, 5, 13938) After two remands, both cases were withdrawn, without any evidence having been given on behalf of the Crown.
('11', 7, 4, 6, 14047) Messrs Karodia Brothers are well known British Indian merchants in Johannesburg.
('11', 7, 4, 7, 14128) To this day, they do not know upon what evidence the charge was brought against them.
('11', 7, 4, 8, 14214) Their arrest caused no little surprise amongst the Indian community, and no little pain to themselves.
('11', 7, 4, 9, 14317) They were fully prepared, as they are now, to meet the charges brought against them.
('11', 7, 4, 10, 14402) That they are merchants of standing is a fact well known to the Asiatic Department.
('11', 7, 4, 11, 14486) They feel, that, if they allow the proceedings against them to end, after the withdrawal of the charges, neither they nor their fellow merchants could consider themselves safe from similar arrest.
('11', 7, 4, 12, 14683) In the circumstances, they request that the names of the deponents on whose evidence the warrant was granted and their affidavits should be handed to them.
('11', 7, 4, 13, 14839) And they respectfully desire also that the Government will be pleased in future to use judicious discretion in obtaining warrants of arrest against Indians of standing.
('11', 7, 5, 14, 15008) Indian Opinion, 23 4 1910
('11', 7, 6, 15, 15034) 8. SUBSTANCE OF LETTER TO L. W. RITCH
('11', 7, 7, 16, 15072) [After April 14, 1910] 1
('11', 7, 8, 17, 15097) In connection with this matter, Mr. Ritch writes to inform us that he has received a letter from Mr. Gandhi, stating that the excuse for sending these men to India is that they refused to give finger prints to identify themselves with their certificates, which documents were already filed with the Registrar.
('11', 7, 8, 18, 15407) He explains that the excuse is invalid, because most ofthese men have already been to gaol as passive resisters, and are consequently known to the authorities.
('11', 7, 8, 19, 15567) He adds that deportation for refusal to give finger prints is illegal, the punishment provided for the offence being imprisonment and not deportation, and confirms the report that many of the deportees were domiciled in South Africa.
('11', 7, 8, 20, 15801) India, 13 5 1910
('11', 7, 9, 21, 15818) 1 The reference is to the fifty nine Indians deported on 14 4 1910; vide “Johannesburg”,18 4 1910
('11', 8, 0, 1, 15916) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 9
('11', 8, 1, 2, 15957) 9. TAMIL SACRIFICE 1
('11', 8, 2, 3, 15978) The arrest of Mr. Chettiar, the fifty five year old Chairman of the Tamil Society, puts the finishing touch to the glorious work that is being done by the Tamil community in the Transvaal on behalf not of themselves but of the whole Indian population throughout South Afri ca.
('11', 8, 2, 4, 16255) Nearly one hundred Tamils are now under custody, either under going imprisonment at Diepkloof or awaiting deportation, which, for many reasons, is much worse than imprisonment.
('11', 8, 2, 5, 16432) There is hardly a Tamil left in the Transvaal who has not suffered imprisonment in the course of the passive resistance struggle.
('11', 8, 2, 6, 16562) Mr. Chettiar himself has been now arrested for the third time, his son, as we have already remarked, for the seventh time.
('11', 8, 2, 7, 16685) These brave men have reduced themselves to poverty and have sacrificed literally their all for the sake of the national honour and their sacred oath.
('11', 8, 2, 8, 16835) It has become such acommon occurrence for Tamils to be arrested that it excites no curiosity and attention.
('11', 8, 2, 9, 16943) Mr. Chettiar, who was at one time in flourishing circu mstances, has now become a pauper.
('11', 8, 2, 10, 17033) We have seen some of the receipts for the jewellery which has been sold in order to provide for the household.
('11', 8, 2, 11, 17144) In view of sacrifices such as these, he must be a godless person who would for one moment doubt that a community that can boast such heroes can ever fail to attain its goal.
('11', 8, 3, 12, 17318) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910
('11', 8, 4, 13, 17344) 10. THE LATE MR. WOODHEAD
('11', 8, 5, 14, 17370) In the death of Mr. Woodhead, the Indian community of Natal has, along with the European, sustained a severe loss.
('11', 8, 5, 15, 17485) The late gentleman, who met with such an untimely end the other day, 2 had held a responsible position on the editorial staff of The Natal Mercury for a period of 28 years.
('11', 8, 5, 16, 17658) During the time that he was Managing Editor, the Mercury has in all matters relating to the Coloured communities of the Colony, maintained a highstandard and has on many occasions struck the note of warning against race hatred and colour prejudice.
('11', 8, 5, 17, 17907) It is fitting that the various Indian associations 3 of
('11', 8, 6, 18, 17963) 1 Vide also “Well Done, Chettiar!”, 16 4 1910 and Letter to Director of Prisons”, 19 4 1910 2 He was run over by a motor car on April 11, 1910. 3 The Natal Indian Congress, the Durban Indian society, etc.
('11', 8, 6, 19, 18168) Vide “Death of Mr. Woodhead”, Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910.
('11', 9, 0, 1, 18225) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 9, 1, 2, 18266) Durban have expressed their sense of sorrow and loss, and we join with them in offering our deepest sympathy with the widow and children of the departed journalist.
('11', 9, 2, 3, 18431) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910
('11', 9, 3, 4, 18457) 11. G. K. GOKHALE’S SERVICES
('11', 9, 4, 5, 18486) The Hon’ble Professor Gokhale has rendered an invaluable service.
('11', 9, 4, 6, 18552) He has always helped us, but his work in the Legislative Council is a very precious achievement.
('11', 9, 4, 7, 18649) The resolution that he moved 1
('11', 9, 5, 8, 18680) for the prohibition of indentured labour and the speech he made 2 on the occasion are worth reading.
('11', 9, 5, 9, 18781) The latter gives a vivid account of the condition of Indians in all parts of South Africa.
('11', 9, 5, 10, 18872) The speech has evoked appreciative comments even from English newspapers.
('11', 9, 5, 11, 18946) We see that he advocated the prohibition of indenture on the ground that it was [in its very nature] an evil thing.
('11', 9, 5, 12, 19062) That is as it should have been.
('11', 9, 5, 13, 19094) Gokhale was followed by other Indian members.
('11', 9, 5, 14, 19140) We propose to give translations 3 of all the speeches in the issues that will follow.
('11', 9, 5, 15, 19226) They will show to all readers how profound has been the effect of the Transvaal campaign.
('11', 9, 5, 16, 19316) Gokhale certainly deserves thanks for what he has done.
('11', 9, 5, 17, 19372) We hope public bodies in all the Colonies will shower resolutions of thanks on him.
('11', 9, 5, 18, 19456) We gather from the newspapers that the whole of India gives credit for this achievement to Mr. Polak.
('11', 9, 5, 19, 19558) At the conclusion of the meeting, congratulations were offered to him.
('11', 9, 6, 20, 19629) [From Gujarati]
('11', 9, 7, 21, 19645) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910

('11', 10, 0, 1, 19917) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 11
('11', 10, 1, 2, 19959) 12. TRANSVAAL PARLIAMENT
('11', 10, 2, 3, 19984) Indians had hoped that the Transvaal Parliament would do something; that was our hope, too.
('11', 10, 2, 4, 20076) However, it is now clear that it will do nothing to make a settlement possible.
('11', 10, 2, 5, 20156) How can we expect a settlement?
('11', 10, 2, 6, 20188) The weakening of the Indian community has raised further hopes in the Transvaal Government.
('11', 10, 2, 7, 20280) It thought that if it waited longer, all the Indians would quietly surrender.
('11', 10, 2, 8, 20358) We are sure that it is because of this calculation that nothing is being brought forward in Parliament.
('11', 10, 2, 9, 20462) This does not dishearten us.
('11', 10, 2, 10, 20491) We do not want to obtain anything by misrepresenting facts.
('11', 10, 2, 11, 20551) We rely on our own strength.
('11', 10, 2, 12, 20580) There are some strong men who in any case will fight till death, so that the ultimate victory of Indians is not in doubt.
('11', 10, 2, 13, 20702) When we shall celebrate that victory depends upon how many of us put forth our strength.
('11', 10, 3, 14, 20791) [From Gujarati]
('11', 10, 4, 15, 20807) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910
('11', 10, 5, 16, 20833) 13. WELL DONE, CHETTIAR!
('11', 10, 6, 17, 20858) Even the Indians who have given in will have their hair standing on end if they read Mr. Chettiar’s case.
('11', 10, 6, 18, 20964) He is an elderly man and the leader of the Tamil community.
('11', 10, 6, 19, 21024) He has served two terms of imprisonment.
('11', 10, 6, 20, 21065) His son has been to gaol a number of times; now he has been ordered to be deported to India.
('11', 10, 6, 21, 21158) Mr. Chettiar has worked hard from outside without fear of being arrested.
('11', 10, 6, 22, 21232) He has been arrested now.
('11', 10, 6, 23, 21258) He has paid no attention to his ailment.
('11', 10, 6, 24, 21299) He has lost all his wealth.
('11', 10, 6, 25, 21327) Every hair on his body thrills with the determination to die for the sake of honour, for the sake of the motherland and the pledge, rather than surrender.
('11', 10, 6, 26, 21482) He is installed in Marshal Square, a smile on his face.
('11', 10, 6, 27, 21538) We hope every Indian, old or young, big or small, will be infected by Mr. Chettiar’s spirit and be proud of his name.

('11', 10, 8, 29, 21672) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1910
('11', 11, 0, 1, 21698) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 11, 1, 2, 21739) 14. SHOULD LORD GLADSTONE BE HONOURED?
('11', 11, 2, 3, 21778) Lord Gladstone will shortly arrive here as Governor General of South Africa.
('11', 11, 2, 4, 21855) Indians in all the Colonies must be wanting to know whether or not we should honour him.
('11', 11, 2, 5, 21944) Considering our situation from every point of view, we think it will not be proper for us to honour Lord Gladstone.
('11', 11, 2, 6, 22060) Whom can we honour in a land in which we ourselves are despised?
('11', 11, 2, 7, 22125) What honour can we give to the representative of a Government which refuses justice to us?
('11', 11, 2, 8, 22216) This is one line of thinking.
('11', 11, 2, 9, 22246) On the other hand, there is the argument that if we are not afraid of demanding our rights, it is because the British flag flies over this land.
('11', 11, 2, 10, 22391) We want to live in amity with the people of this country.
('11', 11, 2, 11, 22449) We want to protect our honour.
('11', 11, 2, 12, 22480) He who insists on being respected himself will always respect others.
('11', 11, 2, 13, 22550) He who values self respect will never be rude to others.
('11', 11, 2, 14, 22607) In honouring the representative of the Emperor, we shall only be honouring ourselves.
('11', 11, 2, 15, 22693) This is another line of thinking.
('11', 11, 2, 16, 22727) According to this, we see nothing wrong in presenting an address to Lord Gladstone as a matter of courtesy.
('11', 11, 2, 17, 22835) Giving an address, not by way of flattery but by way of courtesy, can be justified.
('11', 11, 2, 18, 22919) Whether or not an address is justified will depend upon the attitude behind it.

('11', 12, 12, 24, 25059) This time he has been sentenced at Volksrust, my Association believes, with
('11', 12, 13, 25, 25135) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was signed by A. M. Cachalia, Chairman, British Indian Association.

('11', 13, 3, 7, 25987) 17. THOSE DEPORTATIONS
('11', 13, 4, 8, 26010) Never has a steamer leaving the South African shore for the Indian carried a more precious human cargo than that carried by the Umhloti last week.
('11', 13, 4, 9, 26157) That ship has sailed with some sixty passive resisters unlawfully deported to India from the Transvaal under an administrative order based on the flimsiest evidence and from which there is no appeal to the usual courts of that Colony.
('11', 13, 4, 10, 26392) Who are these passive resisters?
('11', 13, 4, 11, 26425) They are most of them men who have been voluntarily registered, and are all domiciled in the Transvaal.
('11', 13, 4, 12, 26529) Most of them have served their imprisonment as passive resisters.
('11', 13, 4, 13, 26595) Some of them are lads born in South Africa.
('11', 13, 4, 14, 26639) Some are domiciled also in Natal, and some have a right to enter Natal or the Cape on the ground of possessing educational qualifications.
('11', 13, 4, 15, 26778) And many have left families behind them.
('11', 13, 4, 16, 26819) These families, but for the timely assistance from India, would be starving.
('11', 13, 4, 17, 26896) And why have these men been deported?
('11', 13, 4, 18, 26934) We were told at one time that those who were voluntarily registered would not be deported.
('11', 13, 4, 19, 27025) But now the Asiatic officials have discovered that they can get rid of voluntarily registered passive resisters also.
('11', 13, 4, 20, 27143) These men are called upon to produce their certificates.
('11', 13, 4, 21, 27200) They say they have burnt the documents.
('11', 13, 4, 22, 27240) Then they are asked to give their signatures and finger prints.
('11', 13, 4, 23, 27304) These the passive resisters naturally decline to give.
('11', 13, 4, 24, 27359) Now both these omissions— the omission to produce the certificates and the one to give signatures, etc.—are crimes carrying a high penalty.
('11', 13, 4, 25, 27499) But the zealous officials do not wish to adopt the regular course of prosecuting the men.
('11', 13, 4, 26, 27589) They assume that the men have no certificates at all and, therefore, insist on their deportation under an administrative
('11', 14, 0, 1, 27710) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 15
('11', 14, 1, 2, 27752) inquiry.
('11', 14, 1, 3, 27761) They contend that if they do not follow this course, any Asiatic may pretend that he has been voluntarily registered and thus “merely go to gaol”.
('11', 14, 1, 4, 27908) There is a double fallacy in this argument.
('11', 14, 1, 5, 27952) For the man who so pretends, still goes to gaol, and having gone to gaol, he has to give finger impressions which ensure detection of any such pretension.
('11', 14, 1, 6, 28107) And if an examination of finger impressions should betray the man, he would be liable to be committed for perjury in addition to an order for deportation.
('11', 14, 1, 7, 28262) Moreover, the above argument cannot hold water, seeing that such well known stalwarts like Messrs Chettiar and Quinn 1 have also been deported.
('11', 14, 1, 8, 28406) The policy clearly is to subject passive resisters to a treatment such that they cannot bear it.
('11', 14, 1, 9, 28503) We shall see what success attends the efforts of the Asiatic Department.
('11', 14, 2, 10, 28576) Indian Opinion, 23 4 1910
('11', 14, 3, 11, 28602) 18. JOURNALISTS’ DUTY
('11', 14, 4, 12, 28624) We find the following report in a newspaper received from India.
('11', 14, 4, 13, 28689) The manager and the editor of the Gujarat Patra, published from Nadiad, had been served with a notice by Mr. Chakravarti, the District Magistrate of Kaira, under section 124 of the Indian Penal Code, to show cause why they should not be prosecuted.
('11', 14, 4, 14, 28938) When the case came up for hearing at Anand before the District Magistrate, it was stated by the defendants’ advocate, Mr. Maganbhai Chaturbhai Patel, B.A., LL.B., that the matter in respect of which the notice had been issued was a translation of an English letter and that the respondents had no unlawful intention in publishing it.
('11', 14, 4, 15, 29272) At the same time, he expressed regret for [the publication of] the matter whereupon the notice which had been issued was withdrawn.
('11', 14, 5, 16, 29404) We are sorry for the manager and the editor.
('11', 14, 5, 17, 29449) What happened to them may now happen to any other newspaper.
('11', 14, 5, 18, 29510) A time may come when here, too, the same condition will prevail.
('11', 14, 5, 19, 29575) However, we see that just now it is not so, with the result that the full force of what we say cannot be appreciated.
('11', 14, 5, 20, 29693) It may appear somewhat presumptuous for a man who is not himself caught in a fire to write anything about those who are.
('11', 14, 5, 21, 29814) However, some general comments will not be considered out
('11', 14, 6, 22, 29872) 1 Chairman of the Transvaal Chinese Association; vide “The Supreme Court Case”, 7 5 1910
('11', 15, 0, 1, 29961) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 15, 1, 2, 30002) of place on this occasion.
('11', 15, 1, 3, 30029) We think the editors of all such newspapers, which do not run with a commercial motive but only with a view to public service, must be prepared to face extinction at any moment.
('11', 15, 1, 4, 30207) It is obvious that all newspapers do not come within the scope of this rule, but only those which aim at public service by advocating reforms in the Government or among the people or in both.
('11', 15, 1, 5, 30399) What should an editor do when something he has published displeases the Government or is held to violate some law, but is none the less true?
('11', 15, 1, 6, 30541) Should he apologize?
('11', 15, 1, 7, 30562) We would say, certainly not.
('11', 15, 1, 8, 30591) True, he is not bound to publish such matter, but once it has been published, the editor ought to accept responsibility for it.
('11', 15, 1, 9, 30719) This raises a very important issue.
('11', 15, 1, 10, 30755) If the principle we have laid down is correct, it follows that, if any provocative writing has been published unintentionally and no apology is offered for the same, the newspaper will in consequence be prevented from rendering other services as well and the community will go without that benefit.
('11', 15, 1, 11, 31054) We would not, therefore, apply this principle to matter published unintentionally, but it should apply to what is published after full deliberation.
('11', 15, 1, 12, 31203) If a newspaper runs into difficulties for publishing any such matter, we think the closing down of the newspaper will be a better service to the public.
('11', 15, 1, 13, 31356) The argument that in that case one may have to face the confiscation of all one’s property and be reduced to poverty has no force.
('11', 15, 1, 14, 31487) Such a contingency may certainly arise, and it was precisely for this reason that we said that the editor of a journal devoted to public service must be ever ready for death.
('11', 15, 1, 15, 31662) Let us take one or two obvious illustrations.
('11', 15, 1, 16, 31708) Suppose that in a certain region there obtains the cruel practice of kanya vikraya 1. A reformer starts a newspaper there and writes strongly against this practice.
('11', 15, 1, 17, 31873) Those who follow the practice are angry with him and decide to outcaste him if he does not apologize.
('11', 15, 1, 18, 31975) We are sure the reformer ought to go on writing against offering girls in marriage for a price, even if he has to face total ruin or be outcast for that, and, when he is left without a single pie, he should close down the newspaper; he must not apologize, whatever happens.
('11', 15, 1, 19, 32249) It is only by such conduct that he can prepare the ground for rooting out the practice.
('11', 15, 1, 20, 32337) Let us take another illustration.
('11', 15, 1, 21, 32371) Suppose that the Government
('11', 15, 2, 22, 32399) 1 Demanding a price for a girl (offered in marriage)
('11', 16, 0, 1, 32452) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 17
('11', 16, 1, 2, 32494) has committed a gross injustice and robbed the poor.
('11', 16, 1, 3, 32547) A progressive newspaper is being published in such a place.
('11', 16, 1, 4, 32607) It writes against the oppressive measure and advises the people to disregard the unjust law of the Government.
('11', 16, 1, 5, 32718) The Government takes offence and threatens confiscation of property if no apology is forthcoming.
('11', 16, 1, 6, 32816) Should the reformer apologize?
('11', 16, 1, 7, 32847) We think the reply is again the same, that he should stand the confiscation of his property and close down the newspaper but certainly not offer an apology.
('11', 16, 1, 8, 33004) The people would then see that, if the reformer could lose his all for their sake, they should also in their own interest oppose the law.
('11', 16, 1, 9, 33142) If the reformer should apologize, the effect on the people would exactly be the reverse of this.
('11', 16, 1, 10, 33239) They would know that the man would not be concerned overmuch even if their houses were on fire, that, from a safe distance, he would only indulge in meaningless declamations.
('11', 16, 1, 11, 33414) When he himself ran into trouble [they would say], he meekly retired.
('11', 16, 1, 12, 33484) And so they will think of doing likewise and resign themselves to the inevitable.
('11', 16, 1, 13, 33566) They will thus argue themselves into greater weakness.
('11', 16, 1, 14, 33621) It is, therefore, clear in this instance that the best service that the reformer can render will be to stop the newspaper.
('11', 16, 2, 15, 33744) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 4 1910
('11', 16, 3, 16, 33786) 19. “AS ONE SOWS ONE REAPS”
('11', 16, 4, 17, 33814) We all know this saying, but most of us go the opposite way and desire the reverse of what we do.
('11', 16, 4, 18, 33912) Stay at homes, we want to be wealthy.
('11', 16, 4, 19, 33950) Though we eat too much, we will have no indigestion.
('11', 16, 4, 20, 34003) We would not work, but hope to have all our desires fulfilled.
('11', 16, 4, 21, 34066) We deserve hell for our deeds, but wish to go to heaven.
('11', 16, 4, 22, 34123) In newspapers from India, we come across accounts of the miserable condition of the bhangis 1 and other castes.
('11', 16, 4, 23, 34235) These castes are despised by some so called civilized Indians.
('11', 16, 4, 24, 34298) The Maharaja of Baroda has passed an order for the admission of members of these castes to public schools.
('11', 16, 4, 25, 34405) Some Indians, claiming to belong to higher castes, have protested against this and are putting difficulties in the way of the Maharaja.
('11', 16, 4, 26, 34541) This is how we behave as a nation, and yet we do not want to pay the price for this and would not submit to the treatment meted out to us in South Africa.
('11', 16, 4, 27, 34696) How can
('11', 16, 5, 28, 34704) 1 Scavengers
('11', 17, 0, 1, 34717) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 17, 1, 2, 34758) we escape [retribution]?
('11', 17, 1, 3, 34783) Recently, an Indian judge 1 in Madras made some severe remarks [on our behaviour].
('11', 17, 1, 4, 34866) He does not mind, he says, our kicking up a row about South Africa, but complains that we look down upon our own people, think ourselves defiled by their touch, keep them at a distance from us and grind them under our heels; he wants to know why we do not seek to remedy this state of affairs.
('11', 17, 1, 5, 35160) “Why do we not, instead of lashing out at the whites, rain lashes on our own backs?” he asks.
('11', 17, 1, 6, 35254) We have no answer to this charge.
('11', 17, 1, 7, 35288) True, we can say something for ourselves.
('11', 17, 1, 8, 35330) But we do not think it necessary to say it here.
('11', 17, 1, 9, 35379) To be sure, Indians in South Africa must take a lesson from their present condition.
('11', 17, 1, 10, 35464) They must realize that it would not do for them, on returning to India, to treat the bhangis with contempt.
('11', 17, 1, 11, 35572) If those who have been putting difficulties in the way 2 of the Maharaja Gaekwar are representative specimens of high caste Hindus, a time will come when birth in a bhangi family will confer great honour.
('11', 17, 1, 12, 35777) The contemptuous attitude of the [caste] Hindu towards the bhangis and others is a striking illustration of the length to which man is carried by pride and selfish ness.
('11', 17, 1, 13, 35947) We should like every wise and decent Hindu to pray, “O God!
('11', 17, 1, 14, 36007) Save me from this pride and this selfishness”, and to be granted the strength to fight this tyranny.

('11', 19, 1, 2, 39075) 22. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE 1
('11', 19, 2, 3, 39105) JOHANNESBURG, April 25, 1910
('11', 19, 3, 4, 39134) DEAR PROFESSOR GOKHALE, In answer to my cable 2 of the 6th December last, you cabled inquiring what funds were required, and in my replying cable I stated as follows:
('11', 19, 4, 5, 39301) Present requirements thousand pounds.
('11', 19, 4, 6, 39339) Expect imprisonment before end month.
('11', 19, 4, 7, 39377) Much more required later.
('11', 19, 4, 8, 39403) On the same day, I wrote to you 3 how the funds are being dealt with.
('11', 19, 4, 9, 39473) In that letter, I told you that the debt incurred in conducting Phoenix by me personally was paid out of the amount received from you.
('11', 19, 4, 10, 39608) This covers over £1,200. I gave you also the following approximate summary of monthly expenses: Office here £50 Office London £40 Indian Opinion £50 Distressed families £25 In your letter replying to mine, you were good enough to inform me that the expenses were in order.
('11', 19, 4, 11, 39881) In view of the certainty of prolongation of the struggle yet for some considerable time, it is necessary for me to give you a resume of receipts and expenditure, and of the events to date.
('11', 19, 4, 12, 40070) The monies obtained to date since December last are as follows: £ s.
('11', 19, 4, 13, 40139) From Bombay 4,253 3 4 From Rangoon 750 0 0 From London 135 8 2 From Mozambique 50 0 0 From Zanzibar 59 3 6 From Lourenco Marques 11 12 0 From Natal 8 16 0 Local 1 7 7 5,269 10 7
('11', 19, 5, 14, 40317) The Bombay fund is divided into two parts—£3,914 10 0 has
('11', 19, 6, 15, 40375) 1 A Gujarati translation appeared in Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910. 2 Not available 3 Vide “Letter to G. K. Gokhale”, 6 12 1909
('11', 20, 0, 1, 40498) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 21
('11', 20, 1, 2, 40540) been sent to be used for carrying on the struggle generally, and £338 l3 4 has been earmarked for relief of distress among the passive resisters or their dependants.
('11', 20, 1, 3, 40706) These instructions have been closely followed.
('11', 20, 1, 4, 40753) The remittances from Rangoon as also from London have, like the earmarked fund from Bombay, been devoted to the relief of distress only.
('11', 20, 1, 5, 40890) Your letter, as also Mr. Petit’s, has left the expenditure to my discretion, and I have considered it best to avail myself of that latitude.
('11', 20, 1, 6, 41031) The funds are banked to a separate account, called the Passive Resistance Fund Account, in the Natal Bank, Johannesburg.
('11', 20, 1, 7, 41152) So far as the Bank is concerned, I alone operate upon them.
('11', 20, 1, 8, 41212) No special and formal committee has been organized, nor are the funds treated as part of the British Indian Association Account.
('11', 20, 1, 9, 41341) The British Indian Association covers a wider range than that of passive resistance.
('11', 20, 1, 10, 41426) Disbursements are made in consultation with or subject to the approval of Mr. Cachalia, who is the President of the British Indian Association, and other passive resisters.
('11', 20, 1, 11, 41599) The Phoenix debt represented a personal debt incurred by me from European friends and clients by reason of the necessity of having to continue Indian Opinion under somewhat adverse circumstances and at a loss in the interests of the struggle.
('11', 20, 1, 12, 41842) I have devoted to the continuance of Indian Opinion and the establishment of Phoenix all my earnings during my last stay in South Africa, that is, nearly £5,000. I derive no pecuniary benefit from Phoenix, the support of my family and myself being found by a European friend 1. Those Europeans and Indians who are my co workers at Phoenix receive as a rule only what they need, and are practically under a vow of poverty.
('11', 20, 1, 13, 42264) Certain alterations have been made in the management of Phoenix, which I am glad to be able to say have so far enabled the continuance of the paper without the monthly assistance referred to in my letter.
('11', 20, 1, 14, 42469) The Committee in London is being financed on a most economic basis.
('11', 20, 1, 15, 42537) I have to make the same remark in connection with the offices here.
('11', 20, 1, 16, 42605) The expenditure [up] to the 20th instant is as follows: Local Expenses 374 11 8 London Office 175 15 0 Relief of Distress 449 11 11 Relief apart from Distress Fund 50 0 0
('11', 20, 2, 17, 42776) 1 Hermann Kallenbach
('11', 21, 0, 1, 42797) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 21, 1, 2, 42838) Indian Opinion Debt 1,200 0 0
('11', 21, 2, 3, 42868) Total £2,249 18 7
('11', 21, 3, 4, 42886) This leaves a balance of £3,019/12/ .
('11', 21, 3, 5, 42924) The monthly expenses for relieving distress have, however, as you see, gone forward, and, whereas, in the month of December only £25 was paid, on the present basis it comes to nearly £160 per month, over fifty families receiving support.
('11', 21, 3, 6, 43162) Local expenses, besides the carrying on of the office here, include travelling expenses of passive resisters from Durban, etc., as also cables and such other disbursements.
('11', 21, 3, 7, 43335) The above expenditure covers a period of four months and a half.
('11', 21, 3, 8, 43400) Excluding relief expenditure and the item for the Indian Opinion debt, the average monthly expense is nearly £133. The expenses for supporting distressed families are bound to increase as time passes.
('11', 21, 3, 9, 43601) I, therefore, put them down at £200 per month.
('11', 21, 3, 10, 43648) The average monthly expense then may be put down at £333. The balance of £3,019/12/ may thus be exhausted about the month of January next.
('11', 21, 3, 11, 43787) Nearly £50 is being paid towards rent due by the families in dis tress.
('11', 21, 3, 12, 43859) We have, therefore, been considering the advisability of remo ving them to a farm, where women as well as men could do something to earn a living, and where we should probably be able to save half of what is now being paid for relief.
('11', 21, 3, 13, 44094) There was the difficulty about a capital outlay on a farm.
('11', 21, 3, 14, 44153) Mr. Cachalia, others who were out of gaol and I were even prepared to risk that outlay in the hope of being able to sell the farm, if necessary, at the close of the struggle, but a large outlay will probably not be required, as a European friend has offered to buy a farm and place it at the disposal of the passive resisters during the continuance of the struggle, free of charge.
('11', 21, 3, 15, 44535) 1 This very generous offer has been almost accepted and by the time this letter is in your hands, he may have secured a suitable farm, in which [case] all the distressed families and I should be living together on the farm.
('11', 21, 3, 16, 44759) The expenses detailed above take no note of relief that is being granted privately by individuals.
('11', 21, 3, 17, 44858) The estimate I gave you of active passive resisters I now see was an under estimate, and many whom I did not consider would come forward are now either serving imprisonment or have been deported.
('11', 21, 3, 18, 45054) The Authorities have been of late very active in effecting arrests,
('11', 21, 4, 19, 45122) 1 Vide “Letter to H. Kallenbach”, 30 5 1910
('11', 22, 0, 1, 45166) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 23
('11', 22, 1, 2, 45208) particularly of the brave Tamils, than whom no [other] Indians have done better in connection with the struggle.
('11', 22, 1, 3, 45321) These brave men have time after time courted imprisonment.
('11', 22, 1, 4, 45380) There are over thirty at present at the Diepkloof Gaol, which is a penal settlement, in which the regulations are more severe than in the other prisons of the Transvaal.
('11', 22, 1, 5, 45550) Nearly sixty have been deported by the Umhloti and over thirty may be deported any day, orders for deportation having been already made.
('11', 22, 1, 6, 45687) I cannot write about these deportations with sufficient restraint.
('11', 22, 1, 7, 45754) All these men are domiciled in the Transvaal; some of them are domiciled also in Natal; some, again, have a right to enter Natal, being able to pass the education test imposed under the immigration law of that Colony.
('11', 22, 1, 8, 45972) Some are mere lads born in the Transvaal or other parts of South Africa, and many have left behind them families that have been reared in this country.
('11', 22, 1, 9, 46124) I come into constant touch with the brave wives, sisters or mothers of the deported men.
('11', 22, 1, 10, 46213) I once asked them whether they would like to go with the deported to India, and they indignantly remarked: “How can we?
('11', 22, 1, 11, 46333) We were brought to this country as children, and we do not know anybody in India.
('11', 22, 1, 12, 46415) We would rather perish here than go to India, which is a foreign land to us.” However regrettable this attitude of mind may be from a national standpoint, the fact remains that these men and women are rooted to the South African soil.
('11', 22, 1, 13, 46650) Many of these men before the struggle commenced earned a decent living.
('11', 22, 1, 14, 46722) Some of them had stores, some were trolley contractors, and others were hawkers, cigar makers, waiters, etc., the employees earning a minimum wage of £6 and a maximum of £15, whereas the trolley contractors and others who followed an independent calling earned as much as from £20 to £30 per month.
('11', 22, 1, 15, 47021) All these are now reduced to poverty, and their families receive from the Passive Resistance Fund the barest sustenance money.
('11', 22, 1, 16, 47148) I may mention for your information that it was stated at one time by the Government that those who were voluntarily registered in the Transvaal as many of these deported men are, were not deported at all, and that those who were domiciled in parts of South Africa other than the Transvaal were deported to such parts and not to India.
('11', 22, 1, 17, 47483) Both these declarations have been falsified, the excuse given being that these men refuse to supply identification particulars and to prove domicile.
('11', 22, 1, 18, 47633) The first excuse is invalid, because the refusal to supply identification particulars is itself a criminal offence, and these men, seeing that they were voluntarily registered, could have been proceeded against under the special section that deals with refusal to supply identification
('11', 23, 0, 1, 47919) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 23, 1, 2, 47960) particulars.
('11', 23, 1, 3, 47973) There was no occasion to treat them as unregistered Indians and thus deport them.
('11', 23, 1, 4, 48055) The second excuse is equally invalid, in that those who were entitled to enter Natal stated that they were domiciled there and those who had a knowledge of a European language did not need to bring forward any proof.
('11', 23, 1, 5, 48272) In my opinion, the fact is that, having failed to break the proud spirit of the brave Tamils, the Asiatic Department has now embarked upon a plan of extermination, and of taxing our pecuniary resources to the uttermost.
('11', 23, 1, 6, 48492) Be that as it may, I think that I am quite correct in assuring you and, through you, the public in India, that neither these men, nor their wives, mothers nor sisters, as the case may be, are likely to succumb in any appreciable measure.
('11', 23, 1, 7, 48730) I hope that the Motherland will not rest so long as the insult offered to her in the Transvaal legislation that we are fighting has not been removed, and that we shall continue to receive the support that has been hitherto extended to us.
('11', 23, 2, 8, 48969) I remain,
('11', 23, 3, 9, 48979) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI
('11', 23, 4, 10, 49005) From the typewritten original signed by Gandhiji: G. N. 3799; also Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910
('11', 23, 5, 11, 49097) 23. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 1
('11', 23, 6, 12, 49133) [JOHANNESBURG,] April 26, 1910
('11', 23, 8, 13, 49164) Some of the passive resisters recently discharged from Diepkloof have brought to the notice of my Association complaints and information which, in the interests of humanity, my Association feels bound to place before you.
('11', 23, 8, 14, 49386) Mr. Sorabji, who has suffered imprisonment again and again, was on the 26th October last, together with Mr. Medh 2, sentenced to a
('11', 23, 9, 15, 49517) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was signed by E. I. Aswat, Acting Chairman of the British Indian Association.
('11', 23, 9, 16, 49642) 2 Leading Natal Indian satyagrahi, vide “Notable Discharges”, 30 4 1910
('11', 24, 0, 1, 49714) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 25
('11', 24, 1, 2, 49756) further term at Volksrust.
('11', 24, 1, 3, 49783) Mr. Sorabji states that during this last imprisonment at Volksrust, he was roughly treated by a warder named Nell.
('11', 24, 1, 4, 49898) The previous time that he had gone to prison, he was, under medical orders, specially put on light labour, and he was called upon to carry no heavy weight.
('11', 24, 1, 5, 50054) But, on the occasion in question, on the day of sentence, before medical examination had taken place, Warder Nell ordered Mr. Sorabji to water plants, in the doing of which he was called upon to fill full with water two five gallon buckets and to carry them to some distance, a task which the Native prisoner with whom he and the other Indians were made to work could do only with some difficulty.
('11', 24, 1, 6, 50452) Warder Nell knew Mr. Sorabji during his previous term of imprisonment, and knew also that, under special medical instructions, he was put upon very light labour, and his task chiefly consisted in store work, keeping an account of clothing and distributing it.
('11', 24, 1, 7, 50712) Mr. Sorabji was working under another warder named Oberholster, who did not mind Mr. Sorabji taking his own time and only half filling the buckets.
('11', 24, 1, 8, 50860) At 2 o’clock that day, Warder Nell came and insisted upon Mr. Sorabji filling the two buckets full.
('11', 24, 1, 9, 50960) The latter protested and said that the warder knew him and knew also that the Medical Officer had last time put him upon light labour only.
('11', 24, 1, 10, 51100) He also drew the warder’s attention to the fact that he was suffering from rupture and dislocation of one of his arms and from acceleration of the heart.
('11', 24, 1, 11, 51254) The warder took no heed, and still insisted upon Mr. Sorabji carrying the buckets and watering the plants.
('11', 24, 1, 12, 51361) This he was obliged to do up to the time he was able to see the Medical Officer, that is, for two days.
('11', 24, 1, 13, 51465) Upon his bringing the matter to the notice of the Medical Officer, instructions were at once given to the effect that he was not to be put upon any heavy work and that he was not to be made to carry any weight.
('11', 24, 1, 14, 51676) Warder Nell, evidently wishing to be spiteful, brought a charge of breach of discipline against Mr. Sorabji, and the latter was tried before the Magistrate.
('11', 24, 1, 15, 51833) The breach of discipline consisted in Mr. Sorabji’s having drawn attention to his condition, and his having, as was alleged by the warder and denied by Mr. Sorabji, said to the former “Leave me alone.
('11', 24, 1, 16, 52034) You are causing trouble for nothing.” Mr. Sorabji cross examined the warder, and related the whole of the incident to the Magistrate, who, however, said that he was not trying the question of the work that was entrusted to Mr. Sorabji, but that he was simply trying the question of breach of discipline; and punished him with spare diet.
('11', 24, 1, 17, 52372) It is worthy perhaps of remark that, as the Medical Officer had ordered only light labour for Mr. Sorabji, the latter was given by
('11', 25, 0, 1, 52503) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 25, 1, 2, 52544) the same warder the dirtiest work to do, namely, the cleaning of the water closet.
('11', 25, 1, 3, 52627) Mr. Sorabji desires me to state that he had no objection, as a passive resister, to doing the work, but my Association considers it to be its duty to bring the matter to your notice.
('11', 25, 1, 4, 52810) On removal from Volksrust, Mr. Sorabji was accompanied by Messrs Medh and Harilal Gandhi.
('11', 25, 1, 5, 52900) The three were handcuffed together, and marched from the gaol to the station, a distance of over a mile.
('11', 25, 1, 6, 53005) They were, in spite of the handcuffs, made to carry their own bundles, which were fairly heavy, as they contained, in addition to their personal clothing, books also, and they had to carry things belonging to the warder in charge and one blanket each.
('11', 25, 1, 7, 53257) They were marched from Park Station to the Fort in the same manner.
('11', 25, 1, 8, 53325) With reference to the condition at Diepkloof, Messrs Sorabji and Medh, who have been just discharged, confirm the statements made by other discharged men as follows: The Medical Officer continues to be entirely callous to the avoidable sufferings of the prisoners.
('11', 25, 1, 9, 53590) Once, Mr. Thambi Naidoo, who is still at Diepkloof, and who, my Association considers, is one of the bravest men and certainly incapable of lying, complained to the Medical Officer that the prisoners were suffering from partial starvation; whereupon, he called Mr. Naidoo a liar.
('11', 25, 1, 10, 53870) Mr. Medh often complained that he was losing weight, and that he should have the quantity of the food increased and the quality improved, but the Medical Officer laughed at his complaint and turned a deaf ear.
('11', 25, 1, 11, 54080) When Mr. Medh had lost over twenty five pounds, he complained to the Deputy Governor, and it was only on the 1st April, that is, during the last three weeks of his imprisonment, that the quantity was increased.
('11', 25, 1, 12, 54291) Most of the prisoners complain that they lose in weight, but the change in diet is not ordered until the Medical Officer considers that they have lost more weight than they need have.
('11', 25, 1, 13, 54475) The usual remark made by him is that no harm is done to the prisoners if they lose somewhat in weightand throw off what he calls superfluous fat.
('11', 25, 1, 14, 54621) The Medical Officer used often to remark to the prisoners that they were getting fat on the Government rations.
('11', 25, 1, 15, 54733) In the humble opinion of my Association, under treatment such as this, the lot of Indian passive resisters at Diepkloof is being made unnecessarily hard.
('11', 25, 1, 16, 54887) The fact that out of 72 Asiatic prisoners, 18 had to receive an increase in diet shows that the present scale is perilously low both in quantity and quality.
('11', 25, 1, 17, 55045) The approach of the cold weather makes my Association nervous as to the health of these prisoners, who, deprived of the ordinary fat in their
('11', 26, 0, 1, 55187) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 27
('11', 26, 1, 2, 55229) diet to which they are accustomed, will suffer very seriously.
('11', 26, 1, 3, 55292) The discharged men also complain that, whereas, last winter, the articles of clothing included a stout shirt, this time it has not yet been allowed, and the prisoners have already begun to suffer from the absence of this article of clothing.
('11', 26, 1, 4, 55534) My Association is not aware whether this change has been made throughout, but, even if it has on grounds of economy or otherwise, my Association hopes that Indian prisoners, who belong to a much warmer country, will not be deprived of the long sleeved shirts to which they have always been used.
('11', 26, 1, 5, 55830) My Association understands that this complaint has been brought to the notice of the Governor, as also of the Medical Officer, but they informed the prisoners that the change was made by the Government.
('11', 26, 1, 6, 56033) The prisoners complain also of the fewness of the blankets.
('11', 26, 1, 7, 56093) Diepkloof Prison, which is built with corrugated iron only and which is without any ceiling board, being on high ground, is very cold, and three blankets, which may be sufficient in the stone built prison at Volksrust, are undoubtedly not enough cover for the British Indian prisoners at Diepkloof.
('11', 26, 1, 8, 56392) My Association ventures to draw your attention to the fact that, at Volksrust, all the Indian prisoners were allowed, even during warm weather, besides three blankets and matting, a bed board and a pillow.
('11', 26, 1, 9, 56598) The two latter articles are not given to the prisoners at Diepkloof.
('11', 26, 1, 10, 56667) Messrs Sorabji and Medh, who have had experience at Houtpoort and Volksrust, mention that at both these places during winter time four blankets were supplied to British Indian prisoners; and they add that, at Houtpoort, four blankets were ordered by yourself, when you visited the gaol there and the passive resisters complained.
('11', 26, 1, 11, 56997) One very painful incident, too, is reported by Messrs Sorabji and Medh.
('11', 26, 1, 12, 57069) There is an Indian prisoner at Diepkloof, who is over 60 years old.
('11', 26, 1, 13, 57137) He pleaded before the Medical Officer for a shirt and an extra blanket, but that officer point blank declined to grant relief.
('11', 26, 1, 14, 57264) My Association ventures to trust that the matters herein set forth will receive your urgent and careful attention.
('11', 26, 2, 15, 57379) Indian Opinion, 30 4 1910
('11', 27, 0, 1, 57405) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 27, 1, 2, 57446) 24. NOTABLE DISCHARGES
('11', 27, 2, 3, 57469) Messrs Sorabji and Medh, who are among the stalwarts of passive resistance, were discharged on Saturday last.
('11', 27, 2, 4, 57579) Both have served more than twelve months’ imprisonment.
('11', 27, 2, 5, 57635) Both are educated and both have sacrificed their all for the honour of India.
('11', 27, 2, 6, 57713) Mr. Sorabji laid the foundation of the second stage of the struggle and Mr. Medh was among the first batch of Natal Indians who entered the Transvaal in order to test their rights as British subjects.
('11', 27, 2, 7, 57914) Both have suffered much during their incarceration.
('11', 27, 2, 8, 57966) Mr. Medh has lost heavily in flesh.
('11', 27, 2, 9, 58002) But both have gained in moral strength, in soul power.
('11', 27, 2, 10, 58057) Their material loss is the community’s gain.
('11', 27, 2, 11, 58102) We congratulate these servants of India and wish them enough strength to go through what more may be in store for them.
('11', 27, 3, 12, 58222) Indian Opinion, 30 4 1910
('11', 27, 4, 13, 58248) 25. THE PRETORIA MUNICIPALITY 1
('11', 27, 5, 14, 58280) This notorious municipality keeps up its reputation for waging war against Colour.
('11', 27, 5, 15, 58363) A private Bill introduced during the last session of the Transvaal Parliament seeks to perpetuate the Town Regulations of the Boer regime which prevent the use of footpaths by Natives, Coloured people and Asiatics.
('11', 27, 5, 16, 58578) The British Indian Association of the Transvaal has done well in formally protesting against the Bill.
('11', 27, 5, 17, 58681) 2 It contains, as it ought to, a clause to the effect that it will not come into force unless and until His Majesty has expressed his pleasure not to disallow it.
('11', 27, 5, 18, 58844) Lord Crewe has now an opportunity of showing that he is ready to protect the unrepresented classes in South Africa from insult and molestation.
('11', 27, 5, 19, 58988) But the ultimate court of appeal is and must be the people themselves who are affected by hostile legislation.
('11', 27, 6, 20, 59099) Indian Opinion, 30 4 1910
('11', 27, 7, 21, 59125) 26. THE £3 TAX AGAIN
('11', 27, 8, 22, 59146) The Government have notified Indians who are liable to pay the annual poll tax of £3 that by re indenturing they may avoid payment of the tax, and they have notified the women who are so liable that
('11', 27, 9, 23, 59345) 1 Vide also “Pretoria Municipality”, 30 4 1910 2 Vide “Petition to Transvaal Legislative Assembly”, 25 4 1910
('11', 28, 0, 1, 59455) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 29
('11', 28, 1, 2, 59497) they could avoid the tax by showing the Magistrate of their district sufficient cause for avoidance.
('11', 28, 1, 3, 59598) On the face of it, the notice seems to be in the interests of the men and women concerned.
('11', 28, 1, 4, 59689) But in reality, it is nothing of the kind.
('11', 28, 1, 5, 59732) The notice as to the men is totally for the benefit of the employers of Indian labour.
('11', 28, 1, 6, 59819) It was for them that the change in the law was made.
('11', 28, 1, 7, 59872) For, the employers had to pay higher wages in order to enable the Indians who were liable to the tax to discharge it.
('11', 28, 1, 8, 59990) A complacent Government have, therefore, met the employers by exempting from payment Indians who may be employed by them.
('11', 28, 1, 9, 60112) So that the notice is in effect a warning to the unfortunate Indians to re indenture or to pay the tax.
('11', 28, 1, 10, 60216) As for the women, the less said about the disgraceful affair the better.
('11', 28, 1, 11, 60289) After the humiliating surrender to the clamorous party in the Assembly, we could expect nothing better from the Government than the insulting notice to the women.
('11', 28, 1, 12, 60452) Their womanhood should either prove sufficient cause for non payment or none other could.
('11', 28, 1, 13, 60542) If their sex do not protect them, they must re indenture in the same way as men.
('11', 28, 1, 14, 60623) We hope, however, that not a single Indian woman would do anything of the kind.
('11', 28, 2, 15, 60703) Indian Opinion, 30 4 1910
('11', 28, 3, 16, 60729) 27. PRETORIA MUNICIPALITY
('11', 28, 4, 17, 60755) The Pretoria Municipality has never been known to behave better than like the garbage removing body that it is.
('11', 28, 4, 18, 60867) It has earned a name for its hostility to the Coloured people.
('11', 28, 4, 19, 60930) It would seem to have come into existence just to make things go hard with them.
('11', 28, 4, 20, 61011) In the last session of the Transvaal Parliament, too, this Municipality dealt a blow to the Coloureds.
('11', 28, 4, 21, 61114) A private Bill sponsored by it seeks to provide that Coloured persons should not use footpaths.
('11', 28, 4, 22, 61210) “Coloured” will include Cape Boys and Asiatics.
('11', 28, 4, 23, 61258) The British Indian Association has done well to send a petition 1 against this.
('11', 28, 4, 24, 61338) It will also be necessary to send a petition to Lord Crewe.
('11', 28, 4, 25, 61398) Let us see what he and Lord Morley say [in reply].
('11', 28, 4, 26, 61449) But it must always be borne in mind that ourultimate appeal lies only to ourselves.
('11', 28, 4, 27, 61533) Is it possible that the Pretoria Indians will agree to avoid footpaths and walk on the roads?

('11', 29, 1, 2, 61773) 28. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('11', 29, 2, 3, 61801) JOHANNESBURG, May 2, 1910
('11', 29, 3, 4, 61827) DEAR PROFESSOR GOKHALE,
('11', 29, 4, 5, 61851) I am sending you a public letter 1 addressed to you.
('11', 29, 4, 6, 61904) After due deliberation, I thought that it was the best thing for me to do.
('11', 29, 4, 7, 61979) The letter has been handed to the Press here, 2 and I take it that you will publish it on your side also.
('11', 29, 4, 8, 62085) The letter, too, enables me to inform all the contributors.
('11', 29, 4, 9, 62145) I have now heard from Mr. Petit that Mr. Tata approves of the expenses incurred by me in connection with Indian Opinion.
('11', 29, 4, 10, 62266) Your letter, to which I have alluded in the accompanying, had already relieved me of anxiety on this score, but it is as well that I have received specific approval from Mr. Tata also.
('11', 29, 4, 11, 62451) I do hope that my action in publishing Hind Swaraj in Gujarati and now the translation in English does not in any way affect the struggle that is going on in the Transvaal.
('11', 29, 4, 12, 62624) The opinions expressed by me in the booklet are personal to me.
('11', 29, 4, 13, 62688) Though they have been matured in the course of the struggle, they have nothing to do with it at all, and I trust that you will be able, should any prejudice arise against myself personally or the pamphlet, to keep the merits of the struggle entirely separate from me.
('11', 29, 4, 14, 62956) The views expressed by me in Hind Swaraj have not been formed without much thought and consideration.
('11', 29, 4, 15, 63058) Mr. Polak has passed on the typed copy to you.
('11', 29, 4, 16, 63105) I am not sending you the printed copy because, as the Gujarati is confiscated, I suppose the same thing applies to the translation.
('11', 29, 4, 17, 63237) If you have had the time to go through the typed copy, I shall esteem your opinion.
('11', 29, 4, 18, 63321) The booklet has been widely circulated here.
('11', 29, 4, 19, 63366) Much criticism has been received.
('11', 29, 4, 20, 63400) There appears today in The Transvaal Leader a signed criticism, which I am asking Mr. Polak to forward to you.
('11', 29, 4, 21, 63511) I am not answering the personal part of your letter of December.
('11', 29, 4, 22, 63576) I simply felt that it was my duty to lay my views before you, which I have done.
('11', 29, 4, 23, 63657) It is not for me now to argue.
('11', 29, 4, 24, 63688) Should I ever
('11', 29, 5, 25, 63702) 1 Vide “Letter to G. K. Gokhale”,25 4 1910 2 It was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910.
('11', 30, 0, 1, 63794) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 31
('11', 30, 1, 2, 63836) have the privilege of meeting you personally, I shall certainly again press upon your attention some of the views I hold so strongly, and which it appears to me are perfectly sound.
('11', 30, 1, 3, 64018) Meanwhile, with the hope that you have entirely recovered from your malady, and that you will be long spared for the service of the Motherland, I can only remain,
('11', 30, 2, 4, 64181) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('11', 30, 5, 7, 64327) 29. LETTER TO GENERAL MANAGER, C. S. A. R. 1
('11', 30, 6, 8, 64372) [JOHANNESBURG,] May 2, 1910
('11', 30, 8, 9, 64400) Messrs F. A. Moolla and Suliman Kako, of 9 Jubilee Street, Johannesburg, were travelling on the 25th ultimo from Trichardts to Ermelo.
('11', 30, 8, 10, 64535) On boarding the train, they could not secure seats.
('11', 30, 8, 11, 64587) They held second class tickets.
('11', 30, 8, 12, 64619) They mentioned the matter to the conductor, who said that he would find them seats.
('11', 30, 8, 13, 64703) Station after station passed by, and they met the conductor, but no seats were provided until the train reached Breyten.
('11', 30, 8, 14, 64824) At Breyten, Mr. Moolla told the conductor that he would be reported, and the latter said that, in that event, Mr. Moolla would not be allowed to take a seat at all, and went away.
('11', 30, 8, 15, 65004) Mr. Moolla and his companion, however, took their seats in the compartment that had been pointed out to them.
('11', 30, 8, 16, 65114) My Association trusts that you will be good enough to inquire into this matter.
('11', 30, 9, 17, 65194) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1910
('11', 30, 10, 18, 65220) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was sent over the signature of A. M. Cachalia, Chairman, British Indian Association.

('11', 31, 1, 2, 65393) 30. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 31, 2, 3, 65410) Monday [May 2, 1910]
('11', 31, 3, 4, 65431) JOSEPH ROYEPPEN
('11', 31, 4, 5, 65447) Messrs Joseph Royeppen, David Andrew, Samuel Joseph and Dhobi Nayana were to be released on Saturday, but, even on the previous day, they were brought to the gaol here and, instead of being released, were handed over to the police for being deported.
('11', 31, 4, 6, 65698) They were immediately bailed out for two days.
('11', 31, 4, 7, 65745) Though this was their first experience of gaol, Mr. Royeppen and his companions spent their time very cheerfully.
('11', 31, 4, 8, 65859) They are, moreover, in excellent health.
('11', 31, 4, 9, 65900) All of them want to re enter immediately.
('11', 31, 4, 10, 65942) Tuesday [May 3, 1910]
('11', 31, 5, 11, 65964) QUINN’S PETITION
('11', 31, 6, 12, 65981) Mr. Quinn, who has been ordered to be deported and has been kept in custody in Pretoria, challenged in the Supreme Court the Government’s right to hold him in detention pending his deportation and prayed to the Court to order his release.
('11', 31, 6, 13, 66220) The petition was heard and the Chief Justice ruled that the period of detention could not be considered unreasonable.
('11', 31, 6, 14, 66338) 1 The Court held that since it could not pronounce judgment on the order of deportation, the only question for decision concerned the period [of detention].
('11', 31, 6, 15, 66495) The judgment is of little consequence.
('11', 31, 6, 16, 66534) We are where we were.
('11', 31, 6, 17, 66556) A satyagrahi should not go in for all this bother of moving the Supreme Court, but men differ in their views and inclinations and that is the reason why Mr. Quinn was obliged to make this petition.
('11', 31, 6, 18, 66754) The Chinese have not been in the least disheartened by this judgment.
('11', 31, 7, 19, 66824) CHINESE MEETING
('11', 31, 8, 20, 66840) The Chinese held a meeting on Sunday.
('11', 31, 8, 21, 66878) It was attended, among others, by Mr. Royeppen and his companions, the Imam Saheb, and Messrs Coovadia, Bhikhaji, Sorabji, Medh, Gandhi and others.
('11', 31, 8, 22, 67026) Mr. Quinn explained the state of the struggle in all its aspects.
('11', 31, 8, 23, 67092) At the end of the meeting, tea and fruits were served in honour of Mr. Royeppen.
('11', 31, 8, 24, 67173) While in gaol, Mr. Royeppen was a complete vegetarian.
('11', 31, 8, 25, 67228) He says he felt no need of meat.
('11', 31, 8, 26, 67261) Mr. Royeppen and the others were taken to Pretoria this morning.
('11', 31, 9, 27, 67326) 1 Vide also “The Supreme Court Case”, 7 5 1910
('11', 32, 0, 1, 67373) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 33
('11', 32, 2, 2, 67415) Indian prisoners at Diepkloof have sent a message to say that the Government should be requested not to ask Mr. Shelat to carry slop pails and that they are ready to do the work on his behalf.
('11', 32, 2, 3, 67608) The message does them credit.
('11', 32, 2, 4, 67638) Mr. Cachalia has accordingly addressed a letter 1 to the Government, so that, if it feels like it, it may spare Mr. Shelat.
('11', 32, 2, 5, 67762) VISIT TO SODHA
('11', 32, 3, 6, 67777) Miss Schlesin left for Diepkloof on Sunday last in order to visit Mr. Sodha.
('11', 32, 3, 7, 67854) He is to be discharged next Saturday.
('11', 32, 3, 8, 67892) He has maintained good health in gaol.
('11', 32, 4, 9, 67931) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910
('11', 32, 5, 10, 67972) 31. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 2
('11', 32, 6, 11, 68008) [JOHANNESBURG,] May 3, 1910
('11', 32, 8, 12, 68036) Mr. Shelat was some time ago serving imprisonment as a passive resister at Diepkloof, and underwent prolonged solitary confinement for refusing to carry slop pails.
('11', 32, 8, 13, 68201) The discharged passive resisters have brought the message to my Association that the remaining British Indian prisoners at Diepkloof are quite agreeable that Mr. Shelat, who is a Brahmin and has very great conscientious scruples about removing slop pails, should be excused from having to perform that work; and that the other British Indian prisoners will be prepared to replace him whenever his turn comes to remove the pails.
('11', 32, 8, 14, 68630) 3 My Association does not know whether Mr. Shelat has yet been ordered to do this work, but I consider it my duty to bring the above matter to your notice, so that such instructions as you may consider fit may be issued to the officials at Diepkloof.
