('11', 33, 5, 6, 69278) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1910
('11', 33, 6, 7, 69304) 33. THE SUPREME COURT CASE
('11', 33, 7, 8, 69331) The judgment 2 given by the Supreme Court on the application of Mr. Quinn, the Chairman of the Transvaal Chinese Association, does not take us any further.
('11', 33, 7, 9, 69487) The deportations still remain illegal.
('11', 33, 7, 10, 69526) The Court was not called upon to decide upon the legality or otherwise of the warrant itself.
('11', 33, 7, 11, 69620) The Court had no jurisdiction in the matter, the or der being purely administrative.
('11', 33, 7, 12, 69705) The question, therefore, of deporting Asiatics who are lawfully registered residents of the Transvaal remains where it was.
('11', 33, 7, 13, 69829) The only question that the Court had to decide was whether the detention in Pretoria pending deportation was reasonable or not.
('11', 33, 7, 14, 69957) The Court had no difficulty, in view of circumstances, to come to the conclusion that detention was not unreasonable.
('11', 33, 7, 15, 70075) The proceedings, however, throw a curious light on the situation.
('11', 33, 7, 16, 70141) The authorities are unable to carry out their illegal policy through a British port.
('11', 33, 7, 17, 70226) The deportees, if they were to pass through British terri tories, would have a legal remedy.
('11', 33, 7, 18, 70319) They are, therefore, smuggled thro ugh a foreign port.
('11', 33, 7, 19, 70374) As passive resisters, however, theirs is not to comp lain.
('11', 33, 7, 20, 70433) Their duty is simply to go where they are forced to and at the earliest possible moment to retrace their steps as soon as they become free agents, and once more challenge the might of the Transvaal Government.
('11', 33, 8, 21, 70643) Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910
('11', 33, 9, 22, 70668) 1 This cablegram, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was sent through the Deputy Governor of the Transvaal on behalf of the British Indian Association by its Chairman, A. M. Cachalia, on the death of King Edward VII, who had passed away on 6 5 1910. 2 Vide also “Johannesburg”, 2 5 1910
('11', 34, 0, 1, 70952) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 35
('11', 34, 1, 2, 70994) 34. MR. ROYEPPEN AND HIS FRIENDS
('11', 34, 2, 3, 71027) Mr. Joseph Royeppen and his companions are making history.
('11', 34, 2, 4, 71086) Every passive resister who has come out of Diepkloof has spoken of Mr. Royeppen and his companions, Messrs Andrew and Joseph, in most flattering terms.
('11', 34, 2, 5, 71238) They have taken their imprisonment extremely well.
('11', 34, 2, 6, 71289) According to their wont, the Government, evidently to test their strength, have re arrested them 1 and have deported them.
('11', 34, 2, 7, 71412) As Mr. Royeppen states in his letter to the Press, 2 he and his friends have accepted the Government’s challenge.
('11', 34, 2, 8, 71526) We congratulate him and his friends on the brave stand they are making.
('11', 34, 2, 9, 71598) But Mr. Royeppen’s letter reveals a most painful state of things in the gaols of the Transvaal.
('11', 34, 2, 10, 71694) Much of what Mr. Royeppen has stated in his letter is generally known.
('11', 34, 2, 11, 71765) But the details now given by him as to how they were kept standing barefoot on a cold stone floor, how they were kept undressed in a draughty passage, how they were handcuffed and how brutally certain warders dealt with them, revive the memories of a shocking and disgraceful incident.
('11', 34, 2, 12, 72051) Such treatment, instead of unnerving them, has, we are glad to notice, strengthened them in their resolve to vindicate the national honour.
('11', 34, 2, 13, 72191) Mr. Royeppen and his companions have set to the young Indians in South Africa a brilliant and a noble example worthy to be followed.
('11', 34, 2, 14, 72324) They have shown that true happiness lies not in gaining riches but in moulding character.
('11', 34, 2, 15, 72414) We trust that the lead given by Mr. Royeppen will infuse a new spirit into the colonial born and other Indians who have their work cut out before them if they wish to take part in the making of the future South African nation.
('11', 34, 3, 16, 72641) Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910
('11', 34, 4, 17, 72666) 35. OUR PUBLICATIONS
('11', 34, 5, 18, 72687) The Bombay Government Gazette of the 24th March last notifies that Hind Swarajya, Universal Dawn 3, Mustafa Kamel Pasha’s Speech, and Defence of Socrates or The Story of a True Warrior 4—all
('11', 34, 6, 19, 72878) 1 Vide “Johannesburg”, 2 5 1910 2 Vide “Indian Barrister’s Gaol Experiences”, Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910. 3 Vide “ Sarvodaya[ I]”, 16 5 1908, “Sarvodaya[ II]”, 28 5 1908, “Sarvodaya [ III]” 30 5 1908, “Sarvodaya[ IV]”,6 6 1908, “Sarvodaya[ V]”, 13 6 1908, “Sarvodaya[ VI]”,20 6 1908, “Sarvodaya[ VII]”, 27 6 1908, “Sarvodaya[ VIII]” , 4 7 1908 & “Sarvodaya[ IX]”, 18 7 1908. 4 ibid
('11', 35, 0, 1, 73258) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 35, 1, 2, 73299) publications of the International Printing Press—have been forfeited to His Majesty for the reason that they “contain matter declared to be seditious”.
('11', 35, 1, 3, 73451) Hind Swarajya, in the shape of Indian Home Rule, is before our readers.
('11', 35, 1, 4, 73523) Universal Dawn is a Gujarati rendering of Ruskin’s Unto This Last.
('11', 35, 1, 5, 73590) Mustafa Kamel Pasha’s Speech is a Gujarati translation of the Egyptian patriot’s speech delivered just before his death before a vast audience at Cairo.
('11', 35, 1, 6, 73743) Defence of Socrates or The Story of a True Warrior is a Gujarati rendering of Plato’s immortal work printed in order to illustrate the virtue and the true nature of passive resistance.
('11', 35, 1, 7, 73928) All these publications, except Hind Swarajya, have been before the public for a considerable time.
('11', 35, 1, 8, 74027) They are intended to impart a lofty, moral tone to the reader and are, in our opinion, works capable of being put into children’s hands without any danger whatsoever.
('11', 35, 1, 9, 74194) But we have no right to complain.
('11', 35, 1, 10, 74228) We consider this activity on the part of the Government of India a passing phase.
('11', 35, 1, 11, 74310) They are in a state of panic and, wishing to do something, they intend to stop the circulation of literature that shows the slightest independence of spirit.
('11', 35, 1, 12, 74468) This overzeal is bound to kill itself.
('11', 35, 1, 13, 74507) The really dangerous publications will seek all kinds of dubious and devious methods of circulation, and we fear that they will, on that account, be read by the very class whom the Government intend that they do not reach.
('11', 35, 1, 14, 74730) In these circumstances, we, who are uncompromising advocates of passive resistance, have only one course left open to us.
('11', 35, 1, 15, 74852) The repression cannot affect us.
('11', 35, 1, 16, 74885) Our views can only remain the same, and they must find expression on every due occasion, regardless of personal consequences.
('11', 35, 1, 17, 75011) We sympathize with the Government of India in their desire to stop the spread of methods of violence.
('11', 35, 1, 18, 75113) We would do and give much to stop it.
('11', 35, 1, 19, 75151) But the only way we know to eradicate the disease is to popularize passive resistance of the right stamp.
('11', 35, 1, 20, 75257) Any other way, especially repression, must inevitably fail in the long run.
('11', 35, 2, 21, 75333) Indian Opinion, 7 5 1910
('11', 35, 3, 22, 75358) 36. ROYEPPEN
('11', 35, 4, 23, 75371) Everyone will admit that Mr. Royeppen and his companions have rendered excellent service to the community.
('11', 35, 4, 24, 75478) Mr. Joseph Royeppen has put his education to the right use.
('11', 35, 4, 25, 75538) His manner of living
('11', 36, 0, 1, 75559) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 37
('11', 36, 1, 2, 75601) in gaol was also quite worthy of a satyagrahi.
('11', 36, 1, 3, 75648) His simplicity was nothing if not admirable.
('11', 36, 1, 4, 75693) His fellow prisoners, Mr. David Andrew and Mr. Samuel Joseph, also spent their time cheerfully.
('11', 36, 1, 5, 75789) These three heroes among Indians will be soon back in gaol.
('11', 36, 2, 6, 75849) The Government has moved quickly to deport them once again, counting on the fact that they are yet fresh [satyagrahis].
('11', 36, 2, 7, 75969) Its hope is that they will lose courage and return [to Natal].
('11', 36, 2, 8, 76032) It makes one happy to know that this hope will not be fulfilled.
('11', 36, 2, 9, 76097) We give elsewhere a translation of Mr. Royeppen’s letter 2 to the Press; it is worth reading.

('11', 37, 0, 1, 76846) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 37, 1, 2, 76887) 38. LETTER TO W. J. WYBERGH
('11', 37, 2, 3, 76915) May 10, 1910
('11', 37, 3, 4, 76928) DEAR MR. WYBERGH 1,
('11', 37, 4, 5, 76948) I am exceedingly obliged to you for your very full and valuable criticism of the little pamphlet on Indian Home Rule.
('11', 37, 4, 6, 77066) I shall with very great pleasure send your letter 2 to Indian Opinion for publication, and shall treat this reply likewise.
('11', 37, 4, 7, 77190) I entirely reciprocate the sentiments you express in the last paragraph of your letter.
('11', 37, 4, 8, 77278) I am quite aware that my views will lead to many differences of opinion between my staunchest friends and those whom I have come to regard with respect and myself, but these differences, so far as I am concerned, can neither diminish respect nor affect friendly relations.
('11', 37, 4, 9, 77551) I am painfully conscious of the imperfections and defects you point out in your letter, and I know how unworthy I am to handle the very important problems dealt with in the booklet.
('11', 37, 4, 10, 77733) But, having had the position of a publicist practically forced upon me by circums tances, I felt bound to write for those for whom Indian Opinion caters.
('11', 37, 4, 11, 77887) The choice lay between allowing the readers of Indian Opinion, anxious though they were for guidance, to drift away in the matter of the insane violence that is now going on in India, or 3 giving them, no matter how humble, a lead that they were asking for.
('11', 37, 4, 12, 78145) The only way I saw of mitigating violence was the one sketched in the pamphlet.
('11', 37, 4, 13, 78225) I share your views that a superficial reader will consider the pamphlet to be a disloyal production, and I admit, too, that those who will not distinguish between men and measures, between modern civilisation and its exponents, will come to that conclusion.
('11', 37, 4, 14, 78483) And I accept your proposition that I discourage violence only because I think it to be both wrong and ineffective, and not because the object sought to be attained is wrong, that is to say, if it were ever possible, which I hold it is not, to detach the object from the means adopted to attain it.
('11', 37, 4, 15, 78781) I hold that Home Rule obtained by violence would be totally different in kind from that obtained by the means suggested by me.
('11', 37, 4, 16, 78908) I have ventured utterly to condemn modern civilisation because I hold that the spirit of it is evil.
('11', 37, 4, 17, 79009) It is possible to show that some of its
('11', 37, 5, 18, 79049) 1 Member, Legislative Assembly, Transvaal 2 Vide Appendix “W. J. Wybergh’s letter to Gandhiji”, 3 5 1910. 3 A slip for ‘and’
('11', 38, 0, 1, 79174) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 39
('11', 38, 1, 2, 79216) incidents are good, but I have examined its tendency in the scale of ethics.
('11', 38, 1, 3, 79293) I distinguish between the ideals of individuals who have risen superior to their environment, as also between Christianity and modern civilisation.
('11', 38, 1, 4, 79441) Its activity is by no means confined to Europe.
('11', 38, 1, 5, 79489) Its blasting influence is now being exhibited in full force in Japan.
('11', 38, 1, 6, 79559) And it now threatens to overwhelm India.
('11', 38, 1, 7, 79600) History teaches us that men who are in the whirlpool, except in the cases of individuals, will have to work out their destiny in it but I do submit that those who are still outside its influence, and those who have a well tried civilisation to guide them, should be helped to remain where they are, if only as a measure of prudence.
('11', 38, 1, 8, 79933) I claim to have tested the life which modern civilisation has to give, as also that of the ancient civilisation, and I cannot help most strongly contesting the idea that the Indian population requires to be roused by “the lash of competition and the other material and sensuous, as well as intellectual, stimuli”; I cannot admit that these will add a single inch to its moral stature.
('11', 38, 1, 9, 80318) Liberation in the sense in which I have used the term is undoubtedly the immedi ate aim of all humanity.
('11', 38, 1, 10, 80423) It does not, therefore, follow that the whole of it can reach it in the same time.
('11', 38, 1, 11, 80506) But if that liberation is the best thing attainable by mankind, then, I submit, it is wrong to lower the ideal for anyone.
('11', 38, 1, 12, 80629) All the Indian Scriptures have certainly preached incessantly liberation as an immediate aim, but we know that this preaching has not resulted in “activity in the lower worlds” being abandoned.
('11', 38, 1, 13, 80823) I admit that the term “passive resistance” is a misnomer.
('11', 38, 1, 14, 80881) I have used it because, generally speaking, we know what it means.
('11', 38, 1, 15, 80948) Being a popular term, it easily appeals to the popular imagination.
('11', 38, 1, 16, 81016) The underlying principle is totally opposed to that of violence.
('11', 38, 1, 17, 81081) It cannot, therefore, be that “the battle is transferred from the physical to the mental plane”.
('11', 38, 1, 18, 81178) The function of violence is to obtain reform by external means; the function of passive resistance, that is, soul force, is to obtain it by growth from within; which, in its turn, is obtained by self suffering, self purification.
('11', 38, 1, 19, 81408) Violence ever fails; passive resistance is ever successful.
('11', 38, 1, 20, 81468) The fight of a passive resister is none the less spiritual because he fights to win.
('11', 38, 1, 21, 81553) Indeed, he is obliged to fight to win, that is, to obtain the mastery of self.
('11', 38, 1, 22, 81632) Passive resistance is always moral, never cruel; and any activity, mental or otherwise, which fails in this test is undoubtedly not passive resistance.
('11', 38, 1, 23, 81784) Your argument tends to show that there must be complete divorce between politics and religion or spirituality.
('11', 38, 1, 24, 81895) That is what we see in everyday life under modern conditions.
('11', 38, 1, 25, 81957) Passive resistance seeks
('11', 39, 0, 1, 81982) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 39, 1, 2, 82023) to rejoin politics and religion and to test every one of our actions in the light of ethical principles.
('11', 39, 1, 3, 82128) That Jesus refused to use soul force to turn stones into bread only supports my argument.
('11', 39, 1, 4, 82218) Modern civilization is at present engaged in attempting that impossible feat.
('11', 39, 1, 5, 82296) The use of soul force for turning stones into bread would have been considered, as it is still considered, as black magic.
('11', 39, 1, 6, 82419) Nor can I hold with you that motives alone can always decide the question of a particular act being right or wrong.
('11', 39, 1, 7, 82535) An ignorant mother may, from the purest motives, administer a dose of opium to her child.
('11', 39, 1, 8, 82625) Her motives will not cure her of her ignorance, nor, in the moral world purge her of the offence of killing her child.
('11', 39, 1, 9, 82744) A passive resister, recognising this principle and knowing that, in spite of the purity of his motives, his action may be utterly wrong, leaves judgment to the Supreme Being, and, in attempting to resist what he holds to be wrong, suffers only in his own person.
('11', 39, 1, 10, 83007) Throughout the Bhagavad Gita, I can see no warrant for holding that a man who can only control “the organs of action” but cannot help “dwelling in his mind on the objects of the senses” had better use the organs of action until the mind, too, is under control.
('11', 39, 1, 11, 83268) In ordinary practices, we call such use an indulgence, and we know, too, that, if we can control the flesh even while the spirit is weak, always wishing that the spirit were equally strong, we will certainly arrive at a right correspondence.
('11', 39, 1, 12, 83510) I think the text you have quoted refers to a man who, for making a show, appears to be controlling the organs of action, whilst deliberately in his mind dwelling on the objects of the senses.
('11', 39, 1, 13, 83702) I agree with you entirely that a pure passive resister cannot allow himself to be regarded as a martyr nor can he complain of the hardships of prison or any other hardships, nor may he make political capital out of what may appear to be injustice or ill treatment, much less may he allow any matter of passive resistance to be advertised.
('11', 39, 1, 14, 84041) But all action unfortunately is mixed.
('11', 39, 1, 15, 84080) Purest passive resistance can exist only in theory.
('11', 39, 1, 16, 84132) The anomalies you point out only emphasize the fact that the Indian passive resisters of the Transvaal are, after all, very fallible human beings and yet very weak, but I can assure you that their object is to make their practice correspond with pure passive resistance as nearly as possible, and, as the struggle progresses, pure spirits are certainly rising in our midst.
('11', 39, 1, 17, 84506) I am free to admit also that all passive resisters are not fired with
('11', 40, 0, 1, 84576) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 41
('11', 40, 1, 2, 84618) the spirit of love or of truth.
('11', 40, 1, 3, 84650) Some of us are undoubtedly not free from vindictiveness and the spirit of hatred; but the desire in us all is to cure ourselves of hatred and enmity.
('11', 40, 1, 4, 84800) I have noticed, too, that those who simply became passive resisters under the glamour of the newness of the movement or for selfish reasons have fallen away.
('11', 40, 1, 5, 84958) Pretended self suffering cannot last long.
('11', 40, 1, 6, 85001) Such men never were passive resisters.
('11', 40, 1, 7, 85040) It is necessary to discuss the subject of passive resistance somewhat impersonally.
('11', 40, 1, 8, 85124) If you say that physical sufferings of soldiers have vastly exceeded those of the Transvaal passive resisters, I agree with you entirly; but the sufferings of world known passive resisters who deliberately walked into funeral pyres or into boiling cauldrons were incomparably greater than those of any soldier it is possible to name.
('11', 40, 1, 9, 85458) I cannot pretend to speak for Tolstoy, but my reading of his works has never led me to consider that, in spite of his merciless analysis of institutions organised and based upon force, that is governments, he in any way anticipates or contemplates that the whole world will be able to live in a state of philosophical anarchy.
('11', 40, 1, 10, 85785) What he has preached, as, in my opinion, have all world teachers, is that every man has to obey the voice of his own conscience, and be his own master, and seek the Kingdom of God from within.
('11', 40, 1, 11, 85978) For him there is no government that can control him without his sanction.
('11', 40, 1, 12, 86052) Such a man is superior to all government.
('11', 40, 1, 13, 86094) And can it be ever dangerous for a lion to tell a number of other lions who in their ignorance consider themselves to be merely lambs that they, too, are not lambs but lions?
('11', 40, 1, 14, 86269) Some very ignorant lions will no doubt contest the knowing lion’s proposition.
('11', 40, 1, 15, 86348) There will, no doubt, on that account be confusion also, but, no matter how gross the ignorance may be, it will not be suggested that the lion who knows should sit still and not ask his fellow lions to share his majesty and freedom.
('11', 40, 1, 16, 86581) It has indeed occurred to me that an anti Asiatic league which from pure though entirely misguided motives wishes to deport Asiatics from the Transvaal, because it may consider them to be an evil, would be certainly justified, from its own view point, in violently attaining its object.
('11', 40, 1, 17, 86868) It is not open to passive resisters, if they are not weak, to complain of such, in their opinion, high handed action, but for them deportation and worse must be a welcome relief from having to submit to a course of action which is repugnant to their conscience.
('11', 40, 1, 18, 87130) I hope you will not fail to see the beauty of passive resistance in your own illustration.
('11', 40, 1, 19, 87221) Supposing that these deportees were capable of offering physical violence against forcible deportation, and yet from
('11', 41, 0, 1, 87338) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 41, 1, 2, 87379) pure choice elected to be deported rather than resist deportation, will it not show superior courage and superior moral fibre in them?
('11', 41, 2, 3, 87514) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('11', 41, 3, 4, 87544) Indian Opinion, 21 5 1910
('11', 41, 4, 5, 87570) 39. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 41, 5, 6, 87587) Monday [May 9, 1910]

('11', 43, 0, 1, 89981) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 43, 1, 2, 90022) 40. THE LATE KING 1
('11', 43, 2, 3, 90042) King Edward is dead and has left an Empire in mourning.
('11', 43, 2, 4, 90098) The British Constitution keeps the King outside of politics.
('11', 43, 2, 5, 90159) It is, therefore, his personal qualities that alone count in measuring the loss.
('11', 43, 2, 6, 90240) But these guide only those whose lives are affected by them.
('11', 43, 2, 7, 90301) Indians will best remember His late Majesty as a Sovereign who followed in the footsteps of his mother of revered memory.
('11', 43, 2, 8, 90423) Like her, the late King had shown a warm corner in his bosom for the people of India.
('11', 43, 2, 9, 90509) And that will always be a title to our affection for his memory.
('11', 43, 3, 10, 90574) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1910
('11', 43, 4, 11, 90600) 41. LONG LIVE THE KING!
('11', 43, 5, 12, 90624) H.R.H. Prince George of Wales is now King George the Fifth of England and Emperor of India.
('11', 43, 5, 13, 90716) The King is dead: Long live the King!
('11', 43, 5, 14, 90754) are expressions that have to be uttered in the same breath.
('11', 43, 5, 15, 90814) Individual Kings and Emperors come and go but Kingship is eternal.
('11', 43, 5, 16, 90881) The attributes of that office few Sovereigns are able fully to live up to.
('11', 43, 5, 17, 90956) King Edward, in the words of his son, now King George V, wished that, “so long as he drew breath, he would strive to promote the best interests of the people”.
('11', 43, 5, 18, 91116) “That promise”, adds His Majesty, “was carried out to the best of his father’s ability and it would be his earnest endeavour, under God, to follow his father’s example in that respect.” His Majesty asks the prayer of his subjects “that God may grant him strength and guidance”.
('11', 43, 5, 19, 91394) That prayer will go up to heaven from many countries and in many languages.
('11', 43, 5, 20, 91470) We humbly Join in that prayer.

('11', 44, 3, 5, 92042) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1910
('11', 44, 4, 6, 92068) 43. MR. SODHA’S DISCHARGE
('11', 44, 5, 7, 92094) Mr. R. M. Sodha, who was discharged last Saturday, is one of the stalwarts whom we mentioned the other day.
('11', 44, 5, 8, 92202) 1 He has served imprisonment almost continuously for a year.
('11', 44, 5, 9, 92263) Mr. Sodha, again, being an orthodox Hindu, has been obliged to suffer doubly as, during certain months of the year, he restricts himself to only one meal per day.
('11', 44, 5, 10, 92426) Outside the gaol, his one meal will naturally make up more or less for the absence of the other two.
('11', 44, 5, 11, 92527) But, in the prison, he had simply to be satisfied with his portion for the particular meal he chose to take.
('11', 44, 5, 12, 92636) But Mr. Sodha went through it all most cheerfully.
('11', 44, 5, 13, 92687) Mr. Sodha, having been discharged in the Transvaal and not being deported, has returned to Natal to see his wife and family, and proposes to return at an early date to rejoin his fellow prisoners at Diepkloof.
('11', 44, 5, 14, 92897) The calmness with which well tried passive resisters like Mr. Sodha face imprisonment again and again does great credit to themselves and the community to which they belong.

('11', 45, 0, 1, 93129) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 45, 1, 2, 93170) 44. LATE EMPEROR EDWARD 1
('11', 45, 2, 3, 93196) The whole of the British Empire mourns the death of King Edward.
('11', 45, 2, 4, 93261) What is the position of the Indian people?
('11', 45, 2, 5, 93304) Should the fact of their being at present unhappy under British rule prevent them from joining in the mourning?
('11', 45, 2, 6, 93416) Those who refrain must be ignorant of the British Constitution, under which the King takes no active part in the administration.
('11', 45, 2, 7, 93545) He cannot change the policy of his Government.
('11', 45, 2, 8, 93592) Hence, in judging him, we can only take into account his personal qualities.
('11', 45, 2, 9, 93669) Even these have hardly had any impact on the Indian people.
('11', 45, 2, 10, 93729) Those alone will feel their effects who acquaint themselves with his life and reflect over his conduct.
('11', 45, 2, 11, 93833) It is enough for us that King Edward followed the example of his mother, Queen Victoria, and showed love for the Indian people.
('11', 45, 2, 12, 93961) He seems to have cherished kindly feelings for them in his heart.
('11', 45, 2, 13, 94027) Therefore, the Indian people, whatever their views on British policies, will always bear the purest affection for the King.
('11', 45, 3, 14, 94151) [From Gujarati]

('11', 45, 6, 18, 94236) Long live the King.” These two sentences are uttered in the same breath at the time of a king’s death.

('11', 45, 6, 25, 94561) But British monarchy is neither the one nor the other.

('11', 45, 6, 27, 94651) It was his greatness that he never thought of interfering in the conduct of the government.

('11', 46, 3, 4, 95242) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1910
('11', 46, 4, 5, 95268) 46. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 46, 5, 6, 95285) Monday [May 16, 1910]
('11', 46, 6, 7, 95307) CABLES FROM POLAK Three cables have been received from Mr. Polak, in which he reports that a big meeting was held in Madras when the satyagrahis reached Bombay.
('11', 46, 6, 8, 95468) From among them, 26 have already started on the return voyage.
('11', 46, 6, 9, 95531) Those who were deported also included some non satyagrahis.
('11', 46, 6, 10, 95591) Mr. Polak also reports the death of one of them.
('11', 46, 6, 11, 95640) The authorities have been taken aback by Mr. Polak’s brisk work.
('11', 46, 6, 12, 95705) I hope Indians in Durban will welcome and look after those who disembark there.
('11', 46, 6, 13, 95785) The Durban Indians can do this at least, ought to do it, namely, arrange for their lodging, honour them [in public] and send them back to the Transvaal.
('11', 46, 7, 14, 95938) FINE IN DELAGOA BAY A correspondent informs me that passengers bound for the Transvaal have to face much harassment in Delagoa Bay.
('11', 46, 7, 15, 96070) The physician demands eight shillings.
('11', 46, 7, 16, 96109) Afterwards, if the passenger holds a Transvaal pass, they collect £8 from him and then allow him to disembark.
('11', 46, 7, 17, 96220) He is charged a further fee of one and a half pounds.
('11', 46, 7, 18, 96274) He is made to hand over his pass, and gets a ticket after the pass has been inspected.
('11', 46, 7, 19, 96361) He has then to inform the police about his departure.
('11', 46, 7, 20, 96415) A person accompanies him as far as the border and there returns £7 to him after deducting £1. Thus, the Indian remains a prisoner till he reaches the Transvaal and pays a fine of as much as £3. Not only do the incoming Indians submit to all this quietly, but the Delagoa Bay Indians, who are in a position to have matters set right, are too selfish to move in the matter.
('11', 46, 8, 21, 96787) [From Gujarati]
('11', 46, 9, 22, 96803) Indian Opinion, 21 5 1910
('11', 47, 0, 1, 96829) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 47, 1, 2, 96870) 47. THE RETURNED DEPORTEES
('11', 47, 2, 3, 96897) Mr. Polak and the 26 returning deportees deserve the thanks of the Indian community in South Africa, Mr. Polak for the promptness with which he has sent these men, and the deportees for the bravery and self sacrifice they have shown in undertaking the return voyage within four days of their arrival in Bombay.
('11', 47, 2, 4, 97208) It must have been to the latter a great wrench.
('11', 47, 2, 5, 97256) They went to the mother country, some of them perfect strangers to it.
('11', 47, 2, 6, 97327) They could have seen something of it, had they stayed, and no one could have taken exception if they had followed that course, but they chose to put duty before everything else, and, after a trying voyage as deck passengers, they have undertaken an almost equally trying voyage not to find or seek rest after it, but to brave imprisonment or whatever may be in store for them.
('11', 47, 2, 7, 97704) Speculation is rife as to whether these men will be able to land at any of the South African ports.
('11', 47, 2, 8, 97804) If they have been domiciled either at the Cape or in Natal, they should certainly find no difficulty in that.
('11', 47, 2, 9, 97914) By the time they arrive, probably the Union Government will be in full working order.
('11', 47, 2, 10, 98000) It will be interesting to note how they are dealt with by that Government.
('11', 47, 2, 11, 98075) All speculation with reference to their arrival in the Transvaal is needless, because, whether they are tried as prohibited immigrants or otherwise, they have but to seek imprisonment, unless the Government, after having brought them into the Colony, take them again to Delagoa Bay and deport them to India.
('11', 47, 2, 12, 98383) Whatever happens, as passive resisters they have only one course left open, and that is to abide by their obligation not to submit to the Law until the grievance for which they have been suffering has been redressed, irrespective of the results that may follow such a course.
('11', 47, 2, 13, 98659) The Indians of Durban, too, have a duty to perform.
('11', 47, 2, 14, 98711) It will be expected of them that they receive these passive resisters and make them as comfortable as possible, and give them such an ovation as would enable them to know that their self sacrificing work is being appreciated by their countrymen throughout South Africa, and to enable the South African Government to understand that the whole of the Indian community in South Africa is at the back of the movement.
('11', 47, 3, 15, 99125) Indian Opinion, 21 5 1910
('11', 48, 0, 1, 99151) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 49
('11', 48, 1, 2, 99193) 48. HINDUS AND MUSLIMS
('11', 48, 2, 3, 99216) COLONIAL BORN INDIANS AND OTHERS
('11', 48, 3, 4, 99249) We feel ashamed to write under this heading but, ashamed or not, our duty is to speak the truth.
('11', 48, 3, 5, 99346) In Maritzburg, some Hindus and Colonial born Indians had applied for trading licences, and also succeeded in obtaining them.
('11', 48, 3, 6, 99471) We are prepared, if they so desire, to congratulate them on that.
('11', 48, 3, 7, 99537) But the means which they adopted to secure the licences will prove the truth of the saying: “The heart must pay for what the hand has done.” 1 In support of their applications, they submitted a statement from certain whites saying that Hindus and Muslims were not united and that [therefore] Hindus and Colonial born Indians must not be obliged to buy from Muslim shops.
('11', 48, 3, 8, 99908) And so the whites, in their wisdom, suggested that the licences should be granted.
('11', 48, 3, 9, 99991) So far as we can see, such steps can only lead to unhappy results.
('11', 48, 3, 10, 100058) Till now it was only the whites who used to oppose our applications.
('11', 48, 3, 11, 100127) Now we see even Indians opposing one another.
('11', 48, 3, 12, 100173) This augurs ill [for the community].
('11', 48, 3, 13, 100210) We see that Indians are being tempted, with the support of whites, to profit at one another’s expense.
('11', 48, 3, 14, 100313) The wise among the Indians should realize at once that this will bring ruin to both the communities.
('11', 48, 3, 15, 100414) A move of this kind betokens complete lack of vision.
('11', 48, 3, 16, 100468) We, therefore, entreat Indian leaders to think twice before they engage in such activities.
('11', 48, 3, 17, 100560) We look upon everyone, no matter whether an Indian or not, who creates differences between Hindus and Muslims or between Colonial born Indians and other Indians, as an enemy of the community; such a person will certainly deserve to be called so.
('11', 48, 3, 18, 100806) We are emphatic in our view that, if among ourselves one community gets something more than the other, the latter should acquiesce in that rather than allow anything to fall into the hands of the third party.

('11', 50, 9, 11, 102975) 52. CRIMINAL NEGLECT
('11', 50, 10, 12, 102996) Both the Hon.
('11', 50, 10, 13, 103010) Mr. R. Jameson 2 and Mr. W. C. Daugherty 3
('11', 50, 11, 14, 103053) deserve the thanks not only of the Indian community but also of those who have the fair name of Durban at heart, for the outspoken manner in which they have exposed the criminal neglect of the Durban Corporation in not having attended to the sanitation of a plague spot known as the Eastern Vlei Indian Location, containing a population of nearly 800 Indians whom Mr. Jameson describes as “these long suffering, patient and helpless people”.
('11', 50, 11, 15, 103495) Since 1901, the Indian tenants have paid the Corporation in rents and rates the sum of £8,508 and have received in return “nothing but a swamp, a water pipe, and sanitary services”.
('11', 50, 11, 16, 103677) “Had they been Europeans”, adds Mr. Jameson, “this would perforce long since have been righted.” Mr. Daugherty, who gives details, says that “they suffer in health and comfort and material prosperity through being overlooked or forgotten in the improvements which have in every other part of the Borough been progressing and this notwithstanding that their particular part called for amelioration more urgently than any other locality.
('11', 50, 11, 17, 104113) There is not even a paraffin lamp in the road.” Now this is a terrible indictment.
('11', 50, 12, 18, 104196) 1 This telegram was presumably drafted by Gandhiji.
('11', 50, 12, 19, 104248) On June 23, the Secretary replied that Viscount Gladstone could not receive the deputation.
('11', 50, 12, 20, 104340) Vide “Johannes burg”’ 27 6 1910 2 Chairman of the Sanitary Committee 3 Inspector of Nuisances
('11', 51, 0, 1, 104434) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 51, 1, 2, 104475) The first thought on reading it is naturally to swear at the Corporation.
('11', 51, 1, 3, 104549) That it has neglected the Eastern Vlei Indians in a most shocking manner is all too true.
('11', 51, 1, 4, 104639) But maturer consideration must lead to some heart searchings among ourselves.
('11', 51, 1, 5, 104717) We are not inclined to absolve even the Eastern Vlei Indians entirely from blame.
('11', 51, 1, 6, 104799) It was, as it is even now, open to them to decline to live in that swamp.
('11', 51, 1, 7, 104873) But the chief blame must rest upon the shoulders of the leaders of the community.
('11', 51, 1, 8, 104955) It betrays a want of real communal life.
('11', 51, 1, 9, 104996) It is possible to understand the helplessness of the location inmates.
('11', 51, 1, 10, 105067) But it is impossible to understand or excuse the apathy of the leaders who should have led and compelled the Corporation to do its obvious duty.
('11', 51, 1, 11, 105212) Why would the place have received prompt attention, had it been inhabited by Europeans?
('11', 51, 1, 12, 105300) Surely not because they were Europeans but because their leaders, if not they themselves, would have moved heaven and earth to right such a terrible wrong.
('11', 51, 1, 13, 105456) Europeans would have understood communal duty, whereas we have not.
('11', 51, 1, 14, 105524) If, then, the neglect of the Corporation is criminal, that of our leaders is doubly so.
('11', 51, 1, 15, 105612) The Corporation may shelve Mr. Jameson’s letter 1 and Mr. Daugherty’s report 2. Will our leaders allow it todo so?
('11', 51, 1, 16, 105727) Here there is simple work for the various Indian societies.
('11', 51, 1, 17, 105787) It is work that can bear fruit without much trouble.
('11', 51, 1, 18, 105840) They may appoint visiting members to the location, obtain accurate information, bring the inmates themselves to a sense of their duty, tell them what they can do themselves, and, last but not least, they may and should ceaselessly worry the Corporation until it has done its duty.

('11', 52, 3, 11, 107209) Indian Opinion, 28 5 1910
('11', 52, 4, 12, 107235) 54. MR. ROYEPPEN
('11', 52, 5, 13, 107252) Mr. Joseph Royeppen, after having performed the pilgrimage to his aged mother and met his relatives whom he had left after only a short stay with them upon his return from London, has rejoined his companions and has been imprisoned with hard labour for the second time for the offence of entering a British Colony.
('11', 52, 5, 14, 107567) His academic attainments are no protection to him.
('11', 52, 5, 15, 107618) His Indian parentage nullifies the effect of his educational qualifications.
('11', 52, 5, 16, 107695) Had he been a European, his accomplishments would have secured for him a warm welcome.
('11', 52, 5, 17, 107782) The moral of the tragedy, as Mr. Polak would call this event, is obvious.
('11', 52, 5, 18, 107856) For an Indian, the term “British subject” has no meaning in the Transvaal.
('11', 52, 6, 19, 107931) Indian Opinion, 28 5 1910
('11', 52, 7, 20, 107957) 1 Not reproduced here; the complaints were in respect of sleeping accommodation, water supply, medical facilities and rough treatment of the Indian passengers.
('11', 53, 0, 1, 108117) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 53, 1, 2, 108158) 55. MORE DISCHARGES
('11', 53, 2, 3, 108178) Notable passive resisters continue to be discharged from the Diepkloof prison.
('11', 53, 2, 4, 108257) That staunch passive resister, Mr. P. K. Naidoo, and the quiet volunteer, Mr. Raju Naidoo, together with young Manilal Gandhi finished their terms of imprisonment on Monday last.
('11', 53, 2, 5, 108436) Mr. P. K. Naidoo has served for the fourth time during the campaign of passive resistance.
('11', 53, 2, 6, 108527) In order to break his spirit the authorities re arrested Mr. Naidoo immediately on his previous discharge.
('11', 53, 2, 7, 108634) But Mr. Naidoo was adamant.
('11', 53, 2, 8, 108662) The gaol had lost all its terror for him.
('11', 53, 2, 9, 108704) Without, therefore, asking for a remand in order to enable him to pay a hurried visit to his family, he accepted the summons to duty.
('11', 53, 2, 10, 108838) Mr. Naidoo, it may be recalled, was a member of the volunteer Indian Ambulance Corps during the Boer War and holds the war medal.
('11', 53, 2, 11, 108968) But neither scholastic training nor military service counts for an Indian in the Transvaal.
('11', 53, 3, 12, 109060) Indian Opinion, 28 5 1910
('11', 53, 4, 13, 109086) 56. FOR COLONIAL BORN INDIANS
('11', 53, 5, 14, 109116) We hope that every Colonial born Indian will read the annual report of the Inspector of Education in Basutoland for the year ended June last.
('11', 53, 5, 15, 109258) The Inspector, in dealing with the comparative value of English and that of the Sesuto language for the Basutos, says:
('11', 53, 6, 16, 109377) if education is to have any real value for the Basutos, it must be based upon sound teaching in their own language.
('11', 53, 6, 17, 109493) Anything which encourages the teachers to hurry over this stage in order that their pupils may be considered as belonging to the standards is fatal to education in the true sense of the word.
('11', 53, 6, 18, 109685) Among the Natives in Basutoland, the speaking of English is an exotic.
('11', 53, 6, 19, 109756) It is an accomplishment and one which, imperfectly acquired, gains for the exponent little credit with European listeners.
('11', 53, 6, 20, 109879) Opinion in Basutoland is practically unanimous that this elementary education should be given in Sesuto.
('11', 53, 6, 21, 109984) I would deprecate, therefore, any attempt to me a sure the value of a school by the number of pupils who are reading English in advanced reading books, or to belittle the worth of a school because the only thing known by the majority of the pupils is Sesuto.
('11', 53, 6, 22, 110243) A pupil who knows Sesuto thoroughly can read the Bible and the Pilgrim’s Progress.
('11', 53, 6, 23, 110326) He can follow the news of the day in Sesuto newspapers and, in his lighter moments, can even
('11', 54, 0, 1, 110419) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 55
('11', 54, 1, 2, 110461) read Sesuto novels.
('11', 54, 1, 3, 110481) Many Europeans have gone far with little more book knowledge of their own language than this.
('11', 54, 1, 4, 110575) We hope that every Indian will carefully consider these remarks of the Inspector of Education in Basutoland.
('11', 54, 1, 5, 110684) If what the Inspector says be true of the Basutos, how much more must it be so of Indian youths who receive, in the ordinary schools of the Colony, no instruction at all in their mother tongue.
('11', 54, 1, 6, 110878) Moreover, fine as the Sesuto language is, we venture to think that it cannot boast the literary merit of the great Indian languages spoken in the Colony.
('11', 54, 1, 7, 111032) It must be a matter of deep shame to any Indian youth to know that he cannot speak and read his own mother tongue like an ordinary cultured Indian.
('11', 54, 1, 8, 111180) The criminal neglect that is going on among Indian parents and their children as to the learning by the latter of Indian languages is calculated almost to denationalize them.
('11', 54, 1, 9, 111355) Indeed, it is the duty of the Government, as of the missionaries who are in charge of Indian schools, to take to heart the very valuable suggestion made by the Inspector in Basutoland.
('11', 54, 1, 10, 111540) But, whether they perform their duty or not, it is evidently the sacred obligation of Indian parents to repair the mischief while there is yet time.
('11', 54, 1, 11, 111689) The majority of the Indian children taught in the ordinary schools of the Colony study neither English nor their own mother tongue.
('11', 54, 1, 12, 111821) The result is that they become useless as Indians, as citizens of the Colony and are hardly useful as decent wage earners.
('11', 54, 2, 13, 111944) Indian Opinion, 28 5 1910
('11', 54, 3, 14, 111970) 57. JOSEPH ROYEPPEN
('11', 54, 4, 15, 111990) Mr. Joseph Royeppen is once again in gaol.
('11', 54, 4, 16, 112033) He has been sentenced to six weeks’ imprisonment and gone back to do hard labour for the sake of the motherland.
('11', 54, 4, 17, 112146) This is fine courage indeed on Mr. Royeppen’s part.
('11', 54, 4, 18, 112198) His going to gaol has been, and will be, a great gain to himself and to the community.
('11', 54, 4, 19, 112285) It is no trivial matter that an educated man like Mr. Royeppen should have to suffer imprisonment the moment he enters the Transvaal.
('11', 54, 4, 20, 112419) This incident proves that we are not British subjects, but slaves.

('11', 55, 2, 3, 112597) May 30, 1910
('11', 55, 3, 4, 112610) DEAR MR. KALLENBACH,
('11', 55, 4, 5, 112631) I have shown your kind letter 1 to Mr. Cachalia and other fellow passive resisters, and I have to thank you for your generous offer on their and my own behalf.
('11', 55, 4, 6, 112791) I accept your offer, and I need hardly say to what extent your offer will relieve the financial pressure.
('11', 55, 4, 7, 112897) As to the improvements and additions referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3 of your letter, I shall keep an accurate account which shall be open to your inspection, and I shall not undertake improvements or additions without your approval.
('11', 55, 6, 8, 113132) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('11', 55, 7, 9, 113162) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1910
('11', 55, 8, 10, 113188) 1 Which read as follows: May 30, 1910
('11', 55, 9, 11, 113226) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('11', 55, 10, 12, 113243) In accordance with our conversation, I offer to you the use of my farm near Lawley for passive resisters and their indigent families; the families and passive resisters to live on the farm free of any rent or charge, as long as the struggle with the Transvaal Government lasts.
('11', 55, 10, 13, 113521) They may also use, free of charge, all the buildings not at present used by me.
('11', 55, 10, 14, 113601) Any structural alterations, additions or improvements made by you may be removed at your pleasure on the termination of occupation, or they will be paid for by me at a valuation in the usual manner, the terms of payment to be mutually agreed upon by us.
('11', 55, 10, 15, 113855) I propose to pay, at a valuation in the usual manner, [for] all the agricultural improvements that may have been made by the settlers.
('11', 55, 10, 16, 113990) The settlers to withdraw from the farm on the termination of the struggle.
('11', 55, 11, 17, 114065) Yours sincerely, H. KALLENBACH

('11', 56, 1, 2, 114138) 59. LETTER TO THE PRESS
('11', 56, 2, 3, 114162) JOHANNESBURG, June 2, 1910
('11', 56, 3, 4, 114189) SIR, The Union has been ushered in among very general rejoicing among the European races of South Africa.
('11', 56, 3, 5, 114295) Asiatics have been also expected to share in these rejoicings.
('11', 56, 3, 6, 114358) If they have not been able to respond to these expectations, the cause, so far at least as the Transvaal is concerned, is not far to seek.
('11', 56, 3, 7, 114497) On the day of the advent of Union, 1
('11', 56, 4, 8, 114534) nearly sixty families were deprived of their supporters, and were being maintained out of public funds.
('11', 56, 4, 9, 114638) On the first working day of the Union, a cultured Indian and representative Parsee, Mr. Sorabji, who has already suffered six terms of imprisonment, was re arrested, after having been left free for over a month after his last discharge from Diepkloof; and he is now under order of deportation.
('11', 56, 4, 10, 114932) Other passive resisters, too, continue to be arrested.
('11', 56, 4, 11, 114987) Mr. Joseph Royeppen, the Barrister and Cambridge Graduate, and his companions are again in prison.
('11', 56, 4, 12, 115086) And all this suffering is being imposed because an Act that is supposed to have become a dead letter has not been repealed, and the theoretical legal position of British Indians of high attainments to enter the Transvaal on the same terms as Europeans, British or otherwise, is not recognised.
('11', 56, 4, 13, 115380) What can a Union under which the above state of things is continued mean to Asiatics, except that it is a combination of hostile forces arrayed against them?
('11', 56, 4, 14, 115538) The Empire is supposed to have become stronger for the Union.
('11', 56, 4, 15, 115600) Is it to crush by its weight and importance Asiatic subjects of the Crown?
('11', 56, 4, 16, 115675) It was no doubt right and proper that the birth of Union should have been signalised for the Natives of South Africa by the clemency of the Crown towards Dinizulu 2. Dinizulu’s discharge will naturally fire the imagination of the South African Natives.
('11', 56, 4, 17, 115928) Will it not be equally proper to enable the Asiatics in South Africa to feel that there is a new and benignant spirit abroad in South Africa by conceding their demands, which are held, I make
('11', 56, 5, 18, 116120) 1 Wednesday, June 1, 1910 2 Zulu chief; vide “Late Mr. Arathoon”, 14 12 1907. After release, he was settled on a farm in the Transvaal, where he died in October 1913.

('11', 59, 1, 2, 120081) 64. EXTRACT FROM LETTER TO P. J. MEHTA 1
('11', 59, 2, 3, 120122) [TOLSTOY FARM, After June 4, 1910] 2
('11', 59, 3, 4, 120159) I prepare the bread that is required on the farm.
('11', 59, 3, 5, 120209) The general opinion about it is that it is well made.
('11', 59, 3, 6, 120263) Manilal and a few others have learnt how to prepare it.
('11', 59, 3, 7, 120319) We put in no yeast and no baking powder.
('11', 59, 3, 8, 120360) We grind our own wheat.
('11', 59, 3, 9, 120384) We have just prepared some marmalade from the oranges grown on the farm.
('11', 59, 3, 10, 120457) I have also learnt how to prepare caramel coffee.
('11', 59, 3, 11, 120507) It can be given as a beverage even to babies.
('11', 59, 3, 12, 120553) The passive resisters on the farm have given up the use of tea and coffee, and taken to caramel coffee prepared on the farm.
('11', 59, 3, 13, 120678) It is made from wheat which is first baked in a certain way and then ground.
('11', 59, 3, 14, 120755) We intend to sell our surplus production of the above articles to the public later on.
('11', 59, 3, 15, 120842) Just at present, we are working as labourers on the construction work that is going on, on the farm, and have no time to produce more of the articles above mentioned than we need for ourselves.
('11', 59, 4, 16, 121036) From M. K. Gandhi and the South African Indian Problem by Dr. P. J. Mehta

('11', 60, 8, 10, 122060) CRUELTY TO SHELAT These prisoners who have been released have brought the news that the authorities have been trying to compel Shelat to carry [slop ] pails.
('11', 60, 8, 11, 122218) Last week he was sentenced to 24 hours’ solitary confinement and was put on spare diet.

('11', 61, 1, 2, 123336) 67. LETTER TO THE TRANSVAAL ADMINISTRATOR 1
('11', 61, 2, 3, 123380) [JOHANNESBURG,] June 7, 1910
('11', 61, 4, 4, 123409) Indian passive resisters discharged yesterday have brought the information that Mr. Shelat, a Brahmin passive resister, who is serving imprisonment at Diepkloof, has been once sentenced to solitary confinement and spare diet for refusing to carry slop pails on the ground that such work is contrary to his conscience and religion.
('11', 61, 4, 5, 123740) The discharged passive resisters state that Mr. Shelat has been threatened with the punishment of lashes, if he persists in his disobedience.
('11', 61, 4, 6, 123882) My Association is inclined to the belief that the threat, if it has been at all used, 2 is not seriously meant.
('11', 61, 4, 7, 123994) In any event, my Association respectfully trusts that the Government will be pleased to spare the Indian community the shock that is bound to be caused by the carrying out of the threat.
('11', 61, 4, 8, 124181) My Association ventures to draw your attention to the fact that, during his previous incarceration for conscience’ sake, Mr. Shelat underwent solitary confinement for over a month for the same cause, and that the other passive resisters at Diepkloof have stated that they have no objection to Mr. Shelat’s being excused from the duty of carrying slop pails.
('11', 61, 5, 9, 124539) My Association trusts that you will be pleased to give the matter the attention it deserves.
('11', 61, 6, 10, 124632) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1910
('11', 61, 7, 11, 124658) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji and marked “urgent”, was sent by E. S. Coovadia, Acting Chairman, British Indian Association, to the Administrator, Pretoria.
('11', 61, 7, 12, 124830) 2 The Director of Prisons in his reply of 21st June reproduced in Indian Opinion, 25 6 1910, said: “No threat of lashes has been made, nor would such a punishment ever be inflicted for an offence of this nature.” 3 Vide “Letter to Director of Prisons”, 3 5 1910
('11', 62, 0, 1, 125092) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 63
('11', 62, 1, 2, 125134) 68. MR. KALLENBACH’S OFFER
('11', 62, 2, 3, 125161) We do not know whom to congratulate most—Mr. Kallenbach for his highmindedness or the community for having received from Mr. Kallenbach an offer 1 which may enable passive resisters to go through the struggle without undue pecuniary strain.
('11', 62, 2, 4, 125402) The best thanks that can be rendered to Mr. Kallenbach would undoubtedly be for the passive resistance families to make use of the offer and to show to South Africa at large, by exemplary behaviour on the farm, how worthy they were of such handsome treatment.
('11', 62, 2, 5, 125662) The terms of Mr. Kallenbach’s letter 2 are one sided.
('11', 62, 2, 6, 125716) He has given all he legitimately could and has expected no return.
('11', 62, 2, 7, 125783) He does not want to develop his estate through the labour of those passive resisters who could put in their labour without paying them for it.
('11', 62, 2, 8, 125926) Acts such as Mr. Kallenbach’s are calculated to bring East and West nearer in real fellowship than any amount of rhetorical writing or speaking.
('11', 62, 2, 9, 126071) We shall watch this experiment with very great interest.
('11', 62, 3, 10, 126128) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1910
('11', 62, 4, 11, 126154) 69. LASHES!
('11', 62, 5, 12, 126166) Our Transvaal correspondent reports news this week of the gravest character.
('11', 62, 5, 13, 126243) Mr. Shelat has made it a matter of conscience not to carry slop pails.
('11', 62, 5, 14, 126314) During his last incarceration, he was under solitary confinement for over a month, during which time he had for the most part only spare diet.
('11', 62, 5, 15, 126457) We had hoped that this time, with the past experience to fall back upon, the authorities would let the matter rest and not force the issue by requiring Mr. Shelat to do that particular work.
('11', 62, 5, 16, 126648) On messages received from the prisoners at Diepkloof, it was represented to the Director of Prisons not to insist on Mr. Shelat doing the work, 3 as the other passive resisters were quite agreeable to the indulgence being granted him.
('11', 62, 5, 17, 126883) The Director, however, wrote to Mr. Cachalia saying that no such relief could be granted.
('11', 62, 5, 18, 126973) And now we see the result.
('11', 62, 5, 19, 127000) For the sake of the people of the Transvaal, we hope that
('11', 62, 6, 20, 127058) 1 Vide “Letter to H. Kallenbach”, 30 5 1910 2 Dated 30 5 1910; vide footnote of “Letter to H. Kallenbach”, 30 5 1910 3 Vide “Letter to Director of Prisons”, 3 5 1910
('11', 63, 0, 1, 127224) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 63, 1, 2, 127265) the authorities will not take the threatened step.
('11', 63, 1, 3, 127316) To order lashes in order to compel a man to do anything against his conscience would be the height of barbarity.
('11', 63, 1, 4, 127429) As a passive resister, Mr. Shelat will, no doubt, suffer cheerfully even the penalty of lashes.
('11', 63, 1, 5, 127525) But for the authorities to persist in their brutal course can only add to the tension that already exists among Indians.
('11', 63, 2, 6, 127646) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1910
('11', 63, 3, 7, 127672) 70. MR. THAMBI NAIDOO’S RE ARREST
('11', 63, 4, 8, 127706) The re arrest of Mr. Thambi Naidoo has followed close upon that of Mr. Sorabji.
('11', 63, 4, 9, 127786) It is evident that General Smuts, now that he is confirmed in his control over Asiatics, wishes to show his firmness by taking up the bravest passive resisters.
('11', 63, 4, 10, 127947) We wish him joy of his task.
('11', 63, 4, 11, 127976) We hope that we are not doing the great General an injustice in making him responsible for this sudden activity.
('11', 63, 4, 12, 128089) To passive resisters, a lodgment in the gaols of the Transvaal must be a welcome relief so long as their goal remains unreached.
('11', 63, 4, 13, 128218) The re arrest of Mr. Thambi Naidoo is not without a dramatic touch.
('11', 63, 4, 14, 128286) On Monday morning, he met his son who had just been discharged after three months’ service at Diepkloof.
('11', 63, 4, 15, 128391) In the afternoon of the same day he was re arrested.
('11', 63, 4, 16, 128444) Thus the father has not been allowed to remain with the son even for a few days.
('11', 63, 4, 17, 128525) This, no doubt, is merely a coincidence.
('11', 63, 4, 18, 128566) But it shows vividly what the struggle means to many Indians in the Transvaal.
('11', 63, 4, 19, 128645) Mr. Naidoo is one of the most determined and persevering of passive resisters.
('11', 63, 4, 20, 128724) Whether in or out of the gaol, he gives himself no rest.
('11', 63, 4, 21, 128781) His one aim is to live so as to deserve the high title of passive resister as the term is understood among the strugglers in the Transvaal.
('11', 63, 4, 22, 128921) Mr. Naidoo, like Mr. Sorabji, is among the brightest stars of the Indian community in South Africa.

('11', 65, 0, 1, 131268) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 65, 1, 2, 131309) 73. KALLENBACH’S GIFT
('11', 65, 2, 3, 131331) We place a very high value on Mr. Kallenbach’s offer of his farm for the benefit of satyagrahis.
('11', 65, 2, 4, 131428) If the families of the latter use it well, we shall have no occasion for anxiety, however long the struggle lasts.
('11', 65, 2, 5, 131543) There will be much saving in expenditure, and those who settle on the farm will learn to be happy.
('11', 65, 2, 6, 131642) They will have, on the farm, a noble life in place of the unclean and monotonous ways of town life.
('11', 65, 2, 7, 131742) Moreover, what they will learn on the farm will prove useful for a life time.
('11', 65, 2, 8, 131820) Indeed, we have said in the past that the Indian community would be well rewarded if it were to take to agriculture and would be saved the anxieties incidental to business.
('11', 65, 2, 9, 131993) We have to pay a heavy price for not recognizing the value of this best of occupations.
('11', 65, 2, 10, 132081) We hope the leaders [of the community] will address letters of thanks to Mr. Kallenbach.
('11', 65, 2, 11, 132170) His gift will be appreciated at its proper worth only when Indians settle there in large numbers.

('11', 65, 4, 13, 132284) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1910
('11', 65, 5, 14, 132310) 74. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 65, 6, 15, 132327) Monday [June 13, 1910]
('11', 65, 7, 16, 132350) TOLSTOY FARM
('11', 65, 8, 17, 132363) Mr. Kallenbach has given the name “Tolstoy Farm” to the farm which he has offered for [the use of] the satyagrahi families.
('11', 65, 8, 18, 132487) He has great faith in Count Tolstoy’s teaching and tries to live up to it.
('11', 65, 8, 19, 132562) He himself wants to live on the farm and follow a simple mode of life.
('11', 65, 8, 20, 132633) It appears Mr. Kallenbach will gradually give up his work as architect and live in complete poverty.
('11', 65, 8, 21, 132734) Mr. Kallenbach has rendered a valuable service by offering the use of his farm, but more so by deciding to live among our people.
('11', 65, 8, 22, 132864) He has also agreed to look after the womenfolk in the absence of Mr. Gandhi.
('11', 65, 8, 23, 132941) That any white should be moved by such a spirit must be attributed to the power of satyagraha.
('11', 65, 8, 24, 133036) The farm measures about 1100 acres, being two miles in length and three quarters of a mile in breadth.
('11', 65, 8, 25, 133139) It is situated near Lawley
('11', 66, 0, 1, 133166) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 67
('11', 66, 1, 2, 133208) Station, 22 miles from Johannesburg.
('11', 66, 1, 3, 133245) It takes twenty minutes to walk down from the station to the farm.
('11', 66, 1, 4, 133312) By rail, it generally takes about one and a half hours to reach it from here.
('11', 66, 1, 5, 133390) The soil appears to be fertile.
('11', 66, 1, 6, 133422) The farm has about a thousand fruit bearing trees growing on it.
('11', 66, 1, 7, 133487) There are peaches, apricots, figs, almonds, walnuts, etc.
('11', 66, 1, 8, 133545) In addition, there are eucalyptus and wattle trees.
('11', 66, 1, 9, 133597) The farm has two wells and a small spring.
('11', 66, 1, 10, 133640) The landscape is beautiful.
('11', 66, 1, 11, 133668) At the head there is a hill, with some more or less level land at the foot.
('11', 66, 1, 12, 133744) Mr. Kallenbach, Mr. Gandhi and his two sons have already settled on the farm since June 4. They are busy making arrangements for satyagrahis to go over there.
('11', 66, 1, 13, 133903) Mr. Kallenbach and Mr. Gandhi come to the town every Monday and Thursday and spend the other days on the farm.
('11', 66, 1, 14, 134014) Last Sunday, some leading Tamil ladies, accompanied by Mr. Thambi Naidoo and Mr. Gopal Naidoo, went over there to have a look round.
('11', 66, 1, 15, 134147) They spent the whole day on the farm.
('11', 66, 1, 16, 134185) Mr. Kallenbach, Mr. Gandhi and his son cooked a meal for them.
('11', 66, 1, 17, 134248) Mr. Kallenbach showed them round the farm and they all appeared satisfied.
('11', 66, 1, 18, 134323) Mr. Gopal Naidoo, who had already made up his mind to live there, has stayed on.
('11', 66, 1, 19, 134404) Mr. Moosa Nathi, too, who runs a shop nearby, came the same day and promised every possible help.
('11', 66, 1, 20, 134502) Construction work has started now and some buildings are expected to be ready by the end of this month.
('11', 66, 1, 21, 134606) This is a very important venture.
('11', 66, 1, 22, 134640) Its roots go deep; it is up to the satyagrahis who settle there to make it bear sweet fruit by the way they live.

('11', 68, 1, 2, 136420) 76. PASSIVE RESISTERS
('11', 68, 2, 3, 136442) Of the twenty six passive resisters who were deported and who had immediately returned from Bombay 1 and who arrived at Durban on Sunday last, only thirteen have been allowed to land, the claims of the other nine who stated that they were domiciled in the Colony having for the time being been rejected.
('11', 68, 2, 4, 136746) Efforts were made to induce the Principal Immigration Officer to allow the others to land, subject to security being given for their return should they fail to establish their claim.
('11', 68, 2, 5, 136929) But the officer was adamant and refused to grant this reasonable facility.
('11', 68, 2, 6, 137004) These men, therefore, have been obliged to undertake almost without a break a trying voyage for the third time.
('11', 68, 2, 7, 137116) Though British subjects, they have been rejected first by one British Colony and then by another.
('11', 68, 2, 8, 137214) And so misery is added to misery and discontent to discontent.
('11', 68, 2, 9, 137277) But the men who have been forced to go back have that stuff in them of which heroes are made.
('11', 68, 2, 10, 137371) They have gone not dispirited but invigorated by their trials, and the determination with which they have borne themselves hitherto will carry them to their goal.
('11', 68, 2, 11, 137534) The community is proud of them and so should the Empire in whose name they have been so shabbily treated by Natal.
('11', 68, 2, 12, 137649) They have set a noble example in deeds worthy of imitation by Indians throughout South Africa.
('11', 68, 2, 13, 137744) The task before those who have been landed is simple.
('11', 68, 2, 14, 137798) They have to challenge the Transvaal Government, now part of the Union Government, to re arrest and re imprison or re deport them.
('11', 68, 2, 15, 137929) A true passive resister, Wordsworth’s Warrior, has only one goal before him and that is to do his duty, cost what it may.
('11', 68, 3, 16, 138051) Indian Opinion, 18 6 1910
('11', 68, 4, 17, 138077) 77. SATYAGRAHIS

('11', 69, 1, 2, 138442) the community to realize that satyagrahis are its true servants and precious jewels, and so to look after them and encourage them.
('11', 69, 1, 3, 138573) For satyagrahis, public honour and parties should have little attraction.
('11', 69, 1, 4, 138647) Their duty is merely to do and to suffer.

('11', 69, 1, 21, 139774) Therefore, though it is a discredit to us that the Indians had to return, the incident may yet do us good.

('11', 69, 4, 24, 139923) 78. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 69, 5, 25, 139940) Monday [June 20, 1910]
('11', 69, 6, 26, 139963) SATYAGRAHI FARM
('11', 69, 7, 27, 139979) There has been feverish activity on the farm to complete the arrangement for women.
('11', 69, 7, 28, 140063) Mr. Kallenbach is busy with building operations.
('11', 69, 7, 29, 140112) The foundation has been laid for a chawl fifty feet long.
('11', 69, 7, 30, 140170) It is a stone foundation, and Mr. Chinan, Mr. Kuppusamy Naidoo, Mr. Manilal Gandhi and Mr. Gandhi have been working at stone rolling side by side with the Kaffirs.
('11', 69, 7, 31, 140334) Stones are available on the farm itself, but they have to be carried from the hill to the building site.
('11', 69, 7, 32, 140439) Mr. Gopal Naidoo attends to cooking.
('11', 69, 7, 33, 140476) In all, there are six Indians and Mr. Kallenbach living together, with a common mess.
('11', 69, 7, 34, 140562) All the dishes are
('11', 70, 0, 1, 140581) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 71
('11', 70, 1, 2, 140623) prepared in Indian style.
('11', 70, 1, 3, 140649) In the morning, those who want a breakfast have bread and also coffee made from roasted wheat.
('11', 70, 1, 4, 140744) The bread is made at home, without the use of yeast.
('11', 70, 1, 5, 140797) It is prepared from boer meal and whole meal.
('11', 70, 1, 6, 140843) At lunch, they have rice and curry, and bread with home made jam prepared from oranges growing on the farm.
('11', 70, 1, 7, 140951) For dinner, there is porridge, and bread and jam.
('11', 70, 1, 8, 141001) Butter is not used, the ghee employed in cooking being considered sufficient.
('11', 70, 1, 9, 141079) In the afternoon and at night, they have dry fruit and groundnut, if either is at hand.
('11', 70, 1, 10, 141167) Modifications, if necessary, will be made in this diet after the women join.
('11', 70, 1, 11, 141244) I am both surprised and glad that Mr. Kallenbach lives amidst this group like a member of the family.
('11', 70, 2, 12, 141346) DAVID ANDREW Mr. David Andrew, Mr. Samuel Joseph and Mr. Dhobi Nayana will be free for eight days.
('11', 70, 2, 13, 141445) They will be deported next Friday.
('11', 70, 2, 14, 141480) Mr. David Andrew and Mr. Samuel Joseph are staying with the Chairman of the Chinese Association at his invitation.
('11', 70, 2, 15, 141595) They have been put up in the Chinese Club.
('11', 70, 2, 16, 141638) It is a very well run club.
('11', 70, 2, 17, 141666) One really feels the absence of such a building for Indians.
('11', 70, 3, 18, 141727) THAMBI NAIDOO It is not yet known where he is to be taken.
('11', 70, 3, 19, 141786) There are four other satyagrahis with him.

('11', 70, 8, 28, 142424) Indian Opinion, 25 6 1910
('11', 71, 0, 1, 142450) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 71, 1, 2, 142491) 79. INDIANS UNDER THE UNION
('11', 71, 2, 3, 142519) The placing of the Native question above party politics, and the fair and sympathetic treatment of the Coloured races in a broad and liberal spirit; the encouragement of European and the prevention of Asiatic immigration into South Africa.
('11', 71, 3, 4, 142759) —General Botha’s Manifesto.
('11', 71, 4, 5, 142787) To improve the social conditions of the people by opposing the introduction of Asiatics into South Africa, while securing fair treatment for those now lawfully settled in the country; a Commission to be appointed as soon as possible to investigate and report upon the special labour conditions prevailing in Natal, in order to bring them into harmony at the earliest possible date with this principle without detriment to established industries.
('11', 71, 5, 6, 143233) —Unionist Party’s Programme.
('11', 71, 6, 7, 143262) We leave placed in juxtaposition extracts from General Botha’s manifesto and the programme of Dr. Jameson’s new party.
('11', 71, 6, 8, 143381) The reader will see that there is not much to choose between the two, that the statements are as vague as they possibly can be, and that the authors of the two documents consider that Asiatic immigration is inimical to improvement in the social status of Europeans residing in South Africa.
('11', 71, 6, 9, 143672) Both documents desire the prevention of such immigration.
('11', 71, 6, 10, 143730) The Unionist programme qualifies the desire by adding that fair treatment for those now lawfully settled in the country should be secured.
('11', 71, 6, 11, 143869) That programme contemplates also an investigation into the labour conditions of Natal.
('11', 71, 6, 12, 143956) British Indians throughout South Africa, then, must be prepared during the coming months for anti Asiatic activity on a much larger scale than hitherto.
('11', 71, 6, 13, 144109) The prospect, however, is by no means black or hopeless, if the different sections of the community scattered throughout South Africa will realise the significance of the statements we have above quoted and do the needful in order to combat the reactionary policy foreshadowed by them.
('11', 71, 6, 14, 144395) In doing so, however, they will have to recognise well defined limitations.
('11', 71, 6, 15, 144471) Control of Asiatic immigration we are bound to put up with and recognise, but total exclusion amounting to a national insult must be considered by every Indian worth his salt to be an impossibility.
('11', 71, 6, 16, 144670) It appears to us that no sacrifice that may be made by the resident community in South Africa will be too great in order
('11', 72, 0, 1, 144791) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 73
('11', 72, 1, 2, 144833) to avert, such a calamity.
('11', 72, 1, 3, 144860) We hold that this sort of equality is the corner stone of the Imperial edifice, and that Indians who suffer in their attempt to make good the position will have deserved well not only of India but of the whole Empire.
('11', 72, 1, 4, 145078) The two manifestos demonstrate the greatness of the struggle that is now going on in the Transvaal.
('11', 72, 1, 5, 145178) We hope that our countrymen in this continent will carefully study the programme of the two parties, and do theirduty at what is a critical juncture in the history of British Indians in South Africa.
('11', 72, 2, 6, 145378) Indian Opinion, 25 6 1910
('11', 72, 3, 7, 145404) 80. GENERAL BOTHA’S VIEWS
('11', 72, 4, 8, 145430) The manifesto of his party, which General Botha has issued, sets out his views about us.
('11', 72, 4, 9, 145519) These are worth studying.
('11', 72, 4, 10, 145545) He wants European immigration into South Africa to be encouraged and Asiatic immigration to be stopped.
('11', 72, 4, 11, 145649) Dr. Jameson’s party also sets out identical views.
('11', 72, 4, 12, 145700) Its manifesto states, however, that Asiatics who are already settled in South Africa should be treated well, that the question of allowing indentured labour into Natal should be carefully examined and that it should even be stopped altogether if the existing interests of the industry did not suffer thereby.
('11', 72, 4, 13, 146009) Thus, the leaders of both the parties want to stop Asiatic immigration.
('11', 72, 4, 14, 146081) Their manifestos, however, are couched in such terms that they will bear any interpretation that one may choose to put upon them.
('11', 72, 4, 15, 146211) For us, of course, they have only one meaning, namely, that there is imminent danger to us.
('11', 72, 4, 16, 146303) We may understand the view that too many Indians should not be allowed into South Africa.
('11', 72, 4, 17, 146393) That is a hardship we cannot escape.
('11', 72, 4, 18, 146430) When, however, we are told that we cannot enter just because we are Asiatics, it is the whole of India that is being insulted.
('11', 72, 4, 19, 146557) We believe no Indian will put up with such an insult.
('11', 72, 4, 20, 146611) Whatever the consequences of our refusal, we must bear them.
('11', 72, 4, 21, 146672) For that, as we should like to show to every Indian, we must start preparing ourselves right now.
('11', 72, 4, 22, 146770) Otherwise, steps will be taken under the Union to uproot Indians from South Africa altogether.
('11', 72, 4, 23, 146865) We take this opportunity to remind Indians that the Transvaal campaign is a powerful source of strength [to them].

('11', 73, 4, 5, 147124) 81. SPEECH AT SOCIALIST HALL 1
('11', 73, 5, 6, 147155) [JOHANNESBURG, June 26, 1910]
('11', 73, 6, 7, 147185) Mr. M. K. Gandhi delivered an interesting and well thought out address last night at the Socialist Hall, Market Street, under the auspices of the Socialist Committee, entitled “Modern as Compared with Ancient Civilisation”.
('11', 73, 6, 8, 147409) The hall was crowded.
('11', 73, 7, 9, 147431) Mr. Gandhi prefaced his remarks with an apology to those who might differ from his views, and excused himself on the ground that he was an ardent searcher after truth.
('11', 73, 7, 10, 147599) Modern civilisation, he said, could be summed up by two expressions.
('11', 73, 7, 11, 147668) One was that it represented ceaseless activity, and the second was that it aimed at the annihilation of space and time.
('11', 73, 7, 12, 147788) Everybody nowadays appeared to be preoccupied, and to him that appeared a dangerous symptom.
('11', 73, 7, 13, 147881) They were all so intent upon earning bread and butter that they had no time for anything else.
('11', 73, 8, 14, 147976) Modern civilisation made them materialistic, made them concentrate their thoughts upon their bodies and upon the means of multiplying bodily comforts.
('11', 73, 8, 15, 148127) Herbert Spencer had summed up the modern man by saying that the civilized man led a complex life as opposed to the entirely simple life of the savage.
('11', 73, 8, 16, 148278) The source from which the Asiatic trouble arose in the Transvaal was that the Asiatic’s wants were very simple, whereas those of the European were complex and therefore expensive.
('11', 73, 8, 17, 148458) The tendency of modern methods went to make the Native’s life more complex.
('11', 73, 8, 18, 148534) While the wants of the raw Native were easily satisfied, the more enlightened of them required many more embellishments.
('11', 73, 8, 19, 148655) Thus, they required more money, and when they found they could not get it honestly, they resorted to dishonesty.
('11', 73, 9, 20, 148768) After 18 years of study devoted to the consideration of the question, he had come to the conclusion that instead of there being a change for the better, there had
('11', 73, 10, 21, 148931) 1 Indian Opinion, 2 7 1910, published a brief summary in the following words: The speaker said that modern civilization was expressed in an attempt to annihilate time and space and in excessive care for the body.
('11', 73, 10, 22, 149144) The rush of modern life left little time for higher thoughts.
('11', 73, 10, 23, 149206) It looked downward to the earth, whereas ancient civilization looked upward to Heaven.
('11', 73, 10, 24, 149293) It kept the body subservient to the soul.
('11', 73, 10, 25, 149335) It was based on the force of love.
('11', 73, 10, 26, 149370) It avoided the hateful spirit of competition.
('11', 73, 10, 27, 149416) It was best expressed in village life as against modern town life.
('11', 74, 0, 1, 149483) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 75
('11', 74, 1, 2, 149525) been a change for the worse.
('11', 74, 1, 3, 149554) (Applause.) He found that the simple life was better than the complex, in that they found time to devote attention to higher pursuits.
('11', 74, 1, 4, 149689) In ancient civilisation, there had been no rush whatsoever.
('11', 74, 1, 5, 149749) They nowadays looked downwards to the earth; in those days they looked upwards to Heaven.
('11', 74, 1, 6, 149839) They did not concentrate upon the body but upon the soul, which they kept quite distinct from the soul [sic].
('11', 74, 2, 7, 149949) The flesh was not the be all and the end all of life.
('11', 74, 2, 8, 150003) Now was the service of Mammon; then was the service of God.
('11', 74, 2, 9, 150063) If he did not think that the soul existed and if he did not recognise that in all of them there were identical souls, then he for one would not like to live upon this earth.
('11', 74, 2, 10, 150237) He would like to die.
('11', 74, 2, 11, 150259) The body was the vehicle subservient to the soul.
('11', 74, 2, 12, 150309) The body was simply earth, dross and objectionable.
('11', 74, 3, 13, 150361) Ancient civilisation made them look to the higher pursuits of life, the love of God, the respect of a neighbour and the consciousness of the existence of the soul.
('11', 74, 3, 14, 150525) The sooner they returned to the life, the better.
('11', 74, 4, 15, 150575) Rand Daily Mail, 27 6 1910

('11', 76, 4, 18, 154536) In the days of ancient civilization, men were kind, God fearing and simple and looked upon the body as a means of spiritual uplift.
('11', 76, 4, 19, 154668) It is necessary to revert to the ancient way of life and for that purpose to adopt simplicity and village life.
('11', 76, 4, 20, 154780) The speech was followed by numerous questions and answers and a lengthy discussion.
('11', 76, 4, 21, 154864) The audience appeared to have been well impressed.
