('11', 80, 4, 5, 160501) 88. COLOUR PREJUDICE
('11', 80, 5, 6, 160522) America is regarded as a free country.
('11', 80, 5, 7, 160561) It is claimed that everyone enjoys the fullest freedom there.
('11', 80, 5, 8, 160623) A great many people, we find, are inclined to imitate America.
('11', 80, 5, 9, 160686) Men are dazzled by her industry.
('11', 80, 5, 10, 160719) But, on deeper reflection, we shall see that there is not much in America worthy of imitation.
('11', 80, 5, 11, 160814) The people there are given over to the worship of self and of mammon.
('11', 80, 5, 12, 160884) For money they will do the meanest things.
('11', 80, 5, 13, 160927) Only a short while ago, we saw this exemplified in Dr. Cook’s case.
('11', 80, 5, 14, 160995) There are reports now [which suggest] that even the freedom which the Americans boast of is vanishing.
('11', 80, 5, 15, 161098) Colour prejudice is on the increase.
('11', 80, 5, 16, 161135) Indians have enjoyed voting rights till this day.
('11', 80, 5, 17, 161185) An official has now discovered that the framers of the Constitution could never have intended the granting of the franchise to Asiatics.
('11', 80, 5, 18, 161322) He believes that not only Indians but even Turks should be denied the right to vote.
('11', 80, 5, 19, 161407) Though the vast majority of the Turkish people are white skinned, the official has pointed out that they are, after all, Asiatics.
('11', 80, 5, 20, 161538) The agitation against Asiatics going on in the West is likely to have grave consequences.
('11', 80, 5, 21, 161628) We are not thinking just now of what China and Turkey will do.
('11', 80, 5, 22, 161691) It is the duty of every Indian to think of what India should do.
('11', 80, 5, 23, 161756) Japan has shown one way, that of proving one’s strength and defending one’s land with [the power of] arms.
('11', 80, 5, 24, 161863) Following that way, Japan has become like America and the imitation will soon be perfect, if it is not already so.
('11', 80, 5, 25, 161978) To us it appears that, if we wish to avoid being found in America’s predicament, we had better refrain from training in the use of arms.
('11', 80, 5, 26, 162115) Behind the venturesome spirit of America is her armed strength.
('11', 80, 5, 27, 162179) All that India has to do to hold her own is to preserve her ancient civilization, eliminating only its defects.
('11', 80, 5, 28, 162291) The kind of racial discrimination which America practises, we have practised against our own people in India.
('11', 80, 5, 29, 162401) Once there were many reformers in the West who
('11', 81, 0, 1, 162448) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 81, 1, 2, 162489) had hoped and desired that the people there would shun such discrimination, but that is no more so.
('11', 81, 1, 3, 162589) They have now begun to say that there must be no mixing with the Coloured races, that the Asiatics must be kept down.
('11', 81, 1, 4, 162707) We think this movement will grow stronger rather than otherwise—it cannot but do so.
('11', 81, 1, 5, 162792) Where people are concerned only with self interest, it is not possible that they will allow others a foothold.
('11', 81, 1, 6, 162903) Since their selfishness is mounting, their hostility to us will also grow.
('11', 81, 1, 7, 162978) Self interest will make them fight among themselves, too— even today they are fighting.
('11', 81, 1, 8, 163066) That is a characteristic aspect of Western civilization.
('11', 81, 1, 9, 163123) If we imitate the Western people, we may succeed for a time in mixing with them but subsequently we would also be blinded by selfishness and fight with them and fight among ourselves, too.
('11', 81, 1, 10, 163312) Someone may argue that even today we are fighting among ourselves.
('11', 81, 1, 11, 163379) but our fighting is of a different kind.
('11', 81, 1, 12, 163420) We must of course put an end to this.
('11', 81, 1, 13, 163458) But we should be careful to see that in our attempt to mend matters we do not cause greater harm instead.
('11', 81, 2, 14, 163564) [From Gujarati]

('11', 82, 1, 2, 164024) 90. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO GOVERNOR GENERAL 1
('11', 82, 2, 3, 164078) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 4, 1910
('11', 82, 3, 4, 164107) SIR, The Committee of my Association has decided to approach His Excellency 2 with a view to the presentation of a humble and loyal address 3 of welcome, on His Excellency’s approaching visit to Johannesburg; but my Committee has hesitated by reason of a hitch that occurred at the time of the presentation of an address to Lord Selborne 4. My Committee was then at first advised that the Association’s address would be received at the same time and place as the other addresses from public bodies, but, at the eleventh hour, a message was sent to the offices of the Association to the effect that the address would be received privately by His Lordship, and it was ultimately so received.
('11', 82, 3, 5, 164797) My Association then understood that the decision to receive the address at the same time as the others was altered because of the prevailing prejudice against Asiatic and coloured communities in this country.
('11', 82, 3, 6, 165006) My Association is most anxious to avoid a repetition of such an awkward and humiliating position, and, therefore, trusts that, if its humble address may not be received in common with the other addresses next Friday, His Excellency will be graciously pleased to accept this letter as testifying its respect for His Excellency as His Majesty’s representative.
('11', 82, 3, 7, 165365) If the address of my Association cannot be received publicly, my Association can quite understand and appreciate the delicacy of the situation.
('11', 82, 3, 8, 165509) But, should His Excellency consider that the humble address of my Association may be received publicly in common with the others next Friday, I am desired to state that my Association would like to make a formal presentation.
('11', 82, 3, 9, 165735) May I request the favour of a telegraphic reply?
('11', 82, 4, 10, 165784) Indian Opinion, 9 7 1910
('11', 82, 5, 11, 165809) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was signed by A. M. Cachalia, Chairman, British Indian Association.
('11', 82, 5, 12, 165924) 2 Herbert John Gladstone (1854 1930); was the first Governor General and High Commissioner for South Africa, 1910 4 3 Vide the following item.

('11', 83, 7, 9, 166966) 92. ROYEPPEN
('11', 83, 8, 10, 166979) Mr. Joseph Royeppen has been released, and yet not released.
('11', 83, 8, 11, 167040) He was released, but is to be deported again on the 14th.
('11', 83, 8, 12, 167098) We can judge from his case where the struggle stands.
('11', 83, 8, 13, 167152) The last time he was released, he was required to offer a security of £50 in order to be free for a few days and see people.
('11', 83, 8, 14, 167277) This time he has been released on his personal recognizance.
('11', 83, 8, 15, 167338) He did not even have to sign any document.
('11', 83, 8, 16, 167381) This is a measure of the enhanced reputation which Indians enjoy.
('11', 83, 8, 17, 167447) A satyagrahi’s word, thus, is trusted.
('11', 83, 8, 18, 167486) Even in gaol, they have changed their ways.
('11', 83, 8, 19, 167530) Warders are afraid to hold out threats to satyagrahis.
('11', 83, 8, 20, 167585) The latter do not put up with any injustice.

('11', 84, 1, 5, 168143) Not only is it alive, it has a radiant sparkle, so long as there are men with the spirit of Mr. Royeppen, and its effects are spreading wider.
('11', 84, 1, 6, 168286) Every Indian youth should take a lesson from Mr. Royeppen’s example.
('11', 84, 1, 7, 168355) Though a barrister and a man of learning, he holds no manual work to be beneath him.

('11', 84, 4, 13, 168689) 93. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 84, 5, 14, 168706) SATYAGRAHI FARM For the present at least I must say that the Farm is making progress every day.
('11', 84, 5, 15, 168802) The number of settlers has increased considerably and the place has taken on the appearance of a new township.
('11', 84, 5, 16, 168913) There are four tents in addition to the building which I mentioned earlier for the satyagrahis and their families.
('11', 84, 5, 17, 169028) One of the tents is occupied by Mr. Kallenbach and the satyagrahis, and the building has been handed over to the ladies.
('11', 84, 5, 18, 169149) The labour for putting up the building is contributed by the satyagrahis and Mr. Kallenbach.
('11', 84, 5, 19, 169242) They do every kind of work such as loading and unloading, fetching water, chopping wood, transporting goods from the station, etc.
('11', 84, 5, 20, 169373) Even conducting the school is at present a strenuous task and everyone is tired out by the evening.
('11', 84, 5, 21, 169473) Mr. Gopal Naidoo, who looks after the cooking, is giving an excellent account of himself.
('11', 84, 5, 22, 169563) He is busy at it from a quarter past six in the morning to nine in the evening.
('11', 84, 5, 23, 169643) He practises the strictest economy in the use of food stuffs, just as if they were his own.
('11', 84, 6, 24, 169735) VISIT BY OTHER LADIES Other ladies came on a visit of inspection to the Farm on Sunday.
('11', 84, 6, 25, 169823) They were Mrs. Sebastian, Mrs. Francis, Mrs. Chellan Nagappen, Mrs. Marimuthu Padiachy, Mrs. Ellery Moonsamy and
('11', 85, 0, 1, 169936) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 85, 1, 2, 169977) Mrs. Kathu Pillay.
('11', 85, 1, 3, 169996) They went away satisfied with the arrangements on the Farm, and so it looks as though they will decide to settle there.
('11', 85, 2, 4, 170116) VISIT BY BUSINESSMEN There was also a visit from Mr. Cachalia, Imam Saheb Abdool Kadir Bawazeer, Moulvi Saheb Mukhtiar, and Messrs Aswat, Fancy, Hajee Habib, Nagadi, Ebrahim Coovadia, Amod Mia, Suleman Mia, Moosa Esaakji, Goolam Munshi, Ahmed Waja, Moosa Bhikhaji, Ahmed Karodia, Moosa Ebrahim Patel, Ahmed Mamdoo, Mirza, Ebrahim Hajari, Parbhoo, Gosai and Anthony.
('11', 85, 2, 5, 170482) They spent the whole day here and shared a meal with the satyagrahis before leaving.
('11', 85, 2, 6, 170567) The gentlemen also joined in the work.
('11', 85, 3, 7, 170606) KALLENBACH HONOURED Then, as many of them wanted to offer thanks to Mr. Kallenbach, a meeting was held after dinner was over.
('11', 85, 3, 8, 170732) The Moulvi Saheb, on a motion by Mr. Hajee Habib seconded by the Imam Saheb, was elected to the chair.
('11', 85, 3, 9, 170835) He said that the meeting was held to offer thanks to Mr. Kallenbach for what he had done.
('11', 85, 3, 10, 170925) He certainly deserved their thanks.
('11', 85, 3, 11, 170961) Messrs Polak and Kallenbach [he said] had rendered yeoman service, though they were foreigners.
('11', 85, 3, 12, 171057) Mr. Ebrahim Coovadia then proposed a vote of thanks to Mr. Kallenbach for his generous gift and the interest he had shown in the cause.
('11', 85, 3, 13, 171193) The Imam Saheb seconded the motion.
('11', 85, 3, 14, 171229) Mr. Hajee Habib supported it.
('11', 85, 3, 15, 171259) Then there followed speeches by Mr. Cachalia and Mr. Royeppen, after which the motion was unanimously carried.
('11', 85, 3, 16, 171370) Mr. Kallenbach in his reply said that he had gained by the active interest he had taken in the campaign and that this was true of other whites, too.
('11', 85, 3, 17, 171519) The Indians who had joined the struggle [he added] derived still greater benefit, so remarkable was this fight.
('11', 85, 4, 18, 171631) JOSEPH ROYEPPEN [He] was released on Friday.
('11', 85, 4, 19, 171676) He was to be deported immediately after.
('11', 85, 4, 20, 171717) He was therefore released from Johannesburg Gaol and asked to appear at 3 o’clock.
('11', 85, 4, 21, 171800) On presenting himself at three, he was ordered to appear on the 14th for deportation.
('11', 85, 4, 22, 171886) Immediately, therefore, he went to live on the Farm and plunged into work the very first day.
('11', 85, 4, 23, 171980) He was joined by Mr. Solomon Ernest.
('11', 85, 4, 24, 172017) The Farm, thus, has had plenty of

('11', 86, 1, 4, 172303) Full of good humour, he infects others with his genial spirits.
('11', 86, 2, 5, 172367) PRISONERS’ DIET Many changes have been introduced in the regulation diet for prisoners.
('11', 86, 2, 6, 172455) The quota of rice has been increased by two ounces.
('11', 86, 2, 7, 172507) In the evening, they get bread, mealie pap and one ounce of ghee.
('11', 86, 2, 8, 172573) Nothing remains, therefore, to complain of regarding diet.
('11', 86, 3, 9, 172632) NOT DISEMBARKED AT ZANZIBAR A telegram has been received from Mr. Cowasji Dinsha to say that P. K. Naidoo and his companions have not been disembarked at Zanzibar, as was intended.
('11', 86, 3, 10, 172813) The authorities, it seems, raised some legal difficulties.
('11', 86, 3, 11, 172872) Hence all those satyagrahis have proceeded to India.
('11', 86, 3, 12, 172925) We have no reliable information regarding how this new law that Indians cannot land at Zanzibar came to be passed, but, from the point of view of Indians, this is a startling development.
('11', 86, 3, 13, 173113) It shows what British freedom means.

P. Ebrahim.
('11', 86, 4, 15, 173436) It will be a very good thing if others, too, help the Farm in some such way.
('11', 86, 4, 16, 173513) It is not only residents of the Transvaal or Johannesburg who can send help to the Farm.
('11', 86, 4, 17, 173602) Indians from all over South Africa can send clothing, furniture and provisions.
('11', 86, 4, 18, 173682) Fruiterers and vegetable dealers in Durban can send these articles and cloth merchants can send cloth.
('11', 86, 4, 19, 173785) Since there are no customs duties now, the railway freight itself does not amount to much.
('11', 86, 4, 20, 173876) Second hand coats, trousers and similar articles can also be turned to use.
('11', 86, 4, 21, 173952) I hope, every Indian will read this paragraph and offer all possible help.
('11', 86, 4, 22, 174027) Anyone who does so will have, to that extent, participated in the campaign.

('11', 88, 7, 12, 176638) 96. LICENSING LAW
('11', 88, 8, 13, 176656) The Supreme Court Judgment in the matter of Mahomed Goolam and the Maritzburg Corporation (published in our last issue) is worthy of perusal.
('11', 88, 8, 14, 176798) 1 It shows what Indians have to labour under in the Colony.
('11', 88, 8, 15, 176858) The Licensing Officer holds their fortune in the palm of his hand.
('11', 88, 8, 16, 176925) The Supreme Court does not always get the opportunity of exposing his arbitrary decisions.
('11', 88, 8, 17, 177016) Every aggrieved Indian trader cannot afford to take his case to the Supreme Court.
('11', 88, 8, 18, 177099) One can, therefore, only guess what hardships Indian traders have to undergo and what must necessarily remain unnoticed by the public.
('11', 88, 8, 19, 177234) We drew attention only the other day to an Estcourt case which has not yet reached the Supreme Court.
('11', 88, 8, 20, 177336) The only thing Indian merchants can do is to ceaselessly agitate till their trading rights are placed on a firm footing.
('11', 88, 9, 21, 177457) Indian Opinion, 16 7 1910

('11', 88, 10, 23, 177574) The licence fee was accepted but no decision given.
('11', 88, 10, 24, 177626) He continued trading till December when the City Licensing Officer rejected the application.
('11', 88, 10, 25, 177719) The Town Council upheld his decision.
('11', 88, 10, 26, 177757) Goolam then appealed to the Supreme Court, which allowed the appeal with costs.

('11', 90, 5, 13, 180366) 100. WHO IS UNCIVILIZED?
('11', 90, 6, 14, 180391) We published the report of a boxing match 1 in America between a negro and a white.
('11', 90, 6, 15, 180475) Millions had assembled to enjoy the spectacle.
('11', 90, 6, 16, 180522) Among them were both old and young, men and women, rich and poor, government officials and common citizens.
('11', 90, 6, 17, 180630) Many of them had travelled all the way from Europe.
('11', 90, 6, 18, 180682) What did they see?
('11', 90, 6, 19, 180701) Two men were hitting each other and displaying their brute strength.
('11', 90, 6, 20, 180770) The people of America went mad over this show, and America is reckoned a very civilized country!
('11', 90, 6, 21, 180867) What did the spectators gain from this show?
('11', 90, 6, 22, 180912) We can offer no satisfactory answer to this question.
('11', 90, 6, 23, 180966) There are some who hold that the body is strengthened through demonstrations of this kind and people learn how to defend themselves.
('11', 90, 6, 24, 181099) A little reflection will show that this is altogether a mistaken notion.
('11', 90, 6, 25, 181172) It is, of course, good to harden the body, but that cannot be done through boxing matches in public.
('11', 90, 6, 26, 181273) There are many other means, and natural ones, of strengthening the body.
('11', 90, 6, 27, 181346) This is no more than a pretext.
('11', 90, 6, 28, 181378) The truth of the matter is that people enjoy seeing a fight and give their adoration to physical strength only.
('11', 90, 6, 29, 181490) They think nothing else can match it.
('11', 90, 6, 30, 181528) In thinking thus, they deny the soul and therefore deny God.
('11', 90, 6, 31, 181589) The only
('11', 90, 7, 32, 181598) 1 Between Jefferies and Johnson at Reno on July 4, 1910
('11', 91, 0, 1, 181654) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 91, 1, 2, 181695) epithet that can be applied to such a people is “barbarous”.
('11', 91, 1, 3, 181756) There is very little to learn from them.
('11', 91, 1, 4, 181797) We certainly do not wish to say that there were no such shows in ancient times.
('11', 91, 1, 5, 181877) But everyone knew and admitted them to be barbarous.
('11', 91, 1, 6, 181930) No wise men went to them.
('11', 91, 1, 7, 181956) They were attended only by boys and woolly headed young men.
('11', 91, 1, 8, 182017) On the other hand, the show in America was attended by grown up people.
('11', 91, 1, 9, 182089) Lengthy telegrams were dispatched to newspapers at a huge cost.
('11', 91, 1, 10, 182153) The reports were followed with interest by millions.
('11', 91, 1, 11, 182206) Thus, the show was not looked upon as something uncivilized; on the contrary, it was regarded as a mark of civilization.
('11', 91, 1, 12, 182327) This, in our view, is the extreme limit of barbarism.

('11', 91, 5, 19, 182698) NEW GAME OF ASIATIC OFFICE It has been the practice so far to register Indian children on their attaining majority.
('11', 91, 5, 20, 182814) Now, however, they refuse such registration, if the applicants have entered after the coming into force of the Act of 1908. The effect of this will be that hundreds of Indian children will not be allowed to register and so will have to return to India.
('11', 91, 5, 21, 183067) It may not be proper for satyagrahis to take the matter to a court of law.
('11', 91, 5, 22, 183142) But this being a serious issue, some Indians are determined to test their rights in court.
('11', 91, 5, 23, 183233) The result is bound to be favourable.

('11', 94, 7, 15, 187999) 105. ANOTHER BREACH OF FAITH!
('11', 94, 8, 16, 188029) The news that our Transvaal correspondent gives regarding the latest move of the Transvaal Government is indeed astounding.
('11', 94, 8, 17, 188153) It will be remembered that one of the sorest points in the Asiatic Act of 1907 was that it required direct registration of minors under sixteen years.
('11', 94, 8, 18, 188304) This grievance was removed by the Act of 1908 by transferring registration of such children to their parents’ certificates.
('11', 94, 8, 19, 188428) And had everything else gone well, nothing more would have been heard of registration of minor children in the Transvaal.
('11', 94, 8, 20, 188550) Until recently it appears that minor children of non resisters were, on attainment of majority, registered whether such children entered before or after the commencement of the Act of 1908. But it seems that the calmness of the Asiatic Department is simply to find out how to circumvent the
('11', 94, 9, 21, 188841) 1 The boxing match mentioned in the letter took place at Reno in the U.S.A. on July 4, 1910, in which year Ashadh Vadi 6 corresponded to July 28. 2 Vide “Who Is Uncivilized?”, 23 7 1910
('11', 95, 0, 1, 189027) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 95, 1, 2, 189068) Indian community and how to harass it into leaving that Colony.
('11', 95, 1, 3, 189132) Some law officer has therefore discovered that there is a flaw in the Act of 1908 which was drawn up in a day and that that flaw enables the Government to treat minors who entered the Colony lawfully after the commencement of the Act as prohibited immigrants on their attaining majority.
('11', 95, 1, 4, 189420) That the legislature never contemplated any such result is obvious.
('11', 95, 1, 5, 189488) Indian parents could never consent to an arrangement whereby their children should be sent out of the Transvaal on their arriving at the age of sixteen years.
('11', 95, 1, 6, 189647) The Act of 1908 was largely a matter of compromise.
('11', 95, 1, 7, 189699) The history of the negotiations that led up to the passing of the Act shows clearly that the Government and the Asiatics clearly understood that minor children of registered Asiatics were to enjoy the same rights as themselves.
('11', 95, 1, 8, 189927) We do not know what the exact meaning of the Act may be and we care less.
('11', 95, 1, 9, 190001) But this we do know, that, whatever may be the legal effect of the Act, this latest move on the part of the Transvaal Government shows a flagrant breach of faith.
('11', 95, 1, 10, 190164) It emphasizes the charge of bad faith brought by the community against that Government.
('11', 95, 1, 11, 190252) It strengthens and justifies passive resisters in their resolve to continue the fight.
('11', 95, 1, 12, 190339) Non resisters will test the point in the law courts.
('11', 95, 1, 13, 190392) They may be worsted in the struggle.
('11', 95, 1, 14, 190429) So much the worse for the Government.
('11', 95, 1, 15, 190467) If there is a flaw in the Act, it is for them to rectify the error, not to take a mean advantage of it.
('11', 95, 1, 16, 190571) But this move of the Transvaal Government has, for those who will understand it, a deeper meaning.
('11', 95, 1, 17, 190670) It shows that the sheet anchor of our hope lies not in the uncertainty of law suits but in the certainty of passive resistance.
('11', 95, 1, 18, 190798) We therefore trust that Indian parents who have abandoned the fight in despair and from weakness will gird up their loins and once more throw in their lot with those who are continuing passive resistance.
('11', 95, 1, 19, 191003) We shall watch with some curiosity how the Imperial Government will view this latest phase of the question.
('11', 95, 2, 20, 191111) Indian Opinion, 30 7 1910

('11', 96, 1, 2, 191179) 106. PRISON TREATMENT
('11', 96, 2, 3, 191201) Mr. Churchill has announced 1 that passive resisters and Suffragettes shall not henceforth be treated as common felons and that they are not to have degrading associations.
('11', 96, 2, 4, 191374) This is a reform in the right direction.
('11', 96, 2, 5, 191415) It is worthy of note that Mr. Churchill has drawn a distinction between passive resisters and Suffragettes.
('11', 96, 2, 6, 191523) That is to say, even when the latter may not be classed as passive resisters, as for instance, when they assault the Prime Minister and break windows, etc., to draw attention to their cause, they are not to be treated as common criminals.
('11', 96, 2, 7, 191762) This is a great victory for Mrs. Pankhurst and her followers.
('11', 96, 2, 8, 191824) It is a tardy recognition of a principle to which Mr. Robertson and other well known publicists drew the attention of the British public about a year ago.
('11', 96, 2, 9, 191979) But what about the Transvaal passive resisters?
('11', 96, 2, 10, 192027) Are they less worthy of similar treatment?
('11', 96, 2, 11, 192070) Must they who never use violence, who are perhaps the truest passive resisters, be classed as ordinary convicts undeserving of any consideration whatsoever?
('11', 96, 2, 12, 192227) May not the Imperial Government persuade the new Union Government to copy Mr. Churchill’s reform?
('11', 96, 2, 13, 192325) Or must Mr. Joseph Royeppen, a barrister, who seeks imprisonment for conscience’ sake, be placed on the same footing as a homicide or a burglar?

('11', 97, 1, 2, 193035) 108. REPLY TO “RAND DAILY MAIL” 1
('11', 97, 2, 3, 193069) [JOHANNESBURG,] August 3, 1910
('11', 97, 4, 4, 193100) Will you permit me to correct some statements made in your leading article 2 on Lord Ampthill’s action in the House of Lords 3 on the passive resistance struggle?
('11', 97, 4, 5, 193263) You say that passive resistance commenced after the Govern ment had offered to grant permits for priests, lawyers, doctors, etc., but when 4 they refused to grant anything further.
('11', 97, 4, 6, 193444) May I remind you that passive resistance commenced in 1907 when the question of priests, doctors and lawyers had not come up for public discussion, and when it did arise, it simply arose in order to forcibly illustrate the injustice that had been done by the Government in not conceding the demands of the community, which, as Mr. Patrick Duncan has pointed out, have never varied?
('11', 97, 4, 7, 193826) British Indians have always asked for equality in the eye of the law as to immigration but never for unrestricted immi gration of Asiatics.
('11', 97, 4, 8, 193966) 5 I emphatically deny that British Indians who have been deported have in any large numbers declined to givein formation as to their domicile.
('11', 97, 4, 9, 194109) As a matter of fact, the domicile of most of them was within the knowledge of the Asiatic department and no proof of domicile was necessary in connection with those who had educational attainments, as many had.
('11', 97, 4, 10, 194320) You state, again, that in no instances have cases of harsh treatment in the gaols of the Transvaal been proved by the passive resisters.
('11', 97, 4, 11, 194457) May I inform you and the public that the question of diet, which was a very serious one, was very prominently brought before the Government and the public, and that it is only now that the grievance, I am thankful to say, has been partially remedied.
('11', 97, 4, 12, 194708) That passive resisters who are not criminals in the ordinary sense of the term have been sent to a penal settlement, like Diepkloof, where the ordinary privileges of prisoners are withheld in my opinion is
('11', 97, 5, 13, 194914) 1 This was published in Rand Daily Mail under the title, “Indian Passive Resisters”.
('11', 97, 5, 14, 194999) 2 Of 29th July; Vide Indian Opinion, 6 8 1910. 3 Vide the following item.
('11', 97, 5, 15, 195073) 4 Indian Opinion here has “but they” 5 ibid
('11', 98, 0, 1, 195117) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 99
('11', 98, 1, 2, 195159) undoubtedly a glaring instance of harsh treatment.
('11', 98, 1, 3, 195210) You further state that British Indians are keeping up passive resistance for other than the purpose of having their legitimate demands granted.
('11', 98, 1, 4, 195354) In reply, I can only say that the world has not many men who would suffer, without reasonable cause, privation, starvation, separation from those who may be near and dear to them, etc., besides the loss of their worldly possessions.
('11', 98, 1, 5, 195587) I quite agree with you that, if the demands of the community are granted, they should be granted not in response to passive resistance, but because they are intrinsically just; but I hope you will agree that passive resistance ought not to stand in the way of a strong government doing justice.
('11', 98, 1, 6, 195882) You seem to think that passive resistance means coercion.
('11', 98, 1, 7, 195940) In my humble opinion, the self suffering which the community has undergone, and which has been expressed by the term “passive resistance”, has been undertaken after the methods of petitioning, etc., had been exhausted, and in order to draw public attention to a grievance that was keenly felt and resented by the community.

('11', 98, 5, 11, 196340) 109. TRANSVAAL INDIANS IN THE HOUSE OF LORDS
('11', 98, 6, 12, 196385) Lord Ampthill, who has rendered signal services to the cause of the British Indians in South Africa and, thereby, we venture to think, to the Empire, has again raised the question in the House of Lords.
('11', 98, 7, 13, 196588) Reuter’s cable 2 gives only a summary of Earl Beauchamp’s reply to Lord Ampthill’s query.
('11', 98, 7, 14, 196678) And, if the summary gives a correct version, it shows that the policy of the Transvaal Government of misleading the Imperial Government continues unabated.
('11', 98, 7, 15, 196834) In reply to Lord Amp thill’s protest against the deportations to India, Earl Beauchamp is reported to have said that “Every opportunity would be afforded British Indians to prove domicile in South Africa, but that many absolutely refused to give information.” The fact is that, in most
('11', 98, 8, 16, 197120) 1 On July 26, 1910 2 Dated July 27, from London, reproduced in Indian Opinion, 30 7 1910.
('11', 99, 0, 1, 197210) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 99, 1, 2, 197252) cases, the authorities themselves knew the domicile of the parties concerned, and that, save in one or two cases, they all emphatically declared their domicile.
('11', 99, 1, 3, 197413) It was not possible for them to do more.
('11', 99, 1, 4, 197454) The authorities, however, insisted on production of domicile certificates which many did not possess.
('11', 99, 1, 5, 197556) It is a well known fact that possession of such a certificate is not a legal necessity.
('11', 99, 1, 6, 197644) Some Indians take them out as a measure of protection.
('11', 99, 1, 7, 197699) The authorities knew the case of young Manikum Pillay.
('11', 99, 1, 8, 197754) He was a student in Natal; he could enter the Colony by reason of his education; his father is well known to the Asiatic Department; yet the young man was sent away to India.
('11', 99, 1, 9, 197929) Young Pillay, we understand, gave all the information but it was of no avail.
('11', 99, 1, 10, 198007) The fact that young Pillay and other Indians were deported and, on their return from India, could enter Natal; and the further fact that they are now serving imprisonment at Diepkloof, eloquently demonstrates, as no argument by us could, that the Imperial Government has been hoodwinked by the Transvaal Government.
('11', 99, 1, 11, 198323) Then, again, Earl Beauchamp is reported to have said that the Union Government could not agree to “unrestricted immigration” Indians in the Transvaal have repeatedly declared that they do not want unrestricted immigration.
('11', 99, 1, 12, 198546) Passive Resistance has not been undertaken to bring about any such result.
('11', 99, 1, 13, 198621) Indeed, they know that, if they fought for unrestricted immigration, they would forfeit the generous support given to them by Lord Ampthill and other distinguished statesmen.
('11', 99, 1, 14, 198796) They have received universal sympathy and support outside South Africa only because they have shown that their demands are reasonable, moderate and such that they cannot but be satisfied in the end.
('11', 99, 1, 15, 198995) So far as immigration is concerned, all that they ask for is that there shall not be in law any distinction based on race or colour; that there shall not be an insult offered to Indians as a race, as the present legislation does.

('11', 105, 4, 9, 209020) You should be able to know a cheaper method of sending the vegetables if you went through the tariff book.

('11', 105, 4, 13, 209387) Please explain to them that it would be shameful for those who make big profits to be scared by the paltry cost of freight.
('11', 105, 4, 14, 209511) I have not seen anything sent by Babu Talewant Singh.

('11', 105, 4, 18, 209849) Harilal cannot go to India to escort Chanchi.
('11', 105, 4, 19, 209895) We are poor and cannot spend money like that.
('11', 105, 4, 20, 209941) Moreover, a man who has joined the struggle cannot thus go away for three months.
('11', 105, 4, 21, 210023) There would be nothing wrong if Chanchi goes to India in some good company.
('11', 105, 4, 22, 210099) Many poor women do so.
('11', 105, 4, 23, 210122) We do not want our womenfolk to remain delicate.
('11', 105, 4, 24, 210171) I for one am a farmer and I wish you all to become farmers, or to continue as such if you have already become farmers.
('11', 105, 4, 25, 210290) My way of life has completely changed here.
('11', 105, 4, 26, 210334) The whole day is spent in digging the land and other manual labour instead of in writing and explaining things to people.
('11', 105, 4, 27, 210456) I prefer this work and consider this alone

('11', 106, 1, 2, 210730) to be my duty.

('11', 107, 6, 11, 213274) 118. REPORT OF PROTECTOR OF INDENTURED LABOURERS
('11', 107, 7, 12, 213323) The so called “Protector” of indentured labourers has published his annual report.
('11', 107, 7, 13, 213406) We note its main points elsewhere.
('11', 107, 7, 14, 213441) The report is a matter of disgrace for every thinking Indian.
('11', 107, 7, 15, 213503) How many Indians arrived, how many of them died, what were the causes of death—all this is worth knowing and will be found in the abstract of the report.
('11', 107, 7, 16, 213657) The reply by the “Protector” to Mr. Polak’s vivid account of the sufferings of indentured labourers makes interesting reading.
('11', 107, 7, 17, 213784) It is in fact no reply.
('11', 107, 7, 18, 213808) The “Protector” seems to have assumed the role of “Exploiter”.
('11', 107, 7, 19, 213871) When we thus find that the sea has caught fire, where shall we get the water to quench it?
('11', 107, 7, 20, 213962) What we are seriously exercised over at the moment is this.
('11', 107, 7, 21, 214022) Last year, 2,487 indentured labourers arrived from Madras, including 176 boys and 195 girls of all ages.
('11', 107, 7, 22, 214127) Further, it is stated in the same report that more than 27,000 Indians have been born in Natal.
('11', 107, 7, 23, 214223) What has been the fate of all these boys and girls?
('11', 107, 7, 24, 214275) The Government has shown no interest in this matter.
('11', 107, 7, 25, 214328) The Protector has not a single word to say about
('11', 107, 8, 26, 214377) 1 Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 29 3 1910
('11', 108, 0, 1, 214423) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 109
('11', 108, 1, 2, 214466) The employers of indentured labourers do nothing for them.
('11', 108, 1, 3, 214525) The boys, too, are treated as indentured labourers.
('11', 108, 1, 4, 214577) This is the way cattle are dealt with.
('11', 108, 1, 5, 214616) Do we really treat [even] our cattle in this fashion?
('11', 108, 1, 6, 214670) What this reveals is a state of slavery.
('11', 108, 1, 7, 214711) The boys and girls who arrived last year are ruined both materially and morally.
('11', 108, 1, 8, 214792) Any ruffian may cast his evil eye on them.
('11', 108, 1, 9, 214835) From early morning when the parents go to toil like beasts, these delicate children are left to themselves and those of them who are strong enough for a little work are employed on payment of a paltry 5s.
('11', 108, 1, 10, 215040) Thus, it is sugar made with the blood of indentured labourers that we use for gratifying our palate.
('11', 108, 1, 11, 215141) In spite of this, some of us think that the indentured labourers gain by coming here, that they escape starvation [in India] and find happiness in Natal.
('11', 108, 1, 12, 215295) We would not think of applying this argument to ourselves.
('11', 108, 1, 13, 215354) We would rather prefer to starve than accept the slavery of indenture.
('11', 108, 1, 14, 215425) We would not like to bring up our children in such slavery.
('11', 108, 1, 15, 215485) These boys and girls are left entirely to the mercy of God.
('11', 108, 1, 16, 215545) Any Indian who has faith in religion will see that we join in exploiting this slavery and as a punishment for that sin we, who claim to be free Indians, also become the victims of oppression.
('11', 108, 1, 17, 215737) If only we had a pen and an intellect powerful enough, we would awaken the Indians from their deep slumber and rouse the community to take effective measures to put an immediate stop to the system of indenture.
('11', 108, 1, 18, 215948) This is the right time for it.
('11', 108, 1, 19, 215979) A letter signed by the leaders demanding an immediate end to the system of indenture should be sent to all those who wish to enter the Union Parliament.
('11', 108, 1, 20, 216132) We have no doubt that once indenture is stopped, the hardships of Indians will not take long to disappear.

('11', 111, 3, 13, 221952) 121. THE GRAND OLD MAN OF INDIA
('11', 111, 4, 14, 221984) The first Indian to become a member of the British Parliament was Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji.
('11', 111, 4, 15, 222072) Born on September 4th, 1825, in the city of Bombay, he was educated at the Elphinstone School and College, and was, at the age of 29, made Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy—being the first Indian to receive that honour.
('11', 111, 4, 16, 222306) In 1855, Mr. Naoroji visited England as partner in the first Indian business to be established in that country.
('11', 111, 4, 17, 222418) The University College, London, did him the honour of appointing him Professor of Gujarati; and one of the benefits gained for India by Mr. Naoroji was the admission of Indians to the Civil Service in 1870. He was made Prime Minister of Baroda in 1874, and a year later was elected a member of the Corporation and Municipal Council of Bombay, to which body he gave five years’ valuable service.
('11', 111, 4, 18, 222813) Mr. Naoroji was a member of the Bombay Legislative Council from 1885 to 1887. The Indian National Congress honoured him by electing him President in 1886, 1893, and again in 1906. Mr. Naoroji sat in the House of Commons from 1893 to 1895 as Liberal member for Central Finsbury, London, and he did good work for his country as member of the Royal Commission on Indian Expenditure, etc., and, in 1897, gave evidence before the Welby Commission.
('11', 111, 4, 19, 223256) From the very commencement of the British Committee of the Indian National Congress, he was a diligent member and hard worker.
('11', 111, 4, 20, 223383) Among the publications from the pen of Mr.
('11', 112, 0, 1, 223426) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 113
('11', 112, 1, 2, 223469) Dadabhai Naoroji are: England’s Duty to India, Admission of Educated Natives into the Indian Civil Service, Financial Administration of India, and what is, perhaps, the best known of his many writings, Poverty and Un British Rule in India.
('11', 112, 1, 3, 223709) In 1906, the venerable Dadabhai journeyed to the Motherland to preside over the Indian National Congress, a task which was a tremendous strain upon even his iron constitution and indomitable spirit.
('11', 112, 1, 4, 223908) Since the Calcutta Congress of 1906, Mr. Dadabhai has practically retired from public life, and in 1907 he went to reside at Varsova, a small fishing village in the Bombay Presidency where he still watches with a keen interest the progress of events in India which go to make or mar its future.
('11', 112, 1, 5, 224203) Truly has he earned for himself the honoured title of THE GRAND OLD MAN OF INDIA.
('11', 112, 2, 6, 224285) Indian Opinion, 3 9 1910
('11', 112, 3, 7, 224310) 122. LONG LIVE THE GRAND OLD MAN
('11', 112, 4, 8, 224343) Tomorrow is the 86th birthday of Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, the Grand Old Man of India and the Father of Indian Nationalism.
('11', 112, 4, 9, 224463) Every year brings us nearer the day when we must part with him in the flesh.
('11', 112, 4, 10, 224540) The best honour that we can render him is to imitate him in his noble career and dedicate our all to the service of the Motherland.
('11', 112, 4, 11, 224672) On the first page we give a brief biographical sketch with portrait of the aged patriot.
('11', 112, 5, 12, 224761) Indian Opinion, 3 9 1910

('11', 113, 1, 2, 225553) representative gathering it was.
('11', 113, 1, 3, 225586) Sir Mancherji has forwarded the resolutions 1 to Lords Crewe and Morley.
('11', 113, 1, 4, 225659) Reuter has informed us that the Imperial Government is still in correspondence with the Union Government.
('11', 113, 1, 5, 225765) Mr. Ritch has appealed to General Botha to close the struggle before the Union Parliament meets.
('11', 113, 1, 6, 225862) It now remains to be seen what the next month has in store for passive resisters.
('11', 113, 1, 7, 225944) We confess that before the elections are over, General Botha, whose own fate and that of his fellow ministers hangs in the balance, could take no definite action.
('11', 113, 1, 8, 226107) Meanwhile, passive resisters may take additional courage from the fact that their cause is being very vigilantly watched by Lord Ampthill and his Committee 2 and that the opinion of the Metropolis of the Empire is behind them.
('11', 113, 2, 9, 226334) Indian Opinion, 3 9 1910
('11', 113, 3, 10, 226359) 124. INDENTURED LABOUR
('11', 113, 4, 11, 226382) The Rand Daily Mail has made a most excellent suggestion to the effect that the voters should ask every candidate to pledge himself to the immediate stoppage of indentured labour from India.
('11', 113, 4, 12, 226573) So long as that blot remains, it is very much like straining at a gnat and swallowing a camel to persecute a few Indians out of the Transvaal Province.
('11', 113, 4, 13, 226725) Whatever may be the motives of the Rand Daily Mail in urging total prohibition of indentured labour, no Indian can have any difficulty in agreeing with its conclusions.

('11', 114, 1, 2, 227706) labour, thus writes in the course of a letter to the Rand Daily Mail, in reply to that paper’s leading article urging entire prohibition of indentured labour:
('11', 114, 2, 3, 227865) One fact was forced upon the attention of the Commission, namely, the Natal born Indian is useless as a worker; he will play football, sell newspapers or do low class office work but he will not undertake anything of the nature of labour.
('11', 114, 2, 4, 228104) It was admitted by educated Indians that primary education made the Natal born Indian useless in the labour market.
('11', 114, 2, 5, 228220) Agriculture had nothing to hope from him.
('11', 114, 2, 6, 228262) Indians know Mr. Haggar too well to take him seriously.
('11', 114, 2, 7, 228318) His unproved charges against the community have not yet been forgotten.
('11', 114, 2, 8, 228390) But sometimes we do learn a great deal even from our avowed opponents.
('11', 114, 2, 9, 228461) The statement that we have quoted above is not without a modicum of truth in it.
('11', 114, 2, 10, 228542) Curiously enough, we have just received from a correspondent a letter inviting us to open our columns regularly for Indian sporting news.
('11', 114, 2, 11, 228680) We have nothing against sport as such.
('11', 114, 2, 12, 228719) And, if our columns were not almost solely devoted to the cause of the Indian struggle in South Africa, and if we had enough support from the sporting Indians, we would not be unprepared to set apart a portion for regular sporting news.
('11', 114, 2, 13, 228956) But we ask our young friends whether sport should occupy so much of their time and attention as it does now.
('11', 114, 2, 14, 229065) Indeed, those Indians who know what is going on around them, cannot afford to be in a sporting mood.
('11', 114, 2, 15, 229166) Our forefathers did wonderfully well without the fashionable sport of today.
('11', 114, 2, 16, 229243) Sport indulged in for the sake of developing the body is of some use.
('11', 114, 2, 17, 229313) But we venture to suggest that agriculture, the inherited occupation of Indians—indeed of the human race—is better sport than football, cricket and all other games put together.
('11', 114, 2, 18, 229491) And it is useful, dignified and remunerative.
('11', 114, 2, 19, 229537) Football and cricket may be well for those who have the drudgery of the desk work to go through from day to day.
('11', 114, 2, 20, 229650) But no Indian need undertake that task.
('11', 114, 2, 21, 229690) We therefore advise our young sporting friends to take Mr. Haggar’s remarks in good part and leave the contemptible work of clerks, newspaper sellers, etc., for the independent and manly field work.
('11', 114, 2, 22, 229889) They have before them the brilliant example of Mr. Joseph Royeppen who, though a barrister, took up hawking and latterly did manual work on the Passive Resistance Farm 1. Indian Opinion, 3 9 1910

('11', 115, 1, 2, 230142) 126. MEETING IN ENGLAND
('11', 115, 2, 3, 230166) We have now received a report of the meeting held in England concerning the Transvaal struggle, as also of the discussion raised by Lord Ampthill in the House of Lords.
('11', 115, 2, 4, 230335) Both these developments should prove very encouraging to us.
('11', 115, 2, 5, 230396) The meeting was presided over by Sir Mancherji Bhownaggree.
('11', 115, 2, 6, 230456) He has been helping us right from the beginning.
('11', 115, 2, 7, 230505) It was therefore but fitting that he should be in the chair.
('11', 115, 2, 8, 230566) The messages which the meeting received from Justice Ameer Ali and Sir Charles Bruce were noteworthy.
('11', 115, 2, 9, 230668) The meeting was attended by leaders of all parties and communities.
('11', 115, 2, 10, 230736) Their speeches, too, were powerfully stirring.
('11', 115, 2, 11, 230783) We can gather from all this that the movement is receiving good support in England.
('11', 115, 2, 12, 230867) But that support is of far less consequence than our own strength.
('11', 115, 2, 13, 230934) And if we have no strength in ourselves, the support [we have been receiving] in England will only argue our weakness.
('11', 115, 2, 14, 231053) If Lord Ampthill has been fighting [for us], if Sir Mancherji has been striving hard and Mr. Ritch has been working indefatigably, that is due, in fact, to their belief that we submit ourselves to suffering, that we have embraced poverty in the cause of the motherland, that we have staked our all for our honour.
('11', 115, 2, 15, 231367) For the success of this meeting, it is to Mr. Ritch and his army of volunteers that congratulations are due.

('11', 115, 7, 20, 231564) Bhadarva Shud 1 [September 4, 1910] 1
('11', 115, 8, 21, 231602) CHHAGANLAL,
('11', 115, 9, 22, 231614) I write this with a heavy heart.
('11', 115, 9, 23, 231647) I constantly think your going to India has been a mistake.
('11', 115, 10, 24, 231706) 1 This letter was written during the addressee’s absence from South Africa in 1910.
('11', 116, 0, 1, 231790) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 117
('11', 116, 1, 2, 231833) I was deeply pained to read your letter to Doctor [Mehta].
('11', 116, 1, 3, 231892) How can I bear your contracting tuberculosis?
('11', 116, 1, 4, 231938) I write this under the impression that you are still there [in England].
('11', 116, 1, 5, 232011) Maud 1 will redirect this to you if you have left for India.
('11', 116, 2, 6, 232072) Please do as you think fit.
('11', 116, 2, 7, 232100) Treat the following simply as a piece of advice from me.
('11', 116, 2, 8, 232157) I wish to see your health improved.
('11', 116, 3, 9, 232193) Considering only your health, I feel that the best thing for you would be to go to Phoenix.
('11', 116, 3, 10, 232285) You will get fresh air there.
('11', 116, 3, 11, 232315) You will also be able to work on the farm, which is good for a tuberculosis patient.
('11', 116, 3, 12, 232400) Moreover, I hope to be able to assist and nurse you.
('11', 116, 3, 13, 232453) This will be possible only if you are at Phoenix.
('11', 116, 3, 14, 232503) And, God willing, you can stay on this Farm too.
('11', 116, 3, 15, 232552) The climate here is even better than that of Phoenix.
('11', 116, 3, 16, 232606) Brahmacharya, which is necessary for a patient like you, can easily be observed here.
('11', 116, 3, 17, 232692) I therefore think it will be better if you come over here.
('11', 116, 3, 18, 232751) You can go back to India if your health does not improve here.
('11', 116, 3, 19, 232814) Should you be keen on going to India, I have written to Doctor [Mehta] to send you Rs. .
('11', 116, 3, 20, 232903) 2 every month.
('11', 116, 3, 21, 232918) Even otherwise, you may stay in Bombay and do some public work there under my guidance.
('11', 116, 3, 22, 233006) Your main work will relate to the struggle here.
('11', 116, 3, 23, 233055) By doing this you will be free from worry about your livelihood and you can easily pass your life in public service.
('11', 116, 3, 24, 233172) Whether you are ill or well, I wish your life is spent in the service of the country.
('11', 116, 4, 25, 233258) Many things come to mind about which I should write, but I do not feel like doing so.
('11', 116, 4, 26, 233344) My suggestion about your coming over here stands even if you have already reached India.
('11', 116, 4, 27, 233433) In case you do not feel inclined to come here, my suggestion regarding Doctor [Mehta] is there for you to consider.
('11', 116, 5, 28, 233549) However, even if neither of these alternatives is acceptable to you and you want to live independently on your own earnings, be sure that I would not come in your way.
('11', 116, 5, 29, 233717) My only desire is that you should take the course that will give you most satisfaction.
('11', 116, 6, 30, 233805) I shall be waiting for your letter during the next week like a

('11', 117, 6, 8, 234407) In this case, too, the magistrate decided against the boy.
('11', 117, 6, 9, 234466) In all probability, both these cases will go to the Supreme Court.
('11', 117, 7, 10, 234533) STATEMENTS OF GENERAL BOTHA AND OTHERS
('11', 117, 8, 11, 234572) I have sent for the English section the statements 2 of General Smuts, General Botha and de Villiers bearing on this question.
('11', 117, 8, 12, 234699) All three have referred to the position of minors in their speeches or written about it, but none of them has stated anywhere that a child, on attaining majority, can be expelled.
('11', 117, 8, 13, 234879) General Botha, in his written statement, has mentioned that the Government had accepted the Asiatics’ demand in regard to minors.
('11', 117, 8, 14, 235009) General Smuts has said the same thing in his speech.
('11', 117, 8, 15, 235062) The Asiatics never, even in their dreams, thought of agreeing to the expulsion of minors, and none of the three persons mentioned above has claimed that they have so agreed.
('11', 117, 8, 16, 235236) It is only now that the Transvaal Government has begun to put an arbitrary construction on the law.
('11', 117, 9, 17, 235336) [From Gujarati]

('11', 117, 11, 19, 235378) 129. MR. CHHOTABHAI’S CASE
('11', 117, 12, 20, 235405) The case of Mr. Chhotabhai’s son, already reported in these columns, 4 is a most important one.
('11', 117, 12, 21, 235501) It affects the well being of the
('11', 117, 13, 22, 235534) 1 A bird which is supposed to drink only the water that falls from the sky.
('11', 117, 13, 23, 235610) 2 Vide Appendix, ”Transvaal Ministers’ Declaration”, 9 10 1910. 3 Vide “Another Breach of Faith!”, 30 7 1910. 4 Vide “Transvaal Notes”, Indian Opinion, 27 8 1910.
('11', 118, 0, 1, 235773) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 119
('11', 118, 1, 2, 235816) whole Indian community in the Transvaal.
('11', 118, 1, 3, 235857) Analogous to it is also the case of the son of Mr. Tayob Hajee Khan Mahomed.
('11', 118, 1, 4, 235934) If their sons, who entered the Transvaal as minors, cannot remain in that Province, hundreds of Indian parents may be obliged to leave the Transvaal.
('11', 118, 1, 5, 236084) For we cannot imagine these Indian parents in the Transvaal would be inhuman enough to remain in that country if their sons, artificially declared to be majors at the age of 16, are to be deported to India without their natural protectors.
('11', 118, 1, 6, 236324) Parents have taken their babies to the Transvaal but, after the passing of the Act of 1908, assuming that these babies are never sent to India until after they have reached the age of 16, and that both the parents are in the Transvaal, where is the lad now 16 years to be deported to?
('11', 118, 1, 7, 236609) Assuming, further, that a child is born to Transvaal Indian parents on the high seas, where is this child, if male, to be deported after he reaches the Transvaal age of majority?
('11', 118, 1, 8, 236788) One would have thought that the Transvaal Government would have stood appalled by the highly probable consequences of their interpretation of the Act.
('11', 118, 1, 9, 236939) But, apart from the purely humanitarian standpoint suggested above, we quote elsewhere General Smuts’ speech 1 on the introduction of the then Asiatic Bill, General Botha’s minute 2 on the Asiatic Conference and Mr. de Villiers’ (the then Attorney General’s) report 3 on the Asiatic Act.
('11', 118, 1, 10, 237227) All these documents show that there was then not a word said about the exclusion of minor Asiatics not born in the Transvaal entering after the commencement of the Act.
('11', 118, 1, 11, 237396) Indeed, they all say that the Asiatic demand in this respect has been completely met.
('11', 118, 1, 12, 237482) The Asiatics never suspected that their minor children might be treated as prohibited immigrants on reaching the age of majority.
('11', 118, 1, 13, 237612) Whatever may be the interpretation of the Act, there is the pledged word of three Ministers at stake.
('11', 118, 1, 14, 237714) The question is too important to be left where the Supreme Court may leave it, assuming that its decision is adverse.
('11', 118, 1, 15, 237832) We have no desire to anticipate its judgment, but this we cannot help saying, that it is a matter of life and death for the Indians in the Transvaal.
('11', 118, 1, 16, 237982) We wish we could say that it would be a matter of honour with the people of the Transvaal, indeed of the whole of South Africa.
('11', 118, 1, 17, 238110) Will the humanity of the South Africans tolerate what is a war against infants?

('11', 119, 1, 2, 238336) 130. MESSRS RITCH AND POLAK
('11', 119, 2, 3, 238364) According to the cables published in the Press, Messrs Ritch and Polak will soon be among us.
('11', 119, 2, 4, 238458) These two friends of the community in South Africa have worked, laboured and slaved for us as few of our own countrymen have.
('11', 119, 2, 5, 238584) They have identified themselves entirely with our cause.
('11', 119, 2, 6, 238641) They have indeed been friends in need.
('11', 119, 2, 7, 238680) It is difficult, if at all possible, to compare the work of the two.
('11', 119, 2, 8, 238749) Each has done his best in his own special department.
('11', 119, 2, 9, 238803) Mr. Ritch is the soul of Lord Ampthill’s Committee.
('11', 119, 2, 10, 238855) Mr. Polak’s magnificent work received a public recognition at Bombay when Professor Gokhale presented him with a silver tea set.
('11', 119, 2, 11, 238984) 1 It was no exaggeration when the honourable gentleman attributed to Mr. Polak the memorable collection of over £6,000 for assisting passive resisters.
('11', 119, 2, 12, 239136) We trust that both Messrs Ritch and Polak will receive from the community such receptions as no other men have received at our hands.
('11', 119, 2, 13, 239270) They deserve it.

('11', 119, 4, 15, 239313) 131. SUGGESTION TO INDIANS
('11', 119, 5, 16, 239340) We shall know on September 15 who is to rule in South Africa in the immediate future.
('11', 119, 5, 17, 239426) Will it be General Botha or Mr. Merriman or Dr. Jameson?
('11', 119, 5, 18, 239483) In all probability, it will be General Botha.
('11', 119, 5, 19, 239529) Every Indian must have realized by now that General Botha is not likely to be won over by flattery.
('11', 119, 5, 20, 239629) A fire is raging all round the Indians.
('11', 119, 5, 21, 239669) In some parts of America, a forest catches fire and that fire cannot be put out.
('11', 119, 5, 22, 239750) Troops go out to quench it, but even they find it a most difficult task.
('11', 119, 5, 23, 239823) Hundreds of men are burnt to death.
('11', 119, 5, 24, 239859) Neighbouring villages are razed to the ground.
('11', 119, 5, 25, 239906) A similar fire is raging round the Indians in South Africa.
('11', 119, 5, 26, 239966) But we have not yet taken the warning.
('11', 119, 5, 27, 240005) This shows our apathy and our selfishness.
('11', 119, 5, 28, 240048) In Cape Town, thanks to the efforts of Dr. Abdurahman and his friends, Indian trading licences were not touched so far.
('11', 119, 5, 29, 240168) But that has now changed.
('11', 119, 5, 30, 240194) The Town Council has refused to grant any licences in certain areas.
('11', 119, 5, 31, 240263) Mr. Alexander was the only one to oppose this.
('11', 119, 5, 32, 240310) Mr. Liebermann, who was once on our side, said that his eyes had opened
('11', 119, 6, 33, 240382) 1 Vide “Farewell Dinner in Bombay”, Indian Opinion, 3 9 1910.
('11', 120, 0, 1, 240444) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 121
('11', 120, 1, 2, 240487) after the report of the Chamber of Commerce.
('11', 120, 1, 3, 240532) Others, too, spoke to the same effect, with the result that no licences were granted.
('11', 120, 1, 4, 240618) Though the Natal Act has been amended, a man like Mr. Goga did not get a licence [for trading] on his own premises in Ladysmith.
('11', 120, 2, 5, 240747) We find the same kind of high handed treatment in Estcourt, too.
('11', 120, 3, 6, 240812) About the Transvaal, the less said the better.
('11', 120, 3, 7, 240859) There, those who have submitted to the law continue to get licences, but this will not last long.
('11', 120, 3, 8, 240957) In what is described as the gold area, no licences are issued.
('11', 120, 3, 9, 241020) Else where, too, if they can, on some other ground, refuse a licence, they certainly do so.
('11', 120, 3, 10, 241112) Indian businessmen should note that after the Union Parliament is formed, trading licences will come under heavy fire.
('11', 120, 3, 11, 241231) What are we doing, meanwhile?
('11', 120, 3, 12, 241261) First, We must say with regret, we waste our time in idleness or pleasure seeking.
('11', 120, 3, 13, 241344) Secondly, once our own end is served, we show little concern for others.
('11', 120, 3, 14, 241417) Thirdly, we are vindictive and fight among ourselves.
('11', 120, 3, 15, 241471) Fourthly, sometimes there are quarrels between Hindus and Muslims on issues both small and big; and when they are not fighting with each other, they as well as the Muslims are busy quarrelling among themselves.
('11', 120, 3, 16, 241682) Thus, everyone goes his own way, unmindful of the others.
('11', 120, 3, 17, 241740) If there were no fire raging round us, perhaps we would not have much to say against these selfish and otherwise unseemly ways— no one, in any case, would listen to what we might say.
('11', 120, 3, 18, 241924) A little reflection will show to Indians that, if every person looked to his own immediate interest, all of them would be in trouble before long.
('11', 120, 3, 19, 242070) We should not have to point out that the interests of the community comprehend those of every individual Indian.
('11', 120, 3, 20, 242183) We believe they will lay hands first on the traders.
('11', 120, 3, 21, 242236) Some Indians may imagine that traders can escape harassment if they keep aloof from other Indians.
('11', 120, 3, 22, 242335) That this is mere short sightedness is plain enough.
('11', 120, 3, 23, 242388) Right from the time that the movement against the Indians started, the whites have had their eyes on their trade.
('11', 120, 3, 24, 242502) It is the traders alone whom they harass.
('11', 120, 3, 25, 242544) True, some selfish whites, wishing us to chop off our feet, do advise the traders that they will be saved if they dissociate themselves from the others.
('11', 120, 3, 26, 242697) Some say, again, that they will have no difficulty to face, if they do not get involved in the affairs of others.
('11', 120, 3, 27, 242811) Everyone is told the same thing.
('11', 120, 3, 28, 242844) Should we conclude from this
('11', 120, 4, 29, 242873) 1 Vide “Indians under the Union”, 13 8 1910 2 ibid
('11', 121, 0, 1, 242924) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 121, 1, 2, 242966) that there would be difficulties for no one?
('11', 121, 1, 3, 243011) The truth of the matter is that, if they can ruin us by soft words or baits, they would prefer to do it that way.
('11', 121, 1, 4, 243125) Failing that, they will adopt other means.
('11', 121, 1, 5, 243168) There is only one simple way in the face of this snare, and that is to be alert and shake off our apathy, to get rid of our selfishness and our internal quarrels, and to adopt all necessary measures.

('11', 122, 4, 7, 245404) 133. A PRAYER TO THE KING EMPEROR
('11', 122, 5, 8, 245438) The Indian South African League has taken a bold step in sending a cable 1 to the King Emperor praying for His Majesty’s gracious intervention on behalf of the passive resisters in the Transvaal.
('11', 122, 5, 9, 245634) The cablegram as also Mr. Natesan’s spirited letter to the Madras Mail, extracts from which we reproduce elsewhere, shows that the feeling on the question runs high in that Presidency.
('11', 122, 5, 10, 245819) Indeed, Mr. Bennett, the proprietor of The Times of India, said that no question stirred the people of India so much as the question of the sufferings of the Indians in South Africa.
('11', 122, 5, 11, 246002) Now The Times writer confirms the statement.
('11', 122, 5, 12, 246047) 2 It is on rare occasions that personal appeals are made to the sovereign.
('11', 122, 5, 13, 246122) We shall not have to wait long before we learn what answer has been returned to the prayer of the League.
('11', 122, 5, 14, 246228) Whatever the answer, it is most satisfactory to learn that the passive resisters have the full and active sympathy of those for whose honour they are fighting.

('11', 122, 7, 16, 246414) 134. EFFECTIVENESS OF THE STRUGGLE
('11', 122, 8, 17, 246449) We hear it being said by many that the Transvaal agitation has no force left.
('11', 122, 8, 18, 246527) We have repeated, time and again, that so long as at least one person remains to continue satyagraha, we may rest confident that victory will be ours.
('11', 122, 8, 19, 246678) That is the only test of satyagraha.
('11', 122, 8, 20, 246715) During this week two telegrams have been received which lend

('11', 123, 1, 2, 246959) support to our view.
('11', 123, 1, 3, 246980) In one of them, we note that the League 1 in Madras, which has been helping us, has addressed a cable 2 to the King Emperor about the deportees arriving there and prayed for his intervention.
('11', 123, 1, 4, 247172) In England, The Times has been publishing a series of articles on the current unrest in India, in which it is pointed out that the sufferings of India are a disgrace to British rule.
('11', 123, 1, 5, 247355) We can see from these two developments that the Transvaal struggle remains as effective as ever.
('11', 123, 1, 6, 247452) Efforts continue to be made on our behalf from every side.
('11', 123, 1, 7, 247511) Even a person like Mr. Merriman, while speaking on the problem, was obliged to speak out in our favour.
('11', 123, 1, 8, 247615) Commenting on his views, The Transvaal Leader, too, asks for justice.
('11', 123, 1, 9, 247685) This support that we are getting should encourage us and strengthen the weak.
('11', 123, 1, 10, 247763) But at the same time we should like to point out that satyagraha does not require encouragement from others.
('11', 123, 1, 11, 247872) It is like a razor’s edge.
('11', 123, 1, 12, 247899) He who would walk on it does not pause to think of ways of securing help from others.

('11', 124, 3, 5, 248827) He conveyed to the audience an idea of the great strength of the struggle in spite of the fact that only a handful of satyagrahis were participating in it.
('11', 124, 3, 6, 248983) He stressed how important it was for the entire Indian community at Durban to give rousing receptions and banquets to the deportees when they landed at Durban, as the latter were soldiers fighting for the sake of the entire Indian community.

('11', 125, 2, 4, 250765) 139. JUDGMENT IN BOY’S CASE
('11', 125, 3, 5, 250793) Justice Wessels’ judgment has gone against Mr. Chhotabhai’s son.
('11', 125, 3, 6, 250858) If this judgment stands, the Indian community will find itself in a hopeless situation and be uprooted before long.
('11', 125, 3, 7, 250974) An appeal has been filed.
('11', 125, 3, 8, 251000) Its result will be known within only two or three days of the publication of this comment.
('11', 125, 3, 9, 251091) Let the appeal court’s decision be what it may; we are little concerned with it.
('11', 125, 3, 10, 251172) We give elsewhere a report of the case in Justice Wessels’ Court.
('11', 125, 3, 11, 251238) It is worth studying.
('11', 125, 3, 12, 251260) He has stated that the Government’s attitude is unjust and inhuman and that, if it is persisted in, there will be a howl against it throughout the civilized world.
('11', 125, 3, 13, 251424) We are watching what the civilized world has to say.
('11', 125, 3, 14, 251477) There is no doubt, however, that the Government, as pointed out by the judge, acted with great severity.
('11', 125, 3, 15, 251582) If that is so, why did he give judgment against the boy?
('11', 125, 3, 16, 251639) This question will occur to everyone.
('11', 125, 3, 17, 251677) It shows up the degrading position of present day courts.
('11', 125, 3, 18, 251735) They may dispense injustice instead of justice.
('11', 125, 3, 19, 251783) It is considered justice on the part of a court if its judgment follows the letter of the law, when this is in conflict with the spirit of justice.
('11', 125, 3, 20, 251931) In other words, an action which Justice Wessels, the man, pronounces unjust is upheld by him as just in his capacity as a judge.
('11', 125, 3, 21, 252060) We cannot submit to such justice or injustice.
('11', 125, 3, 22, 252107) It is necessary to call meetings everywhere and pass resolutions about this.
('11', 125, 3, 23, 252184) We cannot rest till the matter is settled satisfactorily.
('11', 125, 3, 24, 252242) A perusal of the judgment and the report will show that, even under the Act of 1907, children born outside the Transvaal are not entitled to enter it.
('11', 125, 3, 25, 252393) Mr. Gregorowski fought hard on this point but Justice Wessels was emphatic that such boys were not protected under the Act of 1907. [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 24 9 1910

('11', 125, 5, 27, 252620) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE, If you go on as you are the tables will be turned and I shall have to be the Lower House.

('11', 126, 1, 5, 252909) Then why am I not joining you there?
('11', 126, 1, 6, 252946) My answer is in the language of the Bhagavad Gita that although my work is less than yours, my duty just now lies in that direction.

('11', 128, 1, 2, 256040) 143. INDENTURED INDIANS’ PLIGHT
('11', 128, 2, 3, 256072) We believe that, if we had not been alert and had not raised a protest, the account which appears in The [Natal] Mercury under the title ‘Spotted Fever’ would not have come out.
('11', 128, 2, 4, 256250) The facts are as follows: Some indentured Indians arrived by the Umhloti at the beginning of this month.
('11', 128, 2, 5, 256355) These Indians were brought from India specially for Sir Liege Hulett.
('11', 128, 2, 6, 256425) An epidemic of spotted fever broke out among them, as a result of which several Indians were reported to have died.
('11', 128, 2, 7, 256541) On hearing of this, we addressed an inquiry to the “Protector” of Indians, to which we received an evasive reply.
('11', 128, 2, 8, 256655) We wrote again.
('11', 128, 2, 9, 256671) In reply, we were asked to refer to the Mercury.
('11', 128, 2, 10, 256720) The account in the Mercury 1 did not satisfy us.
('11', 128, 2, 11, 256769) In fact, it was the duty of the “Protector” to give us full information.
('11', 128, 2, 12, 256842) But we shall not say anything about this rudeness on his part.
('11', 128, 2, 13, 256905) It appears from the report in the Mercury, which is, in fact, the “Protector’s” own report, that the gentleman is not concerned about the welfare of those who are placed under his protection.
('11', 128, 2, 14, 257097) He is only worried lest spotted fever should break out among Europeans.
('11', 128, 2, 15, 257169) He says that there is no reason to entertain such a fear.
('11', 128, 2, 16, 257227) Moreover, lest the flow of indentured Indian labour should stop if it were to get known that such epidemics occurred only among indentured Indians, he has put out the report in such skilful language that it would apply to all Indians.
('11', 128, 2, 17, 257462) In point of fact, however, there is seldom any such epidemic among Indians other than indentured labourers.
('11', 128, 2, 18, 257570) He has given no information as to how many indentured labourers had set out, by whom they were to be employed, how many of them fell ill, and the present whereabouts of those who did not fall ill.
('11', 128, 2, 19, 257767) We shall not allow this matter to rest here.
('11', 128, 2, 20, 257812) It is necessary to pursue it to the end.
('11', 128, 2, 21, 257853) We hope that the Congress will take it up.
('11', 128, 2, 22, 257896) Further, the “Protector” has stated that this disease makes its appearance in surroundings which are not cleaned for long periods and are shut out from sunlight and air.
('11', 128, 2, 23, 258066) Well, the epidemic broke out on board a ship and there the supervision and the responsibility are those of the “Protector” or his agent.
('11', 128, 2, 24, 258203) Why did he allow people to remain in filthy, dark and unventilated surroundings?
('11', 128, 2, 25, 258284) It is quite plain that the blame for this lies entirely with the “Protector”.
('11', 128, 2, 26, 258362) Only those
('11', 128, 3, 27, 258373) 1 This and the letters and the replies referred to herein were published in Indian Opinion, 1 10 1910.

('11', 131, 4, 6, 262462) 148. INTERVIEW TO REUTER AND S. A. PRESS AGENCY 1
('11', 131, 5, 7, 262512) VOLKSRUST, [Friday, October 7, 1910]
('11', 131, 6, 8, 262549) M. K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian community in Johannesburg, who had been to Durban to meet Mr. Polak, secretary of the British Indian Association, passed through Volksrust on his return to the Rand by the up mail yesterday evening.
('11', 131, 6, 9, 262783) To the surprise of all, no arrest was made.
('11', 131, 6, 10, 262827) 2 This is strange, because Gandhi had no permit.
('11', 131, 7, 11, 262876) I interviewed Gandhi who said he had burned his permit two years ago in company with about 2,500 Indians in Johannesburg, when, as the Indians contended, the Government failed to carry out its promise to repeal the Asiatic Act of 1907. 3
('11', 131, 8, 12, 263114) Gandhi stated that he himself could not understand why he was allowed to pass unchallenged, while his son with thirty other resisters who will pass through Volksrust this (Saturday) evening will doubtless be arrested.
('11', 131, 8, 13, 263332) The Indian community’s demands were so reasonable that it was difficult to understand why they were not granted.
('11', 131, 8, 14, 263445) They did not want an unrestricted influx of Asiatics.
('11', 131, 8, 15, 263499) All they said was that Indians should not be restricted because they were Indians.
('11', 131, 8, 16, 263582) The Immigration Law could impose a stiff educational test so as to prevent the entry of all but a few highly educated Indians into the Transvaal province.
('11', 131, 9, 17, 263737) Gandhi said he had not yet heard anybody objecting to such a proposal.
('11', 131, 9, 18, 263808) However, so long as this very simple point was not granted the determined passive resistance would continue.
('11', 131, 9, 19, 263917) In conclusion he indignantly repudiated the suggestion that the passive resisters had anything to do with the cases of forged permits which were tried at the Circuit Court in Volksrust on September 26.

('11', 132, 1, 2, 264342) 149. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 132, 2, 3, 264360) CHHOTABHAI CASE
('11', 132, 3, 4, 264376) We have now received the report of the hearing of the appeal 1 in this case.
('11', 132, 3, 5, 264453) The case was argued at great length.
('11', 132, 3, 6, 264490) The bench consisted of Mr. de Villiers, Mr. Mason and Mr. Bristowe.
('11', 132, 3, 7, 264558) Mr. Gregorowski argued hard, and the exchange of arguments between him and the judges showed that the latter’s sympathy was on the side of Mr. Chhotabhai.
('11', 132, 3, 8, 264713) This time, too, the discussion related both to the Act of 1907 and that of 1909 2. Mr. Justice Mason went so far as to observe that the law could not indirectly deprive the boy of the rights which he enjoyed prior to 1907. Mr. Justice Bristowe, commenting on Mr. Chamney’s affidavit, said that they could not rely on his opinion in deciding whether or not Mr. Chhotabhai should be treated as a resident of the Transvaal.
('11', 132, 3, 9, 265134) What [he asked] could Mr. Chamney know about the matter?

('11', 133, 3, 7, 266673) 151. ADDRESS TO H. S. L. POLAK 1
('11', 133, 4, 8, 266706) JOHANNESBURG, October 9, 1910
('11', 133, 5, 9, 266736) DEAR SIR,
('11', 133, 6, 10, 266746) On behalf of the Association we heartily welcome you back among us.
('11', 133, 6, 11, 266814) We have closely watched your mission in India, and every Indian recognises that the magnificent work done by you in India shows that no better choice could possibly have been made.
('11', 133, 6, 12, 266995) You have with unexampled energy informed the whole of India of the true position in this Province.
('11', 133, 6, 13, 267094) The collection made in India for the relief of indigent passive resister families and for helping the passive resistance struggle generally is a magnificent record.
('11', 133, 6, 14, 267259) The whole of the Indian community in South Africa is interested in the stoppage of indentured labour, and your work in that connection fills us with hope that the cruel system will soon cease.
('11', 133, 6, 15, 267452) We shall never forget the sacrifices that you and Mrs. Polak have made in accepting separation from each other for the sake of the cause.
('11', 133, 6, 16, 267590) We trust that both you and yours will be long spared to

('11', 134, 6, 11, 268496) He has shown the Indian demand to be quite reasonable.

('11', 135, 4, 10, 270133) 153. EXTRACT FROM LETTER TO S. A. B. I. COMMITTEE
('11', 135, 5, 11, 270183) [JOHANNESBURG, After October 16, 1910] 2
('11', 135, 6, 12, 270224) You will be deeply pained to hear that one more death among passive resisters has occurred.
('11', 135, 6, 13, 270316) The man who died, by name A. Narayansamy, was one of those who returned with Mr. Polak from India and who was not allowed to land in Durban.
('11', 135, 6, 14, 270457) He proceeded, together with 31 others, to Port Elizabeth, and thence to Cape Town, where his landing, as also that of others, was prevented, and he was obliged to return to Durban, with the prospect of being ultimately sent back to India.
('11', 135, 6, 15, 270696) Mr. Ritch says that he and the other passive resisters were left without boots, hats, and even without sufficient clothing for the body, their clothes having been stolen at Port Elizabeth.
('11', 135, 6, 16, 270885) But for the charity of the local Indians at Cape Town, they might have gone back to Durban without food.
('11', 135, 6, 17, 270990) These men have been continuously on board now under exceptionally severe circumstances for nearly two months.
('11', 135, 6, 18, 271100) It is not at all surprising, therefore, that poor Narayansamy has succumbed.
('11', 135, 6, 19, 271177) I do not consider this a death in the ordinary course.
('11', 135, 6, 20, 271232) It is undoubtedly a legalised murder.
('11', 135, 7, 21, 271270) India, 18 11 1910
('11', 135, 8, 22, 271288) 1 October 15. Polak who had arrived in Johannesburg on October 9, had evidently gone out again during the week.
('11', 135, 8, 23, 271400) 2 Narayansamy, referred to in the letter, died on 16 10 1910.
