('11', 136, 1, 2, 271505) 154. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('11', 136, 2, 3, 271532) JOHANNESBURG, October 17, 1910
('11', 136, 3, 4, 271563) SIR, Most of the newspapers published a telegram from Pretoria some days ago to the effect that at last the Asiatic question that has agitated the Colony for the last four years was about to be satisfactorily settled.
('11', 136, 3, 5, 271781) This news was supposed to be officially inspired, but was immediately followed by the arrest of one of the staunchest and best respected Indians in this province, namely Mr. Sorabji, and his arrest was followed by that of three of his co passive resisters, equally brave, that is, Messrs Thambi Naidoo, Sodha and Medh.
('11', 136, 3, 6, 272100) I should, however, not have trespassed upon your courtesy and the attention of the public in order merely to give the above information.
('11', 136, 3, 7, 272237) But, in my humble opinion, it is due to the public to know something of the trials of those Indians and Chinese who, although lawful residents of the Transvaal, and some of them born in South Africa, were deported to India and returned per s.
('11', 136, 3, 8, 272480) Sultan about the end of last month.
('11', 136, 3, 9, 272516) The tragedy has culminated in the death of a most inoffensive and law abiding Indian named Narayansamy.
('11', 136, 3, 10, 272620) When he left this province for India as a deportee, he possessed a healthy constitution, but over six weeks on the decks of different steamers exposed to all sorts of weather evidently proved too severe for his constitution.
('11', 136, 3, 11, 272845) Mr. Ritch has pointed out that he and his fellow deportees were not allowed to see friends or legal advisers almost for a week while their steamer was in Table Bay, and ultimately he had to obtain an order from the Supreme Court before he could see tham.
('11', 136, 3, 12, 273100) He has stated in a letter to the Cape papers that he found these men bootless and hatless and in some cases even without sufficient protection for the body, shivering on the open deck of that steamer.
('11', 136, 3, 13, 273301) They were refused landing first at Durban, then at Port Elizabeth, then at the Cape, and again at Durban, the last time in defiance of an order of the Supreme
('11', 136, 4, 14, 273460) 1 This was published in Rand Daily Mail under the title “Death of a Deportee”, and in Indian Opinion, 22 10 1910, as a letter to the Press.
('11', 136, 4, 15, 273600) It was published also in The Transvaal Leader of October 18, 1910.
('11', 137, 0, 1, 273667) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 137, 1, 2, 273709) Court restraining the Immigration Officer from removing them from the jurisdiction of the Provincial Division of Natal.
('11', 137, 1, 3, 273829) The Officer, acting under instructions from the Minister of the Interior, and in his over zeal to please his chief, gave a meaning to the order of the Court which no common sense man would give, and in indecent haste sent these men to Delagoa Bay with the result that, as above stated, Narayansamy is no more.
('11', 137, 1, 4, 274139) I have not hesitated to call the death of the late Nagappan legalized murder, and I fear that the death of Narayansamy must be classed in the same category.
('11', 137, 1, 5, 274296) I have the warrant of our own Court for stating that deportation such as Narayansamy’s under an administrative order, described by Mr. Laughton, K.C., as “Star Chamber procedure”, is illegal.
('11', 137, 1, 6, 274488) Narayansamy and his fellows, very properly, as I think every lover of justice and fair play would say, disregard such deportation, attempt to return to the country of their birth or adoption and, in the attempt, are driven from pillar to post.
('11', 137, 1, 7, 274732) Inconceivable difficulties are placed in their way.
('11', 137, 1, 8, 274784) Is such treatment necessary?
('11', 137, 1, 9, 274813) Passive resisters are told that they must not complain if they find their lot to be hard whilst they are defying the laws of the land.
('11', 137, 1, 10, 274948) Passive resisters appreciate the advice.
('11', 137, 1, 11, 274989) They have no desire to avoid the ordinary consequences of the breach they deliberately commit of laws which they consider to be repugnant to their conscience.
('11', 137, 1, 12, 275148) But I make bold to say that the public will never endorse the infliction of what amounts to a sentence of death as in the cases to which I have just drawn attention.
('11', 137, 1, 13, 275314) I doubt not that the people of South Africa wish to see general rejoicing and goodwill among all the communities residing under the Union, on the approaching visit of a representative of the King, and on the eve of the opening of the first Parliament of the Union.
('11', 137, 1, 14, 275579) Is the Indian community in any part of South Africa to be expected to share the rejoicings that will take place at the end of the month, and to partake of the goodwill that should permeate all classes?
('11', 137, 2, 15, 275781) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('11', 138, 1, 2, 275877) 155. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('11', 138, 2, 3, 275911) Wednesday [October 19, 1910] 1
('11', 138, 3, 4, 275942) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('11', 138, 4, 5, 275963) It is just 6 a.m.
('11', 138, 4, 6, 275981) and this is the first letter I have taken up.
('11', 138, 4, 7, 276027) I am at Mr.Omar’s house which you would like immensely.
('11', 138, 4, 8, 276083) It is clean.
('11', 138, 4, 9, 276096) It faces the race course.
('11', 138, 4, 10, 276122) I could not go to Phoenix yesterday as there was a memorial meeting regarding Narayansamy.
('11', 138, 4, 11, 276213) Slept on the verandah of the house and got up at 5.15 a.m., washed my sleeping suit and shirt there.
('11', 138, 4, 12, 276314) I am now writing.
('11', 138, 4, 13, 276332) Passed the whole of the afternoon yesterday seeing the men.
('11', 138, 4, 14, 276392) Afterwards served notice on Chamney who happens to be here.
('11', 138, 4, 15, 276452) He has sent the message asking me to see him at 9 a.m.
('11', 138, 4, 16, 276507) I shall see what happens then.
('11', 138, 4, 17, 276538) Read before going to bed Harishchandra about whom I gave you the book from Natesan.
('11', 138, 4, 18, 276622) It you have not read it yet, I suggest your reading it at once.
('11', 138, 4, 19, 276686) On the way I read The Minds of Two Judges.
('11', 138, 4, 20, 276729) It is a powerful pamphlet and alas too true both in its con demnation of the English methods and the Indian.
('11', 138, 4, 21, 276838) Without the latter being bad, the former could never have secured a footing.
('11', 138, 4, 22, 276915) Cordes, I observe, has taken a deck passage.
('11', 138, 4, 23, 276960) He leaves on the 6th November.
('11', 138, 4, 24, 276991) There is no restraining him.
('11', 138, 4, 25, 277020) He is a wonderful man.
('11', 138, 4, 26, 277043) We can only pray for him and help him to go through the ordeal he has set before himself.
('11', 138, 4, 27, 277133) He will say that we talk and he does it.
('11', 138, 4, 28, 277174) In taking deck passage he has certainly done it.
('11', 138, 4, 29, 277223) Have not yet seen any of the Phoenixites.
('11', 138, 4, 30, 277265) I hope that the roof was finished or at least commenced yesterday.
('11', 138, 4, 31, 277332) With love,
('11', 138, 5, 32, 277343) UPPER HOUSE

('11', 140, 4, 16, 280686) 157. NARAYANSAMY
('11', 140, 5, 17, 280703) Narayansamy is dead, 2 but even in death he lives.
('11', 140, 5, 18, 280754) He is no more in the body, but he has left an immortal name behind him.
('11', 140, 5, 19, 280826) Birth and death are the common lot of all.
('11', 140, 5, 20, 280869) If we consider the matter deeply, we shall realize that death, whether it comes early or late, should be no cause for grieving or rejoicing.
('11', 140, 5, 21, 281010) On the contrary, to die in the service of the community or in the pursuit of some other good aim is in reality not to die but to live.
('11', 140, 5, 22, 281145) Is there any patriotic Indian who will not be prepared to die for the sake of the motherland?
('11', 140, 5, 23, 281239) Of course, none.
('11', 140, 5, 24, 281256) So long as we do not have this [spirit] in us, we cannot claim to be patriotic.
('11', 140, 5, 25, 281336) Narayansamy suffered much.
('11', 140, 5, 26, 281363) A voyage on the deck is full of hazards, all the more so if one has insufficient clothing and is handicapped in other ways.
('11', 140, 5, 27, 281487) Narayansamy undertook such a voyage for the sake of themotherland.
('11', 140, 5, 28, 281554) He has left the world, facing suffering till the end.
('11', 140, 5, 29, 281608) We shall count him a true satyagrahi.
('11', 140, 5, 30, 281646) Terms in which we cannot speak of even the greatest satyagrahi will be quite justified when applied to Narayansamy.
('11', 140, 5, 31, 281762) He has died a perfect satyagrahi.

('11', 140, 6, 33, 281887) The telegram is not available.

('11', 141, 0, 1, 282019) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 141, 1, 2, 282061) a staunch satyagrahi will deserve our praise only when he has proved his worth to the full.
('11', 141, 1, 3, 282153) Nagappen achieved immortal fame in his death.
('11', 141, 1, 4, 282199) And so has Narayansamy.
('11', 141, 1, 5, 282223) While grieving with the members of his family on account of his death, we shall also congratulate them.
('11', 141, 1, 6, 282327) All honour unto their mothers for having given birth to Nagappen and Narayansamy.
('11', 141, 1, 7, 282409) Though we think thus that Narayansamy died a hallowed death, so far as the Transvaal Government is concerned, it can be charged with legalized murder.
('11', 141, 1, 8, 282560) If anyone places another person in circumstances which result in his death, the former may be charged with the latter’s murder.
('11', 141, 1, 9, 282688) This is just what has happened in Narayansamy’s case.
('11', 141, 1, 10, 282742) He and his companions were taken first, from Durban to Port Elizabeth, thence to Cape Town, from Cape Town again to Durban and so on.
('11', 141, 1, 11, 282876) There were innumerable difficulties about accommodation, clothing and food.
('11', 141, 1, 12, 282952) If the Indian community had not provided the other Indians with clothing and food, they too would have been reduced to the same plight.
('11', 141, 1, 13, 283088) In acting thus, the Transvaal Government has been guilty of extreme harshness and its harshness has resulted in Narayansamy’s death.
('11', 141, 1, 14, 283221) Hence we charge the Government with murder.
('11', 141, 1, 15, 283265) Since no legal steps can be taken against it, though it is guilty of murder, we call this legal murder.
('11', 141, 1, 16, 283369) Nagappen and Narayansamy have thus left us.
('11', 141, 1, 17, 283413) The Tamil community is laying the other Indians under an increasingly heavier debt.
('11', 141, 1, 18, 283497) It is covering itself with greater glory day by day.
('11', 141, 1, 19, 283550) How will it ever be possible after this to make an adequate return for the services of the Tamil community?
('11', 141, 1, 20, 283658) Other Indians would do well to take a lesson from it and, copying its example, learn to suffer in silence for the sake of the motherland.
('11', 141, 1, 21, 283796) The [Indian] community will disgrace itself if it fails in this.
('11', 141, 2, 22, 283861) [From Gujarati]
('11', 141, 3, 23, 283877) Indian Opinion, 22 10 1910
('11', 141, 4, 24, 283904) 158. INDIANS’ FUTURE
('11', 141, 5, 25, 283925) We reported last week that Parliament at its next session would pass an Immigration Bill applicable to the whole of South Africa.
('11', 141, 5, 26, 284055) We have received this news through official sources.
('11', 141, 5, 27, 284108) Though we may not rely upon it entirely, it is certain that the Indian community needs to
('11', 142, 0, 1, 284198) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 143
('11', 142, 1, 2, 284241) be on its guard.
('11', 142, 1, 3, 284258) Very likely, they will delude the community with some superficially attractive provisions in the Immigration Bill and pass it.
('11', 142, 1, 4, 284385) It may perhaps contain a provision to the effect that only such Indians as are approved by the Indian residents in South Africa may be permitted to enter as fresh immigrants.
('11', 142, 1, 5, 284560) If the Indians of the Cape or Natal or the Transvaal walk into this snare, that will be a dishonour to the community and will bring disgrace on the name of Indians.
('11', 142, 1, 6, 284725) We should repeat it over and over again to ourselves that we must not accept any law which discriminates against Indians as Indians.
('11', 142, 1, 7, 284858) When it is sought to enact a law applicable to the whole of South Africa, it is but proper for the community to call a meeting of Indians from all parts of South Africa and take whatever steps may be necessary in consultation with them.
('11', 142, 1, 8, 285095) If there is any undue haste in this matter or if a body of Indians or an Indian leader, prompted by self interest, gives any undertaking, they will have reason for regret afterwards.
('11', 142, 2, 9, 285278) [From Gujarati]
('11', 142, 3, 10, 285294) Indian Opinion, 22 10 1910
('11', 142, 4, 11, 285321) 159. TRADING LICENCES IN THE TRANSVAAL
('11', 142, 5, 12, 285360) The Transvaal Government is not likely to leave the Indian traders there in peace, nor are the whites.
('11', 142, 5, 13, 285463) Municipalities in the Transvaal have been passing resolutions asking for the expulsion of Indian traders from the country after payment of compensation.
('11', 142, 5, 14, 285616) We have heard of some Indians approving such a move.
('11', 142, 5, 15, 285669) They are certain that there will be nothing wrong in leaving this country if an adequate amount is paid in excess of the cost [by way of compensation].
('11', 142, 5, 16, 285821) This is a short sighted view.
('11', 142, 5, 17, 285851) In the first place, we believe that even one fourth the amount of profit that we hope for will not be offered.
('11', 142, 5, 18, 285962) They will pass a law which will hardly allow anything over and above the market price [of the stocks].
('11', 142, 5, 19, 286065) Indians, in that case, will be ruined.
('11', 142, 5, 20, 286104) Hardly anyone from among the Indians settled in South Africa earns much after going to India.
('11', 142, 5, 21, 286198) All of them come back to this country.
('11', 142, 5, 22, 286237) In these circumstances, to think of accepting some payment and returning to India is obviously senseless.
('11', 142, 5, 23, 286343) It should also be borne in mind that we shall prove ourselves cowards if we allow the Government to drive us out.
('11', 142, 5, 24, 286457) We think we have as much right to be in this land as the whites have.
('11', 142, 5, 25, 286527) From one point of view, we have a better right.
('11', 142, 5, 26, 286575) The negroes alone are the original inhabitants of this land.
('11', 142, 5, 27, 286636) We have not seized the
('11', 143, 0, 1, 286659) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 143, 1, 2, 286701) land from them by force; we live here with their goodwill.
('11', 143, 1, 3, 286760) The whites, on the other hand, have occupied the country forcibly and appropriated it to themselves.
('11', 143, 1, 4, 286861) That, of course, does not prove their right to it.
('11', 143, 1, 5, 286912) A large number even from among them believe that they will have to fight again to defend their occupation.
('11', 143, 1, 6, 287019) But we shall say no more about this.
('11', 143, 1, 7, 287056) One will reap as one sows.
('11', 143, 1, 8, 287083) All that we wish to point out is that Indians will prove themselves selfish if, for the sake of a little money, they accept the offer of something over and above the cost price of their stocks and leave.
('11', 143, 1, 9, 287287) If they leave out of fear, they will show themselves to be cowards.
('11', 143, 1, 10, 287355) We hope it will not please any Indian to earn either of these epithets.
('11', 143, 2, 11, 287427) [From Gujarati]

('11', 145, 1, 2, 290028) 162. DIWALI
('11', 145, 2, 3, 290040) We have taken to Western ways and manners to such an extent that we find ourselves unable to look upon the New Year of the Hindus, the Muslims and the Parsis as our New Year.
('11', 145, 2, 4, 290215) If we were to adopt “New Year” as the caption of this article, it would carry no meaning.
('11', 145, 2, 5, 290305) When, however, we come to write of the New Year in the [first] issue of January, everyone will understand it to mean the year 1911. There is no convincing reason to justify this state of affairs.
('11', 145, 2, 6, 290501) If we have not forgotten what we are, we should observe all the three New Years and, if so inclined, the Western New Year as the fourth.
('11', 145, 2, 7, 290638) When the Muslim year changes, all the Indians should observe it, and so also when the Parsi year or the Hindu year changes.
('11', 145, 2, 8, 290762) This will betoken our fraternal relations and prove that we have become one nation.
('11', 145, 2, 9, 290846) On the contrary, what we notice in fact is that we show no particular regard for one another’s New Year.
('11', 145, 2, 10, 290951) To create among the inhabitants of India the consciousness of their being one nation, no Herculean efforts are necessary.
('11', 145, 2, 11, 291073) We are of course a single nation and brothers as among ourselves.
('11', 145, 2, 12, 291139) We should regain that consciousness this very instant if we could only be open hearted and get rid of the pride that goes with hypocrisy.
('11', 145, 2, 13, 291277) Diwali falls on Tuesday next.
('11', 145, 2, 14, 291307) It is an important festival for the Hindus.
('11', 145, 2, 15, 291351) Every Hindu has our good wishes on the occasion.
('11', 145, 2, 16, 291400) But we do not see how they can materialize.
('11', 145, 2, 17, 291444) Hindus certainly cannot be happy when their neighbours are not.
('11', 145, 2, 18, 291508) The New Year will prove happy only for the man who has turned the preceding year to good account.
('11', 145, 2, 19, 291606) Expecting a good crop in winter when the monsoon has failed is like building castles in the air.
('11', 145, 2, 20, 291703) The divine law is not that we get what we desire, but that we get what we deserve.
('11', 145, 2, 21, 291786) In other words, our desires will be fulfilled only if they have behind them the force of merit earned by suitable deeds.
('11', 145, 2, 22, 291907) And so we wish a prosperous Diwali to every Hindu who has accumulated during the current year the capital of good deeds, who has borne love to every other Indian as to a brother, who has earned an honest livelihood and shared the sufferings of the unhappy, and we pray to God that the New Year may confirm him in his virtuous disposition.
('11', 145, 2, 23, 292246) And likewise we pray that the Hindu who has, knowingly or unknowingly, failed in his duty and spent his time merely in the
('11', 146, 0, 1, 292369) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 147
('11', 146, 1, 2, 292412) pursuit of self interest, who has borne ill will and not love to other Indians, may learn to repent and, be converted to better ways, wake up to a sense of duty.
('11', 146, 1, 3, 292574) We request our readers’ help in working for the fulfilment of this desire of ours.
('11', 146, 2, 4, 292657) [From Gujarati]
('11', 146, 3, 5, 292673) Indian Opinion, 29 10 1910
('11', 146, 4, 6, 292700) 163. INDIANS’ DUTY IN NOVEMBER
('11', 146, 5, 7, 292731) Mr. Dawad Mahomed has sent a telegram to General Botha to say that he should make it possible for the agitation to be withdrawn, failing which the Indian community cannot participate in the celebrations on the occasion of the inauguration of the Union Parliament in November.
('11', 146, 5, 8, 293007) This is quite correct.
('11', 146, 5, 9, 293030) If the struggle does not end in November, we must observe mourning.
('11', 146, 5, 10, 293098) Thoughtful Indians realize that we should be in mourning for the death of Narayansamy.
('11', 146, 5, 11, 293185) If we do not join in their celebrations, do not turn out to watch their shows, if we confine ourselves to our homes at the time of the celebrations and do not put up decorations over our shops, the rulers cannot but be impressed.
('11', 146, 5, 12, 293415) By doing this, we can show to them that the entire Indian community in South Africa feels sore over the prolongation of the struggle.
('11', 146, 6, 13, 293549) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 29 10 1910

('11', 147, 5, 15, 294585) 165. PROPOSED NEW IMMIGRATION BILL
('11', 147, 6, 16, 294620) The Transvaal Leader of the 31st ultimo published the following telegram from its Cape Town correspondent:
('11', 147, 7, 17, 294727) I learn that the Colonial Secretary will early in the session bring in a Bill
('11', 147, 8, 18, 294805) which, in addition to modifying the existing Transvaal conditions, will, in a
('11', 147, 9, 19, 294883) considerable degree, aim at the consolidation of the immigration laws of the
('11', 147, 10, 20, 294960) Provinces of the Union.
('11', 147, 11, 21, 294984) So far as the Transvaal is concerned, I understand it is the intention to make
('11', 147, 12, 22, 295063) some fairly important concessions to British Indians, which, without weakening the
('11', 147, 13, 23, 295146) attitude of South Africa, will make the law more workable and sensible than the
('11', 147, 14, 24, 295226) regulations now are.
('11', 147, 14, 25, 295247) Among these concessions will be the admittance of a limited
('11', 147, 15, 26, 295307) number of specially qualified Indians per annum (the number suggested in the past was
('11', 147, 16, 27, 295393) six per year, but it may be made even greater than this).
('11', 147, 16, 28, 295451) This and other modifications
('11', 147, 17, 29, 295480) are among those which have been pointed to in the past by the Leader as necessary to
('11', 147, 18, 30, 295565) make the immigration restrictions more satisfactory to all concerned in respect of the
('11', 147, 19, 31, 295652) consolidation of immigration laws.
('11', 147, 20, 32, 295687) This naturally does not imply uniformity of measures in all the Colonies, the position of Natal being a specially difficult problem.
('11', 147, 20, 33, 295820) A great deal of anxiety is felt in
('11', 147, 21, 34, 295855) 1 The second book of the Ramayana by Tulsidas 2 Devotion
('11', 148, 0, 1, 295912) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 149
('11', 148, 1, 2, 295955) Natal about the restrictions which will be imposed there, as the existence of the sugar industry is stated by the majority of representatives from that Province to depend on the ability of planters to rely on a continuous supply of indentured Indian labour.
('11', 148, 1, 3, 296213) The suggestion has been made from some quarters in Natal that this form of labour should be allowed within an area bounded by a strictly limited distance from the coast, which will include the sugar and other plantations.
('11', 148, 1, 4, 296435) What will actually be proposed by the Government will probably not become known till General Smuts brings in his Bill, but it will occur to everyone that, considering the difficulties the country was plunged into as the result of former immigration legislation, the details of the new measure should be laid before both members of Parliament and the public in time for them to consider it very carefully.
('11', 148, 1, 5, 296840) We do not know whether The Transvaal Leader correspondent has given a correct forecast.
('11', 148, 1, 6, 296928) If he has and if the provision for the new entrantsis made on the lines suggested by Lord Ampthill and if no statutory colour bar is created, passive resistance struggle will end, assuming of course that Act 2 of 1907 will be repealed at the same time.
('11', 148, 1, 7, 297181) But Indians all over South Africa are nervous regarding the proposed consolidation of the Immigration Laws of the other provinces.
('11', 148, 1, 8, 297312) Indians of the Cape and Natal cannot accept the Transvaal Registration Act, as registration is totally unnecessary for provinces with a sea border.
('11', 148, 1, 9, 297460) Nor can they accept the unnecessarily rigorous educational test which will be acceptable for the Transvaal under the peculiar conditions prevailing there.
('11', 148, 1, 10, 297615) British Indians have accepted the policy of restriction throughout South Africa but they cannot be expected to become party to making legislation for the Cape and Natal more severe than it already is.
('11', 148, 1, 11, 297816) Indeed, as recent judgments of the Supreme Court at the Cape and Natal have shown, it is severe enough in all conscience.

('11', 149, 4, 15, 299527) 167. WHO IS A SATYAGRAHI?
('11', 149, 5, 16, 299553) Mr. Vallibhai Peerbhai, who is always ready with his hospitality for satyagrahis, writes to say that Mr. Medh received three letters on the very day on which he was arrested.
('11', 149, 5, 17, 299728) On reading them, he went to Mr. Mulla’s shop in Volksrust and performed ablutions and then presented himself for arrest.
('11', 149, 5, 18, 299849) It appears that Mr. Medh received news of his sister’s death, the sister having left three children behind her.
('11', 149, 5, 19, 299961) “Had I been by Mr. Medh’s side”, [says Mr. Vallibhai] “when he read those letters I would not have allowed him to go.
('11', 149, 5, 20, 300079) But no matter, joy and sorrow are the same to a satyagrahi.” It does credit to Mr. Valli to say that if he had known of it, he would have stopped Mr. Medh.
('11', 149, 5, 21, 300235) By going to gaol as a matter of duty without for a moment thinking of staying out because of the news of his sister’s death, Mr. Medh has offered additional proof of his being a true satyagrahi.
('11', 149, 5, 22, 300430) He is a staunch and seasoned satyagrahi.
('11', 149, 5, 23, 300471) The hardships of gaol life hold no terrors for him.
('11', 149, 5, 24, 300523) He deserves all the congratulations we can offer him.
('11', 149, 5, 25, 300577) Mr. Surendrarai Medh has covered the community with glory.

('11', 150, 1, 3, 300939) He who thus loses for the sake of truth shall gain.
('11', 150, 1, 4, 300991) By disobeying his father’s order for the sake of truth, Prahlad not only remained staunch in satyagraha but also did his duty as a son.
('11', 150, 1, 5, 301127) Making himself a satyagrahi, he won his own and his father’s deliverance from this earthly life.
('11', 150, 1, 6, 301224) No one lacking the determined spirit of Prahlad can ever hold on to satyagraha to the end.

('11', 154, 4, 5, 307722) TOLSTOY FARM, Kartak Shud 9 [November 11, 1910] 2
('11', 154, 5, 6, 307772) MAGANLAL,
('11', 154, 6, 7, 307782) Today I saw the letter you mentioned.
('11', 154, 6, 8, 307820) When Narandas wrote to me to send my letters to him through you, I did not find fault with his action as a piece of cowardice.
('11', 154, 6, 9, 307947) I had no such idea in my mind at all.
('11', 154, 6, 10, 307985) In reply to his question as to what he should do, I wrote 3 to him saying that first he should attain fearles sness as described in (fearlessness, purity of heart,) etc.
('11', 154, 6, 11, 308155) And I wrote it with the idea that he should first acquire that virtue if he wanted to engage himself in any public activity.
('11', 154, 6, 12, 308280) True public service can be rendered only if fearlessness can be achieved as regards [the loss of] prestige, money, caste, wife, family and even life.
('11', 154, 6, 13, 308430) Then only will moksha (liberation), the ultimate end of life, be attained.
('11', 154, 6, 14, 308505) I have no time to write a separate letter to Narandas.
('11', 154, 6, 15, 308560) Please therefore send this on to him.
('11', 154, 6, 16, 308598) I shall write about the press when I find time.
('11', 154, 6, 17, 308646) Please let me know how Manilal is getting on.
('11', 154, 7, 18, 308692) Blessings from MOHANDAS

('11', 155, 1, 2, 309425) 177. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('11', 155, 2, 3, 309452) [JOHANNESBURG,] November 14, 1910
('11', 155, 4, 4, 309486) Since the well known Poonia case, the Indian community had come to understand that Indian women crossing the border would not be interfered with, and I know of several cases in which they were permitted to cross the border unchallenged.
('11', 155, 4, 5, 309723) But after the interference with Mrs. Gandhi, over a month ago, when she was travelling alone, I could see that the spell was broken.
('11', 155, 4, 6, 309856) Whenever, therefore, wives or other female relatives of passive resisters wanted to enter the Province from Natal, I took the precaution of informing the Chief Immigration Officer at Pretoria, who is also the Registrar of Asiatics, of the movements of these families, informing him also of their exact relationship to the respective passive resisters, and until very recently there has been no actual difficulty.
('11', 155, 4, 7, 310269) I returned from Natal yesterday week in the company of Mrs. Sodha, the wife of a passive resister who is at present serving imprisonment at Diepkloof for the offence of asserting his right of entry as a free born British subject possessing the qualifications required by the Immigration Law of this Province, as apart from the Asiatic Act.
('11', 155, 4, 8, 310609) Before leaving Natal I had taken the usual precaution of telegraphing to the Immigration Officer that I was crossing the border with Mrs. Sodha.
('11', 155, 4, 9, 310754) On reaching Volksrust I learnt that the Police had received instructions to stop Mrs. Sodha.
('11', 155, 4, 10, 310847) She and I, together with other passive resisters who were in my company, got down from the train.
('11', 155, 4, 11, 310945) Mrs. Sodha 2 has a baby in arms, another under three years and a boy twelve years of age.
('11', 155, 4, 12, 311035) I took her and her children to the Charge Office where I was asked to produce Mrs. Sodhathe following morning, and on my undertaking to do so I was permitted to take her away.
('11', 155, 4, 13, 311211) Needless to say, Mrs. Sodha had never in her life seen a Charge Office or been addressed by a constable.
('11', 155, 4, 14, 311316) An Indian store keeper kindly provided shelter and food for
('11', 155, 5, 15, 311376) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 19 11 1910, as a letter addressed to the South African Press under the title “Mrs. Sodha’s Case”.
('11', 155, 5, 16, 311514) 2 Vide “Telegram to Chief Immigration Officer”, before 6 11 1910
('11', 156, 0, 1, 311579) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 157
('11', 156, 1, 2, 311622) and her children.
('11', 156, 1, 3, 311640) The next day she was charged as a prohibited immigrant and the case was remanded to the 21st instant, she being released on her own recognizance.
('11', 156, 1, 4, 311786) Thinking that Mrs. Sodha’s arrest might have been due to a misunderstanding, I telegraphed 1 again to the Chief Immigration Officer giving him the information about Mrs. Sodha’s children and telling him that she was proceeding to Tolstoy Farm, that she would retire from the Transvaal at the end of the struggle and that she was being taken to the above farm only pending her husband’s continuous incarceration.
('11', 156, 1, 5, 312198) I received at Volksrust a reply to the effect that Mrs. Sodha would be tried as a prohibited immigrant unless she immediately returned to Natal.
('11', 156, 1, 6, 312343) She and I, however, continued our journey as Mrs. Sodha’s case was already adjourned.
('11', 156, 1, 7, 312429) In order to avoid any further complications, Mr. Cachalia, the Chairman of the British Indian Association, telegraphed 2 to the Minister of the Interior, recounting the circumstances of the arrest and requesting that the prosecution might be withdrawn.
('11', 156, 1, 8, 312682) The Minister replied in the negative, stating that her husband was a prohibited immigrant.
('11', 156, 1, 9, 312773) As the British Indian Association was desirous of avoiding importing women into the controversy, it again approached 3 the Minister and requested that a temporary permit should be issued to Mrs. Sodha.
('11', 156, 1, 10, 312975) He, however, declined to do so.
('11', 156, 1, 11, 313007) Mrs. Sodha has entered the Transvaal temporarily as the Sodha family has been reduced to poverty and their home broken up owing to Mr. Sodha’s having been in prison almost continuously for the last eighteen months and as passive resister families are being supported at Tolstoy Farm out of public funds.
('11', 156, 1, 12, 313311) I do not propose to go into the legal merits of this case which is sub judice.
('11', 156, 1, 13, 313390) Possibly Mrs. Sodha has committed a technical legal offence.
('11', 156, 1, 14, 313451) If so, all the Indian women, who were allowed to enter the country and to whom I have made reference, have also committed an offence, in so far as the Government are concerned, for the latter have undoubtedly contended that all Indians who have ever been deported under the Registration Act are prohibited immigrants.
('11', 156, 1, 15, 313769) The Government, however, seem to have distinguished between Mr. Sodha, who is an unregistered pre war resident of the Transvaal, and other passive resisters who are registered residents and whose wives and
('11', 156, 2, 16, 313975) 1 Vide “Telegram to Chief Immigration Officer”, 7 11 1910 2 Vide “Telegram to Minister of Interior”, 8 11 1910 3 Vide “Telegram to Minister of Interior”, 10 11 1910
('11', 157, 0, 1, 314140) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 157, 1, 2, 314182) families, as stated above, have entered the province unmolested.
('11', 157, 1, 3, 314247) As the wife of a passive resister Mrs. Sodha has now no alternative but to face imprisonment and deportation if found technically guilty.
('11', 157, 1, 4, 314385) But why this sudden persecution, for I cannot call it a prosecution, of Indian women?
('11', 157, 1, 5, 314471) The Government are at war with Indian males.
('11', 157, 1, 6, 314516) They are now attempting to hound out of the Province a certain class of Indian boys born of registered parents.
('11', 157, 1, 7, 314628) The community was, however, unprepared for an unchivalrous attack on its womanhood.
('11', 157, 1, 8, 314712) Mrs. Sodha is not a competitor in trade.
('11', 157, 1, 9, 314753) Her character is admittedly above reproach.
('11', 157, 1, 10, 314797) A meeker woman it will be, perhaps, difficult to find throughout South Africa.
('11', 157, 1, 11, 314876) She has committed no crime under the common law of the country.
('11', 157, 1, 12, 314940) Every means that could be adopted was taken to placate the authorities, whose only aim now seems to be to punish Indian women, as the punishment hitherto inflicted on their husbands appears to have failed in its purpose.
('11', 157, 1, 13, 315161) I cannot foresee the extent of the terrible effect that must be produced on the minds of the Indians throughout South Africa and of the people of India when the news of this war on women is spread abroad.
('11', 157, 1, 14, 315366) With this aspect of the question the Minister of the Interior is, apparently, little concerned; but I cannot conceive that the high handed, wantonly cruel and unnecessary proceedings against Mrs. Sodha will meet with the approval of the people of South Africa.
('11', 157, 1, 15, 315627) Here is a question for the Loyal Women’s Guild and other similar organisations to consider.
('11', 157, 1, 16, 315719) Whatever may be their views on Asiatic immigration or on the question of general passive resistance, will not the Christian men and women of this Union rise in unanimous protest against this latest parody of administration on the part of the Government?
('11', 157, 1, 17, 315973) I trust that Mrs. Sodha’s act will not be construed to be one of defiance.
('11', 157, 1, 18, 316048) She is as innocent of the curious laws of this country as a new born babe.
('11', 157, 1, 19, 316123) If anyone is guilty it is the writer, under whose advice and by whose assistance the lady has entered this part of the Union.
('11', 157, 1, 20, 316249) In any case I wish to recall a graceful act of administration under Crown Colony Government.
('11', 157, 1, 21, 316342) In 1906, Dr. Abdurahman of Cape Town entered the Transvaal without a permit.
('11', 157, 1, 22, 316419) Lord Selborne came to know of this and without questioning the legality of Dr. Abdurahman’s action he instructed the then Chief Secretary for Permits, Captain Hamilton Fowle, to send him a permit.
('11', 157, 1, 23, 316616) The mighty and responsible Union Government lacks both the grace and chivalry to refrain from
('11', 158, 0, 1, 316710) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 159
('11', 158, 1, 2, 316753) harassing an inoffensive Indian woman.
('11', 158, 2, 3, 316792) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('11', 159, 4, 6, 318534) 180. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('11', 159, 5, 7, 318565) TOLSTOY FARM, Kartak Shud 13 [November 15, 1910] 1
('11', 159, 6, 8, 318616) MAGANLAL,
('11', 159, 7, 9, 318626) India has come to a very bad pass.
('11', 159, 7, 10, 318661) I have given much thought to the plague and I think there is nothing surprising in its occurrence.
('11', 159, 7, 11, 318760) It may be eradicated from all other countries, but not from India.
('11', 159, 7, 12, 318827) The plague does not leave India because we have made this sacred land profane, either by a misreading of religion or by giving up religion altogether.
('11', 159, 7, 13, 318978) People have learnt to run hither and thither, but they do not change any of their tendencies.
('11', 159, 7, 14, 319072) They go on practising irreligion and do not care to know even the rules of sanitation, etc.
('11', 159, 7, 15, 319164) It is only the magic remedies known to them that they are prepared to adopt.
('11', 159, 7, 16, 319241) No one bothers, while running away, about what happens to the poor who are left behind.
('11', 159, 7, 17, 319329) How can we prosper in these circumstances?
('11', 159, 7, 18, 319372) Our own family, too, is open to this charge.
('11', 159, 7, 19, 319417) What wonder then if we receive news of fever, etc., from India?
('11', 159, 7, 20, 319481) In these circumstances, I can well understand the hesitation and the sense of discourtesy you feel in sending for Kashi here.
('11', 159, 7, 21, 319607) However, this idea is worth considering.
('11', 159, 7, 22, 319648) Chhaganlal, having taken away Kashi with him, is now penitent and is trying to excuse himself by saying that such was the will of God.
('11', 159, 7, 23, 319783) We can talk of God’s will only after first admitting our mistake.
('11', 159, 7, 24, 319849) It is sheer ignorance to speak of His will otherwise.
('11', 159, 7, 25, 319903) And what, after all, is God’s will?
('11', 159, 7, 26, 319939) You need not have any hesitation in sending for Kashi here, for the others will not come without her.
('11', 159, 7, 27, 320041) And even if they wanted to, there

('11', 160, 1, 2, 320281) would be difficulties in their way.

('11', 160, 1, 4, 320384) I have a constant feeling that you alone and none else will be able to master Tamil; hence keep at it under any circumstances.

('11', 162, 1, 10, 324668) Only this we know: that such an epidemic occurs less frequently and with less virulence where personal cleanliness as well as public sanitation is well looked after.
('11', 162, 1, 11, 324834) This, however, is certain: neither cholera nor any other epidemic will occur where there is complete purity of mind.
('11', 162, 1, 12, 324951) Even with tremendous effort rarely does one attain that purity.
('11', 162, 1, 13, 325015) To attain that one should .

('11', 163, 2, 4, 326291) MOVE FOR SETTLEMENT There are persistent rumours that a settlement is imminent.
('11', 163, 2, 5, 326371) On Monday The Star had a lengthy article, which too said that the time was ripe for a settlement.
('11', 163, 2, 6, 326469) There is little possibility of Indian leaders being consulted in the matter.
('11', 163, 2, 7, 326546) It appears, therefore, that whatever happens will happen as a result of direct negotiations with the Imperial Government.
('11', 163, 3, 8, 326668) WHAT WILL SETTLEMENT BE LIKE?
('11', 163, 3, 9, 326698) It is necessary to give some thought to this question.
('11', 163, 3, 10, 326753) It appears the demand of the Indians here will be conceded.
('11', 163, 3, 11, 326813) In other words, Indians and whites will have the same rights of entry so far as the law is concerned, that is, both will have to pass a test in a European language in order to qualify for entry.
('11', 163, 3, 12, 327008) At the same time, the Governor General will be given the discretion to fix the maximum number of persons to be admitted from each community, irrespective of the number of persons passing the education test.
('11', 163, 3, 13, 327215) The obnoxious Act of 1907 will be repealed.
('11', 163, 3, 14, 327259) This much, if it comes about, will be enough to save the Indians’ pledge and uphold their honour.
('11', 163, 3, 15, 327357) This is not the end of the matter.
('11', 163, 3, 16, 327392) There appears to be a snag in it.
('11', 163, 3, 17, 327426) It seems the Government wants to bring the position in the Cape and Natal in line with that in the Transvaal, that is, to make the education test in Natal and the Cape very stiff and to provide for the registration of all Indians.
('11', 163, 3, 18, 327657) I am of the view that the Indians in Natal and the Cape should not acquiesce in either of these two things.
('11', 163, 3, 19, 327765) There should be no question of introducing registration in Natal and the Cape similar to that in the Transvaal—for there can be no justification for it in either province—and to make the education test stiffer would obviously be wrong.
('11', 163, 4, 20, 328001) WHAT ABOUT CHILDREN?
('11', 163, 4, 21, 328022) The Transvaal needs to be watchful about the new threat to the position of children there.
('11', 163, 4, 22, 328113) The matter has a bearing on satyagraha but the problem of children is such that if no justice is done, satyagraha can be and must be offered.
('11', 163, 4, 23, 328255) There are, thus, difficulties in the way of a settlement.
('11', 163, 5, 24, 328313) 1 Vide “Letter to the Press”, 14 11 1910
('11', 164, 0, 1, 328354) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 165
('11', 164, 1, 2, 328397) community’s pledge may be fulfilled, but we may have to face losses in other ways.
('11', 164, 1, 3, 328480) It is necessary to take note of this from the first.
('11', 164, 2, 4, 328533) MEASURES AGAINST THIS Some effective measures against this are possible.
('11', 164, 2, 5, 328606) In the first place, Indians in the Cape, Natal and the Transvaal should present a united front.
('11', 164, 2, 6, 328702) Secondly, the leaders in the different provinces must not in their haste take steps independently of one another.
('11', 164, 2, 7, 328816) Thirdly, meetings should be held in every town to pass resolutions and these should be forwarded to the Government.
('11', 164, 2, 8, 328932) A petition should be addressed to Parliament as also to the Imperial Government and the Indian Government.
('11', 164, 2, 9, 329039) If nothing comes out of all this, the fourth step is resort to satyagraha.

('11', 164, 6, 15, 329518) He seems to be opposed to any discrimination on the basis of race or colour.

('11', 166, 4, 7, 332929) 184. LETTER TO MEMBERS OF ASIATIC CONFERENCE 1
('11', 166, 5, 8, 332976) JOHANNESBURG, [Before November 18, 1910]
('11', 166, 6, 9, 333017) DEAR SIR,
('11', 166, 7, 10, 333027) I take the liberty of addressing you as one of the members of the Asiatic Conference that took place in August, 1908, and at which you were present.
('11', 166, 7, 11, 333176) You may have noticed from the papers that the Asiatic Department have interpreted the Asiatic Act of 1908, which was partly a result of that Conference, that Asiatic minors, sons of registered Asiatics, not born in the Transvaal or resident in the Province at the commencement of the Act, are liable of necessity on reaching the age of 16 years to expulsion, notwithstanding their willingness to apply for registration under the Act, and notwithstanding the fact that the names of these minors appear on the registration certificates of the fathers.
('11', 166, 7, 12, 333726) An actual case has arisen in respect of the son of Mr. A. E. Chhotabhai, a prominent Indian merchant of Krugersdorp.
('11', 166, 7, 13, 333843) The boy, whose name is inscribed upon his father’s registration certificate, on attaining the age of 16 years, applied for registration under the Act; he entered the Colony as a minor with his father, and with the knowledge and consent of the authorities, as he had a legal right to do under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('11', 166, 7, 14, 334168) His application was rejected by the Registrar.
('11', 166, 7, 15, 334215) He appealed to the Magistrate, who upheld the Registrar’s decision, and ordered his immediate removal from the Province, which was suspended, pending proceedings in the Supreme Court.
('11', 166, 7, 16, 334399) The matter went before Mr. Justice Wessels in Chambers, who characterized the action of the Government as “inhuman” and said
('11', 166, 8, 17, 334524) 1 This, along with the following item, was published in The Star, 19 11 1910, under the title, “The Chhotabhai Case”.
('11', 167, 0, 1, 334642) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 167, 1, 2, 334684) “that when known it would create a howl throughout the civilized world”, but the learned judge decided that the Act did not provide for the registration of such boys, and he therefore reluctantly dismissed the application.
('11', 167, 1, 3, 334907) The motion went in appeal before the full bench, which by a majority upheld Mr. Justice Wessels’ decision.
('11', 167, 1, 4, 335014) 1 Notice of further appeal to the Appellate Court has therefore been lodged; the matter is accordingly still sub judice.
('11', 167, 2, 5, 335135) But I wish, however, to draw your attention to the following remarkable results of the proceedings.
('11', 167, 2, 6, 335235) The judges have decided that the Act of 1907 is virtually repealed by the later Act, and that whilst Asiatic minors, in the position of Mr. Chhotabhai’s son, might be protected under the Act of 1907, that protection has been withdrawn by the Act of 1908. Mr. Justice Mason, who delivered a dissentient judgment in favour of the applicant, has also held that the boy cannot be protected under the Act of 1908, but that provisions regarding minors under the Act of 1907 are not repealed.
('11', 167, 2, 7, 335721) Besides this, Mr. Justice Mason and Mr. Justice Bristowe have condemned the Govern ment’s action, as also the Acts themselves, in somewhat scathing terms.
('11', 167, 3, 8, 335876) I have no doubt you will recollect the very lively discussion that took place between several members of the Conference and Mr. Quinn and myself, regarding the proposed repeal of Act 2 of 1907, but General Smuts declined to consider the question of repeal.
('11', 167, 3, 9, 336133) You will recollect too the discussion that took place with reference to minors, who were to be protected, no matter where born, by their names being inscribed upon their father’s registration certificate.
('11', 167, 3, 10, 336338) There never was a question of giving upany substantial rights already possessed under Act 2 of 1907.
('11', 167, 4, 11, 336439) I may be permitted further to add that: (1) General Smuts, at the time of introducing the new measure into the Assembly, never stated that it was calculated to deprive any class of minors of the right of residence in the Colony; (2) Mr. de Villiers as Attorney General, in his minute to the Governor, stated that, among others, the Asiatic demand regarding the registration of minors was conceded, and that both the Acts were to run concurrently; (3) in no part of the British Dominions are the children of lawfully resident Asiatics torn from parents at any age, much less on reaching the tender age of 16 years.
('11', 167, 4, 12, 337053) I venture to submit that you, as a member of the Conference, are
('11', 167, 5, 13, 337118) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('11', 168, 0, 1, 337145) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 169
('11', 168, 1, 2, 337188) concerned directly with the results as to minor Asiatics being defeated by what must appear to you, as it does to me, to be an entirely unexpected judgment of our Courts.
('11', 168, 1, 3, 337359) I hope that I am right in suggesting that the honour of members of the Conference is involved in the maintenance of the principles adopted at the Conference, and I therefore trust that you will, if you can do nothing more, publicly declare that you never contemplated a deprivation of the rights of minor Asiatics of the class referred to in this letter.
('11', 168, 1, 4, 337714) A matter so important as this cannot, in my opinion, be left to be decided by even the highest tribunal of justice, which according to our Constitution, must be entirely unmoved by considerations, however important in themselves, that may have led to the passing of certain laws, and which is obliged to give effect to them, no matter how harshly or morally indefensible these laws may be.
('11', 168, 2, 5, 338104) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('11', 169, 5, 5, 339264) That this meeting of the Committee of the British Indian Association, with profound regret, comes to the conclusion that, in view of the death of the deportee, Narayansamy, the tyrannical proceedings against minor children of a certain class, the impending prosecution of Mrs. Sodha, and the continued sufferings of the passive resisters, by reason of the refusal by the Union Government to grant the demands of the Indian community, universally acknowledged to be just and reasonable, it is not possible for the community to be associated in a public presentation of an address of welcome to His Royal Highness, the Duke of Connaught, and thus identify itself with public rejoicings over the inauguration of the Union, which, for Asiatic British subjects, has meant greater bitterness and increased anxiety for its future; and the meetinghereby authorises the Chairman to address a respectful letter to His Royal Highness, expressing the community’s loyalty to the Throne, and tendering a personal welcome to him as representative of the Sovereign.

('11', 173, 3, 10, 347978) 191. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS, PRETORIA 1
('11', 173, 4, 11, 348025) [JOHANNESBURG,] November 19, 1910 My Association learns with deep anxiety that, owing to continual improper treatment of Indian passive resisters who are at present confined in the Diepkloof Convict Prison, several Indian prisoners have thought it necessary to undertake a fast, by way of protest and in order to secure their removal to the Johannesburg Gaol where, they have reason to believe that, under the more immediate supervision of the Governor, they will be given better treatment.
('11', 173, 4, 12, 348516) I understand that already Messrs Harilal Gandhi and R. M. Sodha have been transferred to Johannesburg Gaol.
('11', 173, 4, 13, 348624) I also learn that Mr. S. B. Medh has also applied for a transfer, and that he has been fasting for the last six days.
('11', 173, 4, 14, 348742) As the matter is one of extreme urgency, I shall be greatly obliged if you will give it your immediate attention.
('11', 173, 4, 15, 348856) I need hardly remind you of the serious consequences to the health of the prisoners and the effect upon the members of the Indian community of the continuance of what is alleged to be the present condition of affairs.
('11', 173, 5, 16, 349074) Indian Opinion, 3 12 1910

('11', 174, 1, 2, 349476) 192. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS, PRETORIA 1
('11', 174, 2, 3, 349523) [JOHANNESBURG,] November 22, 1910
('11', 174, 3, 4, 349557) In reply to your letter herein of the 21st inst., my Association is advised that strong complaint is made against the insulting attitude of some of the warders who appear to regard Indian prisoners as suitable butts upon whom to exercise their mistaken sense of humour, as for example, calling them “Coolie”, “Sammy”, “Bananas”, and so forth.
('11', 174, 3, 5, 349900) Complaints regarding this matter and other pinpricks have constantly been made to the chief warder who either ignores it, or replies in an offensive manner.
('11', 174, 3, 6, 350057) Complaint is also specially made against the conduct of head warder McLoud, who is in charge of the spans.
('11', 174, 3, 7, 350164) This officer, my Association understands, systematically subjects prisoners to every possible form of harassment, requiring them to perform impossible tasks, and seizing every opportunity to report against them to secure their punishment.
('11', 174, 3, 8, 350403) Frequent complaint has been made to the Governor of this officer’s conduct and my Association learns that he has been more than once reported, and on at least two occasions his charges against the Indian prisoners have fallen to the ground upon examination.
('11', 174, 3, 9, 350661) Apparently, the complaints have not resulted in any improvement in Mr. McLoud’s attitude towards the Indian prisoners, who have, it now appears, been exasperated on account of the treatment that has been meted out to them, both by him and the chief warder.
('11', 174, 3, 10, 350918) My Association is quite prepared to learn that these charges are denied by the officers concerned, but, in anticipation of such denial, which has not been infrequent in the past, I would like to point out that no prisoner is likely to refuse to eat for a whole week, as has Mr. Medh, who does not, in his opinion, labour under serious grievances.
('11', 174, 3, 11, 351265) My Association will, accordingly, be grateful if you will be so good as to institute urgent inquiries into this matter.

('11', 175, 1, 2, 351573) 193. THE LATE LAMENTED TOLSTOY THE GREAT
('11', 175, 2, 3, 351614) The great Tolstoy has quit this corporeal frame at the ripe old age of 83. 1 It is truer to say that “he has quit this corporeal frame” than that “he has died”.
('11', 175, 2, 4, 351775) There can be no death for Tolstoy’s soul.
('11', 175, 2, 5, 351817) His name will ever remain immortal.
('11', 175, 2, 6, 351853) Only his body, which was of dust, has returned to dust.
('11', 175, 2, 7, 351909) Tolstoy is known to the entire world; but not as a soldier, though once he was reputed to be an expert soldier; not as a great writer, though indeed he enjoys a great reputation as a writer; nor as a nobleman, though he owned immense wealth.
('11', 175, 2, 8, 352151) It was as a good man that the world knew him.
('11', 175, 2, 9, 352197) In India, we would have described him as a maharshi 2 or fakir.
('11', 175, 2, 10, 352261) He renounced his wealth, gave up a life of comfort to embrace that of a simple peasant.
('11', 175, 2, 11, 352349) It was Tolstoy’s great virtue that he himself put into practice what he preached.
('11', 175, 2, 12, 352431) Hence thousands of men clung loyally to his words—his teaching.
('11', 175, 2, 13, 352495) We believe Tolstoy’s teaching will win increasing appreciation with the passage of time.
('11', 175, 2, 14, 352584) Its foundation was religion.
('11', 175, 2, 15, 352613) Being a Christian, he believed that Christianity was the best religion.
('11', 175, 2, 16, 352685) He did not, however, denounce any [other] religion.
('11', 175, 2, 17, 352737) He said, on the contrary, that truth was undoubtedly present in all the religions.
('11', 175, 2, 18, 352820) At the same time, he also pointed out that selfish priests, Brahmins and Mullas had distorted the teaching of Christianity and other religions and misled the people.
('11', 175, 2, 19, 352986) What Tolstoy believed with especial conviction was that in essence all religions held soul force to be superior to brute force and taught that evil should be requited with good, not evil.
('11', 175, 2, 20, 353174) Evil is the negation of religion.
('11', 175, 2, 21, 353208) Irreligion cannot be cured by irreligion, but only by religion.
('11', 175, 2, 22, 353272) There is no room in religion for anything other than compassion.
('11', 175, 2, 23, 353337) A man of religion will not wish ill even to his enemy.
('11', 175, 2, 24, 353392) Therefore, if people always want to follow the path of religion, they must do nothing but good.
('11', 175, 2, 25, 353488) In his last days, this great man wrote a letter 3 to Mr. Gandhi to acknowledge copies of Indian Opinion in which he expressed these same ideas.
('11', 175, 2, 26, 353632) The letter is in Russian.
('11', 175, 2, 27, 353658) We give in this issue a Gujarati
('11', 175, 3, 28, 353691) 1 Tolstoy died on November 20, 1910. 2 Great seer 3 Vide Appendix, “ Tolstoy’s letter to Gandhiji”, 7 9 1910.
('11', 176, 0, 1, 353801) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 177
('11', 176, 1, 2, 353844) translation of it, based on an English translation.
('11', 176, 1, 3, 353896) 1 The translation is worth reading.
('11', 176, 1, 4, 353932) What he has said there about satyagraha deserves to be pondered over by all.
('11', 176, 1, 5, 354009) According to him, the Transvaal struggle will leave its mark on the world.
('11', 176, 1, 6, 354084) Everyone [he says] has much to learn from it.
('11', 176, 1, 7, 354130) He extends encouragement to the satyagrahis and assures them of justice from God, if not from the rulers.
('11', 176, 1, 8, 354236) The latter, being enamoured of their strength, will certainly not be pleased with satyagraha.
('11', 176, 1, 9, 354330) Despite that, satyagrahis must have patience and continue to fight.

('11', 176, 4, 16, 354866) 194. CHHOTABHAI CASE
('11', 176, 5, 17, 354887) Though [the decision in] this appeal has gone against Mr. Chhotabhai, we count it as a triumph for him and for the Indian community.
('11', 176, 5, 18, 355020) Mr. Justice de Villiers’ judgment is one sided.
('11', 176, 5, 19, 355068) He holds that the Act of 1907 for the most part stands repealed by the Act of 1908. He is, moreover, doubtful whether, even under the former Act, Mr. Chhotabhai’s son was protected.
('11', 176, 5, 20, 355250) This same gentleman, when he was Attorney General, had told Lord Crewe that Asiatic minors were protected under the Act of 1908 and the Act of 1907 could be availed of.
('11', 176, 5, 21, 355419) If the Act of 1907 stood repealed for the most part by the Act of 1908, why has General Smuts so far refused to repeal it altogether?
('11', 176, 5, 22, 355553) The opinion of the other two judges is very good.
('11', 176, 5, 23, 355603) Mr. Justice Bristowe is also of the view that the Act of 1907 for the most part stands repealed by the Act of 1908 and feels that Mr. Chhotabhai’s son would have been protected under the Act of 1907. He shows, moreover, that both the Acts are anomalous and points out that a law
('11', 176, 6, 24, 355882) 1 This translation by Pauline Padlashuk from the original Russian was also published on the first page of Indian Opinion, 26 11 1910.
('11', 177, 0, 1, 356016) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 177, 1, 2, 356058) which does not protect the interests of minors is tyrannical.
('11', 177, 1, 3, 356120) He then goes on to say that he has given his decision with profound misgivings.
('11', 177, 1, 4, 356200) Mr. Justice Mason, on the other hand, has held that the appeal should be decided in favour of Mr. Chhotabhai.
('11', 177, 1, 5, 356310) He has even argued that rights which were protected under the Act of 1907 could not be treated as abrogated by the Act of 1908. Under the latter, the position of children born outside the Transvaal is not clear, but under the Act of 1907 the Registrar has been empowered to issue certificates in such cases and in the present case he would have been justified in granting the certificate.
('11', 177, 1, 6, 356699) According to Mr. Justice Mason, the Registrar had wrongly assumed that he had no discretion under the Act of 1907. He has roundly condemned a state of affairs in which a minor could be expelled.
('11', 177, 1, 7, 356894) From all this, it appears certain to us that the Supreme Court will decide in favour of Mr. Chhotabhai.
('11', 177, 1, 8, 356998) The strictures passed by the judges show that both the Acts are extremely complicated and must therefore be repealed.
('11', 177, 1, 9, 357116) It will not be enough to have an amendment giving effect to Mr. Justice Mason’s decision.
('11', 177, 1, 10, 357206) Since it is within the Registrar’s discretion whether or not to grant a certificate to a minor in the position of Mr. Chhotabhai’s son, it would be a favour on his part to grant one.
('11', 177, 1, 11, 357389) Indians cannot leave it to be decided by anyone as a matter of favour whether or not a minor should receive a certificate.
('11', 177, 1, 12, 357512) Whenever parents enjoy a right, the same right for the minors should be protected as a matter of course.
('11', 177, 1, 13, 357617) Itwill certainly be protected if the Indian community has spirit enough, let the courts give what judgments they will.

('11', 179, 8, 12, 360271) The reason is that these associations are the product of modern civilization.
('11', 179, 8, 13, 360349) The English are more adept in that civilization and can therefore conduct these associations better.
('11', 179, 8, 14, 360450) Our Arya Samaj is not for the general public.
('11', 179, 8, 15, 360496) It is meant only for the educated.
('11', 179, 8, 16, 360531) The English institutions can be said to be for the masses to some extent, because even the masses there have come within the purview of that civilization.
('11', 179, 8, 17, 360686) Therefore their institutions are governed by some discipline.
('11', 179, 8, 18, 360748) Moreover, the people there consider honesty as the best policy and are honest as a matter of policy.
('11', 179, 8, 19, 360849) We, on the other hand, are honest for honesty’s sake; we do not know how to be honest for the sake of policy.
('11', 179, 8, 20, 360959) The general tendency amongst our educated is that if one holds a position where one can serve one’s selfish ends quickly, one is at once led to do so.
('11', 179, 8, 21, 361110) Moreover, those who are born and bred in diplomatic surroundings take to dishonest ways even if they are not educated.
('11', 179, 8, 22, 361229) If we think of our own family, we shall be able to see that the people of whom Kanaiyalal has lost all hopes are a mere drop in the ocean of Indian humanity.
('11', 179, 8, 23, 361387) Please think of the hypocrisy, the

('11', 182, 5, 13, 366170) 201. THE ROYAL VISIT
('11', 182, 6, 14, 366191) In the dignified letter 1 sent by Mr. Cachalia to H. R. H. the Duke of Connaught, the Transvaal Indians have but followed the example set by the Cape Indian and Coloured communities, who, as a sign of mourning, refrained from attending the ceremony of presentation.
('11', 182, 6, 15, 366457) Our countrymen in this Province have done likewise.
('11', 182, 6, 16, 366509) We believe that this is for the first time that Indians throughout South Africa have felt called upon to avoid identifying themselves completely in a public welcome to a Royal representative.
('11', 182, 6, 17, 366701) We will remember what our countrymen did when the present King visited South Africa.
('11', 182, 6, 18, 366786) Magnificent arches, costing hundreds of pounds, were erected, addresses engraved on gold plates were presented, and Indian places of business were profusely decorated.
('11', 182, 6, 19, 366954) Indians were in no way behind the other communities in rendering homage to the Royal visitors.
('11', 182, 6, 20, 367049) The step taken on this occasion, therefore, is a momentous one.
('11', 182, 6, 21, 367113) But there was no other way of marking the community’s sense of the deep grief caused by the protracted struggle in the Transvaal, and the uncertainty of its future, engendered by the Union.
('11', 182, 6, 22, 367303) It is well, however, that Mr. Cachalia and Imam Bawazeer 2 should have emphasised the fact that the community’s loyalty to the Throne had not suffered by reason of

('11', 183, 1, 2, 367594) its afflictions, and that its personal welcome to the Royal visitors was none the less warm on that account.
('11', 183, 2, 3, 367703) Indian Opinion, 3 12 1910
('11', 183, 3, 4, 367729) 202. SUPREME VIRTUE OF AGRICULTURE
('11', 183, 4, 5, 367764) O tiller of the soil, Rightly they call you father of the world; You, and you alone, provide For all mankind;— Cotton, fruits, flowers and grass, And foodgrains too, The food that sustains all creatures, And clothing that is welcome to all.
('11', 183, 4, 6, 368005) Braving heat and rain, Unremitting in toil, Robust of health, Ever you move in contentment.
('11', 183, 4, 7, 368097) Of worth supreme is the tiller’s work, Work that tends to others’ good; Tireless in your labour, You teach a good lesson to the world.
('11', 183, 5, 8, 368232) We have reproduced this poem from the second standard reader which most of us studied at school.
('11', 183, 5, 9, 368329) But how many of us have profited from what we learnt?
('11', 183, 5, 10, 368383) Of course the farmer is the father of the world.
('11', 183, 5, 11, 368432) But it is his greatness that he is not aware of the fact.
('11', 183, 5, 12, 368490) Those who devote themselves to good works of any worth are not aware of their own goodness.
('11', 183, 5, 13, 368582) Just as we breathe every moment but are not aware of the fact, so are good people by their very nature impelled to give expression to their goodness.
('11', 183, 5, 14, 368732) They are not conscious that they deserve any credit.
('11', 183, 5, 15, 368785) They do not care to be honoured.
('11', 183, 5, 16, 368818) If we recite the poem given above before a farmer, he will simply be amused.
('11', 183, 5, 17, 368895) He will not even understand what we mean.
('11', 183, 5, 18, 368937) So true a father is he, and so sincere a benefactor.
('11', 183, 5, 19, 368990) But we who recite the poem, what do we do?
('11', 183, 5, 20, 369033) If the farmer is indeed a father and if his profession is indeed the highest, why are we
('11', 184, 0, 1, 369122) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 185
('11', 184, 1, 2, 369165) busy padding ourselves with heaps of clothes?
('11', 184, 1, 3, 369211) Why do we grind the poor under our heels to extort the last farthing from them?
('11', 184, 1, 4, 369291) Why do we think it manly to be mere clerks, attired in respectable clothes?
('11', 184, 1, 5, 369367) Such is our benighted state.
('11', 184, 1, 6, 369396) We only talk of agriculture.
('11', 184, 1, 7, 369425) It has got stuck in our throats and does not go further than that.
('11', 184, 1, 8, 369492) Those Indians who wish to be happy in this country or wish to render any real service to India should ponder over the poem given above and try to act upon it.
('11', 184, 1, 9, 369651) Even if there is a single reader who is convinced that he must take to agriculture, he need not wait for others [to join him].
('11', 184, 2, 10, 369778) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 3 12 1910
('11', 184, 3, 11, 369820) 203. INDIANS AND H. R. H. THE DUKE
('11', 184, 4, 12, 369855) An unprecedented thing has happened in South Africa.
('11', 184, 4, 13, 369908) Indians have always presented addresses to Royal guests and participated in public celebrations.
('11', 184, 4, 14, 370005) The Cape made a beginning in connection with [the visit of] H. R. H. the Duke this time.
('11', 184, 4, 15, 370094) It sent an address, but did not attend the public function.
('11', 184, 4, 16, 370154) The Transvaal went a step further.
('11', 184, 4, 17, 370189) It explained the reasons for not sending an address, thus bringing to the Duke’s notice the disabilities under which it labours, and conveyed its loyalty in a letter.
('11', 184, 4, 18, 370356) That there was no impropriety in such a step, is made evident by the Duke’s courteous reply.
('11', 184, 4, 19, 370449) How can the Indian community, seething with discontent and in mourning, join public celebrations?
('11', 184, 4, 20, 370547) Its participation can never be sincere.
('11', 184, 4, 21, 370587) However, everyone must acknowledge that the letters 1 addressed by Mr. Cachalia and the Imam Saheb were but proper.
('11', 184, 4, 22, 370703) The Natal Congress, too, has taken a similar step, and rightly.
('11', 184, 4, 23, 370767) The effect of this step will be known in the future.
('11', 184, 4, 24, 370820) People will be all the more convinced of our integrity and attach greater weight to whatever we do.
('11', 184, 4, 25, 370920) They will know that we are no hypocrites, that we do not hesitate to place our views, in proper language, even before an emperor.
('11', 184, 5, 26, 371050) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 3 12 1910
('11', 184, 6, 27, 371092) 1 Vide “Letters to Private Secretary to Duke of Connaught, after 18 11 1910.

('11', 185, 1, 2, 371211) 204. CECIL INDIANS
('11', 185, 2, 3, 371230) Indians are unwelcome, wherever they go.
('11', 185, 2, 4, 371271) As soon as, having settled in a foreign land for some time, they join in its commerce and industry and prosper, they find themselves under attack.
('11', 185, 2, 5, 371418) The island of Cecil has a fairly large Indian population, and the numbers grow every year.
('11', 185, 2, 6, 371509) The majority of the immigrants come from Malabar.
('11', 185, 2, 7, 371559) Most of the shops in this island are owned by Indians.
('11', 185, 2, 8, 371614) A few Chinese traders are also to be found.
('11', 185, 2, 9, 371658) Much of the immovable property in the port has been raised with Indian investment.
('11', 185, 2, 10, 371741) Agriculture there, as in Natal, owes its development to Indians.
('11', 185, 2, 11, 371806) Indians have thus sought their own prosperity while advancing that of the Colony.
('11', 185, 2, 12, 371888) And yet it is interesting to note what kind of attitude the whites adopt to all this.
('11', 185, 2, 13, 371974) In his report for the previous year, the Governor of the island has called attention, by way of warning, to the acquisition of land by Indian traders, saying that Indians are usually bad farmers, for their aim is to get rich quick by exploiting the land for all it is worth and then run back to India.
('11', 185, 2, 14, 372276) Land in this country costs on an average Rs. 100 per acre, though it is quite difficult to get any with fertile soil.
('11', 185, 2, 15, 372394) One wonders, after reading this report, what reason there can be for anything in the nature of a warning if Indians, by their labour on land of ordinary quality, toil for the prosperity of the country and in the process grow prosperous themselves.
('11', 185, 2, 16, 372642) An English poet, Goldsmith, has said 1 that industrious farmers area far greater and truer treasure for any country than kings and nobles.
('11', 185, 2, 17, 372781) It is in the interest of the country and the people that this “treasure” should receive encouragement, instead of being regarded with distrust.
('11', 185, 3, 18, 372925) [From Gujarati]
('11', 185, 4, 19, 372941) Indian Opinion, 3 12 1910
('11', 185, 5, 20, 372967) 1 Princes and lords may flourish, or may fade; A breath can make them, as a breath has made; But a bold peasantry, their country’s pride, When once destroyed, can never be supplied.
('11', 185, 5, 21, 373149) — The Deserted Village

('11', 186, 7, 16, 373755) 206. LETTER TO G. A. NATESAN
('11', 186, 8, 17, 373784) TOLSTOY FARM, December 9, 1910
('11', 186, 9, 18, 373815) DEAR MR. NATESAN,
('11', 186, 10, 19, 373833) I owe you a long reply.
('11', 186, 10, 20, 373857) But being obliged to move about and being otherwise busy over the struggle, I have been unable to save a quiet hour for writing to you.
('11', 186, 10, 21, 373993) Many thanks for the cable remitting £400. The help is most timely.
('11', 186, 10, 22, 374060) The unexpected difficulties about the landing of the returned deportees have cost over £500 leaving nothing for current expenses.
('11', 186, 10, 23, 374190) I was therefore obliged to cable 2 to you for funds.
('11', 186, 10, 24, 374243) A similar cable 3 was sent to Mr. Petit also.
('11', 186, 10, 25, 374289) The same day that brought your cable brought also a letter from Mr. Ratan Tata enclosing a cheque for Rs. 25,000. There is therefore no anxiety nowregarding money.
('11', 186, 10, 26, 374453) I enclose copy of Mr. Tata’s letter.
('11', 186, 11, 27, 374490) 1 The Gujarati translation of Thomas Taylor’s article “Fallacy of Speed”, mentioned in the letter, was published in Indian Opinion, 10 12 1910; this letter was written before the Friday of that week, which fell on 9 12 1910. 2 Not available 3 ibid
('11', 187, 0, 1, 374738) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 187, 1, 2, 374780) Everyone of the returned deportees speaks most highly of your kindness.
('11', 187, 1, 3, 374852) They tell me that you were most unremitting in your attention to them.
('11', 187, 1, 4, 374923) May I thank you for all you have done in their behalf?
('11', 187, 2, 5, 374978) You will have noticed that not a single Indian deportee has had to go back to India—I mean of the 2nd batch.
('11', 187, 2, 6, 375087) It was unfortunate that the 19 Chinese had to go back.
('11', 187, 2, 7, 375142) But partly it was the fault of the Chinese Association.
('11', 187, 2, 8, 375198) That body was not ready for the emergency that faced it.
('11', 187, 3, 9, 375255) You will have noticed too that everyone of the returned men has now already passed through the gaols of the Transvaal or is at present serving his term.
('11', 187, 3, 10, 375408) This does not include the five men who are still at the Cape.
('11', 187, 3, 11, 375470) But I expect them to cross the border shortly.
('11', 187, 4, 12, 375517) Your fear about the payment to the indigent families was natural though groundless.
('11', 187, 4, 13, 375601) It did very great credit to your heart.
('11', 187, 4, 14, 375641) I had suspended payment as I was, as you know, in cable communication 1
('11', 187, 5, 15, 375713) with the men.
('11', 187, 5, 16, 375727) I was in hopes that the men would willingly cable consent to their families going to the Farm, as most of them knew that negotiations were going on for securing one and as they were told that the families could only be supported on the Farm.
('11', 187, 5, 17, 375969) But as soon as I saw that the men would not consent, all the families who had not consented to go to the Farm were paid up to the 7th of October.
('11', 187, 5, 18, 376115) That was the last date fixed because I had conferences with the men at Durban.
('11', 187, 5, 19, 376194) Every fact was placed before them and they were told that the families must either go to the Farm or support themselves.
('11', 187, 5, 20, 376315) I told them too that the funds in hand would not allow of the families being indefinitely supported outside the Farm.
('11', 187, 5, 21, 376433) The men, however, elected to go to gaol.
('11', 187, 5, 22, 376474) Some families have come to the Farm but the vast majority are supporting themselves in Johannesburg.
('11', 187, 5, 23, 376575) The Farm serves a double purpose.
('11', 187, 5, 24, 376609) It enables us to support families at a much cheaper rate thus providing for an indefinite prolongation of the struggle and it prevents fraud and deception.
('11', 187, 5, 25, 376765) For it must be confessed that the fighters—some of them— are not above taking an undue advantage of one’s ignorance.
('11', 187, 5, 26, 376882) The Farm puts a stop to this sort of thing.
('11', 187, 5, 27, 376926) Those who cannot really support themselves must perforce come to the Farm.
('11', 187, 5, 28, 377001) Those who do not are some way or other capable of supporting themselves.
('11', 187, 5, 29, 377074) Moreover this struggle is pre eminently educative.
('11', 187, 6, 30, 377125) 1 Not available
('11', 188, 0, 1, 377141) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 189
('11', 188, 1, 2, 377184) intended therethrough to raise men.
('11', 188, 1, 3, 377220) This cannot be done unless we purge the community of dross.
('11', 188, 1, 4, 377280) On the Farm we are also able to give some kind of education to the families.

('11', 189, 4, 7, 379660) 207. SWEET ARE THE FRUITS OF PATIENCE
('11', 189, 5, 8, 379698) Indians have been showing impatience ever since people began to talk about a settlement.
('11', 189, 5, 9, 379787) “Why has no bill been published yet?
('11', 189, 5, 10, 379824) When will one be published?
('11', 189, 5, 11, 379852) Has the matter been put off till January?
('11', 189, 5, 12, 379894) Will it be as late as February?
('11', 189, 5, 13, 379926) Perhaps there will be no bill, after all.” Such impatience is a sign of timidity and cowardice.
('11', 189, 5, 14, 380022) What we are entitled to, we are bound to get in due time.
('11', 189, 5, 15, 380080) But we grow impatient for something that we do not deserve and thereby prove that we are not worthy of it.
('11', 189, 5, 16, 380187) We shall not show impatience about anything which we know or believe we are entitled to.
('11', 189, 5, 17, 380276) What does it matter whether a bill is published now or later, or never published at all?
('11', 189, 5, 18, 380365) Really speaking, continuing delay is of double advantage to us.
('11', 189, 5, 19, 380429) One, Indians who have remained staunch are being tested.
('11', 189, 5, 20, 380486) Two, those who are not taking part in the struggle will realize that our demands are bound to be met so long as even one person is left to continue the fight.
('11', 189, 5, 21, 380645) Indians who understand this, whether they are satyagrahis or not, will not show impatience.
('11', 189, 5, 22, 380737) We should realize that impatience may delay the result indefinitely.
('11', 189, 5, 23, 380806) Even in simple matters, we lose our presence of mind if we are in too great a hurry and so find ourselves completely bewildered.
('11', 189, 5, 24, 380935) That is why it is said that a man in haste is a man at sea, and a man unruffled is one in full command of his wits.
('11', 189, 5, 25, 381051) 1 We therefore urge all Indians to remain patient.

('11', 193, 2, 6, 386492) His letter is as inspiring as his gift is generous.
('11', 193, 2, 7, 386544) Mr. Tata knows very well that this is not a struggle to secure our own narrow ends, but that it is for the honour of India.
('11', 193, 2, 8, 386668) He has said, in so many words, that the effects of this struggle will be felt in all parts of the world under British rule, and that is exactly what will happen.

('11', 193, 2, 13, 387232) By sacrificing their all for the sake of the nation’s honour, they will but gain what they [seem to] lose.

('11', 193, 2, 15, 387401) What wonder, then, if a wealthy Indian like Mr. Tata contributes money for such a struggle?

('11', 193, 2, 17, 387592) All the same, there is no need to feel sorry.
