('11', 193, 4, 23, 388009) We are dealing with General Smuts.
('11', 193, 4, 24, 388044) The gentleman is capable of backing out without a moment’s hesitation.
('11', 193, 4, 25, 388115) As time passes, he grows more confident that the satyagraha will collapse; if everyone capitulates, why should he go in for a settlement?
('11', 193, 4, 26, 388253) But this unholy expectation of his is not likely to come true.
('11', 193, 4, 27, 388316) We are convinced that so long as there is even a single satyagrahi left, the Act is bound at last to be amended.
('11', 193, 4, 28, 388429) The great Thoreau has said that a worthy cause should never be deemed lost, that it is bound to triumph, so long as there is at least one sincere man to fight for it.
('11', 193, 4, 29, 388596) In fact, though a few more satyagrahis may yet fall, there will certainly remain some who will

('11', 194, 1, 2, 388734) fight on till death.

('11', 194, 1, 4, 388855) This is no ordinary fight.
('11', 194, 1, 5, 388882) Let us lay down our lives in it, and so live.

('11', 194, 4, 15, 389637) 212. CALCUTTA RIOT
('11', 194, 5, 16, 389656) The riot that occurred in Calcutta must have given rise, naturally, to all sorts of reflections among Indians.
('11', 194, 5, 17, 389767) We do not think that this was a “religious” riot; rather, it was “irreligious”.
('11', 194, 5, 18, 389847) Plenty of irreligious things are done in the world in the name of religion.
('11', 194, 5, 19, 389923) Little reflection is needed to show that the Marwari 2 had no reason to kill Muslims because the latter kill cows.
('11', 194, 5, 20, 390038) Surely, the cows will not be saved as a result.
('11', 194, 5, 21, 390086) By killing Muslims, who are his brethren, the Marwari will make himself doubly a sinner.
('11', 194, 5, 22, 390175) Why do the Hindus not feel for the cows which the English kill every day?
('11', 194, 5, 23, 390249) It is known very well that killing anyone is not the way to stop this.
('11', 194, 5, 24, 390320) Why, again, should the Muslims kill only cows?
('11', 194, 5, 25, 390367) But where people are out to spite one another, this is bound to be the result.
('11', 194, 5, 26, 390446) We have been reduced to such a wretched plight and have got so much into the clutches of courts and lawyers, that we cannot use our common sense.
('11', 194, 5, 27, 390592) If we did, we would immediately see that the Marwari had no reason to fight with the Muslim.
('11', 194, 5, 28, 390685) What he should do is to plead with the latter once, twice, and if he does not respond, even a thousand times.
('11', 194, 5, 29, 390795) Such entreaty, however,
('11', 194, 6, 30, 390819) 1 A Gujarati poet ( 1753 1825) 2 Marwaris are Hindus of Marwar in Rajasthan, engaged in business in Calcutta and other cities.
('11', 195, 0, 1, 390946) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 195, 1, 2, 390988) will be sincere only if we have sworn not to fight or go to court, should the Muslim fail to respond.
('11', 195, 1, 3, 391090) If, failing to understand this simple thing, we start riots, we shall only be exploiting religion for selfish ends.
('11', 195, 1, 4, 391206) If this is the simple duty of religious minded Hindus, there is a corresponding duty for religious minded Muslims.
('11', 195, 1, 5, 391321) They too are not justified in fighting.
('11', 195, 1, 6, 391361) Besides, they should abstain from killing cows except on occasions when that is enjoined as a religious duty.
('11', 195, 1, 7, 391471) The two sides, however, should not keep watching each other’s actions.
('11', 195, 1, 8, 391542) Either of them may take the right step without thinking of what the other might do.
('11', 195, 1, 9, 391626) There may also be some who hold back because of the fear that so long as we go on fighting in this manner, we shall always remain a subject people, if not under the British, under some other great power.
('11', 195, 1, 10, 391830) If we go a little deeper into this, we shall see that this is quite a wrong notion.
('11', 195, 1, 11, 391914) In fact, it is because of our subjection that the riots occur.
('11', 195, 1, 12, 391977) So long as we believe that there is a government to shield us when we get the worse of the fighting, the one course that is truly religious will not occur to us.
('11', 195, 1, 13, 392139) We shall thus go on moving round in a circle, like the bullock in the oil mill, his vision blocked, fondly believing that we are progressing.
('11', 195, 1, 14, 392281) There is one royal Toad even out of this difficult situation, and only one.
('11', 195, 1, 15, 392357) Though dependent, we should behave as though we were independent.
('11', 195, 1, 16, 392423) If, in consequence, one has to lay down one’s life, one must do so.
('11', 195, 1, 17, 392491) That alone is the final test.
('11', 195, 1, 18, 392521) He who takes too much thought of this life can gain nothing either in this world or in the other.

('11', 196, 10, 16, 393691) 215. EXTRACTS FROM LETTER TO S.A.B.I. COMMITTEE 3
('11', 196, 11, 17, 393741) [Before December 30, 1910]
('11', 196, 12, 18, 393768) Ministers beg to assure His Excellency that the so called Indian Passive Resisters are not differentiated against in the Transvaal prisons.
('11', 196, 13, 19, 393908) This Mr. Gandhi denies.
('11', 196, 13, 20, 393932) He states:
('11', 196, 14, 21, 393943) 1 This appears to have been written on the Monday after “Letter to Olive Doke”, 15 12 1910. 2 This text is obviously incomplete.
('11', 196, 14, 22, 394072) 3 Gandhiji, citing from the Blue book Cd.
('11', 196, 14, 23, 394114) 5363, wrote a letter to the South Africa British Indian Committee, London, dealing with a number of inaccurate and misleading statements made by the Transvaal Government in its communication to the Transvaal Governor.
('11', 196, 14, 24, 394332) Pertinent extracts from the letter along with the inaccurate statements dealt with were forwarded to the Under Secretary of State, Colonial Office, by Ritch on December 30, 1910.
('11', 197, 0, 1, 394511) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 197, 1, 2, 394553) Bona fide Indian prisoners, before passive resistance commenced, were, because of their known objection to carrying slop pails, as a rule, exempted from that duty.
('11', 197, 1, 3, 394717) That was so when I had the honour to be one of 151 prisoners in Johannesburg and equally so at Volksrust when there were over 75 prisoners.
('11', 197, 1, 4, 394857) The severity of prison treatment has progressed with the progress of passive resistance and it reached its culminating point when all passive resisters were removed to Diepkloof, where, it being a penal settlement, the regulations are far more strict.
('11', 197, 1, 5, 395109) For instance, an Indian, and for that matter a Native, undergoing sentence for, say, attempted murder at Volksrust or Johannesburg is able to receive visitors and also to write letters.
('11', 197, 1, 6, 395295) At Diepkloof, prisoners, whether they are convicted of heinous offences or are passive resisters, cannot by regulation receive visitors for three months.
('11', 197, 1, 7, 395449) Most of the passive resisters are imprisoned for three months.
('11', 197, 2, 8, 395512) Every opportunity was afforded to the individual of proving domicile in any other part of South Africa, but all these persons failed to do so.
('11', 197, 2, 9, 395655) Wherever it appeared that a person had been resident or born in any other part of South Africa, he was returned thither and not deported to India.
('11', 197, 2, 10, 395802) It was ruled by Supreme Court of Transvaal in case of Leung Quinn and another versus Attorney General in May last and subsequently in the question of Naidoo v.
('11', 197, 2, 11, 395962) Rex, that when an Asiatic failed on demand to produce certificate of registra tion, he could be arrested and brought before Magistrate under Section VII of Act 36 of 1908 and if he does not satisfy Magistrate that he was registered Asiatic, Magistrate had no option but was bound to make an order directing Asiatic to be removed from the Colony.
('11', 197, 3, 12, 396308) Mr. Gandhi denies that every opportunity was afforded of proving domicile or South African birth.
('11', 197, 3, 13, 396406) He says: I take the very first case that is quoted by the Government on page 130; it is that of Manikum Pillay.
('11', 197, 3, 14, 396518) I make bold to say that Manikum Pillay was well known to the Registrar and so was his father.
('11', 197, 3, 15, 396612) What is more, Manikum Pillay speaks English fluently.
('11', 197, 3, 16, 396666) He declared himself to have been a student and certainly claimed that he was South African born and that he was entitled to go to Natal by reason of his educational qualifications.
('11', 197, 3, 17, 396847) The other case is that of R.S.C. Pillay.
('11', 197, 3, 18, 396888) He too claimed educational qualifications.
('11', 197, 3, 19, 396931) Similarly T.A.S. Acharya.
('11', 197, 3, 20, 396957) The despatch in his case makes the admission that he claimed the right to reside in
('11', 198, 0, 1, 397041) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 199
('11', 198, 1, 2, 397084) any South African Colony and so he did because of his educational qualifications.
('11', 198, 1, 3, 397166) I have in my possession letters from him whilst he was being detained in Pretoria, telling me that he had stated everything he had to with reference to his qualifications.
('11', 198, 1, 4, 397338) But all the prisoners named were deported to India.
('11', 198, 1, 5, 397390) I know two brothers Pillay who before they went to the Magistrate asked me whether they too would be deported although they were born in Kimberley.
('11', 198, 1, 6, 397538) I told them that they should not be, and that they should state to the Magistrate that they were born in the Old Colony.
('11', 198, 1, 7, 397659) I saw them after the order of deportation was made against them.
('11', 198, 1, 8, 397724) They told me that they had protested that they were born in Kimberley but that it had been of no avail.
('11', 198, 1, 9, 397828) I well recollect the two brothers having felt offended with me because they thought that I had misled them.
('11', 198, 1, 10, 397936) I could multiply such instances.
('11', 198, 2, 11, 397969) In regard to the Supreme Court cases above cited, Mr. Gandhi writes:
('11', 198, 3, 12, 398038) The Government have, I do not know whether consciously or unconsciously, undoubtedly misled Lord Crewe by stating that the cases of Leung Quinn and another v.
('11', 198, 3, 13, 398197) the Attorney General and Naidoo v.
('11', 198, 3, 14, 398232) Rex show that an Asiatic failing to produce a certificate of registration can be arrested and brought before a magistrate under Section 7 for his removal from the Colony.
('11', 198, 3, 15, 398403) In Mr. Quinn’s case, the only question at issue was whether the period of Mr. Quinn’s detention after deportation was reasonable.
('11', 198, 3, 16, 398533) In Mr. Naidoo’s case, the question was that of legal objections as to whether the regulations under which he was charged were applicable to his case and whether the Registrar was duly appointed.
('11', 198, 3, 17, 398728) Ordinarily, the misleading statement now referred to would not matter much, but in the dispatch in which it occurs, it is pertinent in order to justify the extraordinary conduct of the Government in trying to bring passive resisters before an administrative board and to procure their deportation rather than allow them to be tried judicially and to suffer imprisonment to which they had become inured.
('11', 198, 3, 18, 399131) It will not be denied that many of these deportees were during the initial stages of the struggle tried judicially and simply imprisoned.
('11', 198, 3, 19, 399269) They were also known to the police as being registered residents of the Transvaal.
('11', 198, 3, 20, 399352) Why were they subsequently tried administratively and ordered to be deported?
('11', 199, 0, 1, 399430) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 199, 1, 2, 399472) As regards future deportations, instructions have been given to the police to exercise every care that Asiatics who have been registered are not dealt with under the clause of the Act which entails deportation.
('11', 199, 2, 3, 399683) Mr. Gandhi remarks:
('11', 199, 3, 4, 399703) Why this precaution only now?
('11', 199, 3, 5, 399733) Is it not a fact that the proceedings under the deportation section of the Act were taken at the instance of the Law Department and that it was not the police who were responsible for the deportation proceedings?
('11', 199, 3, 6, 399946) I read a Minute from the then Attorney General before the Union was proclaimed addressed to Crown Prosecutors to the effect that passive resisters were to be charged under deportation sections and not under sections for non production of registration certificates as of old.
('11', 199, 3, 7, 400221) I submit therefore that it is highly misleading, if not dishonest, now to state that the police have been instructed to exercise very great care, etc.
('11', 199, 3, 8, 400372) Let me however give a few instances.
('11', 199, 3, 9, 400409) There is case 46, R.S.N. Moodaley.
('11', 199, 3, 10, 400444) He is supposed to have refused to give any means of identification.
('11', 199, 3, 11, 400512) Now I know that the Magistrate who ordered deportation himself hesitated, as he knew Moodaley to be a resident of some twenty years and as he recognised him also to be an old offender (Passive Resister) and a duly registered Indian.
('11', 199, 3, 12, 400745) Why was he ordered for deportation?
('11', 199, 3, 13, 400781) There is the other old offender, Thambi Naidoo.
('11', 199, 3, 14, 400829) He was not only known to the police, the Magistrate, the Registrar and everybody concerned to have been a registered resident but he was one of those who, when voluntary registration was going on (in 1907), helped the Registrar’s Department, and was thanked by the Registrar for his work.
('11', 199, 3, 15, 401118) Short of producing his registration certificate, Mr. Quinn, the leader of the Chinese Association, produced proof before the Magistrate that he was registered.
('11', 199, 3, 16, 401278) He tried hard to avoid deportation.
('11', 199, 3, 17, 401314) He was known to General Smuts, as also to the Registrar.
('11', 199, 3, 18, 401371) Why was he deported?
('11', 199, 4, 19, 401392) Mr. Gandhi adds:
('11', 199, 5, 20, 401409) There are other statements made by the Transvaal Government which are also capable of refutation.

('11', 200, 1, 2, 401634) 216. TRIAL OF RAMBHABAI R. SODHA
('11', 200, 2, 3, 401667) [JOHANNESBURG,] December 30, 1910
('11', 200, 3, 4, 401701) The much adjourned case 1 of Mrs. Rambhabai R. Sodha came up before Mr. D J. Schuurman, in “B” Court, Johannesburg, on Friday, the 30th ultimo.
('11', 200, 3, 5, 401845) She was charged with contravening Section 5, read together with Section 2 of Sub Section 1 of Act 15 of 1907 (the Immigrants’ Restriction Act) in that, being a prohibited immigrant, she entered into or was found within the Transvaal—that is to say, that when asked at Johannesburg by a duly authorised officer, she was unable, through deficient education, to write out and sign in the characters of a European language an application for permission to enter the Transvaal Colony.
('11', 200, 4, 6, 402325) Mr. Cramer prosecuted for the Crown and Mr. M. K. Gandhi appeared for the defence.
('11', 200, 5, 7, 402408) As soon as the case was called, Mr. Cramer (the Public Prosecutor) allowed Mr. Gandhi to go into an adjoining room with the Immigration Officer (Mr. Emphietze) for the purpose of putting the accused through an education test.
('11', 200, 6, 8, 402634) Some difficulty arose in connection with the interpretation of the evidence.
('11', 200, 6, 9, 402711) Mr. Cramer explained that Mr. Gandhi would act as interpreter.
('11', 200, 6, 10, 402774) His worship objected to this course.
('11', 200, 7, 11, 402811) MR. CRAMER: It is not a matter of evidence.
('11', 200, 7, 12, 402855) There is a difficulty about the matter, for there are several dialects.
('11', 200, 8, 13, 402927) HIS WORSHIP: I have no objection personally, but is it quite regular?
('11', 200, 9, 14, 402997) MR. GANDHI: I have no objection.
('11', 200, 10, 15, 403030) MR. CRAMER: I have less.
('11', 200, 11, 16, 403055) Mr. Gandhi was eventually asked to interpret the charge to the accused.
('11', 200, 12, 17, 403127) In reply the accused said that she did not know any European language, but said that she was not guilty.
('11', 200, 13, 18, 403232) For further interpretation Mr. Pragji K. Desai was sworn to perform the duty.
('11', 200, 14, 19, 403310) Mr. Cramer said this case had been a matter of correspondence between Mr. Gandhi and the Attorney General’s office, and he (the speaker) had been instructed to carry on with the case.
('11', 200, 14, 20, 403494) He then called Mr. Emphietze, an immigration officer of the Transvaal and a member of the C.I.D., who said that he had asked the accused through
('11', 200, 15, 21, 403639) 1 She was arrested on November 6, and on November 7 her case was remanded for 14 days; it was then transferred to Johannesburg.
('11', 201, 0, 1, 403767) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 201, 1, 2, 403809) Mr. Gandhi as to whether she could read or write a European language.
('11', 201, 1, 3, 403879) She replied through Mr. Gandhi that she could not.
('11', 201, 1, 4, 403930) She also said she did not know whether her husband was registered under the Act.
('11', 201, 2, 5, 404011) Mr. Gandhi corroborated this evidence, and said he also knew that accused could not speak or write any European language.
('11', 201, 3, 6, 404133) This closed the case for the prosecution.
('11', 201, 4, 7, 404175) Mr. Sodha, the husband of the accused, a passive resistance prisoner at present at the Fort, was called by Mr. Gandhi and said he was serving three months’ imprisonment under the Registration Act.
('11', 201, 4, 8, 404372) He had a wife and three children, had been in South Africa nearly 14 years, and came to the Transvaal in 1897. He did business in Pretoria, but during the War went to Natal as a refugee.
('11', 201, 4, 9, 404559) After the War he came to the Transvaal again, passing the necessary test at Volksrust on the 7th October, 1908. Since then he had been off and on in jail for non compliance with the Registration Act.
('11', 201, 4, 10, 404759) While in jail his store was broken into and he had lost all his property.
('11', 201, 5, 11, 404833) [Questioned] by the Magistrate: His registration pass, before the war, was issued at Komatipoort.
('11', 201, 5, 12, 404931) He had not taken out a registration pass under subsequent legislation because of his conscience.
('11', 201, 6, 13, 405028) Mr. Gandhi again gave evidence and said that, about two months ago, when he was in Natal, the previous witness was there also.
('11', 201, 6, 14, 405155) After consultation, and solely upon witness’s responsibility, the accused came to the Transvaal.
('11', 201, 6, 15, 405252) He telegraphed 1 to the Immigration Officer that the accused with her minor children was entering the Province upon a particular date.
('11', 201, 6, 16, 405387) He received no reply, and the accused and her children left with witness for Johannesburg.
('11', 201, 6, 17, 405478) At the border she was arrested as a prohibited immigrant.
('11', 201, 7, 18, 405536) Cross examined: Witness considered the accused’s real home was in the Transvaal.
('11', 201, 7, 19, 405617) When he came to the Transvaal he left his wife behind in Natal.
('11', 201, 7, 20, 405681) The accused came to the Transvaal after her husband was convicted.
('11', 201, 7, 21, 405748) He left a furnished home for his wife in Natal, but, unfortunately, it was not long furnished.
('11', 201, 8, 22, 405843) MR. CRAMER: I put it to you fairly and squarely.
('11', 201, 8, 23, 405892) Was she not brought up here for the purpose of agitating against the Asiatic law?
('11', 201, 8, 24, 405974) [GANDHIJI]: That is entirely wrong.
('11', 201, 9, 25, 406010) Why was she brought here?
('11', 201, 9, 26, 406036) For the simple reason that the passive resisters’ families had to be supported out of public funds, and It was convenient to support Mrs. Sodha in the Transvaal as also to look after her family.
('11', 201, 10, 27, 406231) For whom to support her?
('11', 201, 11, 28, 406256) 1 Vide “Telegram to Chief Immigration Officer”, before 6 11 1910
('11', 202, 0, 1, 406321) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 203
('11', 202, 1, 2, 406364) For those engaged in looking after the families of the passive resisters.
('11', 202, 2, 3, 406438) In the Transvaal?
('11', 202, 2, 4, 406456) Yes, in the Transvaal.
('11', 202, 3, 5, 406479) Sodha came up here as a passive resister?
('11', 202, 3, 6, 406521) Yes, he entered as a passive resister.
('11', 202, 3, 7, 406560) He came here undoubtedly in order to test his rights.
('11', 202, 4, 8, 406614) And afterwards, in order that the passive resisters might better support his wife, you had her brought up?
('11', 202, 5, 9, 406721) It was not impossible to keep the accused in Natal, said Mr. Gandhi, but it was highly inconvenient in the interests of the health of herself and the youngest child who was sickly.
('11', 202, 5, 10, 406902) Mrs. Sodha was living in a lonely place.
('11', 202, 5, 11, 406943) And she could be best protected at Tolstoy Farm.
('11', 202, 6, 12, 406992) In reply to questions from the Bench, Mr. Gandhi wished to make it quite clear that Mrs. Sodha had not been brought up in order in any manner whatsoever to support what had been called the Asiatic agitation.
('11', 202, 6, 13, 407200) There had been no desire whatsoever to defy the laws of the country in connection with the entrance of Mrs. Sodha.
('11', 202, 6, 14, 407315) On the contrary, every possible attempt had been made to conciliate the authorities, even where he thought they were erring on the wrong side so far as the legal point was concerned.
('11', 202, 7, 15, 407498) In further reply to the Magistrate, Mr. Gandhi said not a single passive resister got a single farthing as wage or pay for going to jail, unless the support given to dependants could be so termed.
('11', 202, 8, 16, 407695) THE MAGISTRATE: No, I do not mean that at all.
('11', 202, 8, 17, 407742) What do the passive resisters do when they are discharged?
('11', 202, 9, 18, 407801) MR. GANDHI: Those who so wish are taken to Tolstoy Farm and there supported.
('11', 202, 10, 19, 407878) THE MAGISTRATE: Are they not paid anything?
('11', 202, 11, 20, 407922) MR. GANDHI: Not a farthing.
('11', 202, 12, 21, 407950) Mr. Gandhi then returned to his chair at the “horseshoe” and said that that was his case.
('11', 202, 13, 22, 408040) Mr. Cramer, in addressing the Court, said that the only question was whether the accused had a knowledge of a European language.
('11', 202, 13, 23, 408169) This it was proved she did not possess.
('11', 202, 13, 24, 408209) It might be unfortunate that the lady was before the Court; but her Asiatic birth had nothing to do with the case.
('11', 203, 0, 1, 408324) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 203, 1, 2, 408366) Mr. Gandhi, addressing the Court, gracefully acknowledged the courtesy extended by the Magistrate and the Public Prosecutor.
('11', 203, 1, 3, 408491) He said that if the case ended with the education test, the Crown was bound to secure a conviction.
('11', 203, 1, 4, 408591) But the speaker submitted that Mrs. Sodha was protected under the other sections of the Act.
('11', 203, 1, 5, 408684) She was not guilty because she was the wife of a person who was not a prohibited immigrant.
('11', 203, 1, 6, 408776) Mr. Sodha was not a prohibited immigrant because, according to the evidence, he had passed the education test at Volksrust on his entry.
('11', 203, 1, 7, 408913) Again, Mr. Sodha, being a pre war resident of the Transvaal, was an eligible Asiatic under the Registration Act, and, therefore, not a prohibited immigrant.
('11', 203, 1, 8, 409070) Mr. Sodha’s conviction did not affect his (Mr. Gandhi’s) contention, as he was convicted only for not producing his registration certificate.
('11', 203, 1, 9, 409212) This did not make Mr. Sodha a prohibited immigrant in any way whatsoever.
('11', 203, 2, 10, 409286) Mr. Gandhi further urged that Mrs. Sodha, being a married woman, could not, under the Common Law of South Africa, be declared guilty of a statutory crime.
('11', 203, 2, 11, 409441) By the common Law she had a right to follow her husband.
('11', 203, 2, 12, 409498) And while her husband was in the Transvaal she had a right to be also.
('11', 203, 2, 13, 409569) In the circumstances, Mr. Gandhi asked for Mrs. Sodha’s discharge.
('11', 203, 3, 14, 409636) The Court reserved judgement up to the 6th January.
('11', 203, 4, 15, 409688) The proceedings were keenly watched by the Indian community.
('11', 203, 4, 16, 409749) Many Indian ladies were present.
('11', 203, 4, 17, 409782) Mrs. Vogl, Miss Schlesin, the Rev.
('11', 203, 4, 18, 409817) Mr. Doke, and Mr. Kallenbach also attended.
('11', 203, 4, 19, 409861) The Indian ladies remained with Mrs. Sodha the whole day and showed her marked attention.
('11', 203, 4, 20, 409951) It was a pathetic scene to see her in the Court house with her baby in her arms and three year old child by her side.

('11', 204, 3, 10, 411950) 218. A MOMENTOUS DECISION
('11', 204, 4, 11, 411976) Reuter’s correspondent at Calcutta cables the gladsome news that the Government of India has decided to issue a notice in April prohibiting the further emigration of indentured Indians to Natal from July 1st.
('11', 204, 4, 12, 412185) The Hon.
('11', 204, 4, 13, 412194) Gokhale, the representative of the non official members of the Imperial Legislative Council, expressed the deep gratitude of Indians for the decision.

('11', 204, 4, 15, 412419) There is no reason why, in South Africa, too, it ought not to give similar satisfaction, except among thosewhose material interests will be somewhat adversely affected by the stoppage of the labour supply.
('11', 204, 4, 16, 412625) South Africa can never be the birth place of a free and enlightened nation if it harbours slave labour, which indentured labour certainly is.
('11', 204, 4, 17, 412767) However that may be, the Indians of South Africa have achieved a notable victory.

('11', 206, 5, 28, 417546) However, I say nothing about putting on bangles round the wrists, as their absence would suggest something inauspicious.

('11', 209, 4, 6, 421851) 223. FROM “TRANSVAAL NOTES”
('11', 209, 5, 7, 421879) Wednesday, January 18, 1911
('11', 209, 6, 8, 421907) I give the following rumour 1 for what it may be worth, but I warn your readers against placing much reliance on this information, which I send not without much hesitation.
('11', 209, 6, 9, 422080) It is stated that General Smuts made it a condition precedent to any settlement of the Transvaal trouble, that the repatriation of time expired indentured Indians should be made compulsory.
('11', 209, 6, 10, 422270) It, thus, appears that, as against repeal of Acts 2 of 1907 and 36 of 1908, and the restoration of legal equality in point of immigration, he wished to impose other conditions and restrictions, which the Imperial Government considered unacceptable.
('11', 209, 6, 11, 422519) It is, accordingly, suggested that practically a deadlock exists, and that a general Immigration Bill may not, after all, be introduced during the present session of Parliament.
('11', 209, 6, 12, 422697) Whether, however, there is or is not any truth in this rumour, I am in a position positively to affirm that passive resisters are thoroughly prepared for an indefinite prolongation of the struggle.
('11', 209, 6, 13, 422895) In view of possibilities, it is as well that there is a movement, amongst Indian merchants, towards supplying settlers at Tolstoy Farm with food stuffs, the supply of which has always been a burden upon passive resistance funds.
('11', 209, 6, 14, 423124) Messrs Hansji Morar Patel and Dulabh Veera Bhaga have sent a bag of bhimri rice and half a case of ghee to the Farm.

('11', 210, 5, 6, 423612) SETTLEMENT MAY NOT COME OFF
('11', 210, 6, 7, 423640) I find it necessary to say this.
('11', 210, 6, 8, 423673) From some reports 1 which I have received, it appears that the negotiations for a settlement which were in progress have been abandoned.
('11', 210, 6, 9, 423810) The Imperial Government has not accepted some of the proposals of General Smuts.
('11', 210, 6, 10, 423891) It is believed that he wanted the period of contract of the indentured labourers to expire in India, that, in other words, the Government of India should enact legislation for their compulsory repatriation, as a condition for his agreeing to a settlement of the Transvaal agitation.
('11', 210, 6, 11, 424174) It also appears that General Smuts wished, as in return for repeal of the obnoxious Act and granting of legal equality, to impose other harsh conditions which the Imperial Government did not accept.
('11', 210, 6, 12, 424373) The new Immigration Bill seems to have been held up for this reason.
('11', 210, 6, 13, 424442) This report is just a rumour and is based only on inference; it need not therefore be taken as very reliable.
('11', 210, 6, 14, 424552) All the same, I should like to caution those who support the satyagraha movement and attach the highest value to it, that, should a settlement fail to materialize this time, the movement may perhaps be drawn out over many long years.
('11', 210, 6, 15, 424786) In that case, the available funds will be exhausted and satyagrahis will be reduced to a pitiable plight; they will then have to depend entirely upon the well to do members of the community.
('11', 210, 6, 16, 424977) That is why I said above that much saving can be effected if Indians take a turn in sending foodstuffs.

('11', 212, 1, 2, 427083) 226. CHHOTABHAI CASE
('11', 212, 2, 3, 427104) We congratulate Mr. Chhotabhai on his great victory.
('11', 212, 2, 4, 427157) In fighting for his son, he indirectly fought for the community as a whole.
('11', 212, 2, 5, 427233) If he had wanted merely to protect his son’s interest, he would have probably succeeded in safeguarding his right by servile entreaties to the Government.
('11', 212, 2, 6, 427388) But he courageously decided that he would fight.
('11', 212, 2, 7, 427437) It is, of course, a matter of regret that Mr. Chhotabhai has submitted to the law and that, even in regard to his son, all that was at issue was merely his right to submit to the law.
('11', 212, 2, 8, 427621) The problem of his son, however, involved a major issue.
('11', 212, 2, 9, 427678) It had to be solved, sooner or later.
('11', 212, 2, 10, 427716) Hence, by obtaining an interpretation of the law, he has to that extent served the cause of satyagraha.
('11', 212, 2, 11, 427820) We hope parents will not now make a rush for their children’s certificates.
('11', 212, 2, 12, 427896) The verdict 1 that has been obtained will not lapse and when a settlement takes place the rights of all children will be protected.
('11', 212, 3, 13, 428028) We shall know later the nature of the Court’s orders.
('11', 212, 3, 14, 428082) One thing is certain, namely, that the Government made an all out attack on minors, but it has failed.

('11', 214, 8, 26, 432275) Not only is there no clear intention in the law to deprive the minors of their rights but

('11', 215, 4, 10, 433301) 230. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('11', 215, 5, 11, 433332) TOLSTOY FARM, Maha Shud 10 [February 8, 1911] 1
('11', 215, 6, 12, 433380) NARANDAS,
('11', 215, 7, 13, 433390) Received your letter of Magsar Vad 7 2. You have asked me good questions about the plague 3. When rats began to die in Rajkot I advised all to leave the house or the town.
('11', 215, 7, 14, 433562) These were my ideas then.
('11', 215, 7, 15, 433588) I now feel that it was a mistake on my part.
('11', 215, 7, 16, 433633) Many of my ideas have undergone a similar change.
('11', 215, 7, 17, 433683) Every time the objective was the same— the search for truth.
('11', 215, 7, 18, 433744) Now I see that it is ignorance of the soul’s virtue to run away from houses.
('11', 215, 7, 19, 433821) This does not mean that one’s house cannot be changed whatever may happen.
('11', 215, 7, 20, 433896) We must leave the house if it is on fire.
('11', 215, 7, 21, 433938) If snakes and scorpions are so rife as to cause instantaneous death, then also we may leave the house.
('11', 215, 7, 22, 434041) I, however, do not mean to say that there is nothing wrong in doing so.
('11', 215, 7, 23, 434113) For him who has completely known and realized the self the sky above is the only roof; he would live in a jungle and look upon snakes and scorpions as his friends.
('11', 215, 7, 24, 434277) We who have not attained such a state live in houses for fear of cold, heat, etc., and we are ready to leave the house when dangers creep in there.
('11', 215, 7, 25, 434425) Despite all this, we should aspire to realize the self as soon as may be.
('11', 215, 7, 26, 434499) At any rate this is what I think.
('11', 215, 8, 27, 434533) 1 From the reference to Chhaganlal Gandhi’s arrival in India, this letter appears to have been written after his departure from England for India on January 30, 1911. 2 December 24, 1910 3 In Rajkot in 1902 when Gandhiji stayed in India for about a year
('11', 216, 0, 1, 434787) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 217
('11', 216, 1, 2, 434830) At the time of the plague Motilal Odhavji 1 left [Rajkot] and posted his steward to look after his house.
('11', 216, 1, 3, 434936) It is improper for one to do so.
('11', 216, 1, 4, 434969) Had the house caught fire, the steward too would have run away.
('11', 216, 1, 5, 435033) From this example you will be able to make out the distinction.
('11', 216, 1, 6, 435097) The danger from plague, etc., I consider an ordinary one.
('11', 216, 1, 7, 435155) The Mussalmans do not leave their houses, but stay on there with faith in God.
('11', 216, 1, 8, 435234) If, however, they took the necessary measures [to fight the plague], they would be doing better.
('11', 216, 1, 9, 435331) There is hardly any likelihood of the plague disappearing so long as we get panicky and run hither and thither.
('11', 216, 1, 10, 435443) It is sheer cowardice if, instead of trying to find out the cause of the plague, we run away from the place where it breaks out.
('11', 216, 1, 11, 435572) But when I myself am not satisfied with this answer, how could you be?
('11', 216, 1, 12, 435643) You will be able to know what passes in my mind only when we meet personally and questions come up incidentally.
('11', 216, 1, 13, 435756) There are two reasons why I cannot explain things fully to your satisfaction.
('11', 216, 1, 14, 435834) One is that I am so engrossed in other activities that I have no time to think over the matter and put my ideas on paper; the other is that there is no accord between my preaching and practice.
('11', 216, 1, 15, 436028) If there were that accord which I would like to achieve, I would get the right words to make the thing instantly clear to you.
('11', 216, 1, 16, 436155) When respected Khushalbhai asks you to leave the house or the town for fear of the plague, it is but proper for you to do so.
('11', 216, 1, 17, 436281) It is our duty to obey our elders so long as their orders do not conflict with our moral life.
('11', 216, 1, 18, 436376) Therein lies our ultimate good.
('11', 216, 1, 19, 436408) If you leave the plague infested house not from fear of death but to please your parents, your behaviour will be quite blameless.
('11', 216, 1, 20, 436538) However, the conditions are so difficult in some places and for some people that we have to think before obeying the orders of elders.
('11', 216, 1, 21, 436673) I personally feel that the love of parents is so mysterious that one should not offend them without very strong reason.
('11', 216, 1, 22, 436793) But my mind is not prepared to go to the same extent in respect of the other elders.
('11', 216, 1, 23, 436878) When we have any doubt concerning problems of morality, we may disregard the orders of other elders; nay, it would be our duty to disobey them.
('11', 216, 1, 24, 437022) But when there is no doubt about the morality of a question, even parents orders can be disregarded; nay, it will be our duty to do so.
('11', 216, 1, 25, 437158) If my father asks me to steal, I must not.
('11', 216, 1, 26, 437201) If I want to observe brahmacharya and my parents’ orders are to the contrary, I must politely disobey them.
('11', 216, 1, 27, 437309) I consider it to be a duty not to betrothe Ramdas and Devdas till they
('11', 216, 2, 28, 437380) 1 Motichand Odhavji Sharaf of Rajkot
('11', 217, 0, 1, 437417) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 217, 1, 2, 437459) come to their own.
('11', 217, 1, 3, 437478) Were my parents alive and held a contrary opinion, I would have very politely opposed them.
('11', 217, 1, 4, 437570) At the same time I believe that my mind is so free from prejudice in these matters that they would have accepted my views.
('11', 217, 1, 5, 437693) This is enough.
('11', 217, 1, 6, 437709) You may question me, if further doubts arise.
('11', 217, 1, 7, 437755) I have written the foregoing, knowing that you, being virtuous, will not misinterpret my words.
('11', 217, 1, 8, 437851) A hypocrite, on the other hand, would, because of what I have written, either consider me to be arrogant or, putting blind faith in my words, misinterpret me and disobey elders for the wrong reasons and would interpret what I have written about the plague to mean that as a proper remedy for plague even liquor, meat, etc., could be taken.

('11', 218, 9, 18, 440634) It seems to us that the future of Indians in South Africa will be determined by what Natal Indians do.
('11', 218, 9, 19, 440737) There are two main reasons for
('11', 218, 10, 20, 440768) 1 This is followed by a figure of the foot with marks made on it for the strap.

('11', 219, 0, 1, 441080) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 219, 1, 2, 441122) First, the number of Indians in Natal is large, and they have struck deep roots.
('11', 219, 1, 3, 441203) Secondly, being rather small, Natal allows itself to be led by the Transvaal and the Orange Free State where people are comparatively more hostile to Indians.
('11', 219, 1, 4, 441362) The new Railway regulations which have been notified will not be brought into force in the Cape, but will be in Natal.
('11', 219, 1, 5, 441481) They are being followed in the Transvaal though, as we have seen, legally they stand repealed.
('11', 219, 1, 6, 441576) More will be known from the reply to the letter 1 which Mr. Cachalia has written.
('11', 219, 1, 7, 441658) In the Orange Free State, these regulations have been in force for some time past.
('11', 219, 1, 8, 441741) Natal, therefore, has a new case, and a strong one at that.
('11', 219, 1, 9, 441801) The regulations cannot survive there for a single moment if we protest against them.
('11', 219, 1, 10, 441886) We think they are only in the nature of a feeler.
('11', 219, 1, 11, 441936) If we do not protest against them vigorously, by and by severer measures will follow.
('11', 219, 1, 12, 442022) It is our view that, since these regulations do not yet have the force of law, we can gofurther than making a petition and challenge them in a court of law.
('11', 219, 1, 13, 442179) We trust the Congress 2 will immediately take up the matter.
('11', 219, 1, 14, 442240) These regulations should set us thinking.
('11', 219, 1, 15, 442282) As time passes the Union Parliament will harden, rather than relent, in its attitude to us.
('11', 219, 1, 16, 442374) Our strength, our enthusiasm, our unity and our spirit of patriotism should grow likewise.
('11', 219, 1, 17, 442465) In the present circumstances, we have every chance of succeeding if we exert ourselves sufficiently.
('11', 219, 1, 18, 442566) This is a matter to which Natal Indians would do well to pay some attention.

('11', 221, 1, 2, 444854) above will be at the discretion of the authorities.

('11', 221, 1, 4, 445015) This seems to be the position.
('11', 221, 1, 5, 445046) It appears from General Smuts’ speech 1 that Indians will enjoy only the rights which they possess at present in their respective provinces, and that only a limited number of fresh immigrants will be permitted every year.
('11', 221, 1, 6, 445268) If the Bill permits educated Indians to come in as fresh immigrants without requiring them to register, it will enable the satyagraha campaign to be withdrawn.
('11', 221, 1, 7, 445428) Whether or not the Bill bears any such meaning, it is not possible as yet to say with certainty.
('11', 221, 1, 8, 445525) But what will be the position of Natal and the Cape?
('11', 221, 1, 9, 445578) It is serious enough to call for a bit of thinking.
('11', 221, 1, 10, 445630) If the Bill passes into law, educated persons will not be able to come in as freely as they have been doing, and the rights of those who are already there will not be protected.
('11', 221, 1, 11, 445808) Natal and the Cape need to take immediate steps.
('11', 221, 1, 12, 445857) I think they should first correspond with General Smuts and then petition 2 the Assembly.
('11', 221, 1, 13, 445947) This is a critical time.
('11', 221, 1, 14, 445972) The Bill does not yet appear to have received publicity.

('11', 223, 3, 4, 449590) 237. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE 1
('11', 223, 4, 5, 449621) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 2, 1911
('11', 223, 5, 6, 449651) ERNEST C. LANE , ESQ.
('11', 223, 5, 7, 449673) PRIVATE SECRETARY TO GENERAL SMUTS CAPE TOWN
('11', 223, 6, 8, 449718) DEAR MR. LANE,
('11', 223, 7, 9, 449733) I have just read the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill published in the Government Gazette Extraordinary dated the 25th ultimo.
('11', 223, 7, 10, 449856) As it appears to me to be highly complicated, I am not certain of the meaning to be attached to it; and, as I am most desirous of helping, to the best of my ability, to end the prolonged Asiatic struggle in the Transvaal, I venture to submit the following to General Smuts.
('11', 223, 7, 11, 450130) Passive resistance has been continued in order to secure repeal of Act 2 of 1907 and the theoretical legal equality of Asiatics as to immigration into the Transvaal, in practice reduced to the admission of a certain number, say six, of highly educated British Indians per year.
('11', 223, 7, 12, 450408) I observe that Act 2 of 1907, save as to the rights of Asiatic minors, is to be repealed.
('11', 223, 7, 13, 450498) This, therefore, practically meets the first point.
('11', 223, 7, 14, 450550) I do not, however, quite understand the clause as to the education test, and its effect.
('11', 223, 7, 15, 450639) As Section 1, besides repealing the laws referred to in the first schedule, also repeals other laws to the extent to which they may be repugnant to the provisions of the Bill, it seems to me that educated Asiatics who pass the test prescribed by the immigration officers will be able to enter and remain in the Transvaal, without being liable to take out registration under Act 36 of 1908. And, if such be the meaning of the first section of the Bill, the Transvaal struggle can happily end.
('11', 223, 7, 16, 451131) But I venture to submit that such meaning should be clearly and unequivocally brought out in the Bill

('11', 224, 5, 6, 451579) 238. LETTER TO R. GREGOROWSKI
('11', 224, 6, 7, 451609) JOHANNESBURG, March 2, 1911
('11', 224, 7, 8, 451637) DEAR MR. GREGOROWSKI 1,
('11', 224, 8, 9, 451661) The enclosed Bill 2, of a copy of which I seem to be the only possessor, I must confess baffles me, the more so as I am suspicious of the intentions of General Smuts.
('11', 224, 8, 10, 451828) I, therefore, do not trust myself to give a correct interpretation of it.
('11', 224, 8, 11, 451902) May I, therefore, fall back upon you?
('11', 224, 8, 12, 451940) The following are my deductions: (1) Inasmuch as all laws to the extent that they are repugnant to the provisions of the Bill are to be repealed, an educated Asiatic passing the education test prescribed by an officer is a competent immigrant to the Transvaal, without the necessity of having to submit to the Registration Act No.
('11', 224, 8, 13, 452271) 36 of 1908 (vide Sections 1 and 4) (2) It is not competent for the aggrieved party to have the decision of the officer imposing the education test brought in review before a Court of Law, no matter how ridiculously harsh the test imposed may be (vide Section 4).
('11', 224, 8, 14, 452534) (3) An Asiatic immigrant admitted under the education test will be a lawful immigrant even for the Orange Free State, in spite of its exclusive Asiatic Ordinance (vide Section 1).
('11', 224, 8, 15, 452714) (4) A Transvaal Asiatic will not be able to move to Natal or the
('11', 224, 9, 16, 452779) 1 A lawyer of Johannesburg whose opinion Gandhiji frequently sought on matters legal and constitutional 2 Immigrants’ Restriction Bill (1911); vide Appendix, “Immigrants’ Restriction Bill”, 4 3 1911.
('11', 225, 0, 1, 452979) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 225, 1, 2, 453021) Cape, because he will be excluded under Section 4 by means of a rigid education test, unless such Asiatic happened to have residential rights in either of those Provinces.
('11', 225, 1, 3, 453193) (5) An Asiatic who has once passed the education test under the Act cannot be challenged in the different Provinces, as soon as he shows that he has been once examined.
('11', 225, 1, 4, 453362) (6) The present residents in the respective Provinces do not appear to be in any way protected or exempted from the operation of the education clause.
('11', 225, 1, 5, 453513) What is their legal position?
('11', 225, 1, 6, 453543) (7) The wives and minor children of resident Asiatics or such Asiatics as may enter under the education test are also not protected specifically by the Bill.
('11', 225, 1, 7, 453701) What is their status?
('11', 225, 1, 8, 453723) And, if they are protected under the common law, does it mean that the son under the age of twenty one of a resident Asiatic can claim entry?
('11', 225, 1, 9, 453865) (8) Under the reservation clause in the first schedule following the repeal of Act 2 of 1907, minor sons of Asiatics registered in the Transvaal will always be able, if under the age of 16, to enter the Transvaal, and, on attaining the age of 16, to demand registration as a matter of right in virtue of the Chhotabhai judgement.
('11', 225, 1, 10, 454195) (9) In virtue of Section 25 Sub section 2, it seems that every Asiatic leaving South Africa or the respective Provinces in which he may be resident can be made a prohibited immigrant by the Minister declining to give him a certificate of domicile.

('11', 226, 4, 8, 455134) I enclose also my letter 2 to Smuts, and the interview with the Leader.
('11', 226, 4, 9, 455206) 3 I, at first, wanted to send a letter to Smuts in accordance with [the] interview, which is really taken from the letter that was to be sent to Smuts.
('11', 226, 4, 10, 455358) Cartwright 4 thought that I ought to publish the letter and make the position clear, but I told him it would be wise not to do that.
('11', 226, 4, 11, 455491) He, therefore, published the main contents in the form of an interview.
('11', 226, 4, 12, 455563) Subsequently, I changed my mind, and I thought that to Smuts I should simply write on the struggle, so that, in the event of future disputes, the issues might not be clouded.
('11', 226, 4, 13, 455738) While, from the theoretical standpoint, the Bill is admirable, seeing that it recognises the equality of Indian languages also with the languages of Europe, the practical effect of the Bill, so far as the Cape and Natal Asiatics are concerned, is, in my opinion, disastrous, as you will see from my analysis.
('11', 226, 4, 14, 456047) You may just compare the Cape Immigration Act with the Bill, and you will see the glaring difference.
('11', 226, 4, 15, 456149) Smuts stated definitely, as you will see from the Leader report of his speech on Neser’s 5 amendment, enclosed herewith, 6 that the way he wishes to meet Asiatic trading is by stopping Asiatic immigration entirely, except for a certain number to be agreed upon between the Imperial Government and the Union Government.
('11', 226, 4, 16, 456468) This doctrine may be all very well for the Transvaal, but how can the Cape and Natal Asiatics agree to a material curtailment of their rights?
('11', 226, 4, 17, 456611) It will hinder them

('11', 231, 14, 17, 465680) 245. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 3
('11', 231, 15, 18, 465717) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 3, 1911
('11', 231, 17, 19, 465747) Mr. Daniel Armugam, who was discharged from Diepkloof Gaol as a passive resister on the 1st instant, informs my Association that in the cell occupied by him and his fellow prisoners, about a fortnight before his discharge, at one o’clock, when he was half asleep, he found a snake just crawling on his neck.
('11', 231, 17, 20, 466055) He naturally got up
('11', 231, 18, 21, 466075) 1 Vide “Letter to E.F.C. Lane”, 2 3 1911 2 On 2 3 1911 3 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was sent over the signature of A. M. Cachalia.
('11', 232, 0, 1, 466224) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 233
('11', 232, 1, 2, 466267) somewhat terrified, and succeeded in shaking it off.
('11', 232, 1, 3, 466320) Fortunately, there was a light in the cell, and he awakened his neighbour, towards whom the snake was going.
('11', 232, 1, 4, 466429) In an instant, all the occupants of the cell were awake.
('11', 232, 1, 5, 466486) It appears that one of the prisoners was allowed to enter the cell with his sandals, and these were used for killing the snake.
('11', 232, 1, 6, 466614) Mr. Armugam, as also the other Indian prisoners who were discharged with him, inform my Association that the cells at Diepkloof are ill constructed, and are not proof against reptiles.
('11', 232, 1, 7, 466799) Some of the passive resisters further inform my Association that the discovery of a snake at night time is not an entirely unusual occurrence in that cell.
('11', 232, 1, 8, 466955) Within their experience, a snake was found there some time before also.
('11', 232, 1, 9, 467027) I, therefore, respectfully draw your attention to the matter, so that the cells may be so constructed as to avoid danger of the kind herein mentioned.

('11', 234, 1, 2, 469720) 248. HELP FROM THREE WOMEN
('11', 234, 2, 3, 469747) In the Transvaal struggle we have received help not only from prominent men but in equal measure from notable women also.
('11', 234, 2, 4, 469869) Readers of Indian Opinion are aware of the help received by Mr. Polak in India under the leadership of Mrs. Ramabai Ranade and Mrs. Petit.
('11', 234, 3, 5, 470008) And now we have had a Reuter message about a forceful article of Mrs. Mayo [published] in England.
('11', 234, 3, 6, 470107) 1 We have also received an advance copy of the article itself and have a clearer idea of its contents.
('11', 234, 3, 7, 470210) She writes about the whole of South Africa.
('11', 234, 3, 8, 470254) As we intend to publish a translation, we do not wish to say more about the article here.
('11', 234, 3, 9, 470344) We shall merely give some particulars of Mrs. Mayo.
('11', 234, 3, 10, 470396) She is an old lady of about 60. She is a novelist and journalist, and one of those selected by the late Tolstoy to translate his works.
('11', 234, 3, 11, 470532) We can therefore see why it was that her article caused the stir it did.
('11', 234, 4, 12, 470605) Besides Mrs. Mayo, there is Miss Hilda Howsin.
('11', 234, 4, 13, 470652) The report of her lecture at the East India Association is worth reading.
('11', 234, 4, 14, 470726) In this she discussed the issues involved in matters relating to the Transvaal problem.
('11', 234, 4, 15, 470814) Everyone who commented on her lecture admired the satyagraha struggle and expressed sympathy for the satyagrahis.
('11', 234, 4, 16, 470928) About the same time that these two ladies were thus engaged in writing or speaking, Miss Polak was appointed Secretary of the Committee.
('11', 234, 5, 17, 471065) What need is there, then, to feel dispirited, when we have been thus getting help, whether or no we ask for it, when the struggle has become well known, and when South African Indians are attracting world wide attention and India’s prestige is rising correspondingly?
('11', 234, 5, 18, 471333) Seeing that this is the fruit of our struggle having been prolonged, we should fight on with still greater zeal.
('11', 234, 6, 19, 471446) We intend to publish Mrs. Mayo’s article 2 and the report of Miss
('11', 234, 7, 20, 471512) 1 Mrs. John R. Mayo occasionally wrote under the assumed name of Edward Garrett.
('11', 234, 7, 21, 471593) The article appeared in the Millgate Monthly.
('11', 234, 7, 22, 471639) 2 Vide Indian Opinion, April 22, 29, May 6, 13, 20 and 27, 1911 for the Gujarati translation.
('11', 235, 0, 1, 471733) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('11', 235, 4, 5, 471856) 249. RAMBHABAI SODHA
('11', 235, 5, 6, 471877) The wrangling over Rambhabai’s case still continues.
('11', 235, 5, 7, 471930) The Transvaal High Court having confirmed the decision of the Magistrate, 2 an appeal has been filed to a higher court.
('11', 235, 5, 8, 472050) This being the first case involving a woman, it will be wise, from a practical point of view, to take all possible steps to prevent her being lodged in gaol.
('11', 235, 5, 9, 472208) That will be no special reflection on our idealism and the appeal may therefore be welcomed.
('11', 235, 5, 10, 472301) By filing the appeal, moreover, we secure ourselves against all blame.
('11', 235, 5, 11, 472372) We give proof to the world of our determination not to send women to gaol except as a last resort.
('11', 235, 5, 12, 472471) General Smuts can no longer allege that we are intent on sending them to gaol.
('11', 235, 5, 13, 472550) The clay is on the potter’s wheel.
('11', 235, 5, 14, 472585) We shall see what kind of a pot it turns out.
('11', 235, 5, 15, 472631) Meanwhile, we urge Indians, both men and women, to emulate the example of Rambhabai.

('11', 237, 2, 8, 474968) opinion, which advises that my interpretation is totally wrong, and that Section 1 of the Bill does not protect educated Asiatics from being subject to Act 36. The opinion before me states emphatically that Section 7, if nothing else, militates against any such interpretation.
('11', 237, 2, 9, 475246) I, therefore, venture to submit that the Bill should be so amended in Committee as to make the point absolutely clear.
('11', 237, 2, 10, 475365) I am sure that General Smuts will agree with me that this time nothing should be left understood or uncertain so far as the meaning of the Bill and the intention of the Government are concerned.
('11', 237, 2, 11, 475560) The opinion in question also raises a difficulty which I had not anticipated, namely, that the minor children of registered Asiatics who are not at present in the Transvaal are not at all protected, in spite of the judgment in the Chhotabhai case, 3 and that neither the wives nor the minor children will have common law protection in this Bill.
('11', 237, 2, 12, 475906) I trust, therefore, that these two points will also be made perfectly clear during the Committee stage.
('11', 237, 2, 13, 476010) On receipt of a satisfactory assurance on the points I have taken the opportunity of raising in this letter, I shall be prepared to advise the community in the Transvaal to send a formal acquiescence, 4 and passive resistance will then naturally end.

('11', 241, 1, 4, 483091) There is nothing to be ashamed of in your being weak in mathematics and general literary education.
('11', 241, 1, 5, 483191) You could have learnt them had I given you the necessary opportunity.

('11', 241, 1, 7, 483405) It is due to the meritorious deeds of our ancestors that we find healthy standards of behaviour, thrift, etc., around us, in spite of the repeated inroads of modern education, the immorality that we see among the people and their growing selfishness.
('11', 241, 1, 8, 483656) This I am writing to you to give you courage and ask you to go deeper into the matter and observe things for yourself.

('11', 241, 4, 18, 484470) 256. LETTER TO H. S. L. POLAK
('11', 241, 5, 19, 484500) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 6, 1911
('11', 241, 6, 20, 484530) MY DEAR POLAK,
('11', 241, 7, 21, 484545) I have your two letters.
('11', 241, 7, 22, 484570) I am glad that you rated our friends in Durban so soundly, as I knew you would.
('11', 241, 7, 23, 484650) They appreciate it, at least from you.
('11', 241, 7, 24, 484689) A suspected person may, in my opinion, be challenged by an immigration officer anywhere, even within the border of the Union.
('11', 242, 0, 1, 484815) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 243
('11', 242, 1, 2, 484858) That being so, why could an educated Indian not be challenged on entering Natal from the Transvaal?
('11', 242, 1, 3, 484958) If you say that he could not be challenged, such an Indian then could not be prohibited from crossing the Natal border from the Transvaal side, and the provincial check would break down, in spite of Clause 7 of the Bill.
('11', 242, 1, 4, 485179) Any such legislation at present in existence does notprevent the entry of such persons into Natal.
('11', 242, 1, 5, 485278) Your argument about Joseph 1 entering from Natal seems to be sound.
('11', 242, 1, 6, 485346) It seems difficult to believe that the omission of wives and minor children is deliberate, and, if it is, we ought to be able to wreck the Bill.
('11', 242, 1, 7, 485491) I think that we are bound to protest strongly as from Natal and the Cape against the education test, and we must in this connection raise the question of inter communication.
('11', 242, 1, 8, 485666) If Smuts gives a public assurance that the education test will be for purposes of inter communication, assuming that challenge within the border is possible, we may waive the objection.
('11', 242, 1, 9, 485852) Otherwise, it should be persisted in.
('11', 242, 1, 10, 485890) The question Anglia 2 raises about domicile is not a bad one.
('11', 242, 1, 11, 485952) In law, I think that it is not possible for a man to claim a double domicile.
('11', 242, 1, 12, 486030) Hitherto, domicile certificates produced by Transvaal residents have passed muster.
('11', 242, 1, 13, 486114) I have, however, always feared a legal difficulty in the matter, and it may well be that those who are registered in the Transvaal may, in future, be taken to have forfeited their Natal domicile.
('11', 242, 1, 14, 486310) Production of a certificate of Natal domicile is proof, at most, only of domicile to the day of leaving that place but is not proof that domicile subsists at the time of re entry.
('11', 242, 1, 15, 486490) I would suggest that those of the Transvaal Indians who are registered, but who are anxious to retain their Natal domicile, and who are in possession of certificates, should, for the time being, remain in Natal, or, not being there, return to Natal rather than remain in the Transvaal, because in the Transvaal the question of domicile cannot be raised, and a man who is found in Natal at the time of the taking effect of the new Bill cannot be sued.
('11', 242, 1, 16, 486941) The same remarks apply to the Indians at the Cape.
('11', 242, 1, 17, 486992) I hope to send a leading article on the Bill tomorrow.
('11', 242, 1, 18, 487047) 3 It will be sent to Phoenix, but a copy will be sent to you in Durban.
('11', 242, 1, 19, 487119) For further information I refer you to my letter to Ritch 4 herewith.
('11', 242, 2, 20, 487189) Yours sincerely,
('11', 242, 3, 21, 487206) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 5235

('11', 243, 1, 2, 487532) 257. LETTER TO MAUD POLAK
('11', 243, 2, 3, 487558) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 6, 1911
('11', 243, 3, 4, 487588) MY DEAR MAUD,
('11', 243, 4, 5, 487602) The enclosures will tell their own tale.
('11', 243, 4, 6, 487643) You will have the full text of the Bill in Indian Opinion 1. I do not envy your having to study the Bill.
('11', 243, 4, 7, 487749) However, I suggest your not writing anything at all about the Bill, unless you hear anything from me by cable.
('11', 243, 4, 8, 487860) I am not at all certain of the meaning of the Bill; nobody seems to be; and in the absence of a certainty all presumption must be against the Bill.
('11', 243, 4, 9, 488008) When agitation there becomes necessary, you will have the views emphatically one way or the other, and you will have objections from me in concrete form.
('11', 243, 4, 10, 488162) Till then, you can only give the information to inquirers.
('11', 243, 4, 11, 488221) I have refrained from cabling anything to you, because we do not want any agitation there at the time of writing.
('11', 243, 4, 12, 488335) I have anxious cable inquiries from India, but have simply replied 2 that they are to await further cables.
('11', 243, 4, 13, 488443) All that we for the time being should say is that no Bill will satisfy passive resisters, unless two things are unconditionally granted—repeal of Act 2 of 1907, and the entry of educated Indians who may pass the education test without liability to any registration laws.
('11', 243, 4, 14, 488714) If the Bill clearly means the latter, as it clearly repeals Asiatic [Act] 2 of 1907, we shall lay down our arms, however bad in other respects the Bill may be.
('11', 243, 4, 15, 488874) This does not mean that we cease to worry the Government here or the Government there with our other troubles, but we do not take up passive resistance regarding them.
('11', 243, 4, 16, 489042) For the time being, we still endeavour to carry on a less active agitation.
('11', 243, 4, 17, 489118) I do not call the petitioning agitation constitutional to distinguish it from passive resistance, because passive resistance is just as constitutional as simple petitioning.
('11', 243, 4, 18, 489292) What a happy coincidence it is that Mr. Ritch should be here just in the nick of time.
('11', 243, 4, 19, 489379) I think that he himself will agree that his presence is far more necessary here just now than there.
('11', 243, 4, 20, 489480) You may unreservedly express your opinion that with reference to the Cape and Natal, the Bill is as bad as it possibly can be.
('11', 243, 4, 21, 489607) There theoretical equality does not weigh so, because we have it already.
('11', 243, 5, 22, 489681) 1 Dated 4 3 1911 2 Vide cable to G. K. Gokhale quoted in “Letter to L. W. Ritch”, 4 3 1911.
('11', 244, 0, 1, 489773) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 245
('11', 244, 1, 2, 489816) deprivation of practical rights under this Bill, therefore, is a very serious and tangible grievance requiring redress, and, as you will see, the Cape and Natal are moving.
('11', 244, 1, 3, 489989) I only hope that they will move sufficiently to be able to make an impression on the Government.
('11', 244, 1, 4, 490086) I am perfectly at ease, seeing that Messrs Ritch and Polak are on the respective spots.
('11', 244, 1, 5, 490174) When I receive the address 1 for Mr. Ritch, I shall gladly buy an oak frame in accordance with your instructions, send you a memo of charges, and present the thing to him.
('11', 244, 1, 6, 490346) This time, instead of sending £15 for the Committee, I am sending £18. That ought to enable you to get on without a handicap, and there should be no difficulty in paying the quarterly charges.

('11', 252, 9, 11, 502883) 269. LETTER TO L. W. RITCH
('11', 252, 10, 12, 502910) [JOHANNESBURG,]
('11', 252, 11, 13, 502926) March 8, 1911
('11', 252, 12, 14, 502940) MY DEAR RITCH,
('11', 252, 13, 15, 502955) The enclosures will speak for themselves.
('11', 252, 13, 16, 502997) I hope my telegram 2
('11', 252, 14, 17, 503018) was quite clear to you.
('11', 252, 14, 18, 503042) We have got to work for the Cape and the Natal Indians whether they find funds or not, so far as the personal exertions of the three of us are concerned.
('11', 252, 14, 19, 503196) The expenses of your stay in Cape Town will be found from the funds here, so that the only funds that the Cape people and the people in Natal have to find are for legal opinion and such other matters.
('11', 252, 14, 20, 503397) If they do not wish to pay the cost of the wires that you may be sending them, we need not worry about this cost.
('11', 252, 14, 21, 503511) If they will not find the funds, we shall have to work without Schreiner’s opinion, which might be valuable.
('11', 252, 14, 22, 503620) Anyhow, we know how the land lies and, after all, we have to secure if possible the necessary amendments in order to make the position certain and remove ambiguity.

('11', 254, 1, 2, 505741) present Bill, and if Gregorowski’s contention is correct, the Transvaal Indians will be free to enter the Cape or Natal without let or hindrance, because there is no Asiatic legislation there except for the Chinese.
('11', 254, 1, 3, 505957) I do not think that the rights of Colonial born Indians in Natal are protected under the seventh section.

('11', 254, 4, 9, 506664) 272. NATAL PETITION TO UNION ASSEMBLY 1
('11', 254, 5, 10, 506704) DURBAN, March 9, 1911
('11', 254, 6, 11, 506726) TO THE HON’BLE THE SPEAKER AND THE MEMBERS OF THE HON’BLE
('11', 254, 7, 12, 506784) THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA IN PARLIAMENT ASSEMBLED CAPE TOWN
('11', 254, 8, 13, 506872) THE PETITION OF DAWAD MAHOMED, DADA OSMAN AND MAHOMED CASSIM ANGLIA, IN THEIR CAPACITIES AS CHAIRMAN AND JOINT HONORARY SECRETARIES, RESPECTIVELY, OF THE NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS
('11', 254, 9, 14, 507048) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT
('11', 254, 10, 15, 507068) 1. At a public meeting of British Indians, held on the 9th day of March, 1911, under the auspices of the Natal Indian Congress, your Petitioners were authorised to petition this Honourable House with respect to the Bill to consolidate and amend the Laws in force in the various Provinces of the Union relating to Restrictions upon
('11', 254, 11, 16, 507399) 1 Drafted by Gandhiji.
('11', 254, 11, 17, 507422) Vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 7 3 1911, from which it is clear that the petition was ready on 7 3 1911.
('11', 255, 0, 1, 507529) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 255, 1, 2, 507571) Immigration thereto, to provide for the establishment of an Union Immigration Department and to regulate Immigration into the Union or any Province thereof, now before it.
('11', 255, 1, 3, 507743) 2. Your Petitioners consider it unfortunate that the blessings of Union are not to be enjoyed by His Majesty’s Indian subjects of South Africa, in that their movements are to remain as heretofore under Provincial restriction; but your Petitioners have been authorised by the public meeting aforementioned to state that, in view of the anti Asiatic prejudice existing in many parts of the Union, those represented by yourPetitioners do not desire to raise, for the time being, any objection to the restriction.
('11', 255, 1, 4, 508253) 3. Your Petitioners have, however, been asked to bring to the notice of this Honourable House the following objections to the said Bill:
('11', 255, 2, 5, 508390) (a) Under the existing immigration laws in force in this Province, the clause dealing with the education test enables an intending immigrant to submit to the test in a European language known to him.
('11', 255, 2, 6, 508590) The present Bill leaves the selection of the language for purposes of examination in the hands of the immigration officer, thus making it possible for that officer to completely prevent the entry of any person or persons of any class, race, or religion, whether such person or persons be British subjects or not.
('11', 255, 2, 7, 508903) In the humble opinion of your Petitioners, such a prohibition is unwarranted by previous experience.
('11', 255, 3, 8, 509004) (b) Unlike as in the immigration laws of the Province now under repeal in virtue of Schedule I to the said Bill, the wives and minor children, absent from the Province, of those who are now resident or domiciled in the Province of Natal are not protected.
('11', 255, 4, 9, 509260) (c) The rights of those who are at present residing in the Province of Natal, and those who are temporarily absent but are domiciled in the Province, do not appear to be protected as they are in the Provincial Laws already referred to herein.
('11', 255, 5, 10, 509503) (d) Sub section (b) of Section 25 of the Bill gives absolute discretion to the Minister as to the granting of permits to lawful residents who may wish to absent themselves temporarily.
('11', 255, 5, 11, 509688) Hitherto the right to such permits or certificates
('11', 256, 0, 1, 509739) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 257
('11', 256, 1, 2, 509782) of domicile, as they have been called, has remained unquestioned; and, in the humble opinion of your Petitioners, it will be a great injustice to the resident Indian population of the Province of Natal if this right is now taken away.
('11', 256, 2, 3, 510017) (e) The said Bill does not appear to give the party who may be declared a prohibited immigrant by an immigration officer, or who may be prevented from re entering the Union or this particular Province by such officer, any recourse, as under existing legislation, to the Courts of Law established under the Union.
('11', 256, 2, 4, 510330) 4. In conclusion, your Petitioners humbly pray that this Honourable House will take into consideration the objections urged herein, and amend the Bill so as to remove those objections, or grant such other relief as to this Honourable House may seem meet.
('11', 256, 2, 5, 510585) And for this act of justice andmercy, your Petitioners shall, as in duty bound, for ever pray, etc.
('11', 256, 3, 6, 510685) (Sd.) DAWAD MAHOMED,

('11', 260, 1, 23, 517214) Ba became nervous when she had a sudden attack of acute pain.
('11', 260, 1, 24, 517276) I was busy and could not go to see her a second time.
('11', 260, 1, 25, 517330) She must have got angry and when I went to her she burst into tears and made it appear as if she would die.

('11', 260, 1, 27, 517562) There is plenty of wood.
('11', 260, 1, 28, 517587) We shall cremate you on this Farm itself.” At this she also laughed.
('11', 260, 1, 29, 517656) Half the pain disappeared with the laugh.

('11', 260, 1, 31, 517756) Earth alone would not do.

('11', 260, 1, 33, 517860) She should live on wheat and fruits only.
('11', 260, 1, 34, 517902) She might take, if she wanted, saltless rice with ghee.
('11', 260, 1, 35, 517958) She said, “Even you cannot do it.” I said, “From today I give up salt, vegetables, etc.” How could she take these things then?
('11', 260, 1, 36, 518085) The result is that for the last one month both of us have been taking food without salt, vegetables and pulses.
('11', 260, 1, 37, 518197) As for myself, I have no desire for other food.
('11', 260, 1, 38, 518245) Ba has it sometimes.
('11', 260, 1, 39, 518266) Once when she could not restrain herself, she took a little gavar.
('11', 260, 1, 40, 518333) Otherwise it appears she has lived on this diet.
('11', 260, 1, 41, 518382) There was a miraculous change for the better.
('11', 260, 1, 42, 518428) The bleeding stopped immediately.
('11', 260, 1, 43, 518462) I got the incidental benefit of extra self control.
('11', 260, 1, 44, 518514) This is my argument [as regards the eschewing of salt]: Salt is a powerful
('11', 261, 0, 1, 518589) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 261, 1, 2, 518631) chemical.
('11', 261, 1, 3, 518641) Even a little when added to something changes its quality and taste.
('11', 261, 1, 4, 518710) Its effect must be to thin the blood.
('11', 261, 1, 5, 518748) So far as I can think, salt is bound to have an instant effect on the sick—and mostly adverse at that.
('11', 261, 1, 6, 518851) When I first read the writings of Mrs. Wallace and others [on the subject], they had little effect on me.
('11', 261, 1, 7, 518957) On this occasion I felt all the time that it would be fine if the doctor could be kept away.
('11', 261, 1, 8, 519050) Thereupon, it occurred to me to note the effect of saltless diet.
('11', 261, 1, 9, 519116) Even though Ba may continue her [saltless diet] throughout this month, she won’t keep it up beyond that.
('11', 261, 1, 10, 519221) I think of carrying on the experiment as long as possible.

('11', 261, 4, 13, 519435) 278. TRANSVAAL PETITION TO UNION ASSEMBLY 1
('11', 261, 5, 14, 519479) JOHANNESBURG, March 10, 1911
('11', 261, 6, 15, 519508) TO THE HON’BLE THE SPEAKER AND THE MEMBERS OF
('11', 261, 7, 16, 519554) THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA CAPE TOWN
('11', 261, 8, 17, 519618) THE PETITION OF AHMED MAHOMED CACHALIA, IN HIS CAPACITY AS CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION OF THE TRANSVAAL
('11', 261, 9, 18, 519737) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT
('11', 261, 10, 19, 519757) The Members of the Association have read the Bill published in Government Gazette Extraordinary dated the 25th February, to consolidate and amend the Laws in force in the various Provinces of the Union relating to restrictions upon immigration thereto, to provide for the establishment of an Union Immigration Department and to regulate Immigration into the Union of any Province thereof.
('11', 261, 11, 20, 520146) 1 A copy of this was sent to Ritch; vide “Letter to L. W. Ritch”, 10 3 1911.
('11', 262, 0, 1, 520223) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 263
('11', 262, 1, 2, 520266) 2. In the humble opinion of the Petitioning Association the restriction of the residential rights of British Indians at present residing in the various Provinces of South Africa to the provincial limits laid down in the Bill is inconsistent with the Union of the Provinces and unjust to the British Indians of South Africa.
('11', 262, 1, 3, 520590) But, in view of the prejudice that exists in South Africa against the community represented by the Petitioning Association, it has been decided for the time being to acquiesce in the restriction above referred to.
('11', 262, 1, 4, 520804) But the Petitioning Association ventures to submit to this Honourable House that the said Bill is ambiguous in several essential particulars which very materially affect the interests of British Indians residing in the Transvaal, which particulars are as under: (a) The Bill, according to its present wording, does not permit of the residence in the Transvaal of educated Indians who might pass the education test required under Section 4 of the said Bill, by reason of the existence of the Asiatic Registration Act No.
('11', 262, 1, 5, 521324) 36 of 1908. The Association has been legally advised that, in the absence of any special mention in the Bill, such Asiatics will be subject to the provisions of the said Asiatic Registration Act, and will, therefore, be unable to enter the Transvaal, or, if they are allowed to do so, they will be obliged to be registered thereunder.
('11', 262, 1, 6, 521659) The Petitioning Association respectfully submits that British Indians who may pass the education test will be sufficiently identified by reason of such examination, and that, therefore, the Bill may be so amended as to leave no uncertainty as to the right of educated Asiatics passing the education test of entering and remaining in the Transvaal and other Provinces of the Union without being subject to the Registration Laws or such other Laws of the different Provinces.
('11', 262, 1, 7, 522133) (b) The Petitioning Association respectfully draws the attention of this Honourable House to the fact that there seems to be no provision in the said Bill protecting the wives and minor children of registered Asiatics, which protection has been hitherto enjoyed by them owing to the existence of Act 15 of 1907, Transvaal, together with the Registration Act.
('11', 262, 1, 8, 522492) Act 15 of 1907 of the Transvaal is to be repealed by the said Bill.
('11', 263, 0, 1, 522560) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 263, 1, 2, 522602) 3. In conclusion, the Petitioning Association prays that this Honourable House will take into consideration the submission made herein, and amend the Bill in the desired direction, or grant such other relief as to this Honourable House may seem meet.
('11', 263, 1, 3, 522853) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioner shall, as in duty bound, for ever pray.
('11', 263, 2, 4, 522948) CHAIRMAN,
