('11', 270, 7, 15, 534830) 290. LETTER TO MAUD POLAK
('11', 270, 8, 16, 534856) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 13, 1911
('11', 270, 9, 17, 534887) MY DEAR MAUD,
('11', 270, 10, 18, 534901) A long cable 4 was sent to you on Saturday.
('11', 270, 10, 19, 534945) I hope that you thoroughly understood it.
('11', 270, 10, 20, 534987) The cable was not sent without a great deal of hesitation.
('11', 270, 10, 21, 535046) The Bill having been published, I am rather sanguine of the necessary amendments being made.
('11', 270, 10, 22, 535139) Yet, in order that it might not become law immediately after it is read a third time in Parliament, I sent the cable, so that you could consult Lord Ampthill and Sir Muncherjee, and at least warn the Imperial Government.
('11', 270, 10, 23, 535360) Similar
('11', 270, 11, 24, 535368) 1 Vide “Telegram to Members of Parliament”, 11 3 1911. 2 Alexander, T. L. Schreiner, and W. P. Schreiner 3 Vide “Transvaal Petition to Union Assembly”, 10 3 1911. 4 Vide “Cable to Natesan, Gokhale and S.A.B.I. Committee”, 11 3 1911.
('11', 271, 0, 1, 535601) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 271, 1, 2, 535643) cables 1 have been sent to Bombay and Madras.
('11', 271, 1, 3, 535689) I suppose you know the procedure with reference to a Bill.
('11', 271, 1, 4, 535748) It is formally read a first time; a full debate takes place on the second reading, and, unless there is opposition to the principle of the Bill, the second reading is carried.
('11', 271, 1, 5, 535924) Then it is read in Committee, at which stage amendments are made.
('11', 271, 1, 6, 535990) Then comes the third reading.
('11', 271, 1, 7, 536020) After that it goes to the Senate, and, if the Senate approves of it, it is submitted to the Governor General for the Royal Assent.
('11', 271, 1, 8, 536151) If the Bill does not contain a reservatory clause, it becomes the law of the land immediately.
('11', 271, 1, 9, 536246) The reservatory clause is inserted when there is any racial differentiation.
('11', 271, 1, 10, 536323) As there is none in this Bill, there is no reservatory clause at all.
('11', 271, 1, 11, 536393) It may, therefore, come into force immediately, unless the Governor General is advised by the Imperial Government not to give his sanction without first submitting the Bill to them.
('11', 271, 1, 12, 536575) The last recourse left open to objectors is to secure a veto, even though the Bill may come into operation, because a clause in the Royal instructions provides that any Bill, although it may have the force of law, may be vetoed within two years of its promulgation by the King in Council.
('11', 271, 1, 13, 536864) I expect that the Bill will have been passed through the Lower House by the time this letter reaches you, but it may not have gone to the Senate, or at least it may not have received the Governor General’s sanction.
('11', 271, 1, 14, 537080) You will have further cables as to the progress of the Bill.
('11', 271, 1, 15, 537141) I am anxious to make the following position quite clear to you.
('11', 271, 1, 16, 537205) Passive Resistance has been continued for securing repeal of Act 2 of 1907, and to secure legal equality as to the immigration of highly educated Asiatics.
('11', 271, 1, 17, 537361) In the cablegram, however, you have been told that, if the Bill does not protect minors and the wives of lawful residents, it may not end passive resistance.
('11', 271, 1, 18, 537519) It might be said that this is a new point raised by us.
('11', 271, 1, 19, 537575) I hope, however, that any such misconception you will be able to remove.
('11', 271, 1, 20, 537648) Wives and minor children are under the existing legislation fully protected—you will notice that from Mr. Gregorowski’s opinion 2—but the new Bill seeks to deprive us of that right, and passive resisters can hardly be expected to bargain away the rights of parents, specially such inherent rights as those of taking their wives
('11', 271, 2, 21, 537976) 1 Vide “Cable to Natesan, Gokhale and S.A.B.I. Committee”, 11 3 1911. 2 Available in part; vide “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 4 3 1911.
('11', 272, 0, 1, 538109) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 273
('11', 272, 1, 2, 538151) and children with them, against a grant of legal equality.
('11', 272, 1, 3, 538210) I do not think that there will be any difficulty about getting the necessary amendment carried here, but, supposing that the difficulty does arise and General Smuts again talks of new points being raised by me, you will know how to deal with it.
('11', 272, 1, 4, 538456) It is General Smuts who is raising a new point, if he is raising it at all.
('11', 272, 1, 5, 538532) I give him the credit of not raising any contentious issues, by supposing that the matter has only been overlooked by his draughtsmen, and that he will rectify the difficulty at the Committee stage.
('11', 272, 1, 6, 538731) As to the Cape and Natal, whether the position there is ameliorated or not, the present passive resistance will stop, if the Bill is amended, so far as the Transvaal is concerned, in the manner suggested by me.
('11', 272, 1, 7, 538942) You will carefully go through the Petition 1
('11', 272, 2, 8, 538987) to the House of Parliament here, and all the other documents.
('11', 272, 2, 9, 539049) I am asking 2 Mr. Ritch to write to you from Cape Town, so that the information I am giving you will be brought up to date by Mr. Ritch.
('11', 272, 3, 10, 539186) Yours sincerely,
('11', 272, 4, 11, 539203) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S.N. 5281

('11', 273, 4, 7, 540676) 292. LETTER TO H. S. L. POLAK
('11', 273, 5, 8, 540706) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 13, 1911
('11', 273, 6, 9, 540737) MY DEAR POLAK, Whether you send money from your side to Ritch or not, I have sent £10 from here.

('11', 275, 0, 1, 544332) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 275, 1, 2, 544374) 294. LETTER TO “RAND DAILY MAIL” 1
('11', 275, 2, 3, 544409) JOHANNESBURG, March 15, 1911 2
('11', 275, 4, 4, 544440) There is only one thing in your leading article of today’s date on which you will, perhaps, permit me to say a few words.
('11', 275, 4, 5, 544562) So far as I can voice my countrymen’s aspirations, there is no question now, and there was none before, of quietly accepting the existing position governing British Indians in the different Provinces.
('11', 275, 4, 6, 544763) All that the present Bill can do, so far as the Transvaal is concerned, is to stop passive resistance, and that, too, if it is amended so as to make it clear that the rights at present enjoyed by the minor children and wives of domiciled Asiatics, whether they be at present inside the Transvaal or outside the Province, are not to be taken away by it, and that those few highly educated Asiatics who will enter under the education test will be able to reside in any part of the Union without being subject to Provincial registration laws.
('11', 275, 4, 7, 545303) Apart from passive resistance, Indians have never ceased, nor have, for that matter, the Imperial and Indian Governments, to press for repeal of legislation which prohibits their holding landed property, interferes with their freedom of movement, etc.
('11', 275, 4, 8, 545555) I am quite sure that the Cape and the Natal Indians will certainly never submit to legislation restrictive of the rights at present enjoyed by them, without making a desperate effort to avoid such a calamity.
('11', 275, 4, 9, 545764) In an age which we fondly believe is an age of progress, there can be no such thing as finality, and my countrymen would be less than human, if they did not make a serious endeavour to deserve, at the hands of the European residents in the Union, better treatment than they have hitherto received.
('11', 275, 4, 10, 546062) The education test in the present Bill is not a fraud, unless you are prepared to give that name to the whole of the British Constitution.
('11', 275, 4, 11, 546201) The adoption by General Smuts of the policy enunciated by Lord Crewe is a recognition by him of the idea of equality.
('11', 275, 4, 12, 546319) The administration of the measure will be undoubtedly
('11', 275, 5, 13, 546373) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 25 3 1911, along with an extract from the leading article.
('11', 275, 5, 14, 546473) 2 The source bears the date March 16. But vide “Letter to L W. Ritch”, 15 3 1911
('11', 276, 0, 1, 546554) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 277
('11', 276, 1, 2, 546596) unequal.
('11', 276, 1, 3, 546605) There is no secret about it.
('11', 276, 1, 4, 546634) Administrative inequality will be a concession to the prevalent prejudice in South Africa and to human weakness.
('11', 276, 1, 5, 546747) Self respecting Asiatics are bound to make an honest attempt to remove the prejudice, first, by removing the causes that have led to the rise of any such prejudice and, secondly, by showing that largely it is based on ignorance.
('11', 276, 2, 6, 546976) I am, etc.,

('11', 277, 10, 12, 548813) Certain inaccuracies in the interview with me which you have published have led, I see, to a great deal of misunderstanding in Natal, and the interview is being used much to the detriment of the cause I have at heart.
('11', 277, 10, 13, 549031) Inaccuracies are inevitable in an interview, unless it is revised by the interviewed, especially when such an interview takes place, as this one did, over the telephone.
('11', 277, 10, 14, 549201) I hope, therefore, that you will permit me to remove through your columns the misunderstanding created by the interview in question.
('11', 277, 10, 15, 549334) This is my position: If the new Bill admits Asiatics who pass the education test into the Union without their being subject to Asiatic Registration Laws, and if it does not take away, as it is apprehended its present wording does, the rights of wives and minor children of those registered or entitled to be registered to enter the Transvaal, passive resistance must cease; and to that extent I consider the Bill to be satisfactory.

('11', 281, 4, 8, 556050) 302. LETTER TO J. J. DOKE
('11', 281, 5, 9, 556076) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 17, 1911
('11', 281, 6, 10, 556107) DEAR MR. DOKE,
('11', 281, 7, 11, 556122) I fear that for a little thing, little, that is, from the European standpoint, the struggle will have to be prolonged.
('11', 281, 7, 12, 556241) Mr. Ritch telegraphs, saying that General Smuts will introduce an amendment exempting future immigrants from the operation of the Asiatic Act of the Transvaal, that is to say, they will still be liable to the Asiatic Ordinance of the Orange Free State, and, therefore, the colour bar will still remain in the Immigration Law.
('11', 281, 7, 13, 556567) I feel that we cannot possibly accept such a concession.
('11', 281, 7, 14, 556624) The removal of the colour bar throughout the Union so far as the new immigrants are concerned means nothing for the Orange Free State, because the local disabilities may and will still remain, but, unless the exempting clause is put in, an educated Indian immigrant will have no foothold at all in the Free State.
('11', 281, 7, 15, 556938) In practice, no educated Indian can exist in the Free State, because there are very few Indians for whom he could cater.
('11', 281, 7, 16, 557059) I am sending you copies of the correspondence 1 bearing on this point, and am anxious to know how the whole thing strikes you.
('11', 281, 7, 17, 557186) I feel that, if it is wrong to accept the colour bar in the Transvaal Immigration Law, it is wrong to accept it in the Union Immigration Law which replaces it.
('11', 281, 7, 18, 557346) I do not want to leave the office just now.
('11', 281, 7, 19, 557390) Otherwise, I would have come down.
('11', 281, 8, 20, 557425) Yours sincerely,

('11', 285, 6, 10, 563568) 308. THE IMMIGRATION BILL
('11', 285, 7, 11, 563594) The debate on the second reading of this Bill shows how fortunate we have been in having Mr. Ritch at Cape Town just at this juncture.
('11', 285, 7, 12, 563729) The words of The Times to the effect that Mr. Ritch was coming to South Africa in order to co operate with those who were trying to settle the vexed Asiatic question may be said, in the light of what is happening, to have been prophetic.
('11', 285, 7, 13, 563967) We can see Mr. Ritch’s hand in the weighty contribution to the debate by Mr. Advocate Alexander.
('11', 285, 7, 14, 564064) He allowed not a single point raised by the Indians throughout the three Provinces to escape him, and he has shown clearly that, if the Bill goes through unaltered, passive resisters will have paid too dear a price for peace; and it is certain that, if passive resisters were not bound morally to cease struggling immediately on their demands being granted, they would be very properly justified in rejecting the Bill as an honourable compromise, if the position of the Natal and the Cape Indians were not altered by making the amendments necessary to meet the Indian objections from these two Provinces.
('11', 285, 7, 15, 564669) But we hope that General Smuts will accept the advice given to him by Sir Percy Fitzpatrick, and grant the very reasonable requests made by the Indians at the Cape and in Natal.
('11', 285, 7, 16, 564847) They ask for nothing new.
('11', 285, 7, 17, 564873) They merely wish to stipulate that existing rights shall not be disturbed.
('11', 285, 7, 18, 564948) It is said that General Smuts wants to admit only
('11', 285, 8, 19, 564998) 1 Vide, “Telegram to Private Secretary to General Smuts”, 17 3 1911.
('11', 286, 0, 1, 565067) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 287
('11', 286, 1, 2, 565109) twelve Asiatics per year under the education test.
('11', 286, 1, 3, 565160) In our opinion, this is absurd.
('11', 286, 1, 4, 565192) The Transvaal Indians suggested that six per year should be allowed for the Transvaal.
('11', 286, 1, 5, 565279) Surely six for Natal and the Cape is a very small number.
('11', 286, 1, 6, 565337) The smooth working of the Act will depend very largely upon the spirit that actuates General Smuts in framing his regulations, and the spirit in which the Act and the regulations are administered.
('11', 286, 1, 7, 565534) The fate of passive resisters will be decided in the course of the next few days.
('11', 286, 1, 8, 565616) General Smuts has stated that the Bill is intended to exempt those who may enter under the education test from the operation of registration laws.
('11', 286, 1, 9, 565763) He has, therefore only to make a verbal amendment in order to bring that meaning out clearly in the Bill; and we refuse to believe that he wishes to go behind the judgment of the Supreme Court and deprive minor Asiatics of the rights which that Court has recognised, or that he dots not wish to clothe with absolute protection the wives of lawful residents.
('11', 286, 2, 10, 566121) Indian Opinion, 18 3 1911
('11', 286, 3, 11, 566147) 309. NEW BILL IN PARLIAMENT
('11', 286, 4, 12, 566175) Every Indian should go through the debate on the second reading of this Bill.
('11', 286, 4, 13, 566253) One will find it very instructive.
('11', 286, 4, 14, 566288) Irrespective of whether or not the new Bill is suitably amended, what was said about it and the emphasis that was laid on its bearing only on the Asiatic problem are worth noting.
('11', 286, 4, 15, 566468) Everyone can see that this is entirely the result of the power of satyagraha.
('11', 286, 4, 16, 566546) Lord Crewe revised the view which he had expressed in 1909 and requested General Botha to grant the Indians’ demands.
('11', 286, 4, 17, 566664) As satyagraha became protracted, the views of the Imperial Government and the Local Government underwent changes.
('11', 286, 4, 18, 566778) The Act 2 of 1907 would never be repealed [it was said], and they agreed [subsequently] to repeal it.
('11', 286, 4, 19, 566880) They accepted voluntary registration, which [they earlier said] they would never do.
('11', 286, 4, 20, 566965) They were not prepared to permit the admission of educated Indians, but agreed to do solater under a separate law.
('11', 286, 4, 21, 567080) They declared then that further than this they would never go, that it would be immoral to grant the Asiatics’ demands; the bogey of immorality has vanished now and the demands of the Asiatics have been conceded.
('11', 286, 4, 22, 567293) It may be asked: what does it profit us if such a demand has been accepted?
('11', 286, 4, 23, 567369) We shall consider an answer after the Bill has gone through in a form that satisfies us.

('11', 288, 1, 2, 569018) 311. LETTER TO L. W. RITCH
('11', 288, 2, 3, 569045) March 18, 1911
('11', 288, 3, 4, 569060) MY DEAR RITCH,
('11', 288, 4, 5, 569075) What is the meaning of “anticipating trouble from all quarters”?
('11', 288, 4, 6, 569140) 1 I take it to mean that the Bill will be assailed not only by us, but by the Members on behalf of the community in general.
('11', 288, 4, 7, 569265) I must confess that I should feel delighted if the Bill were withdrawn, and the Immigration Act of the Transvaal amended.
('11', 288, 4, 8, 569387) But, if the Bill does go through, you will have to answer all kinds of questions in connection with the Free State, as, for instance, [the] right of the future Asiatic immigrants to be free from restrictions, are they to hold landed property, etc.
('11', 288, 4, 9, 569635) We ask for no such thing.
('11', 288, 4, 10, 569661) All we say is that, as to immigration and as to residence, because residence is part of immigration, they should be on the same footing as Europeans.
('11', 288, 4, 11, 569811) As to all civil rights, they would share the same disabilities as the Asiatics.
('11', 288, 4, 12, 569891) To illustrate my point, an educated Indian entering the Transvaal would not be subject to the Registration Law, but he would still be subject to Law 3 of 1885. Now, Chapter 33 of the Orange Free State Constitution Act not only deals with the manner in which an Asiatic may reside, but it also takes away other common law rights.
('11', 288, 4, 13, 570220) Sections 7 and 8 affect such rights.
('11', 288, 4, 14, 570257) The amendment, therefore’ may exempt Asiatics from Clauses 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10 and 11 so far as they may be applicable.
('11', 288, 4, 15, 570381) If you take hold of the Chapter, you will understand my meaning still more fully.
('11', 288, 4, 16, 570463) We want to appear before the public with absolutely clear hands, as I profess we actually are.
('11', 288, 4, 17, 570558) The present passive resistance has absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with the personal gain of a single individual; and if we make this clear and still our approach is rejected, we place our opponent in the wrong in every respect.
('11', 288, 4, 18, 570791) It is just at a time like this that General Smuts, whom Cartwright considers to be either absolutely disloyal or intensely stupid, betrays either the one or the other of these qualities in refusing to see you.
('11', 288, 4, 19, 571001) One good interview could settle the whole question, and could also appease the wrath of the Free Staters by showing that their
('11', 288, 5, 20, 571128) 1 The reference is to Ritch’s telegram of March 18: Committee stage remote.
('11', 288, 5, 21, 571204) Budget takes precedence.
('11', 288, 5, 22, 571229) Advise me Smuts reply your wire.
('11', 288, 5, 23, 571262) I anticipate trouble all around.

('11', 293, 1, 2, 577086) 317. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE
('11', 293, 2, 3, 577115) March 20, 1911
('11', 293, 3, 4, 577130) DEAR MR. LANE,
('11', 293, 4, 5, 577145) I telegraphed today 1 in reply to your letter 2of the 16th instant regarding the correspondence between you and me over the Immigrants, Restriction Bill.
('11', 293, 4, 6, 577299) I now venture to amplify my telegram.
('11', 293, 4, 7, 577337) There is no occasion, neither has it been asked on behalf of British Indians, to repeal Chapter 33 of the Orange Free State Constitution; but I respectfully submit for General Smuts’ considera tion that, just as educated Indian immigrants will, under the amendment he proposes to move, be free from registration under the Transvaal Act No.
('11', 293, 4, 8, 577677) 36 of 1908, so may such immigrants be free from the Sections of Chapter 33 of the Orange Free State Constitution regarding what amounts to registration.
('11', 293, 4, 9, 577830) Such seems to have been the intention of General Smuts at the time the telegram of the 4th instant, referred to in your letter of the 16th instant, was sent.
('11', 293, 4, 10, 577988) It is therein stated that
('11', 293, 5, 11, 578014) Asiatics admitted as immigrants under new Immigration Bill would not fall under registration laws and would not be restricted to provincial limits.
('11', 293, 5, 12, 578162) A similar statement appears in the dispatch to Lord Crewe, published in the Blue Book U/7/11. All that Asiatics ask for is full immigration rights in law under the Bill without a colour bar.
('11', 293, 5, 13, 578353) If an educated Indian has to apply under Chapter 33 for permission to reside in the Orange Free State, it means a colour bar in the Immigration Bill, and an amendment exempting such immigrants from the operation of Sections 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10 and 11 would meet the point, and would still make the immigrants liable to the disabilities as to holding fixed property, etc., common to the other Asiatics.
('11', 293, 5, 14, 578759) I venture to suggest that paragraph 2 of your letter is not clear.
('11', 293, 5, 15, 578826) You say that the amendment to be moved will, in effect, exempt the educated Indian immigrants from registration under the Transvaal Act No.
('11', 293, 5, 16, 578966) 36 of 1908. This may mean that an educated Indian immigrant will not be free from the operation of Act No.
('11', 293, 5, 17, 579073) 36 of 1908 entirely, but that he will simply not be required to register.
('11', 293, 5, 18, 579147) It may be that, in that
('11', 293, 6, 19, 579171) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('11', 293, 6, 20, 579198) 2 Vide Appendix, “Lane’s letter to Gandhiji”, 16 3 1911.
('11', 294, 0, 1, 579255) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 295
('11', 294, 1, 2, 579297) case, an educated immigrant will be in a worse position than a resident Asiatic, a state of things which will hardly be acceptable to the Indian community.
('11', 294, 1, 3, 579453) As to the third paragraph, I may state that two advocates of long standing and wide experience, of the Transvaal and Natal respectively, have given their opinion to the effect that the wives and minor children of Asiatic residents will not be able to join them as heretofore, because they will be treated as prohibited immigrants, unless they can satisfy the education test; and, if it is the intention of the Bill not to debar the wives and minor children of such Asiatics, I submit that an exemption clause of a general nature should be added to the Bill.
('11', 294, 1, 4, 580011) The matters I have herein submitted are all of no intrinsic importance from the European standpoint, and I venture to think, not at all contentious, but they are of the greatest importance for the Asiatics.
('11', 294, 1, 5, 580218) I hope, therefore, that General Smuts will be pleased to give them the consideration they deserve, and grant relief.
('11', 294, 2, 6, 580335) I am, Yours faithfully,
('11', 294, 3, 7, 580359) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S.N. 5327; also Indian Opinion, 25 3 1911

('11', 301, 1, 2, 590815) 327. REPORT OF EUROPEAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('11', 301, 2, 3, 590857) [March 23, 1911] 1
('11', 301, 3, 4, 590876) A meeting of the European Committee of sympathisers, in Johannesburg, met at Mr. Hosken’s office, on the 23rd ultimo, to discuss the situation.
('11', 301, 3, 5, 591020) Mr. Hosken presided, and amongst those present were Rev.
('11', 301, 3, 6, 591077) J. J. Doke, Rev.
('11', 301, 3, 7, 591094) Phillips, Rev.
('11', 301, 3, 8, 591109) J. Howard, Rev.
('11', 301, 3, 9, 591125) T. Perry, and Messrs A. Cartwright, T. R. Haddon, D. Pollock, E. Dallow and M. K. Gandhi.
('11', 301, 3, 10, 591215) The following resolution was unanimously passed:
('11', 301, 4, 11, 591264) This meeting of the European British Indian Committee, having considered the correspondence between the Minister of the Interior and Mr. Gandhi (especially telegrams dated 17th and 19th March from Mr. Gandhi and the Minister’s reply thereto dated 22nd March), desires to record its entire approval of Mr. Gandhi’s communications, and is of opinion that the telegram of 22nd March from Mr. Gandhi clearly and equitably sets out the case, and urges the Government to accept the solution proposed therein.
('11', 301, 4, 12, 591767) The Committee regrets to learn that the Minister of the Interior has thought fit to raise a new point regarding the Free State, in conflict with the Prime Minister’s despatch dated 20th December, 1910, which stated, ‘It is, however, proposed notwithstanding this test, to instruct these officers to allow the entry of a limited number of educated Indians who will after such entry possess permanent residential rights in any Province of the Union,’ and the telegram from the Minister of the Interior to Mr. Gandhi, dated 4th March, which stated, ‘Asiatics admitted as immigrants under the Immigration Bill would not fall under registration laws and would not be restricted to provincial limits.’
('11', 301, 5, 13, 592463) From a photostat of the original draft, partly in Gandhiji’s hand: S.N. 5396 b; also
('11', 301, 6, 14, 592548) Indian Opinion, 8 4 1911
('11', 301, 7, 15, 592573) 1 The draft of the report contains the resolution passed on March 23 with correction in Gandhiji’s hand.

('11', 302, 5, 7, 593137) 329. LETTER TO L. W. RITCH
('11', 302, 6, 8, 593164) March 23, 1911
('11', 302, 7, 9, 593179) MY DEAR RITCH,
('11', 302, 8, 10, 593194) I have your letters.
('11', 302, 8, 11, 593215) I wish I had the time to write to you more fully than I can.
('11', 302, 8, 12, 593276) I am just going to the station to catch my train 2. How I wish I could chat with you, and persuade you that we cannot possibly abandon the Free State point.
('11', 302, 8, 13, 593433) The Members of the European Committee—whose names 3 you are having—saw the whole point without the slightest difficulty.
('11', 302, 8, 14, 593554) Mr. Doke is now as strong as any of them, although he cross examined me severely yesterday, and although, as I have told you, I read the whole of your objections to him.
('11', 302, 8, 15, 593724) We are not asking for repeal of Chapter 33. We are simply asking for exemption for educated Indians in a Union Bill, because the colour bar of the Transvaal is being transferred to the Union Bill.
('11', 302, 8, 16, 593921) General Smuts it is who is raising a new point, because he is committed in his speech and in his telegrams to the principle of such educated Asiatics being able to enter and reside in any Province of the Union.
('11', 302, 8, 17, 594132) You will note, too, that Lord Crewe has anticipated our objection to any colour bar in the Union Bill.
('11', 302, 8, 18, 594235) Hence his very serious anxiety on that score, and hence, too, General Botha’s emphatic declaration 4 that educated Asiatics who may enter under the Bill can

('11', 307, 7, 8, 600826) MY DEAR POLAK,
('11', 307, 8, 9, 600841) I have your letter.
('11', 307, 8, 10, 600861) I am glad that your tooth is out.
('11', 307, 8, 11, 600895) I certainly congratulate you upon getting such a splendid dentist.
('11', 307, 8, 12, 600962) All I can say is that he is an exception.
('11', 307, 8, 13, 601004) Karamat’s case 2 is shocking.
('11', 307, 8, 14, 601034) He is undoubtedly a great liar.
('11', 307, 8, 15, 601066) He will not obey instructions.
('11', 307, 8, 16, 601097) It is, therefore, difficult to treat him.
('11', 307, 8, 17, 601139) Otherwise, I consider that his is not a hopeless case.
('11', 307, 8, 18, 601194) Until he can be sent to India, and supported somewhere, all I can suggest is that, if the people at Phoenix are reconciled to the idea, Mr. Rustomjee should build him a hut, and he should live in that hut by himself and cook for himself, the settlers to have strict instructions not to supply him with any other food at all.
('11', 307, 8, 19, 601519) The cost will be trifling.
('11', 307, 8, 20, 601546) He could pass his time in a fairly easy manner, and he will have some sympathetic company also.
('11', 307, 8, 21, 601642) He can take a small plot, which he may do anything he likes with, so long as he keeps his hut and the plot in a sweet condition.
('11', 307, 8, 22, 601771) He can only be allowed to come to Phoenix, subject, as I say, to the consent of the settlers, if Mr. Rustomjee will undertake to see him personally at least once per month.
('11', 307, 8, 23, 601944) To send him to a lazaretto is, in my opinion, to ask him to commit suicide.
('11', 307, 8, 24, 602020) I would far rather place in his hands a revolver than be party to sending him to any place of compulsory segregation.
('11', 307, 8, 25, 602138) I dare say you know something of the scandals about Robben Island 3. Unless some telegram is received from Smuts, I shall be leaving

('11', 309, 4, 5, 604962) 338. RESOLUTIONS AT NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS MEETING 2
('11', 309, 5, 6, 605014) [DURBAN, March 26, 1911]
('11', 309, 6, 7, 605039) The Natal Indian Congress meeting passed the following resolutions: (1) Proposed by Mr. Abdul Caadir: This mass meeting of British Indian residents of Natal hereby places on record its emphatic protest against the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill now before the Union Parliament, in that: (1) It inaugurates a policy of most total exclusion of British Indians from this Province, and is thus calculated to curtail the facilities which the resident Indian population has hitherto enjoyed of importing from India clerical and other assistance; (2) No definite provision has been made for recognising the residential rights of the present Indian population, especially those of Indians born in this Province; (3) Unlike as heretofore, the issue of certificates of residence has been left by the Bill to the discretion of the Administration; (4) No provision seems to have been made for assisting persons declared to be prohibited by an Immigration Officer to assert their rights before a Court of Law; (5) The wives and minor children of the resident Indian population do not appear to be protected as heretofore; (6) The Bill seeks to introduce a racial or colour bar, by rendering British Indians, who may enter the Union under the education test, liable to the Asiatic Laws as to residential rights in one Province of the Union;
('11', 309, 7, 8, 606364) 1 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897 2 Vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 22 3 1911
('11', 310, 0, 1, 606477) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 311
('11', 310, 1, 2, 606519) and respectfully trusts that the Union Government will introduce the necessary amendments granting relief.
('11', 310, 2, 3, 606626) Seconded by Mr. G. P. Gandhi; supported by Mr. J. R. Solomon (Tongaat).
('11', 310, 3, 4, 606698) (2) Proposed by Mr. Ismail Gora: This meeting of British Indian residents of Natal declares that, in the event of the clauses imposing the disabilities described in Resolution No.
('11', 310, 3, 5, 606878) I, not being removed from the Bill, or otherwise satisfactorily amended, those present at the meeting shall respectfully oppose the Bill with all their strength.
('11', 310, 4, 6, 607040) Seconded by Mr. R. N. Moodley (Maritzburg); supported by Mr. S. Emam mally.
('11', 310, 5, 7, 607116) (3) Proposed by Mr. Abdulla Haji Adam: This meeting of British Indian residents of Natal hereby authorises the collection of a fund to effectively carry out the objects of the foregoing resolutions.
('11', 310, 6, 8, 607315) Seconded by Mr. R. B. Chetty; supported by Mr. M. M. Suliman (Umzinto).
('11', 310, 7, 9, 607387) (4) Proposed by Mr. Parsee Rustomjee: This meeting of British Indian residents of Natal hereby congratulates the Transvaal Indian community upon, and cordially endorses their determination to continue, the “passive resistance” struggle until the racial or colour bar referred to in Resolution No.
('11', 310, 7, 10, 607684) 1 is removed.
('11', 310, 8, 11, 607698) Seconded by Mr. Lutchman Panday; supported by Mr. Mahomed Cassim Coovadia.
('11', 310, 9, 12, 607773) (5) Proposed by Mr. Suliman Karwa: This meeting of British Indian residents of Natal hereby authorises the Chairman to forward copies of the foregoing resolutions to the Union, Imperial and Indian Governments.
('11', 310, 10, 13, 607983) Seconded by Mr. P. K. Naidoo; supported by Mr. Rooknoodeen.

('11', 311, 11, 15, 608480) 341. LETTER TO SONJA SCHLESIN 1
('11', 311, 12, 16, 608512) [CAPE TOWN, March 27, 1911]
('11', 311, 13, 17, 608540) Here is roughly the purport of the conversation between J.C.S. and me:
('11', 311, 14, 18, 608611) SMUTS: You see, Gandhi, I am giving you everything.
('11', 311, 14, 19, 608663) I could have done so by regulation but now I am protecting wives and children in the Bill.
('11', 311, 14, 20, 608754) I do not know why, but I know that everybody suspects me.
('11', 311, 14, 21, 608812) I am also recognising domicile.
('11', 311, 14, 22, 608844) But you are very unreasonable.
('11', 311, 14, 23, 608875) Your point is absolutely new.
('11', 311, 15, 24, 608905) GANDHIJI: How can you say so, General Smuts?
('11', 311, 15, 25, 608950) Are you not creating a racial bar?
('11', 311, 16, 26, 608985) 1 The addressee’s name is not available, as the first two pages of the letter are missing; but from the instructions given in the last four paragraphs, it appears to have been written to Miss Sonja Schlesin, who looked after Gandhiji’s Johannesburg office.
('11', 312, 0, 1, 609242) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 313
('11', 312, 1, 2, 609284) S.: No, I am not.
('11', 312, 1, 3, 609302) Can you show it to me?
('11', 312, 2, 4, 609325) G.: Certainly.
('11', 312, 2, 5, 609340) Will you admit that throughout the four years we have been simply fighting against the racial or colour bar?
('11', 312, 3, 6, 609449) S.: Started and said after some hesitation, ‘Yes’.
('11', 312, 4, 7, 609500) G.: You know that in the Transvaal Immigration Law there is no colour bar, but you read sub section 4 and the Asiatic Act, and you have the bar.
('11', 312, 5, 8, 609645) S.: You are not stating it fairly.
('11', 312, 6, 9, 609680) G.: Then you shall state it in your own words.
('11', 312, 7, 10, 609727) S.: In the Transvaal we wanted total exclusion and that is brought about by the combined effect of the two laws.
('11', 312, 8, 11, 609840) G.: And now you want the same thing for the Free State.
('11', 312, 8, 12, 609896) The combined effect of the Free State Law and the new Bill will be [to] shut out the Nizam of Hyderabad, and I assure you that the passive resisters will fight against it.
('11', 312, 9, 13, 610068) S.: There you are unreasonable.
('11', 312, 10, 14, 610100) G.: I must deny the charge.
('11', 312, 10, 15, 610128) I am not at all anxious that a single Indian should actually enter the Free State.
('11', 312, 10, 16, 610211) I am sincerely anxious to help you.
('11', 312, 11, 17, 610247) S.: You do not know my difficulties.
('11', 312, 12, 18, 610284) G.: I do.
('11', 312, 12, 19, 610294) And because I do, I suggest that only so much of the Free State Law should be a basis for exemption as will enable a highly educated Indian to enter the Free State.
('11', 312, 12, 20, 610459) If you send for the Law, I will show you what I mean.
('11', 312, 13, 21, 610513) S.: (Sends for the law): But the Free Staters will never consent.
('11', 312, 14, 22, 610579) G.: Then why did General Botha write to Lord Crewe that educated immigrants will be able to enter any province?
('11', 312, 15, 23, 610691) S.: You do not know all the dispatches.
('11', 312, 15, 24, 610731) We have not printed everything, you know.
('11', 312, 15, 25, 610773) Lord Crewe knows that we never wanted to give the rights as to the Free State.
('11', 312, 16, 26, 610852) G.: But you repeated the same thing at the second reading.
('11', 312, 17, 27, 610911) S.: Yes.
('11', 312, 17, 28, 610920) I was simply sounding the Free Staters, and I noticed that they were very much opposed.
('11', 312, 18, 29, 611008) G.: If they are, it is your duty to persuade them, and if they cannot be, you may simply amend the Transvaal Legislation.
('11', 312, 19, 30, 611130) S.: But I am bound to the Imperial Government to pass this Bill.
('11', 312, 19, 31, 611195) (Reads the Law and asks G. to go over to his side.
('11', 312, 19, 32, 611246) G. points out the
('11', 313, 0, 1, 611264) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 313, 1, 2, 611306) section from which the exemption is to be granted.) Yes, I now see what you mean.
('11', 313, 2, 3, 611388) G.: Yes, the educated Asiatics will be still prohibited from owning fixed property and from trading.
('11', 313, 2, 4, 611489) I am not raising that issue at all.
('11', 313, 2, 5, 611525) We have still to fight you on the question of Law 3 of 1885. But this has nothing to do with passive resistance.
('11', 313, 2, 6, 611638) I for one do not wish to offer passive resistance for material gains, but the racial bar we can never accept.
('11', 313, 3, 7, 611748) S.: But you have no idea of my difficulties.
('11', 313, 4, 8, 611793) G.: I know that you are quite able to overcome greater difficulties.
('11', 313, 5, 9, 611862) S.: All right, I shall now talk to the Free State members.
('11', 313, 5, 10, 611921) You should leave your address with Lane.
('11', 313, 5, 11, 611962) I hope you will keep the Cape and the Natal Indians silent.

('11', 314, 12, 14, 613523) 343. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE
('11', 314, 13, 15, 613552) 7, BUITENCINGLE STREET, CAPE TOWN, March 29, 1911
('11', 314, 14, 16, 613602) DEAR MR. LANE,
('11', 314, 15, 17, 613617) I observe that amendments proposed to be moved by General Smuts to the Immigration Bill require that evidence in respect of domicile, marriage and parental relationship should be furnished to the satisfaction of the Immigration Officer.
('11', 314, 15, 18, 613854) I venture to submit for General Smuts’ consideration that such requirement may open the door to favouritism, corruption and bribery.
('11', 314, 15, 19, 613987) I also submit that such delicate questions as to marital and parental relationship could only be decided by Courts of Law in case of doubt but not by an administrative officer nor should the matter be left to be dealt with by regulation.
('11', 314, 15, 20, 614225) With reference to the question of domicile it is a matter of the
('11', 314, 16, 21, 614290) 1 Vide Appendix, “General Smuts Telegram to Hosken”, 24 3 1911. 2 Published in Indian Opinion, 1 4 1911
('11', 315, 0, 1, 614394) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 315, 1, 2, 614436) utmost importance that an illustrative definition such as occurs in the Natal Statute should be given.
('11', 315, 1, 3, 614539) Members of the Indian community here lay the greatest stress on this point owing to their unfortunate experience in the past.
('11', 315, 1, 4, 614665) As to section 25, the feeling is very strong that those who prove their right of residence should be entitled to receive, on their making application there for, a permanent residential certificate.
('11', 315, 1, 5, 614863) These are points which are of vital importance to the residents, and I hope that they will receive General Smuts’ favourable consideration.
('11', 315, 2, 6, 615003) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S.N. 5385; also Indian Opinion, 8 4 1911

('11', 315, 8, 12, 615285) 345. INTERVIEW TO “CAPE ARGUS” 2
('11', 315, 9, 13, 615318) [CAPE TOWN, Before March 30, 1911] 3
('11', 315, 10, 14, 615355) A mistaken impression has got about that the British Indians of the Transvaal are perfectly satisfied with the provisions of the Immigrants’ Restriction.
('11', 315, 10, 15, 615509) Mr. Advocate Gandhi, spokesman of the Transvaal Indian community, who is at present in Cape Town, in conversation with an Argus representative, detailed various points of the Bill, which, are not approved of by the Transvaal Indians.
('11', 315, 10, 16, 615743) [Gandhiji said:] The chief drawback, so far as the passive resisters are concerned,
('11', 315, 11, 17, 615827) 1 For the correspondence, vide Appendix, “General Smuts Telegram to Hosken”, 24 3 1911. 2 The report was “Special to Cape Argus” and was published under the heading “Emigration Bill—Mr. Gandhi’s Grievances—Some Fresh Points”.
('11', 315, 11, 18, 616053) 3 The Argus interview was published in The Star of the 30th.
('11', 316, 0, 1, 616114) VOL. 11: 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 317
('11', 316, 1, 2, 616156) is in the racial bar set up, if educated Asiatics who may enter the Union under the education test may not have residential rights in the Free State.
('11', 316, 1, 3, 616306) It will be remembered that General Botha in a despatch to Lord Crewe, dated December 20, said that such Asiatics could settle in any Province of the Union, and a like statement was made by General Smuts at the second reading of the Bill.
('11', 316, 1, 4, 616544) It now appears that the intention is to go back upon this, and debar such Asiatics from entering the Free State.
('11', 316, 1, 5, 616657) I may mention at once that the question is purely an academic one, because no Indian will care to enter the Free State under the present circumstances, but the removal of the racial bar in an Immigration Bill is absolutely necessary to salve Asiatic sentiment.
('11', 316, 1, 6, 616918) We do not contend that the general disabilities Asiatics labour under in the Free State should be removed.
('11', 316, 1, 7, 617025) That is to say, if an educated Asiatic immigrant enters the Free State, he would still be under disabilities as to the holding of fixed property and the carrying on of any trade.
('11', 316, 1, 8, 617204) The objection against the entrance of such educated Asiatics is based upon ignorance of the situation.
('11', 316, 1, 9, 617307) I can hardly imagine that the Free State members would object to conciliating Asiatic sentiment by a simple removal of the racial bar.
('11', 316, 1, 10, 617442) There is little probability that a single British Indian of education will seek to enter the Free State, since the Indian population there is too sparse to support an Indian barrister or doctor.
('11', 316, 1, 11, 617637) Unless this racial bar is removed, passive resistance, I fear, must continue, and I do not know but that its extent may be increased by the British Indians of Natal and the Cape joining it.
('11', 316, 2, 12, 617827) NATAL AND THE CAPE
('11', 316, 3, 13, 617846) I have been receiving telegrams from Natal on other points of the Bill, and on these I am conferring with my countrymen in Cape Town.
('11', 316, 3, 14, 617980) They are all agreed that the existing rights should be fully protected, and they therefore reason that full protection should be given to the wives and children of those who are domiciled in South Africa, and that the rights of domicile should be fully recognised, as they have been hitherto.
('11', 316, 4, 15, 618273) THE TERM “DOMICILE”
('11', 316, 5, 16, 618293) Past experience shows that the term domicile, being a highly technical word, needs exact definition to avoid the possibilities of bribery and corruption.
('11', 316, 5, 17, 618447) The Natal Act makes it possible for an Asiatic
('11', 317, 0, 1, 618494) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 317, 1, 2, 618536) who has resided for three years to receive a certificate of domicile.
('11', 317, 1, 3, 618606) It is also contended that those having rights of residence should be able to take out certificates if they choose to do so, so as to enable them to move to and fro without difficulty, without having to incur constant expense to prove their rights.
('11', 317, 1, 4, 618854) It seems to me, indeed, that many of these matters are easily capable of adjustment.
('11', 317, 2, 5, 618939) EDUCATION TEST
('11', 317, 3, 6, 618954) The great question for British Indians in Cape Colony and Natal is the disability imposed by the severe education test in the new Bill.
('11', 317, 3, 7, 619090) Some guarantee is, I think, undoubtedly necessary in order that Indian residents may obtain clerical assistance from India, since this is not to be obtained in South Africa.
('11', 317, 3, 8, 619264) Hitherto Indians having a fair education have entered under the immigration test, and such facilities will be still necessary if the existing rights are to be protected.
('11', 317, 3, 9, 619434) Some of us even go so far as to contend that now, under Union, there should be no restriction of movement from Province to Province, but the most moderate are for the time being reconciled to provincial restrictions.
('11', 317, 3, 10, 619651) We recognise the difficulty of the Government in the matter’ but it is still a pressing grievance.
('11', 317, 4, 11, 619750) From a photostat of the cutting from Cape Argus in the Sabarmati Sangrahalaya: S.N. 5214; a1so Indian Opinion, 8 4 1911

('11', 318, 1, 2, 620180) 347. SPEECH AT RECEPTION IN CAPE TOWN 1
('11', 318, 2, 3, 620220) [March, 30, 1911]
('11', 318, 3, 4, 620238) Brothers, I am obliged to you for the trouble you have taken for my sake.
('11', 318, 3, 5, 620312) If you love me and my work, the only thing I would ask you to do is to join me in the work.
('11', 318, 3, 6, 620404) I do not think I deserve the praise you have lavished on me.
('11', 318, 3, 7, 620465) Whatever I have done and am doing still must be attributed to the religious ardour in me.
('11', 318, 3, 8, 620555) We all know that Prahlad 2
('11', 318, 4, 9, 620582) opposed his father, embraced a red hot iron pillar and went through many other ordeals.
('11', 318, 4, 10, 620670) He suffered all this, he refused to submit to his father, not because of any animosity towards his father but because of his hatred for untruth.
('11', 318, 4, 11, 620815) Similarly, friends, we may say that we have resorted to satyagraha not in a spirit of hostility to the Government, but because it is a religious duty to fight untruth.
('11', 318, 4, 12, 620983) Some believe that satyagraha consists only in going to gaol, but that is not true.
('11', 318, 4, 13, 621066) Satyagraha means resisting untruth by truthful means.
('11', 318, 4, 14, 621120) It can be offered at any place, at any time and by any person, even though he may be in a minority of one.
('11', 318, 4, 15, 621227) If one remains steadfast in it in a spirit of dedication, it always brings success.
('11', 318, 4, 16, 621311) Satyagraha knows neither frustration nor despair.
('11', 318, 4, 17, 621361) The admiration you have expressed for the success of satyagraha in the Transvaal does show that you realize its great value.
('11', 318, 5, 18, 621486) [Referring to the Immigration Bill, Gandhiji said:]
('11', 318, 6, 19, 621538) We are nearing the end, and victory will undoubtedly be ours if we work on in the spirit of satyagraha.
('11', 318, 6, 20, 621642) What is most humiliating to us in the new Bill is the provision that educated Indians cannot enter the Orange Free State, and that the Orange Free State Act, based on racial discrimination, will stand.
('11', 318, 6, 21, 621844) This is humiliating to all Indians.
('11', 318, 6, 22, 621880) We in the Transvaal and in Natal are firm in our opposition to it, and I am glad to know that the Cape Indians have also joined us.
('11', 318, 6, 23, 622012) If we are united in offering satyagraha, our victory is assured.
('11', 318, 7, 24, 622077) Gandhiji then explained the position with regard to the correspondence between General Smuts and himself, and also described how the families of satyagrahis were maintained on the Tolstoy Farm, outlining the steps taken to give
('11', 318, 8, 25, 622305) 1 Given by the Cape Town United Hindu Association on March 30, 1911 in honour of L.W. Ritch and Gandhiji 2 Gandhiji often refers to him as the ideal Satyagrahi of his conception.
('11', 319, 0, 1, 622484) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 319, 1, 2, 622526) them some education of practical value.
('11', 319, 1, 3, 622566) Finally, he referred to the urgent need for clothes, blankets, etc., for the use of the inmates of the Farm during the winter.

('11', 321, 4, 5, 625919) I have your ‘slating’ letter.
('11', 321, 4, 6, 625949) It is certainly a sign of ‘thickness’ that I should not write to please you but write only when I have something to say.

('11', 321, 4, 11, 626482) With you, as I have so often said, the heart comes first.

('11', 321, 6, 22, 627066) He always waits till the last moment.

('11', 322, 4, 9, 628215) 1 Probably Gopal Naidoo, who came to stay at Tolstoy Farm around June 13, 1910 and was looking after the cooking there; vide “Letter to Maganlal Gandhi”, 15 6 1910 and “Johannesburg”, 9 7 1910. 2 This meeting held by Cape Indians demanded the following changes, among others, in the Union Immigrants Restriction Bill: (1) proof regarding domicile from wives and children of domiciled Asiatics be left to courts of law; (2) Immigration Officers’ decisions be made justiciable; (3) the less severe education test existing in the Cape be retained in the new law; and (4) educated Asiatic immigrants be allowed to enter and reside in any Province of the Union.

('11', 325, 5, 10, 633005) [CAPE TOWN] April 5, 1911
('11', 325, 6, 11, 633031) There is another matter which is likely to cause the greatest distress in the Transvaal, if not ruin to hundreds of Indians; the Gold Law of 1908 (Transvaal) 2 Section 130 provides that no right under it can be held by or sub let to an Asiatic or Coloured person.
('11', 325, 6, 12, 633295) It has been discovered that many townships are affected by this law.
('11', 325, 6, 13, 633364) Klerksdorp Indians have received notices to vacate premises occupied by them 3. The notices have been served by the owners, who in turn have been notified by the Government that they are committing a breach of the law by allowing Asiatics to occupy Stands registered in their names.
('11', 325, 6, 14, 633647) There is a Supreme Court case which says that Asiatics who have leases cannot be disturbed during the period of their leases, if their leases were entered into prior to the passing of the law.
('11', 325, 6, 15, 633840) This will not protect existing rights, for very few have long leases.
('11', 325, 6, 16, 633910) Monthly tenants will therefore be ruined.
('11', 325, 6, 17, 633952) The legal opinion has been sent to you; it shows that, if the law is carried out, the whole Asiatic
('11', 325, 7, 18, 634052) 1 This was forwarded to the Colonial Office on May 5, 1911 by Maud Polak, sister of H. S. L. Polak and Assistant Honorary Secretary of the SABI Committee in London.

('11', 325, 7, 20, 634446) The European holders had accordingly asked their Indian tenants to vacate.
('11', 325, 7, 21, 634521) In May, 1911, Klerksdorp Indians petitioned the Minister of the Interior appealing that the law be repealed and the Prosecutor’s notices withdrawn, but the Acting Secretary for the Interior replied in June saying that the questions raised were of a “purely legal character” and that the Minister could not move Parliament for altering the law.

('11', 327, 3, 5, 637792) 1 Jan Christiaan Smuts (1870 1950); Gandhiji found him “as able a general and administrator as he is a lawyer”, but mentions that he was warned that “slim Janny”, as Smuts was known, was a “trimmer”; vide Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XXV.
('11', 327, 3, 6, 638034) After a brilliant academic career at Cambridge, Smuts was admitted to the Cape Town Bar in 1895; commander in chief of rebel commandoes in the Cape during Boer War; in 1902 urged compromise with the British at the Vereeniging peace negotiations; strongly opposed Milner’s policy, especially the importation of Chinese coolies for the gold mines; founded in 1904. along with Botha, the Het Volk party; after Responsible Government became Transvaal’s Colonial Secretary; an advocate of Union along with Lionel Curtis (“Johannesburg Letter”, 9 5 1908) and an author of the South Africa Act of 1911; in 1910 became Union Minister for Interior, Mines and Defence; in 1912 took over the treasury, retaining Defence; in 1916 during World War I, accepted Imperial command in East Africa; joined War Cabinet and initiated unification of the flying services; after Armistice, wrote his Memorandum, The League of Nations: A Practical Suggestion, which subsequently became the covenant of the League.

('11', 332, 3, 4, 647200) 7, BUITENCINGLE [STREET,] CAPE TOWN, April 7, 1911
('11', 332, 4, 5, 647251) DEAR MR. LANE, In accordance with conversation 2 between us, I reduce to writing my suggestions for bringing the Asiatic struggle in the Transvaal to a close.
('11', 332, 6, 6, 647410) The new clause tabled by General Smuts to follow clause 27 in the present Bill should be amended as follows: Anything to the contrary notwithstanding in Act No.
('11', 332, 6, 7, 647571) 36 of 1908 of the Transvaal and Chapter XXXIII of the Orange Free State Constitution, a person who, by complying with the conditions described in paragraph (a) of section four of this Act, has been permitted to enter the Union shall not be deemed to be subject to registration under the provisions of the said Act of the Transvaal and to Clauses 1 to 6 of the said Chapter XXXIII.
('11', 332, 6, 8, 647952) (The words underlined are the additions suggested by me.
('11', 332, 6, 9, 648009) ) Subject to such amendment and subject to unequivocal protection of existing rights, especially of wives and children of lawful residents and immigrants, the bill will be acceptable to the passive resisters.
('11', 332, 6, 10, 648218) I offer no comment on the special objections that the Cape and Natal Indians have naturally raised, and which I think ought to receive careful and favourable consideration.
('11', 332, 6, 11, 648391) B As an alternative solution, I suggest as follows: (1) The present bill be dropped.
('11', 332, 6, 12, 648476) (2) A bill to amend Transvaal Act 15 of 1907 3 be introduced and
('11', 332, 7, 13, 648541) 1 These words are in Gandhiji’s hand.
('11', 332, 7, 14, 648579) 2 Vide “Letter to L. W. Ritch”, 5 4 1911 3 This is the Transvaal Immigrants’ Restriction Act which came into force in January, 1908, without, however, superseding the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907, and against which the satyagraha campaign of 1908 was directed; for text of the Bill,
('11', 333, 0, 1, 648866) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 333, 1, 2, 648908) thereby (a) The Transvaal Act 2 of 1907 1 be repealed “except so far as it is applicable to the registration of minors lawfully resident in the Transvaal”.
('11', 333, 1, 3, 649064) (The wording is taken from the first schedule to the present bill.
('11', 333, 1, 4, 649131) My reading of the reservation is that minor children of registered Asiatics, no matter where they may be, shall be free to enter the Transvaal and be liable to and entitled to registration on reaching the age of 16. ) (b) The education clause of Act 15 of 1907 may be replaced by sub clause (a) of clause 4 of the present bill in order, if necessary, to make the test more severe.
('11', 333, 1, 5, 649512) (c) Sub clause 4 of section 2 of Act 15 of 1907 be repealed.
('11', 333, 1, 6, 649573) (d) General Smuts’ new clause 28 be added mutatis mutandis to Act 15 of 1907, without of course the addition suggested by me and which addition is necessary for the present bill but NOT for the alternative solution.
('11', 333, 1, 7, 649789) In my opinion the alternative solution is the simplest; it raises no question as to the Free State and its acceptance by General Smuts will not only close passive resistance, but I feel sure will meet with the entire approval of the Indian community.
('11', 333, 1, 8, 650040) This, however, does not mean that the community waives its right to move for an amelioration of its position in many other matters.
('11', 333, 2, 9, 650172) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

It was virtually a re enactment of its precursor, the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, which had been disallowed by the Imperial Government on protest made against it by the Gandhi Ally deputation of 1906. Both the Ordinance and the Act envisaged, among other things, the compulsory registration of Asiatics and the affixture of their finger impressions on their certificates.

('11', 337, 2, 3, 657282) 7 BUITENSINGLE, April 8 [1911] 1
('11', 337, 3, 4, 657315) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('11', 337, 4, 5, 657336) You are certainly not regular about letters this time.
('11', 337, 4, 6, 657391) This proposed London visit causes me a deal of worry.
('11', 337, 4, 7, 657445) Again to leave Mrs. Gandhi and the two youngsters, again to masquerade in the wretched costume, etc.
('11', 337, 4, 8, 657546) You know here I have not observed the rules of decency.
('11', 337, 4, 9, 657602) I go about the House of Assembly and to Smuts in sandals and my usual jacket.
('11', 337, 4, 10, 657680) I wore the shoes for two days.
('11', 337, 4, 11, 657711) I saw that they were uncomfortable and really not necessary.
('11', 337, 4, 12, 657772) So I discarded them.
('11', 337, 4, 13, 657793) I am none the worse received for that reason.
('11', 337, 4, 14, 657839) You will say perhaps it is because the men I meet are too gentlemanly, not that I am wise or right in breaking the social convention.
('11', 337, 4, 15, 657973) If you did say so, you would probably be right.
('11', 337, 4, 16, 658021) But that is just my position.
('11', 337, 4, 17, 658051) If it were not for the passive resisters who are anxious for a settlement and for Polak, whom I want to see in London with his wife, probably I would not make even this effort and simply trust to passive resistance pure and simple to do its work.
('11', 337, 4, 18, 658298) 2 What is one to do.
('11', 337, 4, 19, 658319) I am torn by confliction emotions as to this London visit.
('11', 337, 4, 20, 658378) Now you have the whole thought running through my mind.
('11', 337, 4, 21, 658434) Still on saltless diet.
('11', 337, 4, 22, 658458) It causes me no worry.
('11', 337, 4, 23, 658481) The quantity I take now is very small.
('11', 337, 4, 24, 658520) I have little exercise.
('11', 337, 4, 25, 658544) With love,
('11', 337, 5, 26, 658555) UPPER HOUSE

('11', 340, 9, 12, 663413) 1 The Immigrants’ Restriction Bill.
('11', 340, 9, 13, 663449) 2 Vide “Letter to L. W. Ritch”, 8 4 1911. The letter to Polak, however, is not available.
('11', 340, 9, 14, 663539) 3 Henry Solomon Leon Polak; assistant editor of The Transvaal Critic who joined Indian Opinion (“Our Trial”, 31 12 1904) after Gandhiji had struck up a “casual” acquaintance with him in the Johannesburg vegetarian restaurant; “had a wonderful faculty of translating into practice anything that appealed to his intellect”; he took to life in Phoenix “like a duck takes to water” and “we began to live like blood brothers, ” says Gandhiji who was also best man at his wedding; became editor of Indian Opinion in 1906 during Gandhiji’s absence in England and a full fledged attorney in 1908 after having served an apprenticeship with Gandhiji; was arrested after the Great March into the Transvaal in 1913; visited India and England to help the African Indian cause.
('11', 340, 9, 15, 664303) Vide An Autobiography, Part IV, Ch. XVIII, XXI & XXII and Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XXIII & XLV.

('11', 340, 9, 17, 664549) 5 Partick Duncan; member of the Transvaal Legislative Assembly; Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal, 1903 6, while it was still a self governing colony; initiated in 1906 the Transvaal Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance in the face of Indian opposition; the Golden Number of Indian Opinion (1914), however, mentions that he had since become more sensible of “the Imperial issues involved” in the Indian question and had “advocated measures of redress” for Indians.

('11', 341, 1, 2, 665053) He came and said, “Perhaps it would be better for us not to talk lest it might be thought that you were influencing me.” I said, “Not [at] all.
('11', 341, 1, 3, 665197) I have been informing Lane about all my movements.
('11', 341, 1, 4, 665248) He knows whom I see and talk to.” “But”, he said, “you need not worry.
('11', 341, 1, 5, 665319) I think you will get what you want.
('11', 341, 1, 6, 665355) It is high time the thing was over.” “But”, I said, “do you know anything of the latest[?].” “Yes”, he said, “General Smuts showed me your letter 1 to him.
('11', 341, 1, 7, 665511) I think, we shall drop the present Bill and adopt your alternative solution.
('11', 341, 1, 8, 665588) But you will not bring in anything more.
('11', 341, 1, 9, 665629) “I said, “How can you say that, Mr. Duncan?
('11', 341, 1, 10, 665673) You have yourself stated our proposition very fairly.” “Yes”, he said, “I notice you have been quoting me.
('11', 341, 1, 11, 665780) But you have not always brought that point forward.
('11', 341, 1, 12, 665832) I thought at times you kept it in the background.” “I could not help giving that appearance at times,” I said, “we had to give prominence to one point or another as occasion required unless we were to overload every speech and letter with details.
('11', 341, 1, 13, 666080) It is General Smuts who has always raised new points and each time granted less than our demands, etc.” He then wanted to know what I wanted about children, whether I wanted them to get in without giving proofs, etc.
('11', 341, 1, 14, 666297) I assured him on that point.
('11', 341, 1, 15, 666326) But I could not help noticing how unfortunate it was that Smuts had seen him before I, and how fortunate it was that I saw him yesterday whilst his talk with Smuts was fresh in his mind.
('11', 341, 1, 16, 666513) After this experience, I have decided to stick here until the Bill is through or I am certain that nothing is to be done.
('11', 341, 1, 17, 666635) One may consider it to be pretty certain that the general bill is doomed, and I am more than ever hopeful that the alternative proposal will be accepted.

('11', 343, 4, 7, 668512) I wonder why my letter 2 regarding diet reached you so late.

('11', 345, 2, 3, 671133) [CAPE TOWN] April 12, 1911
('11', 345, 3, 4, 671160) MY DEAR RITCH, I thought that I would ask Lane whether he could give me definite information for cabling to Madras.
('11', 345, 3, 5, 671276) Smuts was not then in.
('11', 345, 3, 6, 671299) Lane therefore went over to the House and sent me a letter 1 as per copy.
('11', 345, 3, 7, 671373) I hope you understood my wire 2 sent to you thereafter.
('11', 345, 3, 8, 671429) So that now we must wait the whole of this week.
('11', 345, 3, 9, 671478) From Friday, there will be no work till Monday.
('11', 345, 3, 10, 671526) The House meets again on Tuesday.
('11', 345, 3, 11, 671560) I think we are bound to get definite information next week.
('11', 345, 3, 12, 671620) Smuts is in no hurry.
('11', 345, 3, 13, 671642) He certainly would like to prolong the agony if he could.
('11', 345, 3, 14, 671700) We can but wait.
('11', 345, 3, 15, 671717) I am not now seeing any member.
('11', 345, 3, 16, 671749) I think that I have seen the principal ones and that now it would be better to refrain.
('11', 345, 3, 17, 671837) I am anxiously waiting to know how you are getting on there.
('11', 345, 3, 18, 671898) You do not seem to have got any work yet.
('11', 345, 3, 19, 671940) Please ask Miss Schlesin to send me Dr. Mehta’s manuscript.
('11', 345, 3, 20, 672000) He says he had sent a certain speech, & c.
('11', 345, 3, 21, 672043) I should like to have it here.
('11', 345, 3, 22, 672074) I want also Finot’s Race Prejudice.
('11', 345, 3, 23, 672110) I think that book is among Polak’s books.
('11', 345, 3, 24, 672152) I want it at once for Canon Allmett who is here but who is leaving for England shortly.
('11', 345, 3, 25, 672240) How is Harold keeping in health?
('11', 345, 3, 26, 672273) The weather here is most oppressive.
('11', 345, 3, 27, 672310) How do you manage for cooking, & c.?
('11', 345, 4, 28, 672347) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] Please ask Miss S. to sent the enclosed to Mr. Barrett of Pretoria, whose address she knows or ought to, telling him that the letter unfortunately went by mistake to England from where it has only now been returned.
('11', 345, 4, 29, 672599) She should add that I would do my best to sent him something as soon as I was free.
('11', 345, 4, 30, 672683) M. K.G. [PPS.] From Friday to Saturday I am not wiring as there will be holidays during that time.

('11', 349, 2, 3, 678016) Unrevised April 14, 1911 MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE, L.H. says ‘I AM COMING’.
('11', 349, 2, 4, 678087) U.H. says ‘I AM NOT SURE WE ARE GOING.’So you had better be careful in order to avoid disappointment.
('11', 349, 2, 5, 678189) When I seriously think of it my head turns.
('11', 349, 2, 6, 678233) I certainly want to be with Mrs. Gandhi and the children for some little time.
('11', 349, 2, 7, 678312) The idea of another deputation is absolutely repulsive.
('11', 349, 2, 8, 678368) 1 I am not at all sure that it is my duty to be present at the Conference.
('11', 349, 2, 9, 678443) But I am sure that it is my duty to be on the Farm and with Mrs. Gandhi and the children; it is my duty to be with the boys on the Farm; it is my duty to be with the women on the Farm; it is my duty to send Polak away at the earliest opportunity 2 ; it is my duty to help Ritch to build up his practice; and if passive resistance is still to go on, it is my duty to seek imprisonment and if I cannot get that, at least to do what I can for the dependents of passive resisters.
('11', 349, 2, 10, 678920) All the above catalogue can be gone through if I am in the Transvaal.
('11', 349, 2, 11, 678990) Put all the above in one scale and the proposed visit to the Conference in the other and find out which weighs heavier.
('11', 349, 2, 12, 679110) I am in a fog.
('11', 349, 2, 13, 679125) I am therefore leaving the things to shape themselves.
('11', 349, 2, 14, 679180) You can talk light heartedly about going to Germany.
('11', 349, 2, 15, 679233) But what about the Farm, the fencing, the borehole, Mountain View, your office and a host of such other things?
('11', 349, 2, 16, 679345) They all require careful thinking out, before you can stir from Johannesburg.
('11', 349, 2, 17, 679423) It will be easier for you to go if I remained behind.
('11', 349, 2, 18, 679477) The problem becomes doubly difficult if we both must go.
('11', 349, 2, 19, 679534) I hope Gordon is getting on.
('11', 349, 2, 20, 679563) Pray remember me to him.
('11', 349, 2, 21, 679588) I understand that today is your fasting day.
('11', 349, 2, 22, 679633) Wish you well in every respect.
('11', 349, 2, 23, 679665) You say autumn has set in there.
('11', 349, 2, 24, 679698) We are being boiled here.
('11', 349, 2, 25, 679724) The heat is very severe.
('11', 349, 2, 26, 679749) I had a day of manual labour yesterday.
('11', 349, 2, 27, 679789) (I have marked the

('11', 356, 4, 15, 691340) 391 LETTER TO GENERAL SMUTS
('11', 356, 5, 16, 691368) [CAPE TOWN] April 19, 1911
('11', 356, 6, 17, 691395) DEAR GENERAL SMUTS,
('11', 356, 7, 18, 691415) After having thought over our conversation 1 of this morning, I feel that I should place the position frankly before you.
('11', 356, 7, 19, 691537) If the question is not settled during the present session, the prospect of passive resisters remaining totally inactive is too appalling to contemplate.
('11', 356, 7, 20, 691690) There are men on Tolstoy Farm with their families who are pecuniarily ruined.
('11', 356, 7, 21, 691768) There are others outside in the same position.
('11', 356, 7, 22, 691815) If they are not to court arrest or are to avoid it, their movements must be hampered.
('11', 356, 7, 23, 691901) If they cannot for instance go to Natal and return without being challenged at the Border.
('11', 356, 7, 24, 691992) Some who are traders cannot trade because they will not produce their registration certificate[s] so long as the struggle lasts.
('11', 356, 7, 25, 692121) I should have nothing to say about all this misery if we were conducting an active campaign.
('11', 356, 7, 26, 692214) But, to continue using military terms, our conversation contemplates a truce for a year or longer i.e., until the Parliament meets again.
('11', 356, 7, 27, 692352) I do not
('11', 356, 8, 28, 692361) 1 Vide the following item.
('11', 357, 0, 1, 692388) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 357, 1, 2, 692430) know how this is to be done.
('11', 357, 1, 3, 692459) As you know the campaign has cost us heavily, and our monthly expenditure for supporting families, &c., is naturally great.
('11', 357, 1, 4, 692583) If we are to again start begging, we must agitate here, in India and in England.
('11', 357, 1, 5, 692664) There are men from Natal.
('11', 357, 1, 6, 692690) They have broken up everything.
('11', 357, 1, 7, 692722) Are we to keep them for months in a state of suspense?
('11', 357, 1, 8, 692777) I am sincerely anxious to help you, but I do not know how I could promise inactivity on the part of the passive resisters.
('11', 357, 1, 9, 692900) What you, the Imperial Government and I want to avoid is the ferment.
('11', 357, 1, 10, 692970) I fear that, in the nature of things, it is well nigh impossible to avoid it if the matter is not closed during this session.
('11', 357, 1, 11, 693096) On the other hand, it will be churlish for me not to appreciate your own difficulty, especially at the fag end of an exhausting session.
('11', 357, 1, 12, 693233) You have many difficult questions to solve.
('11', 357, 1, 13, 693277) Indians know at present only one.
('11', 357, 1, 14, 693311) But I confess that I do not apprehend the difficulty your legal advisers do as to the alternative solution suggested by me.
('11', 357, 1, 15, 693435) Seeing that you want some day or other to pass the general bill, there is no reason why the Transvaal Province may not anticipate the education test of that bill.
('11', 357, 1, 16, 693598) It will keep out not a single white man whom you may want in the Transvaal and it will keep out all the Indians save six highly educated men per year.
('11', 357, 1, 17, 693749) So far as I have been able to gauge the feeling of the leaders of the opposition, they will not raise any opposition.
('11', 357, 1, 18, 693867) All will understand that the solution will be tentative and intended to meet the trouble in the Transvaal.
('11', 357, 1, 19, 693974) The Free Staters will have a long time to consider your general bill and at the next session all will start anew.
('11', 357, 1, 20, 694088) Is it too much then, sorely tried though you are with many other troubles, to ask you to remove the serious handicap in the way of my countrymen, and enable them to take their humble share in the approaching Coronation festivities[?] As this letter is of a very personal nature and arises out [of] a conversation part of which you wish shall remain confidential, I will not publish [it] without your authority.
('11', 357, 2, 21, 694499) I remain,
('11', 357, 3, 22, 694509) Yours faithfully, [PS.] As Mrs. Sodha’s appeal comes up on Saturday at Bloemfontein, why not now instruct the Attorney General not to arrest her in the event of its being lost by her.

('11', 358, 6, 10, 695173) “Well, Gandhi, I am sorry for you.
('11', 358, 6, 11, 695208) You have been long delayed, but what can I do?
('11', 358, 6, 12, 695255) You will insist on enjoying yourself in Cape Town,” commenced G. S drawing, while speaking as above, a chair near his and asking G. to be seated.
('11', 358, 6, 13, 695401) “You, as a lawyer, will understand when I tell you that it is difficult to carry out your alternative suggestion 3.” G. S. turns away from G., appears to [be] looking at something in his basket and con tinues, “Gandhi my boy, I am sorry for you.
('11', 358, 6, 14, 695647) You know I want peace.” (I suppose he is having a quiet laugh while saying all this.) “But”, looking now towards G., “my advisers consider that your suggestion cannot be carried out.
('11', 358, 6, 15, 695830) How can we keep out whites from the other provinces[?] Parliament will not pass such a bill.
('11', 358, 6, 16, 695923) I therefore want to pass my bill which I like and which I consider is fair.
('11', 358, 6, 17, 695999) I shall try but I may fail to pass it during this session.
('11', 358, 6, 18, 696058) All the members want to go away.
('11', 358, 6, 19, 696091) And the Free State members are still opp[osed] to admitting any Asiatic.
('11', 358, 6, 20, 696164) I think I can beat them in the Assembly but the Senate will throw out the Bill.
('11', 358, 6, 21, 696244) I therefore want to pass the measure during the next session, if I cannot carry it this session.
('11', 358, 6, 22, 696341) But meanwhile I want peace.
('11', 358, 6, 23, 696369) I do not want to harass your people.
('11', 358, 6, 24, 696406) You know that.
('11', 358, 6, 25, 696421) And I do not want you to bring people from India and elsewhere to fight.
('11', 358, 6, 26, 696494) I want to help the Imperial Government & they want to help me.

('11', 359, 2, 37, 698544) 1 Hind Swaraj; vide “Hind Swaraj”, 22 11 1909. 2 Hermann Kallenbach; a prosperous German architect of Johannesburg with “a vein of other worldliness” who, when challenged to a duel by a Volks rust European for his Indian sympathies, declined, saying that he had “accepted the religion of peace”; himself a satyagrahi, he gave his 1100 acre Tolstoy Farm near Johannesburg for the maintenance of satyagrahis’ families; taught on the farm carpentry, gardening and sandal making, the last of which he had learnt at a Trappist monastery; Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association for a time during the absence of Gandhiji and Polak; associated in dietetic experiments with Gandhiji who describes him as “a man of strong feeling, wide sympathies and childlike simplicity”.

('11', 365, 1, 2, 707939) May I then suggest the following for his consideration so that the suspicion that is sure to be roused among my countrymen owing to a postponement of the solution may be allayed?
('11', 365, 2, 3, 708118) An assurance should be given that:
('11', 365, 3, 4, 708153) (a) legislation will be passed next session repealing Act 2 of 1907 subject to the reservation of the rights of minor children in terms of the Chotabhai judgment 1 and restoring legal equality as to the immigration of Asiatics into the Transvaal and maintaining existing rights.
('11', 365, 3, 5, 708432) If the racial bar in the present Immigration Act of the Transvaal is removed by a general bill, such bill should naturally be free from a racial bar throughout the Union; (b) passive resisters who but for their resistance would have been entitled to registration should now be so entitled notwithstanding anything to the contrary in Act 36 of 1908; (c) educated passive resisters who are now in the Transvaal but who are not registrable under the Asiatic Act should be allowed to remain in the Transvaal as educated immigrants in anticipation of the forthcoming legislation, their number not to exceed six.
('11', 365, 3, 6, 709039) They may have special certificates in order to enable them to
('11', 365, 4, 7, 709101) 1 A.E. Chotabhai, domiciled in the Transvaal since 1899 and registered lawfully under Act 36 of 1908, brought his minor son aged 15, whose name appeared in his father’s registration certificate, in January, 1910. On the boy’s attaining majority, his application for separate registration under Act 36 of 1908 was rejected by the Registrar of Asiatics.
('11', 365, 4, 8, 709453) Chotabhai appealed to Magistrate Jordan who dismissed the appeal and ordered deportation.
('11', 365, 4, 9, 709543) Chotabhai then moved the Provincial Court where Justice Wessels in Chambers dismissed the application but restrained the order of deportation pending appeal to the higher Court.
('11', 365, 4, 10, 709721) The Full Bench of the Transvaal Division of the Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with a dissenting judgment by Justice Mason.
('11', 365, 4, 11, 709849) Finally on January 25, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of South Africa ruled that, although Act 36 of 1908 provided only for registration of minors resident in the Transvaal at the commencement of the Act or born within its boundaries, it did not follow that minors entering lawfully after that date were to be excluded from the registration provided for under the earlier Act 2 of 1907, and that it appeared improbable that the Legislature would allow Asiatic minors free entry into the Transvaal but allow the Registrar no discretion to permit them to remain in the country on their attaining majority.
('11', 365, 4, 12, 710466) The appeal was upheld.
('11', 365, 4, 13, 710489) The case, in its various stages, was reported in several issues of Indian Opinion between August 1910 and April, 1911; vide also “Cable to S.A.B.I. Committee”, 29 8 1910; “Speech at Meeting of Kathiawad Arya Mandal”, 20 9 1910; “Johannesburg”, before 17 11 1910 & “Chhotabhai Case”, 28 1 1911.
