In the case of the Transvaal, the Bill repealed all the earlier “obonoxious” immigration and registration laws except Act 36 of 1908 (Appendix, “Immigrants’ Restriction Bill”, 4 3 1911), while, in the case of the Orange Free State, Chapter 33 of th Conostitution, which Gandhiji contended was racial in character and therefore repugnant to the spirit of the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill (vide “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 20 3 1911 & “Letter to Private Secretary to Minister of Interior”, 24 3 1911), was neverthe less retained.
('11', 432, 3, 7, 859837) The Bill, besides, left unprotected the immigration rights of wives and minor children of domiciled Natal and Transvaal Asiatics, and others domiciled but temporarily absent from Natal; vide “Natal Petition to Union Assembly”, 9 3 1911. Polak was sent to Durban to help Natal Indians (vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 2 3 1911) to organize against the whittling down of what were, by comparison, almost unlimited rights of immigration
('11', 433, 0, 1, 860272) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('11', 433, 1, 2, 860314) 10. Enactment of further thoughtless legislation in the Transvaal has been prevented.
('11', 433, 2, 3, 860400) 11. The Railway regulations which were promulgated in the Transvaal, making distinctions between whites and Coloureds, were
('11', 433, 3, 4, 860524) which Asiatics possessed under previous laws; Ritch was similarly sent to the Cape to help the divided Indian community in that province (vide “Letter to Abdul Hamid Gool”, 2 3 1911), which, in his estimate, lacked the will to defend itself against the projected diminution of its rights.
('11', 433, 3, 5, 860813) It was at this stage that Gandhiji argued that the satyagraha campaign had been waged for, and on behalf of, the Transvaal alone and that, while he was willing to help with advice, Natal and the Cape should raise the funds and conduct their own campaigns when their rights were threatened; vide “Letter to L.W. Ritch”, 8 3 1911; “Letter to Maud Polak”, 13 3 1911 & “Letter to L.W. Ritch”, 17 3 1911. He was, therefore, content to handle the Transvaal problem from Johannesburg and to try and secure the exemption of educated Asiatics from the purview of Act 36 of 1908. He left for the Cape to conduct the negotiations in person only when Smuts refused to receive Ritch as a representative of the Indians; vide “Telegram to L. W. Ritch”, 9 3 1911. On March 4, 1911, Smuts informed Gandhiji that educated immigrants were free to enter the Union and reside in any Province and were exempt from registration laws; vide “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 4 3 1911. When Gandhiji replied that he had had legal advice saying that these private assurances were not contained in the Union Bill (ibid), Smuts recanted and moved an amendment which accorded Asiatic immigrants into the Transvaal legal equality with other races and exempted them only from registration under Act 36 of 1908; vide., “Letter to J. J. Doke”, 17 3 1911 & appendix, “Lane’s letter to Gandhiji”, 16 3 1911. Gandhiji, who had anticipated this clever move (“Letter to L. W. Ritch”, 16 3 1911), now demanded that the principle of legal equality of races which was conceded to the1909 deputation in London (Appendix, “Lord Crew’s Minute”, before 17 9 1909) and in Botha’s despatch of December 20, 1910, to the Imperial Government (“Report of European Committee Meeting”, 23 3 1911) should extend to the Orange Free State also (vide “Telegram to Private Secretary to General Smuts”, 17 3 1911); that is to say, the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill should nullify relevant provincial legislation in the Free State to the extent necessary for securing this objective; vide “Telegram to Private Secretary to General Smuts”, 10 3 1911. Hosken’s Committee, coming out in support of the Indian cause, denied Smuts’ allegation that this demand was a new one; vide., “Letter to H. S. L Polak”, 22 3 1911. Gandhiji then said he would be content if the Union immigration bill was dropped and the Transvaal legislation alone amended suitably; vide., “Letter to Sonja Schlesin”, 27 3 1911. Smuts thereupon decided, for reasons of his own, that this could not be done during the current session of the Union Parliament.
('11', 433, 3, 6, 863369) Gandhiji’s claim that satyagraha had prevented the extension of the unfavourable Transvaal immigration laws to the rest of the Union should be viewed against this background of facts.
('11', 433, 3, 7, 863553) In fact, the Secretary of State for India had himself admitted that the Union immigration legislation extended “the Transvaal policy of practical exclusion” to the entire Union; vide India, 31 3 1911.

('11', 438, 2, 3, 872768) JOHANNESBURG, June 9, 1911 WILLIAM HOSKEN, ESQ.
('11', 438, 3, 4, 872816) DEAR SIR,
('11', 438, 4, 5, 872826) We, the undersigned, on behalf of the British Indian Recep tion Committee, hereby wish to place on record our gratitude to you and the members of the Committee over whose deliberations you have presided during the past three years that the Committee has been in existence.
('11', 438, 4, 6, 873099) We are aware that it is due to the efforts of your Committee that the provisional settlement of the Asiatic question that has so agitated the country for the past four years has been hastened.
('11', 438, 4, 7, 873292) Though the question that gave rise to passive resistance is not yet finally settled, it is a matter for satisfaction that we have a declaration from the chief opponent of the demands of the Asiatic communities that they should be satisfied.
('11', 438, 4, 8, 873533) It was no small thing for you and your Committee to espouse what was undoubtedly an unpopular cause.
('11', 438, 4, 9, 873634) It is not in our power to reward you for your labours.
('11', 438, 4, 10, 873689) We can but pray to the Almighty to reward you, and the other Members of the Committee, for your advocacy of a cause which you believed to be just.
('11', 438, 4, 11, 873836) We shall pray that you may have long life and health, so as to enable you to continue to serve high ideals as you have done in the past.
('11', 438, 5, 12, 873973) [A. M. CACHALIA V. CHETTIAR ABDUL KADIR BAWAZEER SORABJI SHAPURJI ADAJANIA M. K. GANDHI] 2

('11', 439, 1, 2, 874435) 445. ENCIRCLED
('11', 439, 2, 3, 874450) The draft Municipal Councils Ordinance to be introduced in the Provincial Council of the Transvaal is a very drastic measure.
('11', 439, 2, 4, 874576) The British Indian Association of the Transvaal has entered a timely protest against its provisions that bear upon Indians.
('11', 439, 2, 5, 874700) 1 The most injurious section is no doubt that which gives the Municipal Councils absolute control over hawkers’ and other licences.
('11', 439, 2, 6, 874832) The effect of the Gold Law, read together with the Townships Act, is to ruin Asiatic store keepers.
('11', 439, 2, 7, 874932) The effect of the draft Ordinance, if it be allowed to pass in its present shape, will be to crush Asiatic hawkers.
('11', 439, 2, 8, 875048) It is a well known fact that the majority of the Indians of the Transvaal depend upon hawking for their bread and butter.
('11', 439, 2, 9, 875170) And it is evident that the framers of the Ordinance had Indian hawkers in view.
('11', 439, 2, 10, 875250) Thus a circle is being drawn—it does not much matter whether with or without the knowledge of General Smuts−round the Transvaal Asiatics, although the General intends next year to bring in legislation to give effect to his promise to the passive resisters, and although he has stated that it is his intention to treat the resident Indians with fairness and justice.
('11', 439, 2, 11, 875616) We fear very much that, if the draft Ordinance is an indication of what is meant by fairness and justice, the Indian idea of these two words is totally different from General Smuts’.
('11', 439, 2, 12, 875799) We hope, however, that better counsels will prevail among the Provincial Councillors and that the Ordinance will be amended in the direction pointed our by Mr. Cachalia.
('11', 439, 3, 13, 875969) Indian Opinion, 10 06 1911
('11', 439, 4, 14, 875996) 1 This Ordinance in effect consolidated municipal regulations and decrees, most of which Transvaal Indians had objected to at one time or another and which empowered Town Councils to enforce these with the authority of provincial law.
('11', 439, 4, 15, 876231) For instance, it empowered the Government, in the main, to: (a) shift Asiatic Locations and demarcate new ones; (b) withhold a variety of licences without judicial review; (c) exclude Asiatics from the Municipal Voters’ List.

('11', 440, 3, 4, 876873) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('11', 440, 4, 5, 876894) Nothing has pained me so much in my leaving Johannesburg, at the present juncture, as your physical and mental condition.
('11', 440, 4, 6, 877016) If I could have avoided going to Natal, I would certainly have done so, if only so that I could be with you and exercise the privilege and the duty of a friend to nurse you and encourage you.

('11', 440, 4, 10, 877432) The coach I am in is a corridor, 3rd class, for well dressed 3rd class passengers.
('11', 440, 4, 11, 877515) It is truly more comfortable than the 1st class on these trains.
('11', 440, 4, 12, 877580) It is cleaner.
('11', 440, 4, 13, 877595) It is cushioned, has a lavatory and sleeping accommodation and I am the only passenger.
('11', 440, 4, 14, 877683) Our miserable false pride often keeps us from so many good things of the world.

('11', 440, 4, 16, 877820) Here I have everything added to the pleasure of travelling 3rd class.

('11', 440, 4, 21, 878149) The moral effect will be great.
('11', 440, 4, 22, 878181) It will be good discipline for you.
('11', 440, 4, 23, 878217) You must have noticed too that it attracted no attention at the station.
('11', 440, 4, 24, 878290) It is only our own false pride and self consciousness which make so many worries and troubles.

('11', 440, 4, 26, 878445) What I have suggested is, I am sure, the best remedy.

('11', 440, 4, 28, 878551) But it has been accentuated by your mental condition.

('11', 443, 2, 3, 881701) Friday [June 16, 1911] 1
('11', 443, 3, 4, 881726) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('11', 443, 4, 5, 881747) I have your two letters together.
('11', 443, 4, 6, 881781) I am sorry for Hilt and glad for you.
('11', 443, 4, 7, 881819) Both Hilt and Albert will prove a blessing to you for they put you on your mettle.
('11', 443, 4, 8, 881902) I do not know that we have need to be sorry for Hilt’s illness.
('11', 443, 4, 9, 881966) There should be sorrow for the cause of it.
('11', 443, 4, 10, 882010) You must have produced a different and pleasurable sensation in Hilt when you laid him by your side.
('11', 443, 4, 11, 882111) Yes, indeed, the real individual life is only to be lived in the open and in close touch with our neighbours.
('11', 443, 4, 12, 882221) Living the other so called individual life in our rooms, fearing the touch of a fellow being, we must feel like thieves having no light to the property we may be holding.
('11', 443, 4, 13, 882392) Call is indeed a fine letter writer.
('11', 443, 4, 14, 882429) The coming union may make him.
('11', 443, 4, 15, 882460) He is idealizing it and for that reason it may be very good for him.
('11', 443, 4, 16, 882529) I am not going to congratulate you on getting new work.
('11', 443, 4, 17, 882585) I shall wait and see what it makes of you.
('11', 443, 4, 18, 882628) Sorabji receives his address tonight from the Congress.
('11', 443, 4, 19, 882684) With love,
('11', 443, 5, 20, 882695) Yours sincerely, UPPER HOUSE
('11', 443, 6, 21, 882724) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('11', 443, 6, 22, 882777) Courtesy: National Archives of India

('11', 444, 1, 2, 882995) 449. SPEECH AT DURBAN FAREWELL TO SORABJI 1
('11', 444, 2, 3, 883039) [June 16, 1911]
('11', 444, 3, 4, 883055) As a satyagrahi Mr. Sorabji has displayed many fine qualities.
('11', 444, 3, 5, 883118) He has rightly been described as the greatest of the satyagrahis.
('11', 444, 3, 6, 883184) From one point of view I place Mr. Thambi Naidoo on par with him.
('11', 444, 3, 7, 883250) (Applause.) Another person who can match Mr. Naidoo in self sacrifice is unlikely to be found even in India.
('11', 444, 3, 8, 883359) To be sure, Mr. Sorabji stands out from the rest because we volunteered for suffering.
('11', 444, 3, 9, 883446) He came from Natal and was the first from that Colony to join the campaign.
('11', 444, 3, 10, 883522) 2 Complaints were frequently made against the satyagrahis in gaol, but never against Mr. Sorabji, He is by nature, a mild and amiable person.
('11', 444, 3, 11, 883664) That cannot be said even of Mr. Thambi Naidoo.
('11', 444, 3, 12, 883711) No improper word was ever heard to escape his mouth.
('11', 444, 3, 13, 883764) He has none of the Parsis’ faults but I have found in him all their finerqualities.
('11', 444, 3, 14, 883848) Though so well endowed he is without a trace of pride.
('11', 444, 3, 15, 883903) Though a Parsi, he is an Indian first.
('11', 444, 3, 16, 883942) Hindus, Muslims and Christians alike admire him.
('11', 444, 3, 17, 883991) That he continues firm on his course, having once set it, and that he tries to understand every issue, is his fourth virtue.
('11', 444, 3, 18, 884116) Mr. Sorabji is without compeer.
('11', 444, 3, 19, 884148) The best way of honouring such a man is to emulate him.
('11', 444, 3, 20, 884204) India will prosper only when it produces many more Sorabjis.
('11', 444, 4, 21, 884265) [From Gujarati]
('11', 444, 5, 22, 884281) Indian Opinion, 24 6 1911

('11', 445, 1, 2, 884917) But the letter 1 addressed to the Town Clerk by Mr. Dawad Mahomed and other leaders, we understand, still remains unanswered.
('11', 445, 1, 3, 885043) If the Town Council cannot see their way to accord the same treatment to all the subject of the Crown, on a unique occasion like the Coronation of our Sovereign, if Europeans cannot forget their prejudice at such a time, we consider that it is the duty of the Indian community to refrain from taking any part in the local official celebrations, to refuse to accept any grant that may made for a separate celebration by us.
('11', 445, 1, 4, 885466) The community will express its loyalty to the Throne by sending an appropriate message.
('11', 445, 1, 5, 885554) We have been informed that the Town Council officials, instead of returning a definite reply to Mr. Dawad Mahomed, are trying to hoodwink the unwary and ignorant or poor Indians to submit to degradation by accepting a miserable grant for a hole and corner celebration among themselves.
('11', 445, 1, 6, 885840) The market master has, wee are told, been approaching the stall holders and asking them whether they would agree to take part in some tamasha he may arrange for them.
('11', 445, 1, 7, 886007) We hope that these designs will be furstrated and that the leaders will see to it that not a single Indian in the Borough of Durban has anything to do with the official celebrations.
('11', 445, 1, 8, 886190) We would appeal to the Town Council to rise to the occasion.
('11', 445, 1, 9, 886251) If it boldly decided for the time being to refuse to recognize any racial distinctions, it would perform a service to the model Borough, to South Africa and to the Empire, That brief but happy interruptionneed not prevent us from resuming our prejudices the day after and setting about quarrelling again.
('11', 445, 1, 10, 886556) But let the 22nd of June be held as a sacred day on which, at any rate, we may practise Imperial ideals.
('11', 445, 1, 11, 886661) We are sure that such conduct on the part of the Town Council will be a tangible proof of its loyalty and will please King George much more than any lip loyalty.
('11', 445, 1, 12, 886823) At the time of the late war, on the battle field, all distinctions disappeared as if by magic.
('11', 445, 1, 13, 886918) Tommy drank from the same cup—or
('11', 445, 2, 14, 886951) 1 In this letter dated April 18, 1911, Dawad Mahomed and other Natal leaders had expressed the Indians’ inability to join in the Durban Corporation’s Coronation celebrations so long as the Transvaal passive resistance continued.
('11', 445, 2, 15, 887180) Should, however, a settlement be reached and the Indian community decide to participate, they would join in “the general festivities” provided they were enabled to take an equal part there in with any other section of the population”.
('11', 445, 2, 16, 887415) But if the corporation made distincitons on racial grounds, they would celebrate the occasion independently of it.

('11', 446, 1, 2, 887600) rather tin—of water as the Indian stretcher bearer.
('11', 446, 1, 3, 887652) 1 Tommy shared the same tent with the Indian, and was often glad to have the same food as his Indian brother.
('11', 446, 1, 4, 887762) There was perfect fellowship between them.
('11', 446, 1, 5, 887805) We know that incidents like the above gladdened the hearts of the thousand Indians who were on the battle field.
('11', 446, 1, 6, 887918) Punch was so delighted that it sang, in connection with the incident: “We are sons of the Empire after all.” 2 After the close of the war, we know that the fellowship gave place to bitter jealousy, and consequent discord.
('11', 446, 1, 7, 888140) But the lesson of the war remained and was repeated at the time of the Zulu revolt.
('11', 446, 1, 8, 888224) The small band of Indian ambulance bearers 3 met the Colonial soldier citizen on terms of equality.
('11', 446, 1, 9, 888324) Captain Sparks and other officers appreciated the corps’s services, and the Indians were enabled again to realize that they were “Sons of the Empire after all”.
('11', 446, 1, 10, 888485) Is it impossible to repeat the two experiences on the Coronation Day?
('11', 446, 1, 11, 888555) We appeal to South Africa for an answer.

('11', 446, 3, 13, 888623) 451. THE BANQUET
('11', 446, 4, 14, 888640) We congratulate the organizers of the Banquet to Mr. Hosken’s Committee on the splendid success that attended their efforts.
('11', 446, 4, 15, 888765) From allaccounts received, this banquet was quite worthy of its predecessors.
('11', 446, 4, 16, 888843) The response from the Europeans to the invitation of the Reception Committee was liberal.
('11', 446, 4, 17, 888933) The banquet was the least that the community owed to its European friends and supporters.
('11', 446, 4, 18, 889023) In the beginning states of the struggle, when everybody poured ridicule on the heads of passive resisters, it required a great deal of nerve, courage and sacrifice on the part of the European sympathizers to stand by us.
('11', 446, 4, 19, 889244) We know how Mr. Hosken became the butt of the cartoonist.
('11', 446, 4, 20, 889302) We can have no notion of that these friends of the cause must have been obliged to put up with in their clubs and their churches.
('11', 446, 4, 21, 889432) Indeed, theirs must have been at times a lot as hard as, if not harder, than that of our

('11', 447, 1, 4, 890172) We echo the sentiments expressed by Mr. Doke, that the European Committee and the passive resisters were true Imperialists, who fought in the teeth of tremendous opposition to uphold Imperial ideals.

('11', 447, 3, 8, 890690) 452. HOSKEN’S PORTRAIT
('11', 447, 4, 9, 890713) We publish Mr. Hosken’s portrait as a supplement to this issue and we are sure our readers will welcome it.
('11', 447, 4, 10, 890821) It was first published in The Star.
('11', 447, 4, 11, 890857) We have secured it though the courtesy of the paper’s proprietors.
('11', 447, 4, 12, 890924) We should like our readers to have the portrait glazed and to hang it up in their rooms.
('11', 447, 4, 13, 891013) We have noticed that Indians have on the walls of their rooms pictorial advertisements set in frames, which are issued by wine and tobacco merchants.
('11', 447, 4, 14, 891163) At other times, we see meaningless pictures stuck on walls, and we are often judged by thethings with which we surround ourselves.
('11', 447, 4, 15, 891294) We earnestly hope that every Indian will have in his living room only the portraits of thosewho have us in their debt or whose memory we wish to cherish, and that they will be careful about the other things with which they choose to surround themselves.

('11', 449, 7, 17, 894179) I leave for J’HB on Monday.
('11', 449, 7, 18, 894207) You would have enjoyed yesterday’s scenes in Town.
('11', 449, 7, 19, 894258) I remained at Phoenix ≈ West went there to report.
('11', 449, 7, 20, 894309) The whole affair was spontaneous.
('11', 449, 7, 21, 894343) I merely guided.
('11', 449, 7, 22, 894360) And yet Ramsay Collins thought the Indians would have accepted anything if I had not been in D[urba]n.
('11', 449, 7, 23, 894463) Anyhow they certainly surpassed themselves.
('11', 449, 7, 24, 894507) Well, they have had their first lesson in passive resistance.
('11', 449, 7, 25, 894569) I have told them that they might have to raise passive resistance over the £ 3 tax.
('11', 449, 7, 26, 894653) West tells me Rustomjee 2
('11', 449, 8, 27, 894679) was grand.

('11', 449, 8, 30, 894789) He showed not a single virtue of a Jew and showed every weakness which the Jew is reported to possess.
('11', 449, 8, 31, 894892) I was ashamed of him for your sake.
('11', 449, 8, 32, 894928) In the report, I have laid him down very gently.
('11', 449, 8, 33, 894977) He was really much worse than he appears in the report.
('11', 449, 8, 34, 895033) Collins was mad with him.

('11', 450, 5, 29, 896690) 457. THE CORONATION
('11', 450, 6, 30, 896710) Our countrymen through out South Africa sent their loyal greeting to their Majesties on the Coronation Day.
('11', 450, 6, 31, 896818) It may seem some what anomalous to a stranger why and how British Indians of South Africa should tender their loyalty to the Throne or rejoice over the crowning of Sovereigns in whose dominions they do not even enjoy the ordinary civil rights of orderly men.
('11', 450, 6, 32, 897077) The anomaly would however,
('11', 450, 7, 33, 897104) 1 Vide “The coronation”, 24 6 1911 2 Lewis Harcourt, Secretary of State for the Colonies 3 Vide also “Letter to Harilal Gandhi”, 3 7 1911
('11', 451, 0, 1, 897242) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATAMA GANDHI
('11', 451, 1, 2, 897285) disappear, if the stranger were to understand the British constitution.
('11', 451, 1, 3, 897357) British Sovereigns represent, in theory, purity and equality of justice.
('11', 451, 1, 4, 897430) The ideal of King George is to treat his subjects with equality.
('11', 451, 1, 5, 897495) His happiness depends upon that of his subjects.
('11', 451, 1, 6, 897544) British statesmen make an honest attempt to realize the ideals.
('11', 451, 1, 7, 897608) That they often fail miserably in doing so is too true but irrelevant to the issue before us.
('11', 451, 1, 8, 897702) The British monarchy is limited and rightly so under the existing circumstances.
('11', 451, 1, 9, 897783) Those then who are content to remain under the British flag may, ought to, without doing may violence to their conscience, tender their loyality to the Sovereign for the time being of these mighty dominions, although, like us, they may be labouring under severe disabilities.
('11', 451, 1, 10, 898059) In tendering our loyalty, we but show our devotion to the ideals just referred to; our loyalty is an earnest of our desire to realize them.
('11', 451, 1, 11, 898199) The genius of the British constitution requires that every subject of the Crown should be as free as any other, and, if he is not, it is his duty to demand and fight for his freedom so long as he does so without injuring anyone else.
('11', 451, 1, 12, 898433) There is no room for helotry and slavery in this constitution, though both exist abundantly.
('11', 451, 1, 13, 898526) Largely it is the fault of the helots and the slaves themselves.
('11', 451, 1, 14, 898591) The British constitution provides a happy means of freedom but it must be confessed that it is not easy of adoption.
('11', 451, 1, 15, 898708) There is no royal road to freedom.
('11', 451, 1, 16, 898743) British people themselves have reached what they mistake for freedom through much travail and suffering.
('11', 451, 1, 17, 898848) Yet they are strangers to real freedom—the freedom of self.
('11', 451, 1, 18, 898908) They cannot and do not blame the constitution for the disability.
('11', 451, 1, 19, 898974) Nor can we because we have ours.
('11', 451, 1, 20, 899007) And we have not even bled for our freedom, real or so called.
('11', 451, 1, 21, 899069) If, however, we understand the spirit of the British constitution, though we suffer from disabilities in this sub continent and though we are far from happy in the sacred land of our birth, we are bound heartily to shout.
('11', 451, 2, 22, 899291) LONG LIVE THE KING !
('11', 451, 3, 23, 899312) Indian Opinion, 24 6 1911
('11', 451, 4, 24, 899338) 458. CORONATION
('11', 451, 5, 25, 899354) The Coronation of King George V was celebrated all over the Empire.
('11', 451, 5, 26, 899422) The Indian residents of this country sent congratulatory cables on the occasion thus declaring their loyalty.
('11', 451, 5, 27, 899532) We, however, find
('11', 452, 0, 1, 899550) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 453
('11', 452, 1, 2, 899593) some Indian asking questions: “Why, and to whom shall we show our loyalty?
('11', 452, 1, 3, 899668) With what face can we take part in the celebrations?
('11', 452, 1, 4, 899721) We are submerged in a sea of troubles.
('11', 452, 1, 5, 899760) Conditions in our dear country give us no cause for rejoicing.
('11', 452, 1, 6, 899823) That the King is to go to India for his Coronation gives us no reason to be happy.
('11', 452, 1, 7, 899906) That will only result in the draining of (Indian) money.
('11', 452, 1, 8, 899963) Indian will only be ruined further.” Such thoughts are but natural.
('11', 452, 1, 9, 900031) Indeed it is harmful to suppress them.
('11', 452, 1, 10, 900070) It is necessary, therefore, to put them to the test of logic.
('11', 452, 1, 11, 900132) Our view of the matter is that, if those who argue in this manner feel that they cannot be loyal, they should declare their want of loyalty and outlaw themselves.
('11', 452, 1, 12, 900295) Otherwise they will lay themselves open to the charge of insincerity and cowardice.
('11', 452, 1, 13, 900379) We believe, however, that we can remain loyal to His Majesty despite our untold sufferings.
('11', 452, 1, 14, 900471) Our sufferings here are to be blamed on the local authorities, and more so on ourselves.
('11', 452, 1, 15, 900560) If we become truthful [that is] if we rebel against ourselves (against the Satanic within us), thus exorcizing the devil, and ourselves manage our affairs instead, we will not have to put up with any hardship whatever and shall be able to declare, ‘Oh, how happy we are under the reign of King George!’ To the extent that we are unable to exorcize the Satan in us, we shall have to take to entreating the local authorities, and we might there by slake our burning woes.
('11', 452, 1, 16, 901030) If we do not do either, how is King George to blame?
('11', 452, 1, 17, 901083) Someone may answer saying that everything is done in the name of King George, and therefore the credit for the good things and blame for the wrong things should both be his .
('11', 452, 1, 18, 901258) What we have said above disposes of that argument.
('11', 452, 1, 19, 901309) The British monarchy is not free, but is confined within limits.
('11', 452, 1, 20, 901374) These checks are implicit in that British system of monarchy.
('11', 452, 1, 21, 901436) If the King oversteps the limits, he will be dethroned.
('11', 452, 1, 22, 901492) Moreover, the British Constitution aims at securing equality of rights and equality before the law for every subject.
('11', 452, 1, 23, 901610) Those who do not enjoy such equality are free to fight for it, the only restriction being that the mode of agitation shall not harm others.
('11', 452, 1, 24, 901750) Not only is every British subject free to fight in this way, but it is his duty to do so.
('11', 452, 1, 25, 901840) It is a duty to express one’s loyalty to such a constitution and to its head, the King Emperor, for that will only be an expression of loyalty to one’s own manhood.
('11', 452, 1, 26, 902005) The loyalty of a slave is no loyalty.
('11', 452, 1, 27, 902043) He only serves.
('11', 452, 1, 28, 902059) If a slave can be loyal, that must be due to coercion.
('11', 452, 1, 29, 902114) The loyalty of a free man is willed.
('11', 453, 0, 1, 902151) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATAMA GANDHI
('11', 453, 1, 2, 902194) It may be urged against this reasoning that it would justify submission even to a wicked king or a vicious constitution; the argument then is not quite proper.
('11', 453, 1, 3, 902354) For instance, we could not, as free men, be loyal to the pre War Boer constitution and to its head, President Kruger, for the constitution itself laid down that there shall be no equality between Europeans and Coloureds in the governance of the country or in ecclesiastical affairs.
('11', 453, 1, 4, 902637) We cannot fight such a constitution and be loyal to it at the same time.
('11', 453, 1, 5, 902710) In a situation like that wewould have to defy not only the head but the basis of his authority as well.
('11', 453, 1, 6, 902814) If we refused to fight, we would cease to be men and be thought brutes.
('11', 453, 1, 7, 902886) If the British Constitution were to change and lay down that there would be no equality, not even in theory, as between whites and Coloureds, we could no longer owe allegiance to such a constitution and would have to oppose it.
('11', 453, 1, 8, 903114) Even in such a contingency, however, we could remain loyal to the King within limits; such is the virtue of the British system.
('11', 453, 1, 9, 903242) It is not here necessary to explore these limits for the question does not arise.
('11', 453, 1, 10, 903324) It must be remembered that the British people won what they consider their freedom after they had let rivers of blood flow.
('11', 453, 1, 11, 903448) Real freedom, however, even they have yet to win.
('11', 453, 1, 12, 903498) We, on the other hand, have shed no blood, endured nothing, for the sake of freedom, real or imaginary.
('11', 453, 1, 13, 903602) The Transvaal satyagrahis alone gave evidence of having suffered in some measure in the course of their great campaign.
('11', 453, 1, 14, 903722) But their suffering was a drop in the ocean.
('11', 453, 1, 15, 903767) Only when we come forward to suffer as much—and infinitely more—shall we succeed in winning freedom for ourselves.
('11', 453, 1, 16, 903882) The British Constitution permits one to seek this freedom.
('11', 453, 1, 17, 903941) The British Emperor must wish that all his subjects get such freedom; such is the British way.
('11', 453, 1, 18, 904036) And there are Englishmen who sincerely strive to act on these principles according to their own lights.
('11', 453, 1, 19, 904140) We can, therefore, and ought to, remain loyal to the British Emperor, our grievances notwithstanding.
('11', 453, 2, 20, 904242) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 24 6 1911

('11', 460, 1, 2, 916690) 465. KRUGERSDORP BAZAAR
('11', 460, 2, 3, 916714) The action of the Municipality of Krugersdorp in trying persistently to abolish the Asiatic Bazaar or Location at Krugersdorp is quite on a par with the zeal that the European residents of that dorp have generally shown in their anti Asiatic crusade.
('11', 460, 2, 4, 916965) 1 The School Committee has been a willing tool in the hands of the interested agitators.
('11', 460, 2, 5, 917054) But we hope that the Krugersdorp Indians will not fail to place before the authorities the other side of the question.
('11', 460, 2, 6, 917173) We have little to say regarding compensation.
('11', 460, 2, 7, 917219) For that question cannot arise unless Indian consent to vacate the Stands they occupy or unless they are by law compelled to do so.
('11', 460, 2, 8, 917351) We wish merely to point out that the state of things the School Committee blame has been deliberately brought about by those who have control of the Location.
('11', 460, 2, 9, 917510) 2 The threat of removal has hung over the heads of the Indian residents of that Location for several years.
('11', 460, 2, 10, 917618) We are sorry if the school children have to overlook the closets of that Location.
('11', 460, 2, 11, 917701) Give the residents fixity of tenure, and we promise that in a month’s time they will carry out all desirable alterations.
('11', 460, 2, 12, 917823) We know that our harassed countrymen have pleaded, times without number, that they should he placed in a position to construct substantial and up to date buildings on their Stands.
('11', 460, 2, 13, 918004) Not only has no encouragement have given to them in that direction but they have been actually thwarted in any such effort they have made.
('11', 460, 2, 14, 918143) To say the least, it is dishonest to blame them for a state of things for which their very detractors are largely if not entirely responsible.
('11', 460, 3, 15, 918286) Indian Opinion, 8 7 1911
('11', 460, 4, 16, 918311) 466. INDIAN WIVES
('11', 460, 5, 17, 918329) The decision of Justice Wessels in the matter of an application on behalf of an Indian woman to enter the Transvaal, being the wife of a registered Indian.
('11', 460, 5, 18, 918485) Raises points of the highest importance to the
('11', 460, 6, 19, 918532) 1 Vide “Krugersdorp Agitators”, 3 6 1911. 2 Vide “Johannesburg”, 8 7 1911
('11', 461, 0, 1, 918606) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATAMA GANDHI
('11', 461, 1, 2, 918649) Indian throughout South Africa.
('11', 461, 1, 3, 918681) 1 The lady in question is the same person who was some time ago turned away by the Immigration Officer at Durban and whose case we have already referred to.
('11', 461, 1, 4, 918838) The Judge’s remarks show that Bai Rasul (for that is the applicant’s name) has been unduly hampered in her endeavour to make good her claim.
('11', 461, 1, 5, 918979) The Judge said that, if the Court had the power, he would have granted a temporary permit to enable the applicant to produce the necessary proof of her marriage.
('11', 461, 1, 6, 919141) Had the Immigration Officer granted such a permit, there would have been no case in the Court.
('11', 461, 1, 7, 919236) We still hope that Bai Rasul will be given every facility to prove her claim.
('11', 461, 1, 8, 919314) For surely, there is no question of Indian competition in trade.
('11', 461, 1, 9, 919379) But what is of greater importance is the Judge’s obiter dictum that an Indian may not bring more than one wife.
('11', 461, 1, 10, 919491) Hitherto those who have more than one wife have been allowed to bring them without any let or hindrance.
('11', 461, 1, 11, 919596) If the Judge’s dictum is sound law, all we can say is that it will have to be altered.
('11', 461, 1, 12, 919683) In British Dominions, wherein all religions are respected, it is not possible to have laws insulting to any recognized religion flourishing under it.
('11', 461, 1, 13, 919833) To hold otherwise in this country would simply create misery in many an Indian household in South Africa.
('11', 461, 1, 14, 919939) We are glad, therefore, that the British Indian Association and the Hamidia Islamic Society have already moved in this matter.
('11', 461, 1, 15, 920066) It ought to be possible to settle this matter without any agitation being necessary.

('11', 461, 3, 17, 920176) 467. JOHANNESBURG
('11', 461, 4, 18, 920194) TALE OF KRUGERSDORP 1
('11', 461, 5, 19, 920216) Indians living in the Krugersdorp Location should not become complacent.
('11', 461, 5, 20, 920289) We learn from a Krugersdorp newspaper that the conflict between the Government and the Municipality regarding the Location continues.
('11', 461, 5, 21, 920423) It is thanks to the local School Committee that the issue has
('11', 461, 6, 22, 920485) 1 Adamjee, an old registered resident of the Transvaal, brought over Bai Rasul, his wife, from India, at Durban, the Immigration Officer refused her permission to disembark, although normally such immigrants were allowed to land temporarily on furnishing a bail of £10. Bai Rasula then attempted to enter the Transvaal from Delagoa Bay, and her case eventually went up to the Transvaal Supreme Court.
('11', 461, 6, 23, 920886) For a report of the judgment, vide the following item.
('11', 461, 6, 24, 920941) 1 Vide “Krugersdorp Bazaar”, 8 7 1911.
('11', 462, 0, 1, 920980) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 463
('11', 462, 1, 2, 921023) become public knowledge.
('11', 462, 1, 3, 921048) It has complained that pupils of the school which overlooks the Location have to suffer the sight of Indian closets.
('11', 462, 1, 4, 921165) The municipal authorities have replied to the School Committee saying that £1,100 would have to be paid to the Indians as compensation if the Location were to be shifted.
('11', 462, 1, 5, 921336) The Government contends that this sum should be paid by the Municipality.
('11', 462, 1, 6, 921410) The municipality has argued that it should not be asked to pay this money, because it is the Government which has been pocketing the income (from the Location).
('11', 462, 1, 7, 921571) As it was the Government that had set up the Location, it should it self pay.
('11', 462, 1, 8, 921649) The editor of the newspaper has suggested that the Europeans should hold mass meetings, pass resolutions, make the Government pay this amount and have the Location shifted.
('11', 462, 1, 9, 921822) It appears to have been agreed at a previous meeting of the Committee that the compensation of £1,100 would have to be paid.
('11', 462, 1, 10, 921947) My own advice to the Indians living in the Location is that they should immediately address the Government and the Municipality saying that they are willing to make the necessary improvements in the building if allowed to do so.
('11', 462, 1, 11, 922176) They should also say that they had given no undertaking as to the shifting of the Location and that it is impossible to shift as there is a mosque within its precincts.
('11', 462, 1, 12, 922345) I hope the Indians in the Location will not delay action in this matter.
('11', 462, 2, 13, 922418) DEPORTATION ORDER CANCELLED
('11', 462, 3, 14, 922446) There is an Indian youth named Mr. N. Dala.
('11', 462, 3, 15, 922490) He was arrested in Barberton and ordered to be deported.
('11', 462, 3, 16, 922547) The main reason for this order was that he was believed to be eighteen years of age.
('11', 462, 3, 17, 922632) His friends sought Mr. Ritch’s advice and told him that Mr. Dala was not in fact over sixteen years of age.
('11', 462, 3, 18, 922740) His case was then referred to the Supreme Court for getting the order of deportation cancelled.
('11', 462, 3, 19, 922836) A medical practitioner deposed in Courtthat Mr. Dala’s age should be around sixteen.
('11', 462, 3, 20, 922921) On the strength of his evidence the Court has cancelled the deportation order.
('11', 462, 3, 21, 923000) The plea was that the law did not confer any authority [on the Court] for deporting young Indian below sixteen.
('11', 462, 3, 22, 923112) Mr. Dala has not however, secured the right of residence in the Transvaal as a result of this case.
('11', 462, 3, 23, 923212) He will have to submit an application for this purpose, and he will get a registration certificate only if he is legally entitled to it.
('11', 462, 3, 24, 923349) Only Mr. Dala benefits from the judgement in this case; otherwise there is nothing notworthy about it.
('11', 463, 0, 1, 923452) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATAMA GANDHI
('11', 463, 1, 2, 923495) BAI RASUL CASE 1
('11', 463, 2, 3, 923512) But the judgment given by the Supreme Court last week in the case of Bai Rasul is an important one.
('11', 463, 2, 4, 923612) Bai Rasul is Mr. Adamjee’s wife.
('11', 463, 2, 5, 923645) Some facts of this case have already appeared in Indian Opinion.
('11', 463, 2, 6, 923710) As she could not disembark in Natal, she went to Delagoa Bay with her husband and from there tried to enter the Transvaal.
('11', 463, 2, 7, 923833) The case then went up to the Supreme Court, the demand being that Mr. Chamney, the Immigration Officer, should not restrain her (from entering the Transvaal).
('11', 463, 2, 8, 923992) It was an intricate case.
('11', 463, 2, 9, 924018) When Mr. Adamjee got his registration certificate, his marriage with Bai Rasul had already been solemnized.
('11', 463, 2, 10, 924126) Even so, he had mentioned (in his application) the name of the women from whom he was divorced as his present wife.
('11', 463, 2, 11, 924242) Hence it became difficult for him to prove that Bai Rasul was his present wife.
('11', 463, 2, 12, 924322) Giving its ruling, the Court said that no one could being his concubine into the Transvaal.
('11', 463, 2, 13, 924414) That the former wife [of Mr. Adamjee] had been given a divorce was not proved to the Court’s satisfaction, nor that the marriage with Bai Rasul had been duly solemnized, For these reasons the Court did not grant the prayer and dismissed the suit with costs.
('11', 463, 2, 14, 924672) The Court said in the course of the judgement that if it I had the power, it would have granted a temporary permit to Bai Rasul to enable her to prove her right (of entry) but that it was not so empowered.
('11', 463, 2, 15, 924878) If the Court’s verdict has stopped here, there would have been no great difficulty.
('11', 463, 2, 16, 924962) But the court went on the observe that, if a person had more then one wife, if could grant right of entry only to one of them, that is, the first wife.
('11', 463, 2, 17, 925114) Other wives could not be deemed lawful..
('11', 463, 2, 18, 925155) If this opinion of the judge stands and the [Immigration] Officer acts on it, our Muslim brethren are likely to be greatly inconvenienced.
('11', 463, 2, 19, 925294) So for there has been no difficulty in securing entry for as many wives as a person had, but now objections are likely to be raised.
('11', 463, 2, 20, 925427) Both the Hamidia Islamic Society and the [British Indian] Association will soon launch a campaign in this regard.
('11', 463, 2, 21, 925541) I hope Mr. Adamjee’s advisers will now have Bai Rasul brought to Durban and then proceed cautiously in the matter.
('11', 463, 2, 22, 925656) As regards marriage and divorce, it is necessary to produce affidavits from respectable Moulvis and others.
('11', 463, 2, 23, 925764) Bai Rasul’s affidavit will also have to be produced along with these.
('11', 463, 2, 24, 925834) If this is done, I believe that the court
('11', 463, 3, 25, 925876) 1 Vide the preceding item
('11', 464, 0, 1, 925902) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 465
('11', 464, 1, 2, 925945) cannot but pass an order [in her favour].
('11', 464, 1, 3, 925987) Once an order is obtained in the case of Durban, she will clearly have no difficulty in entering the Transvaal.

('11', 465, 3, 4, 927401) LETTER FROM GENERAL MANAGER, C. S. A. R., TO GANDHIJI
('11', 465, 4, 5, 927455) JOHANNESBURG, April 11, 1910 SIR,
('11', 465, 5, 6, 927489) With reference to the interview that Mr. Bell, Solicitor to the Railway Administration Mr. Hoy, Assistant General Manager, and the undersigned had with Mr. Cachalia and yourself this morning, I now place on record, as agreed, a summary of the understanding arrived at in the course of the discussion, namely:—
('11', 465, 6, 7, 927799) 1. That Regulations 221 to 224 inclusive be replaced by the following:
('11', 465, 7, 8, 927870) 221. It shall be lawful for the General Manager where practicable to set apart different compartments on trains for passengers of different races, and the passengers for whom the compartments are so reserved shall travel only in such compartments and no other, nor will any other compartment be considered as available.
('11', 465, 7, 9, 928190) Such compartments shall be marked “Reserved”.
('11', 465, 8, 10, 928236) 222. It shall be competent for the guard or the conductor or any other railway official to remove passengers from one compartment to another without giving any reason therefor.
('11', 465, 9, 11, 928413) 223. It shall be competent for the station master or other authorised official to refuse a first or second class ticket to any passenger who may, in his opinion, not be dressed in a decent or cleanly condition.
('11', 465, 10, 12, 928624) 224. The penalty provided in Section 42 of the Act will apply to any contravention of Regulations 221 to 223, inclusive.
('11', 465, 11, 13, 928745) 2. That the foregoing alterations in the wording of the regulations have been adopted so as to meet the views and wishes of the community Mr. Cachalia and yourself represent.
('11', 465, 12, 14, 928920) 3. That the manner in which the regulations and the authority entrusted to the Administration has been carried out in the past has been acceptable to the Asiatic community with the exception of such cases as have been brought specially under notice and which, when it was found that there was just cause for complaint, have been dealt with in a manner that you and the community you represent considered to be proper and just.
('11', 465, 13, 15, 929347) 4. I undertook that the Administration would continue to act in this spirit, and it was agreed that, should it be represented to you at any time that any member of the staff has acted in an improper manner and you have satisfied yourself by previous enquiry that there has been good cause for complaint, you would communicate with the Assistant General Manager and the Administration would, after investigation,
('11', 466, 0, 1, 929759) VOL. 11 : 11 APRIL, 1910 12 JULY, 1911 467
('11', 466, 1, 2, 929802) deal with the case as the circumstances call for, and in the spirit of requiring justice and proper treatment being extended to yourselves and to your countrymen.
('11', 466, 1, 3, 929965) 5. For the purpose of giving effect to the foregoing, you approved, on my suggestion, that while the regulations to be published should be framed in the manner now provisionally agreed to, there would be no objection to the Administration rene wing the instructions to the staff on the lines at present obtaining or with such modi fication of the existing instructions as circumstances may from time to time call for.
('11', 466, 1, 4, 930383) 6. It was agreed that, in giving effect to the intention of the agreement now arrived at, toleration would have to be exercised, and that, if an instance should occur (as it is quite possible may be the case) when, say, one of your countrymen might desire to travel by a train and the officers of the Administration considered difficulty and possibly disturbance would probably result therefrom, it shall be open to the officers of the Administration, at their discretion, to require such passenger to travel by another train, and if needs be on another date.
('11', 466, 2, 5, 930943) 7. It was further agreed that should difficulties arise in connection with the proposed new regulations which may seriously interfere with their practical working, a meeting would be convened with a view to altering the regulations, and you undertook to approach the question of such alteration in the spirit in which our present discussion has been conducted.
('11', 466, 3, 6, 931304) 8. May I take this opportunity of reiterating the expression of satisfaction I conveyed to Mr. Cachalia and yourself at the spirit in which the discussion had been conducted by both of you and which has resulted in the arrangement now arrived at subject to confirmation by the Transvaal and Orange River Colony Governments and the Railway Board.
('11', 466, 3, 7, 931650) I have, etc.,
('11', 466, 4, 8, 931664) T. R. PRICE General Manager
